headline: Liquid Metal Cools A Japanese Reactor
abstract: A Japanese company received a patent this week for a nuclear reactor in which liquid metal is to be used as coolant.

headline: Afghan Rebel Leader Appeals for More Arms
abstract: A leader of an Afghan rebel movement said yesterday that there was now greater cooperation among the various anti-Soviet guerrilla groups.

headline: Companies
abstract: I.B.M. announced that it would acquire Rolm, one of Silicon Valley's leading makers of telephone switching equipment, for $1.25 billion in securities. The acquisition, I.B.M.'s largest ever and its first since 1962, would place the computer giant in direct competition with A.T.& T. and several Japanese companies in the market for complex telephone equipment. (Page A1.)   Continental Illinois expects to nearly break even in the third quarter, the chairman of the beleaguered bank said. The executive, William S. Ogden, also said that the bank would soon release a strategic plan, detailing where it would make cuts in its operations. Shareholders, meanwhile, overwhelmingly approved the $4.5 billion rescue plan for the bank put together by the F.D.I.C., the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve. (D1.)

headline: Frederick's Inc.
abstract: Frederick's of Hollywood Inc. said its board had voted to omit the quarterly cash dividend.

headline: Article 091719 -- No Title
abstract: The Amalgamated Sugar Company, a concern controlled by Harold Simmons, a Dallas investor, said it had offered to acquire Baker, Fentress & Company for $40 a share.   Baker, Fentress, a closed-end management investment company based in Chicago, said that the offer was inadequate and that it would recommend that shareholders reject it.

headline: Canada Cites Trade Surplus
abstract: Canada exported $1.6 billion more of goods in May than it imported, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today, giving the figures in Canadian dollars. This narrowed the monthly trade surplus by $70 million from the April level.

headline: Debris Complicates Salvage Of Nuclear Cargo Off Belgium
abstract: Efforts to salvage the nuclear cargo from a sunken freighter off the Belgian coast were complicated when floating debris crashed through its deck, officials said today. Bad weather had already hampered the efforts.   The Belgian officials said two empty barrels broke free during the night through a hole torn in the upper deck of the submerged French cargo ship Mont Louis.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.02     An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds   compiled weekly by The Bond   Buyer.   Aa Utility Bonds*13.625     Salomon Brothers' estimate for   new long-term issues.

headline: FRENCH DOCTORS SAY THEY HELPED PATIENTS DIE
abstract: A group of French doctors declared today that they had helped some of their patients to die.   The doctors, who are well known in medical circles in France, did not use the word euthanasia in a statement issued here today.   But their declaration that they have helped terminally ill patients to die is a rare instance of physicians announcing publicly that they have carried out euthanasia on patients who no longer wanted to live.   ''I have helped them to die if that was their wish or demand by active means or measures,'' Dr. Bernard Fonty, a surgeon who was among the signers of the declaration, said in a telephone interview.

headline: CANADIAN POWER WILL LOWER NORTHEAST'S BILLS
abstract: This morning at the La Grande 2 hydroelectric plant here, enough water was bypassing idle turbines and flowing over the spillway to have produced 1,600 megawatts. Utilities in New York or New England would pay $80,000 or more an hour for that amount of power on a hot summer afternoon.     But Hydro-Quebec, the provincial utility, with nine turbines producing 3,300 megawatts of electricity here today at its giant new complex, had no use for the electricity and no way to export it.   That will change in the next few years, however, when the generating stations being completed here, at the edge of the Canadian tundra, are linked by new transmission lines to New England and New York.   At that point the relative abundance of electricity in the northeastern portion of the continent should bring lower prices. This abundance will largely result from the output of the La Grande project, rising out of a vast area of taiga, the terrain of caribou moss, scrawny black spruce and jack pines.

headline: ZIMBABWEAN TAKING CHARGE
abstract: Before the elections in 1980 that brought Robert Mugabe to power, there were many who predicted that civil war would erupt in this divided land, a contest for the spoils of freedom.  The thinking was rooted in recent history.  Throughout the years of guerrilla campaigns that finally ended white minority rule in the country once called Rhodesia, there were two distinct national armies in the field, divided from each other by tribe and personality. One fought under Mr. Mugabe's banner, the other was loyal to his archrival, Joshua Nkomo. Both were committed to an independent Zimbabwe under their own leaders.    Four years later, despite close calls and with the help of good fortune not always of his own making, Mr. Mugabe boasts that the war some saw as inevitable has not taken place.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Miller Beer to Cut 375 Salaried Jobs          The Miller Brewing Company, in its latest step to adjust to the intense competition and sluggish growth in the beer industry, said yesterday that it was streamlining its management organization by eliminating 375 salaried positions.    The cutback represents about 8.5 percent of the company's 4,430 salaried work force.

headline: Your Money; Family Sharing Of Home Costs
abstract: MANY adults have helped their elderly parents pay their home mortgage expenses, and many parents have helped their children become first-time home buyers. Now both practices have been made formal by new arrangements that allow the help to be given in a business-like setting.     The arrangements were started this year by the Family Backed Mortgage Association, a private company based in Oakland, Calif. One is called Grannie Mae - an acronym for the Golden Retirement Annuity Mortgage Association - and the other is known as Daddy Mac, which stands for nothing. Obviously, the names are meant to evoke such well-known Government-operated or quasi- governmental agencies as the Government National Mortgage Association (Ginnie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac).

headline: U.S. RESOLVE TO KEEP BEIRUT EMBASSY IS AFFIRMED
abstract: An Assistant Secretary of State, Richard W. Murphy, said here today that the bombing of the United States Embassy on Thursday had failed to shake American resolve to remain in Lebanon.    ''We are not going home,'' he said at the American Ambassador's residence in this southeast suburb of Beirut. Mr. Murphy was surrounded by bodyguards bristling with automatic weapons, pistols, knives and walkie-talkies as he spoke with reporters.   Officials later said that Mr. Murphy himself left by helicopter in the evening en route back to the United States after 24 hours in Beirut. He had arrived Friday with eight experts to investigate the bombing of the new embassy building at Aukar, a northeast suburb. It was the third suicide bomb attack on an American installation in the Beirut area in 17 months.

headline: Busch Has 15.1% Gain In Quarter
abstract: The Anheuser-Busch Companies bucked the trend in the beer industry and reported a strong 15.1 percent increase in second-quarter earnings. The nation's leading beer producer said that it had increases both in the volume of beer it shipped in the quarter and in its market share.    Busch's board of directors also voted to increase the quarterly dividend on common stock to 50 cents a share from 44 cents.

headline: A NEW PATH FOR CANADA
abstract: Brian Mulroney and his Progressive Conservative Party, which on Tuesday won the biggest political majority in Canadian history, appear to have fundamentally changed the country's political landscape.  The result, wrote Richard Gwyn, a columnist for The Toronto Star, Canada's largest newspaper, ''almost certainly made the Conservatives the majority party for the rest of this century.''    Liberals - as well as members of the New Democratic Party, which fared unexpectedly well - would debate that. But the returns clearly marked a setback for Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Liberal Party, which has run Canada for most of this century. Even more, however, it reflected dissatisfaction with Canada's stagnant economy and lack of a sense of direction.

headline: SPEAKERS AT U.N. STRESS ECONOMICS
abstract: Argentina, Brazil and Mexico, three of Latin America's major debtor nations, called today for a ''north-south dialogue'' on international economic matters that they said was as much needed as East-West security negotiations.    On the first day of debate of the 39th session of the General Assembly, Raul Alfonsin, President of Argentina, said the world economic order was ''gradually becoming a financial order exclusively.'' He called this a distortion to be avoided because ''a world where politics are replaced by arsenals and economy by finance is simply a world in danger.''   Argentina's debt to international banks has been put at $45 billion, Brazil's at $98 billion and Mexico's at $96 billion. In recent weeks those nations and Venezuela, which owes $37 billion, have taken some steps to alleviate their short-term debt burdens.

headline: Housing Agency's Note Offering
abstract: A $120 million issue of three-year notes of the New York City Housing Development Corporation was tentatively priced to yield at 7 1/4 percent.   The issue, part of the agency's turnkey construction loan program, will be sold to investors at par with a maturity date of Sept. 1, 1987.   The underwriters are led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, which expects a formal award for the notes today.

headline: Military Contracts
abstract: The B.M.V. division of the Harsco Corporation received a $44.7 million Army contract for self-propelled howitzers, the Defense Department said. In addition, the Air Force gave a $39.2 million contract to the ITT Avionics division of the ITT Corporation for B-52 bomber aircraft equipment.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *  Boeing Co. 's Boeing Military Airplane Co. received a $34.2 million Air Force contract for test package sets, the Defense Department said.     *  Coca-Cola Bottling Co.  of Charlotte, N.C., said it had completed the acquisition of Federal Coca-Cola Bottling Co. for $22.6 million.

headline: Vietnam Accuses China Of Border Incursions
abstract: Vietnam accused China today of staging air, land and sea incursions into Vietnamese territory last week and of increasing efforts to ''destabilize'' Vietnam's border provinces.   The Vietnam News Agency, monitored in Bangkok, said Chinese troops had fired nearly 3,000 artillery shells into three districts of Ha Tuyen Province and about 100 mortar rounds into a village of Quang Ninh Province.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.18     An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds   compiled weekly by The Bond   Buyer.   Aa Utility Bonds*13.75     Salomon Brothers' estimate for   new long-term issues.

headline: PUBLISHER SEEKS BOARD'S APPROVAL
abstract: ROBERT J. COLE    Rupert Murdoch, the Australian- born publisher, told directors of the St. Regis Corporation yesterday that he was prepared to pay $52 a share - or $757 million in cash - for enough stock in the company to give him 50.1 percent control. He asked for a response from St. Regis by Monday.   Mr. Murdoch said he had received ''assurances'' that a banking syndicate headed by the Midland Bank of London would provide ''not less than'' $750 million in financing. The balance of the cash needed to gain control, he said, would come from funds on hand and existing credit facilities.

headline: COMPUTER MAKER A TAKEOVER TARGET
abstract: Four years ago, Sir Kenneth Corfield tried unsuccessfully to persuade the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to let its Standard Telephones and Cables Ltd. subsidiary make a takeover bid for International Computers Ltd. The target, a British company, had run into a financial trouble after establishing itself as Europe's most successful mainframe computer maker.   Today, Sir Kenneth is still chairman of Standard Telephones, but the ITT Corporation, as it is now known, is just a minority shareholder in the concern. And Sir Kenneth is taking obvious pleasure in starting a surprise $516 million takeover bid by Standard Telephones for the rapidly recovering computer maker.

headline: THE U.S. RESPONSE ON CRUISE MISSILES
abstract: The Reagan Administration said today that the Soviet Union had been developing cruise missiles ''long before'' the deployment of new American-made medium-range missiles in Europe last December.   On Saturday, the Soviet Union announced that it had conducted successful tests of ground-launched cruise missiles in response to the deployment of the American cruise missiles and Pershing 2 ballistic missiles.    Today John Hughes, the State Department spokesman, said the Soviet announcement came ''as no surprise.''   ''The Soviets have long had an active cruise missile program and have already deployed a substantial force of shorter-range cruise missiles,'' he said. The cruise is a pilotless, ground-hugging craft designed to evade radar.  It evolved from the German Buzz Bomb of World War II.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Aug. 16, 1984 SECURITY COUNCIL   Meets at 10 A.M. on South Africa.  GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.

headline: POLISH DISSIDENT IS CARRIED OUT OF PRISON
abstract: A key Polish dissident jailed since the declaration of martial law in December 1981 said today that Polish security men picked him up and carried him out of the main prison here.   The dissident, Adam Michnik, was freed under a sweeping amnesty approved by Parliament July 21. He had demanded that his name be cleared of sedition charges before he would agree to be released from prison.

headline: Soviet on Reagan Meeting
abstract: The Soviet Union acknowledged for the first time today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko would meet with President Reagan on Sept. 28. A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Vladimir B. Lomeiko, would not tell Western reporters what would be discussed in Mr. Reagan's first contact with a high-level Soviet official.

headline: Ford Plans 1.9% Rise in 85 Prices
abstract: The Ford Motor Company advised its dealers today that it was tentatively increasing the price of its 1985 model cars by 1.9 percent, or an average of $225 a car.    Ford was the last of the domestic auto companies to indicate prices on the 1985 models, most of which will go on sale shortly after Oct. 1. A spokesman for the company said final prices will probably be released within 10 days.

headline: WHY INFLATION REMAINS LOW
abstract: Remarkably, in the face of the economy's continued rapid growth, the stubbornly high inflation that blighted the American economy for more than a decade has dissipated, and a vast majority of the nation's economists see little reason for it to return for as far as they can predict into the 1980's.    Prices continue to rise, of course, but at lower rates than the country has seen since the 1960's.   Some experts say the United States may have entered a long-lived period of disinflation in which a broad range of prices would increase at a rate significantly slower than in the past.    Economists attribute this slowing of inflation partly to the determination of the Federal Reserve to discourage rising prices - by restraining growth of the money supply, starving demand for credit and letting interest rates soar - even at the cost of the long 1981-82 recession.   Convergence of Forces    Economists also cite the fortuitous anti-inflationary convergence of several other forces: the surprising strength of the dollar, softening prices for vital raw materials such as oil, food and other commodities, a low level of wage increases, and deregulation of such industries as airlines and telecommunications.

headline: AN IDEALIST'S SHORT LIFE ENDS IN A KILLING IN A TOGO VILLAGE
abstract: Twelve months into her tour as a Peace Corps volunteer, Jennifer Lynn Rubin, a 23-year-old from Oneonta, N.Y., seemed finally to have come to terms with the loneliness of being the sole volunteer in the village of Defale, population 500, in the West African country of Togo.   Her letters home told of her trouble adjusting to her relocation from upstate New York. In some letters, Miss Rubin repeatedly mentioned a villager she had befriended, a 19-year-old woman named Gieselle who helped her adjust to the culture in northern Togo, a former French colony.   On June 11 Miss Rubin was bludgeoned to death in her home, and the police in Togo have charged Gieselle with the murder. The police say they believe Miss Rubin was killed in revenge for telling Gieselle's father that she had stolen clothing and other items from Miss Rubin's home. Gieselle's last name has not been made public.

headline: MORE ANALYSTS BULLISH ON G.M.
abstract: SOUND too good to be true? A giant industry leader with two dividend increases since November, rapidly rising profits, a treasure chest of cash and its common stock selling at less than five times estimated earnings for 1984 normally might be considered an attractive investment. Until recently, the shares of the General Motors Corporation, which fit this description, were distinct market laggards.    In late July, G.M.'s stock languished below 65. Investors chose to shun the issue as they focused instead on such negatives as fear of a strike later this year, a falloff in profits after 1985 and the company's ongoing competition with Japanese auto makers. Then, too, stock buyers in general seemed to go on strike earlier this summer.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Central Louisiana Electric Co., Alexandria, La., has appointed William F. Terbot to the post of executive vice president.     *  Dataram Corp., Cranbury, N.J., a manufacturer of minicomputer-related products, has named Raymond P. Von Culin, chairman, to the additional post of president, and appointed Robert V. Tarantino president and chief operating officer.

headline: CHERNENKO MAKES APPEARANCE ON TV
abstract: Konstantin U. Chernenko appeared on television today for the first time in more than seven weeks to hand awards to three astronauts, calming a spate of rumors that he has been ailing.   The Soviet leader, who is 72, looked tanned and somewhat thinner than in his last television appearancebefore he left on vacation July 15.   In today's televised Kremlin ceremony, he read a four-minute speech with no more difficulty than he has demonstrated in the past, and he seemed to give the astronauts, including Svetlana Savitskaya, the first woman to walk in space, a hearty handshake.    Mr. Chernenko's appearance was scrutinized closely by foreigners and Russians because of rumors that he had returned to Moscow prematurely from vacation in early August for medical treatment.

headline: 2d Large Bank Cuts Its Prime
abstract: The Wells Fargo Bank, the 11th-largest bank in the country, yesterday became the nation's second major lending institution to reduce its prime rate.    Wells Fargo, which has assets of $26.8 billion, said in San Francisco that it was trimming the prime to 12 1/2 percent, from 13 percent, effective today.

headline: ANGLICANS PLAN TO RESTORE CATHEDRAL AT YORK
abstract: A fire early this morning severely damaged the ancient cathedral of York Minster, particularly its 13th-century south transept, but authorities said damaged areas would be restored and expressed relief that treasures elsewhere in the church had been spared.    The cause of the fire had not been determined, authorities said, but there were indications that it had been started by lightning.   The roof of the south transept, the major casualty of the fire, lay in a charred pile today. It had been erected over vaults so broad that medieval masons could not span them with stone.

headline: ANOTHER GANDHI OPPONENT IS FORCED OUT OF STATE POST
abstract: The Governor of the southern state of Andhra Pradesh dismissed the region's top elected official today and replaced him with a rival politician who pledged cooperation with the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.    The ousted leader, N. T. Rama Rao, an influential foe of Mrs. Gandhi, was briefly arrested when he sought to stop the Governor from installing his rival, N. Bhaskara Rao. Mr. Rama Rao and 175 others were detained and then released, a Government spokesman said.   Mr. Bhaskara Rao, who is not related to Mr. Rama Rao, leads a faction of Mr. Rama Rao's Telegu Desam Party.   The dismissal of the Andhra Pradesh chief minister was the second such action in six weeks. On July 2 the Governor of Jammu and Kashmir, another Gandhi appointee, ousted the Government of Farooq Abdullah and installed a rival faction leader of the same party as chief minister with support from Mrs. Gandhi's Congress Party.

headline: TUESDAY, JULY 31, 1984 Companies
abstract: St. Regis and Champion International plan to merge, according to industry insiders. The deal, reported to be worth $2 billion, would thwart the attempts of Rupert Murdoch to acquire St. Regis. The publisher has proposed two separate offers to acquire the paper company. Champion also has paper operations. (Page D1.)   Alexander's is planning a merger valued at $125 million , or $27.75 a share, with an investor group it declined to identify. According to financial sources, though, the group includes investors tied to Bass Brothers Enterprises and Interstate Properties. The transaction may be a leveraged buyout. (D1.)

headline: Liberian Church Leaders Call for End to Arrests
abstract: Church leaders called on the Liberian leader, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, today to stop what they called arbitrary arrests and mysterious disappearances in an effort to end unrest in this West African nation.   The appeal, issued by the Liberian Council of Churches and read today from pulpits throughout Liberia, came amid a political crisis arising from the arrest of four leading Liberians for unspecified security reasons.    The statement asked General Doe, 34 years old, to lift a recent decree providing 10-year prison terms for people convicted of spreading rumors against authorities.

headline: Times Mirror Gains
abstract: Times Mirror Company, parent of The Los Angeles Times and other media companies, said today that its net income increased 36.7 percent in the second quarter, compared with the same period in 1983.

headline: Circle K Purchase
abstract: The General Post Corporation agreed to sell its 435 Little General Stores to the Circle K Corporation for about $100 million, the companies announced.

headline: Israelis Close 50 ShopsAfter Attack in Lebanon
abstract: Israeli troops shut down 50 shops in the southern Lebanese town of Nabatiyeh today after a guerrilla attack on an Israeli patrol, security sources said.   An Israeli Army spokesman said the grenade attack Thursday killed one soldier and wounded another.   The attack in the town, 36 miles south of Beirut, raised to 587 the Israeli death toll in Lebanon since the Israeli invasion in June 1982.

headline: MANILA'S ECONOMY: SIGNS OF ANGUISH EVERYWHERE
abstract: In the year since the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was shot to death at the Manila Airport last Aug. 21, the political and economic situation in the Philippines has deteriorated badly.    The signs are everywhere.   In a nation where education is cherished, many parents for the first time in recent years cannot spare the modest sums of money required to send their children to high school.   For the urban poor, a day with two meals is now a pretty good day. This year, the bits of beef and pork that occasionally used to be mixed in with the rice and vegetables are unaffordable. Sometimes, mothers say, so are the vegetables, leaving only rice flavored with salt or sugar.

headline: No Southeast, Atlanta Linkup
abstract: The Southeast Banking Corporation of Miami and the First Atlanta Corporation of Georgia said today that they would not merge, ending eight months of speculation that began when the two banks announced a cross-investment program last November.   In a joint statement, Southeast and First Atlanta said they had not been able to arrive at a satisfactory common stock exchange ratio to allow a so- called merger of equals.

headline: GTE'S PROFITS CLIMB 18.4%
abstract: The GTE Corporation, bolstered by its telephone operations' continuing strong performance, reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 18.4 percent.    The company, based in Stamford, Conn., said net income in the latest quarter advanced to $273.1 million, or $1.36 a share, from $230.7 million, or $1.22 a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 16 percent, to $3.63 million, from $3.13 million.

headline: PERU CONSIDERING MARTIAL LAW
abstract: More than 140 people have died in the last two weeks as a result of growing guerrilla attacks and President Fernando Belaunde Terry may declare martial law, a Presidential spokesman said today.   The spokesman, Demetrio Tupac Yupanqui, said martial law - called a state of siege under Peru's Constitution - was an option Mr. Belaunde Terry would bring up at a Cabinet meeting Friday.   Mr. Tupac did not specify whether the President was considering applying martial law nationwide or only in the insurgency area of south central Peru, where the deaths have occurred.

headline: A.T.& T. Adding To '800' Service
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it was preparing to extend its toll-free ''800'' service across the Atlantic Ocean to France.

headline: GERMAN TO DISCUSS DISPUTE IN POLAND
abstract: A leader of the Roman Catholic Church in West Germany left today for a visit to Poland that will include efforts to calm a conflict with Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Polish Primate.    The two-day visit by Wilhelm Sch"atzler, secretary general of the Council of German Catholic Bishops, was planned months ago. But it gained new significance after West German newspapers reported extensively on a sermon by Cardinal Glemp two days ago asserting that concern about a German ethnic minority in Poland was an ''artificial problem.'' The Cardinal said the Polish church could not ''in good conscience'' continue celebrating masses in the German language, the press said.

headline: People
abstract: *  Richard Villante named general manager of Marschalk, New York, and  Kenneth I. Roffe, Eric J. Einhorn and  Stephen Bayer promoted to executive vice presidents of the agency.     *  Jeanne Chinard, James P. Murphy, Philip Peppis and  Myron Polenberg promoted to senior vice presidents at N.W. Ayer.     *  Dennis H. Plansker named group senior vice president of Campbell- Ewald, Warren, Mich.

headline: PENSION SWITCH TO BONDS AT BETHLEHEM, CHRYSLER
abstract: Two of the nation's largest corporations, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation, sold huge amounts of stock held in their pension funds last month to switch into high-yielding bonds. The moves will enable them to save hundreds of millions of dollars in pension fund contributions they must make over coming years.     The continued opportunity to lock in yields of higher than 13 percent on a mix of high-grade corporate bonds and Government securities is tempting many other corporations to make similar moves, said James F. A. Biggs, a pension fund actuarial consultant with Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co.    Bethlehem liquidated more than $700 million in equities on its way to revamping its $2.4 billion pension plan, Arthur J. Roth, a company spokesman said yesterday. Bethlehem said last week in its quarterly earnings report that the company had increased the fixed-income portion of its pension fund portfolio, which would result in a $50 million savings in annual pension fund contributions.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; State's Hospital Issue Has a 9 1/2% Top Yield
abstract: The New York State Dormitory Authority is offering $42.17 million of bonds for the St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in New York City. Underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets offered the bonds with preliminary price of 100 for the 9 3/8 percent issue due in 2004 and the 9 1/2 percent issue due in 2015.

headline: West German Strikes' Impact
abstract: West Germany's labor disputes in June, the nation's worst ever, struck the economy more seriously than was first estimated, a leading economic research institute said today.   Last week, Martin Bangemann, the Economics Minister, said that strikes and lockouts in the engineering and print industries over union demands for shorter working hours had probably resulted in a decline in the gross national product of 1 percent in the second quarter.   But the West Berlin DIW Institute, a leading independent researcher, said it estimated the drop at 2 percent.

headline: People
abstract: *  John E. Byrne has been appointed vice president, marketing, for Porsche Cars North America Inc.  ADVERTISING

headline: Midwest Bottling Plant
abstract: The Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company has agreed to sell its Lincoln plant to a group of seven Pepsi-Cola bottlers from Nebraska, Missouri, Kansas and Colorado. Steven Bloch, a lawyer representing these bottlers, declined today to disclose the purchase price.

headline: IRAN IS SAID TO CLOSE GULF OIL PORT
abstract: Iran was reported today to have closed its key oil export terminal at Kharg Island until Sept. 10 to repair ''severe damage'' to jetties caused by Iraqi air attacks. There was no comment on the report from Teheran.    A Manama-based English-language newspaper, The Gulf Daily News, said the Iranians had informed tanker companies of the temporary closing. The paper based its report on unidentified shipping sources in the gulf.

headline: Thailand and Laos Open Border Talks
abstract: Thailand and Laos opened talks today on a border dispute triggered by the occupation of three villages by Thai troops in a skirmish two months ago.   Arriving at Bangkok's Don Muang Airport, the Laotian Deputy Foreign Minister, Soubahn Srithirath, said his Government hoped for an agreement on the villages of Ban Mai, Ban Klang and Ban Sawang, 300 miles northeast of Bangkok.

headline: Certificates Set At American Air
abstract: American Airlines Inc. is issuing $103 million of secured equipment certificates series B with a top yield of 14.375 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: FED PANEL TO MEET ON GOALS
abstract: On the eve of an important policymaking meeting of the Federal Reserve, many of the analysts here and on Wall Street who monitor the Fed expect no more than a fractional increase in interest rates, at least through the summer, and some doubt that the Fed will even go that far.    The 12 members of the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee meet Monday and Tuesday, as they do eight times a year, to plot the course of interest rates, the money supply and the economy's spirited expansion.    ''I don't think they are going to do much of anything,'' said Timothy Howard, an economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association. So far this year, he added, the Fed has been letting credit demands of the marketpace push the important Federal funds interest rate, which banks charge one another for overnight loans, from under 10 percent early this year to a ltttle above 11 percent in recent weeks. ''What they intended to do,'' Mr. Howard said, ''has already been done.''

headline: PATENTS;  Cancer Treatment
abstract: Dr. M. David Goldenberg and Dr. Dan Shochat of the Center for Molecular Medicine and Immunology at the Newark unit of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey were granted patent 4,468,457 this week. It covers isolation and purification of an antigen from gastrointestinal and ovarian cancers, as well as production of antibodies against the antigen, known as C.S.A.p. The patent has been licensed to Immunomedics Inc., a company on the Newark campus. Dr. Goldenberg has been granted other patents on tumor treatment.

headline: Bid for Fischbach
abstract: Victor Posner, chairman of the Pennsylvania Engineering Corporation, said the company intends to acquire enough shares of the Fischbach Corporation to raise its holdings to more than 50 percent of the voting securities outstanding.

headline: Article 104687 -- No Title
abstract: Energy Transportation Systems Inc. today canceled a proposed $3 billion coal- slurry pipeline project that would have extended 1,800 miles from Wyoming to the Gulf Coast.   ''The decision to terminate is a result of protracted railroad opposition that has brought about costly delays in securing all necessary permits, rights-of-way and other clearances for the project,'' the company's president, Paul G. Doran, said in a statement released in Houston, where Energy Transportation is based.

headline: RUMANIAN JOURNALIST DEFECTS
abstract: A Rumanian journalist who helped The San Diego Union cover the Olympic Games has asked for political asylum in the United States, the newspaper reported today.   The journalist, Vladimir Moraru, a reporter with the Rumanian sports daily Sportul, was to have flown home Monday with the rest of Rumania's Olympic delegation, The Union said.

headline: St. Paul Companies Loss
abstract: The St. Paul Companies yesterday reported a net loss of $42.9 million for the second quarter.

headline: POLAND ASKS TALKS ON ENDING U.S. SANCTIONS
abstract: The Government informed the United States today that it was prepared to begin talks on the Reagan Administration's statement of intent to lift some economic sanctions, saying that it saw ''a positive element'' in the move.   But at the same time, Warsaw declared it did not regard the Reagan statement as evidence of a change in Washington's policies.    The Administration has said it is ready to restore landing rights for LOT Polish Airlines and to renew scientific cooperation.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
abstract: The Long Island Lighting Company, beset with financial problems stemming from the nuclear power plant at Shoreham, is offering $100 million of 17 1/2 percent general and refunding bonds due in 1989 and priced at par. The underwriters are led by Shearson Lehman/American Express.

headline: Pan Am Loss Linked to Discounts
abstract: Pan American World Airways, hurt by an unusually high amount of free or discounted travel, yesterday reported a loss of $49.8 million in the second quarter, in contrast to earnings of $10.4 million, or 13 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1983.    Pan Am said revenues, which slipped 2.9 percent to $918.3 million in the quarter ended June 30, from $945.6 million a year ago, suffered because of a high redemption rate of awards from the carrier's Worldpass program, in which passengers accumulate free-travel credits for mileage flown.   ''In carrying these free or reduced- fare passengers, Pan Am is replacing revenue-producing customers,'' said Candace Browning, an airline analyst at Oppenheimer & Company.

headline: 380 Die as a Typhoon Rakes the Philippines
abstract: A typhoon whipped the southern Philippines with winds of 115 miles an hour today, leaving at least 380 people dead in a trail of flattened houses, uprooted trees and darkened cities, officials said.   Officials in this provincial capital on the island of Mindanao, 450 miles southeast of Manila, said they feared the death toll from the storm, which came ashore Sunday, might go as high as 1,000.

headline: ISRAEL, JORDAN AND MOSQUITOES
abstract: Mosquitoes in neighboring port cities in the Gulf of Aqaba have brought Israel and Jordan into direct contact despite the state of war that has existed between them since 1948, an Israeli newspaper and a Government official said today.   The Tel Aviv daily Haaretz said mosquitos infesting the port cities of Eilat and Aqaba on either side of the Israel- Jordan border were among local problems being discussed by low-level Israeli and Jordanian officials.

headline: Allied Extends Chief's Tenure
abstract: The Allied Stores Corporation said yesterday that its board had extended the employment contract of Thomas M. Macioce, president and chief executive officer, to Jan. 31, 1990, from Jan. 31, 1987.

headline: A GOLD RUSH SWEEPS AMERICA
abstract: Golconda, Nev.    Its price performance has hardly been   spectacular lately and there are still   plenty of people who consider it nothing but a barbaric relic of the dark past. But the lure of gold is gripping American prospectors and mining companies alike these days in a gold boom reminiscent of the last century.    Suddenly, old and forgotten mining operations are reopening in such unlikely gold towns as Walnut Creek, Va., within commuting distance of Washington, and Ishpeming in Michigan's Upper Peninsula. Hundreds of prospectors, usually employees of small mining companies, are searching for new veins of gold in the West, and sometimes finding them, as the Pinson Mining Company did in the mountainous desert country near this old gold town. In fact, new strikes are making Nevada's northern desert and California's wine-making Napa Valley busy centers of gold production.

headline: POPE, LEAVING CANADA, DEPLORES HEDONISM
abstract: Pope John Paul II ended his 12-day visit to Canada today with a denunciation of the ''generalized tendency to hedonism.''     At the same time, he called on Canada's bishops to reaffirm traditional Roman Catholic teachings.   The Pope's address to the bishops included the most stinging words on moral questions he has used during his journey here.   The Pope, who pleased Canada's more liberal and socially involved Catholics with his remarks against unfettered capitalism and ''imperialistic monopoly,'' seemed to be calling the North American church to order today with a warning against ''a humanism without reference to God.''

headline: PROPOSAL ON A.T.&.T. PROFIT MARGIN
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it was considering the development of a new ''formula system'' that would make it relatively easy to revise the profit margin of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on a regular, two-year schedule to reflect changing financial circumstances.    The F.C.C. sets a profit margin on the regulated operations of A.T.&T. The new system would also apply to the seven regional telephone companies created in the Jan. 1 breakup of A.T.& T.    A.T.& T. said it was confident that any review of its profit margin would lead to an increase.   If adopted, such a system could possibly lead to more frequent changes in long-distance telephone rates. In recent years, the F.C.C. has reviewed A.T.& T.'s profit margin an average of only once every five years after conducting a detailed investigation.

headline: UPROAR AND IRRELEVANCE WORRY INDIA'S PARLIMENT
abstract: There was no visible hint of the uproar to come when India's lower house convened this week for the opening of what was likely to be its last session of the current parliamentary term.   The members chatted, relaxed and joked - variously clothed in the coarse cotton pajama tops called kurtas, in Congress caps and Sikh turbans and the peaked wool hats favored by Moslems, in saris and safari suits and short-sleeved summer shirts and even one or two in coats and ties.   Prime Minister Indira Gandhi made the rounds of the front row, greeting even the members of her bitter opposition.   But hardly a second had elapsed after the opening moment of silence for deceased members before some 20 opposition members jumped to their feet. Screaming and bellowing, they demanded that the Speaker immediately schedule a debate on what they called Mrs. Gandhi's illegitimate toppling of an opposition state government recently in Kashmir.

headline: Ethiopia and Kenya To Get More U.S. Grain
abstract: Ethiopia and Kenya, two countries hard hit by drought, will receive additional shipments of American grain, United States officials said today.

headline: Pic 'n' Save Corp.
abstract: William Zimmerman, chairman and founder of the Pic 'n' Save Corporation, and his family, who control about 22.4 percent of the company's stock and are the largest shareholders, said they are exploring alternatives regarding the family's ownerhip position, including the sale of the family's block of stock. The action follows the recent rejection by the company of a $720 million leveraged buyout offer by Adler & Shaykin, a New York investment fund. Pic 'n' Save, based in Carson, Calif., operates a chain of discount retail stores, mainly in southern California.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Air Canada's Net Off 67.2% MONTREAL, Aug. 17 (AP)   - Air Canada said today that   its profits in the second quarter   fell 67.2 percent from a year   earlier as lower fares offset an   11 percent increase in passenger traffic.

headline: First Interstate Offering Notes
abstract: First Interstate Bancorp is offering $150 million of two-year extendible notes with a final maturity in 1999 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The notes are offered at a price of 100, with an initial coupon of 13 percent, to yield about 55 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than two-year Treasury notes.

headline: 3D PARIS BOMB IN 2 DAYS RIPS OFFICE
abstract: A banned group of extremists, Direct Action, claimed responsibility today for its third bomb attack here in 48 hours.    The explosion late Saturday blasted a hole through the ground-floor offices of the Ministry of Industry, shattered windows in nearby buildings and left three people slightly wounded. The attack came on Bastille Day, the French national holiday.   Early this morning, a caller to Agence France-Presse said the bombing was carried out in the name of the so-called Lahouri Farid Benchellal Combat Unit, Direct Action. Lahouri Farid Benchellal, a French leftist extremist, was found dead in a jail cell in Helsinki in January 1982.

headline: Private Flights
abstract: To the Editor:    The misconceptions about the role of general aviation aircraft in our society are so widespread that even gifted government servants like Alfred Kahn would banish such aircraft without any understanding of the social and economic impacts of that action (''Raise the Cost of Landing at Peak Hours,'' Forum, Sept. 9).   Corporate aircraft increase the efficiency of thousands of businessmen and businesswomen. Yet it would seem that government is being lured into the anti-general aviation chorus - an irony for an Administration dedicated to free enterprise.

headline: TORIES IN CANADA WIN A BIG VICTORY OVER THE LIBERALS
abstract: The opposition Progressive Conservative Party of Brian Mulroney scored a huge victory over the Liberal Party of Prime Minister John N. Turner today in voting for a new national government.     With some results in from every district, the Tories were elected or leading in 211 of the 282 districts nationwide, the Liberals in 40, the New Democratic Party in 30 and an independent in one. The independent, elected in metropolitan Toronto, has said he will turn Tory in the near future.    ''Canada has responded to a call to unity,'' Mr. Mulroney told a crowd of widely cheering supporters in his hometown of Baie Comeau. He said the party's mandate was ''to create jobs and get the economy of Canada moving again.'' Mr. Mulroney won his own district of Manicouagan in Quebec's north shore.

headline: MOROCCO-LIBYA PACT: THE AFTERSHOCK
abstract: A month ago, King Hassan II left a meeting with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, and made a number of telephone calls.    The King, considered a faithful ally of the United States, called the Presidents of France and Algeria and members of the Reagan Administration and told them that he was signing a treaty of union with Libya.   The phone calls, which were described by officials of the various countries, did little to calm the diplomatic maelstrom that still surrounds the treaty and its provisions for mutual defense.   President Francois Mitterrand of France and Gen. Vernon A. Walters, a United States roving envoy, visited Morocco in the last two weeks. The United States, which considers Colonel Qaddafi virtually Public Enemy No. 1, and France, whose troops are facing Libyan forces in Chad, fear that the treaty will embolden Colonel Qaddafi.

headline: Bangladesh Election Set
abstract: The election commissioner said today that voters would choose a 300-member Parliament on Dec. 8, six months later than scheduled. The official, A. K. M. Nurul Islam, did not say when presidential elections would be held. Opposition parties are demanding an end to military rule.

headline: CURBING LEAKY STORAGE TANKS
abstract: Leaking tanks that store fuel and chemicals underground are increasingly being viewed as a   threat to drinking water supplies and as a potential source of large economic losses. Federal experts say that up to 600,000 gasoline storage tanks - 25 percent of the total in the United States - are leaking. The Environmental Protection Agency last month identified the problem as a main part of its national water cleanup effort.   Many of the solutions are coming from such new technology, experts say, as computerized leak warning systems, new designs and materials for tanks, and innovative leak containment and treatment systems. State and local regulations in the last year have generated a lot of new business for companies providing such detection and cleanup systems.

headline: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC. TO TRY MEN'S WEAR
abstract: This autumn the bright colors and stylish clothes that distinguish Liz Claiborne apparel are omnipresent in the women's department of any major store. Next year, if the Seventh Avenue company has its way - and so far, it has - there will be Liz Claiborne fashions for men.   Miss Claiborne, the designer who has built a multimillion-dollar business by offering moderately priced, stylish but not trendy, separates to women, announced last month that she was introducing a line of men's wear.    ''We had requests to enter men's wear two years ago, but the male mindset was still pretty conservative,'' she said. ''I think men's retailing is now ready for something a little more casual that would compare in concept to our women's line.''

headline: Futures/Options; Link Set To Amex For Index
abstract: NEXT Monday the securities and futures markets will take a giant step toward the integration of their industries. On July 23, members of the Chicago Board of Trade, the largest futures exchange market, will have access to the options on the Major Market Index of the American Stock Exchange.     Later, when the Chicago Board starts trading futures on the M.M.I., Amex specialists will be able to offset options positions in that market.    Also on July 23, the value of the Amex index of 20 blue-chip stocks will be doubled to $200 a point, from the current $100. This will provide institutional portfolio managers with more efficient and economical hedging opportunities.

headline: China to Let the Dalai Lama Send a Delegation to Peking
abstract: China has agreed to allow the Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual leader, to send a three-man delegation to Peking, the official New China News Agency reported today.   It quoted a spokesman for China's Nationalities Affairs Commission, which supervises the country's ethnic minorities, as saying China had agreed to a request by the Dalai Lama to send a delegation.   The delegation is expected to prepare the ground for a visit the Dalai Lama hopes to make next year to Peking, the press agency said.

headline: Business Digest; TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1984
abstract: The Economy    The deficit in the nation's current account set a record of $24.4 billion in the second quarter. Analysts blame the strong dollar because it led to heavy tourist travel by Americans abroad and weaker income from American investment overseas. (Page A1.)    Business inventories rose 0.8 percent in July, while sales fell 0.8 percent. Analysts said the new numbers were another sign that the economy was slowing from the pace of this year's first half. (D1.)

headline: Gannett Net Grows 14%
abstract: The Gannett Company said that second- quarter net income rose 14 percent, to $59.7 million, or 75 cents a share, from $52.5 million, or 66 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues were $492 million, up from $427 million.

headline: MEXICO MOVING TO EXTRADITE EX-POLICE CHIEF
abstract: Mexico today began seeking the extradition from the United States of Mexico City's former police chief, who is wanted on a wide range of corruption charges here.   The effort to prosecute the former police chief has been widely viewed here as a key test of the seriousness of President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado's ''moral renovation'' campaign.   After a months-long manhunt that spanned three continents, the 61-year- old former police chief, Arturo Durazo Moreno, was captured Friday night in San Juan, Puerto Rico. He was seized at Customs by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and United States deputy marshals and was held without bail.

headline: MANILA'S POLICE ON ALERT ON EVE OF AQUINO RALLIES
abstract: The police have been placed on a high state of alert for possible violence Tuesday, when a major rally is planned to mark the first anniversary of the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.     ''We certainly hope that the military will stay away from us,'' said Reli German, one of the rally's organizers. ''If they are there, we want them to escort us and not try to disperse us.''   In recent months the police have routinely used tear gas and truncheons to break up anti-Government demonstrations, causing injuries to marchers and bystanders.

headline: Manville Net Drops
abstract: The Manville Corporation, which sought Federal Bankruptcy Court protection two years ago because of mounting asbestos-related health claims, said today that its second-quarter profits dropped 28.7 percent, to $18.1 million, from a year earlier. The profit represented 49 cents a common share, down from $25.4 million, or 66 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1983. Revenues rose 2.6 percent, to $466 million, from $454 million.

headline: Revises Estimates
abstract: The Detroit Edison Company said that fuel loading at its Fermi 2 nuclear power plant near Monroe, Mich., would be extended about four months and that the estimated cost of the plant had been increased $300 million.

headline: A Reorganization At Hill & Knowlton
abstract: Hill & Knowlton Inc., an international public relations company, said yesterday that it had reorganized its 52 offices worldwide into domestic and international units. Hill & Knowlton is a subsidary of the JWT Group.

headline: Tunisian Ruler Names Aide
abstract: President Habib Bourguiba named Mohammed Sayah today as Minister of Equipment and Housing in a move seen as reinforcing the 82-year-old leader's control over the Government.

headline: JOURNALISTS FIND GROWING DIFFICULTY IN GETTING INTO MUCH OF THIRD WORLD
abstract: On the last day of 1983, there was a military takeover in Nigeria; on April 3, 1984, a coup in Guinea, and three days later, a violent attempted overthrow of the Government in Cameroon.   As each of these West African political upheavals took place, one of the first measures taken by the authorities was to close their borders and stop issuing visas to foreigners, including journalists.   Many overseas reporters, as well as editors and administrators, say problems in West Africa are symptomatic of a growing difficulty faced by foreign journalists, particularly Americans. The problem is gaining access to many parts of the third world.   Journalists who work for newspapers, magazines and television, particularly in Africa and the Middle East, say they are encountering long and frustrating waits for visas, which in some cases are not granted at all.

headline: KUWAIT INITIALS A $327 MILLION SOVIET ARMS DEAL
abstract: Kuwait has initialed a $327 million arms deal with the Soviet Union aimed at defending Persian Gulf commercial shipping against Iranian attacks, Kuwaiti officials said today.   The officials said in Kuwait that the deal included surface-to-air and surface-to-surface missiles, tanks and other military equipment. They said it did not include any SAM-7 antiaircraft missiles or MIG jet fighters.

headline: Debt Review
abstract: *  Bethlehem Steel Corp.'s debt and preferred stock ratings are being reviewed by Moody's for a possible downgrading.      Corporate Bonds    *  Nippon Kokan Kabushiki Kaishi , a major Japanese steel producer, is offering $100 million of seven-year, 13 1/8 percent noncallable bonds due in 1991, through Morgan Guaranty Ltd.     *  Ryan Mortgage Acceptance Corp.'s $24.9 million of Government National Mortgage Association collateralized bonds, due in 2014, have been offered at par with a 12 3/4 percent coupon through Dean Witter Reynolds.

headline: Four Indicted in a Plan To Export Arms to Iran
abstract: Four men were indicted Friday in connection with an agreement to illegally export 400,000 chemical warfare protective suits to Iran, which has charged that Iraq is using chemical weapons in the Persian Gulf war.   A seven-count indictment was returned in United States District Court in New Haven against Rene Schuler, a Swiss national now living in Brazil; William Cherry, also known as William Cherri, of Hempstead, N.Y.; and Harold Buck and John Reed, both of Las Vegas.

headline: PATENTS ;
abstract: Fuel Assembly Design For Nuclear Reactors    A new design for fuel assemblies in liquid metal, fast breeder nuclear reactors has been invented for the Department of Energy.

headline: A BIG THRIFT IN TROUBLE
abstract: The high-risk lending practices of Charles W. Knapp, chairman of the Financial Corporation of America, haunted the nation's largest thrift institution last week. Rumors circulated that its main bank, American Savings and Loan, had a net outflow of funds in July. On Wednesday, that was confirmed, as the thrift reported a $582 million loss of funds, primarily from $1.4 billion in institutional withdrawals. Moreover, Financial reported a $107.5 million loss for the quarter ended June 30, the result of changing its accounting procedures at the insistence of the S.E.C. It was thought to be the largest quarterly loss ever reported by a thrift, and it cut the bank's net worth to 2.3 percent of its assets, well below its required 4 percent minimum. As fears mounted that the U.S. had another major banking crisis on its hands, trading in the thrift's certificates of deposit almost stopped, adding to its liquidity problems. Analysts said the next few days could be critical.      The G.M. Challenge.  The New York Stock Exchange decided not to resist General Motors in its desire to trade a special class of stock linked with its $2.5 billion purchase of Electronic Data Systems. Despite Big Board rules that prohibit trading two classes of stock, it agreed to list G.M. Class E stock that E.D.S. shareholders will receive. The stock has one-half the voting rights of G.M. common.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM GOVERNMENT STATEMENT ON CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS
abstract: Following are excerpts from the Comprehensive Statement of the Permanent Assistance Program for the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago. The statement was issued today by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Federal Reserve Board.             Financial Assistance Program    Loan Purchase      The bank has a substantial volume of troubled loans. The first major element in the financial assistance program involves removing most of those loans from the bank.   The loans in question have a face value of over $5.1 billion and a May 31, 1984, book value of approximately $4.5 billion, based on earlier charge- offs by the bank of over $600 million in face value.

headline: BIG BANKS WORRIED BY AN F.D.I.C. PLAN
abstract: The near collapse and multibillion- dollar rescue of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company has been an embarrassment for the nation's biggest banks. It could be expensive for them as well.     Part of the fallout has been the reopening of a long-standing debate among regulators and the big banks over whether banks should be required to pay insurance premiums to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on their foreign deposits. Currently, the law exempts foreign deposits from such premiums, but that policy is being reconsidered by an interagency group under the Treasury Department's leadership.

headline: Nicaragua to Ease Some Restrictions
abstract: Daniel Ortega Saavedra, leader of the Nicaraguan junta, said Monday night that the Government would relax press censorship, restore the right to strike and allow people to petition the courts for release from jail.   His announcement, in a speech at an international conference of mayors, came the same day that the Government said the country's main opposition coalition had lost its legal status because it failed to meet a deadline for registering for the Nov. 4 election.   The three opposition parties in the Nicaraguan Democratic Coordinate coalition have said they will not take part in the elections unless the Sandinistas remove restrictions on press and other freedoms and enter into a national discussion with United States- backed rebels.

headline: U.S. CRITICIZES A.B.A.'S LAWYER CODE
abstract: The Justice Department's antitrust division said today that the American Bar Association's model rules of legal ethics were anticompetitive in some of their proposals to limit attorneys' advertising, solicitation and fees.   J. Paul McGrath, the antitrust division chief, said the A.B.A.'s ''overly broad'' proposals for restricting advertising and solicitation ''would restrict the flow of useful information from attorneys to consumers of legal services.''   He also said the A.B.A.'s model rule requiring that fees be ''reasonable'' might ''adversely affect price competition among lawyers'' because it could be construed as prohibiting unusually low fees.

headline: THE U.N.'S VISION IS 'CLOUDED,' ITS CHIEF FUNDS
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today in his annual report that the once ''majestic vision'' of the United Nations had been ''clouded by the differences of the major powers.''   The result, he said, has been ''the sidestepping'' of the world body in favor of force and independent action.   In the report, his third since taking office in 1982, Mr. Perez de Cuellar, a Peruvian, spoke more about the neglect and misuse of the world body by member nations than of the shortcomings within the United Nations itself.

headline: TOLL AT 25
abstract: Police gunfire killed at least 6 people and wounded 38 in Andhra Pradesh state today in new confrontations arising from the dismissal of the opposition-led state government, state authorities said.   There have now been at least 25 deaths in street protests since the administration of N. T. Rama Rao was ousted on Thursday by the state governor, an appointee of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. About 275 protesters and 40 police officers have been injured.

headline: COCAINE MEANS CASH IN BOLIVIA BANK
abstract: In this cold capital, just below the glaciers of the Andes, it seems an abstract notion that thousands of people are busily picking, processing and transporting coca leaves across a lower and warmer part of Bolivia.  But when it ''snows'' in the tropical lowlands, businessmen smile knowingly here.  It means, they say, that a new wave of cocaine money is entering this country's tiny economy.    Recently, it was snowing again, according to a banker. He said that in one of his provincial branch offices ''a single deposit of $1 million'' had just come in.

headline: Nigeria to Indict Aide Who Was Found in Crate
abstract: Nigeria will lodge corruption charges against a fugitive former Cabinet member who was the target of an attempted kidnapping in Britain this month, the Government said Monday.   Foreign Minister Ibrahim Gambari told reporters that the authorities considered former Transport Minister Umahuru Dikko their No. 1 enemy among fugitives who fled the country after the military coup Dec. 31.

headline: French Hold Basque Leader
abstract: The man thought to be second- in-command of the military wing of the Spanish Basque separatist movement was arrested near here today, according to police sources. They said Eugenio Echeveste was picked up at a police road block.

headline: PERLMANS TO SELL REGENT AIR
abstract: A New York investment banker has purchased controlling interest in the Regent Air Corporation, the financially troubled luxury air service.     J. Roger Faherty said he agreed last week to buy the 61.2 percent stake in Regent owned by Clifford and Stuart Perlman, the brothers who helped found the company in 1982. Mr. Faherty is managing partner at Rooney, Pace Inc., the investment company that has been Regent's financial adviser. He is also a member of Regent's board,    During a telephone interview, Mr. Faherty declined to disclose what he paid for the Perlman stake. However, according to officials of the Civil Aeronautics Board, documents filed last Friday with the board state that Mr. Faherty has pledged to pay the Perlmans $6 million for their 111 million shares.

headline: U.S. and China Weigh Port Calls by Warships
abstract: Top United States and Chinese military officials have discussed the possibility of port calls by American warships in China, but there has been ''no firm agreement yet,'' the Pentagon spokesman, Michael I. Burch, said today.   Mr. Burch was replying to a question about published reports that China appears ready to allow United States naval ships to visit its ports for the first time in more than 30 years and that this possibility arose after recent discussions between the Secretary of the Navy, John F. Lehman, and the Chinese authorities.

headline: GRENADA, AGAIN PORT OF CALL, GREETS THE TOURISTS HAPPILY
abstract: They came off the big white ship in shorts and sundresses. Some headed for the long line of taxis. Others wandered around the picturesque harbor, past the creaky wooden motorized sailboats taking on cargo and then on through the clean, narrow streets to the central market.

headline: NUCLEAR NATIONS AGREE TO TIGHTEN EXPORT CONTROLS
abstract: Western countries that supply nuclear technology met in Luxembourg last week and decided to strengthen controls on nuclear exports, according to Administration officials.    The officials said the suppliers agreed they had to do more - expanding safeguards on existing plants, pressing new suppliers to tighten sales and controlling transfers of components - to prevent the spread of the ability to build nuclear weapons.   The meeting, arranged at the iniative of the Reagan Administration, began on Wednesday and concluded on Friday.   Meeting Kept Secret    The participants decided to keep the meeting secret to avoid charges, as one Administration official put it, ''of the big guys ganging up on the little ones'' to dictate terms for nuclear cooperation.

headline: DOW DECLINES 3.64 AMID RATE CONCERN
abstract: Profit taking and concern over interest rates weakened stock prices slightly yesterday in quiet pre-Labor Day trading.    At the final bell, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 3.64 points, at 1,223.28. In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored gainers,   794 to 687.

headline: I.B.M. Ends Pact
abstract: Intermetrics Inc. said it had been notified that the International Business Machines Corporation had invoked the termination provision in a 1981 contract. Intermetrics, which develops computer software products and services, said I.B.M.  made it clear that the termination did not reflect dissatisfaction with the work done by the company. The contract represented about 19 percent of Intermetrics' revenues for fiscal 1983, 17 percent for fiscal 1984 and about 15 percent for the first quarter of fiscal 1985.The company said the impact on its earnings could not be determined, but noted that the contract calls for termination payments by I.B.M.

headline: CONTINENTAL BORROWING WAS HEAVY THIS WEEK
abstract: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company's borrowings from the Federal Reserve were far larger than believed in the days just before its rescue package was announced, according to officials of the bank.   These borrowings climbed to between $5 billion and $6 billion a day, David G. Taylor, the bank's outgoing chairman, said today at a lunch with reporters.    That was in addition to a longer- term, $2 billion injection of funds by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and a group of major banks last May. It also was in addition to drawings of about $4.12 billion on a $5.5 billion special line of credit from 28 banks.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.10     An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds   compiled weekly by The Bond   Buyer.   Aa Utility Bonds*13.50     Salomon Brothers' estimate for   new long-term issues.

headline: Holding Company Buys Cigar Unit
abstract: MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc. said it had acquired Consolidated Cigar Holdings Ltd.

headline: COMPANY EARNINGS ; Alcoa Surged in 2d Quarter ;  Inland Steel Shows Profit
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum concern, reported yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose almost threefold over the quarterly results of a year ago.   In another report, the Inland Steel Company, reflecting a modest upturn in the still struggling steel industry, reported a profit for the second quarter, compared with a loss the year before.     AlcoaAlcoa, based in Pittsburgh, said net income totaled $112.8 million, or $1.38 a share, for the three months ended June 30, compared with $34.6 million, or 43 cents a share, a year earlier. Alcoa's revenues rose 15.9 percent, to $1.46 billion, compared with $1.26 billion, the company said.

headline: EASTER I. DRIFTING TOWARD, AND AWAY FROM, CHILE
abstract: The 1,900 people of this tiny dot in the South Pacific are grumbling.   Chile, 2,350 miles to the east, laid claim to the island 96 years ago. But today, after years of tranquillity, many of the islanders are jobless, poor and questioning whether they are Polynesian or Latin American.   ''We feel like birds on a lonely island,'' said Margarita Pakarati, a 38-year- old housewife. ''No one feeds them.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: Emery Going To Thompson Emery Worldwide, which   split with Benton & Bowles   after a mutual agreement, said yesterday that it would deliver its   business to J. Walter Thompson, New York.

headline: Key Banks Stake
abstract: The Edinburgh Investment Trust P.L.C., an Edinburgh-based investment concern, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it holds 701,900 common shares, or 5 percent of the total outstanding, of Key Banks Inc. The trust said that it had acquired the stake out of a desire to invest in an American regional bank, and that it might buy additional Key securities but had no firm plans to do so. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Key, which is based in Albany, closed at $18.875, up 87 1/2 cents.

headline: 7 Shot Dead in Philippines
abstract: Two gunmen killed seven male boarders of a lodging house in gangland fashion in this southern Philippine city today, the police reported. A spokesman said the killers entered the Dance Inn early this morning, woke up the 10 residents, herded them into another room and opened fire with high-powered rifles. The police could offer no motive.

headline: GOING AFTER THE ICEBERG, NOT JUST THE TIP
abstract: HOUSTON    Paine Webber's acquisition of the Houston-based brokerage house of Rotan Mosle was barely a half hour old when Donald B. Marron, Paine Webber's chief executive, telephoned John B. Young, one of Rotan's superbrokers. The message: ''Don't walk.'' And, no wonder. With annual commissions averaging more than $1 million for the last three years, Mr. Young was a hot ticket and Mr. Marron wanted to keep him.   As it turned out, Mr. Young, 43, needed little convincing. He's comfortably ensconced in Rotan's Post Oaks office, just a stone's throw from where he grew up in Houston's opulent River Oaks section. Mr. Young is a son of Houston, with friends and clients throughout the city, and he has built a business that blends his personal and professional worlds.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Audiotronics Corp.'s employee stock ownership trust said it had increased its holdings in the Hollywood- based company's common stock to 258,243 shares, or 21.7 percent of the total outstanding.     *  Coated Sales Inc.  of Parlin, N.J., said it had acquired 51 percent of Cal- Pen Textile Inc., a Los Angeles-based wholesale industrial textile distributor.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Uranium Suit Won, UNC Chief Retires
abstract: After successfully guiding UNC Resources Inc. through nearly nine years of litigation over uranium pricing, Keith A. Cunningham, chairman and chief executive, has announced his retirement from the company.   UNC Resources, a diversified manufacturing and natural resources concern based in Falls Church, Va., filed suit in 1975 against the General Atomic Company of San Diego to break up what it called an international uranium cartel. General Atomic was acquired by the Gulf Oil Corporation in 1982, and Gulf, in turn, recently agreed to be acquired by the Standard Oil Company of California, which has changed its name to the Chevron Corporation.

headline: A REVERSAL FOR GANDHI
abstract: Just when Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's political stock seemed to be rising as a result of her bold action in June against Sikh extremists in Punjab, the furor over the dismissal last month of N. T.  Rama Rao as the elected leader of the southern state of Andhra Pradesh appears to have sent it plummeting again.   ''She has lost the advantage she gained after Punjab,'' said Bashiruddin Ahmed, a political scientist. ''It's turned 180 degrees.''    While the situation may change in the weeks and months ahead, a number of other political scientists as well as politicians and journalists say they believe Mrs. Gandhi's parliamentary majority could be threatened in the coming general election.

headline: ISRAELI PRESIDENT DESIGNATES PERES TO FORM CABINET
abstract: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, was asked today to form a new government of Israel.    Mr. Peres received the mandate from President Chaim Herzog nearly two weeks after national elections that left both the Labor Party and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc without a parliamentary majority.   Standing in bright sunshine outside the President's residence, Mr. Peres said he would seek ''as broad a government as possible, a government of national unity, which will bridge the rifts that have been discovered in the ground of our existence.''   Meeting With Shamir    ''Mr. Shamir told me he would cooperate in forming such a government,'' Mr. Peres said, in response to questions, adding that the two political leaders were discussing whether the first meeting should ''be between the two of us with our delegations.''

headline: New Cabinet Named In Bourkina Fasso
abstract: The leader of Bourkina Fasso, formerly Upper Volta, has named a new Cabinet that reduces the influence of the Marxist Patriotic Development League, officials said today.

headline: A.T.& T.-Contel
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had signed an agreement to supply digital switiching equipment valued at up to $100 million to the Contel Service Corporation. The agreement covers shipments of A.T.& T.'s 5ESS equipment through 1987. A.T.& T. said the first shipment is being installed in Hershey, Pa. Contel is based in Atlanta.

headline: NEW NETWORKS OF IMMIGRANT ENTERPRENEURS; ALL IN THE FAMILY APPROACH
abstract: ON the surface, there is no pattern to John Lam's mix of businesses. The 32-year-old Mr. Lam, who came here from Hong Kong 15 years ago, is a garment contractor who makes clothes for such quality houses as Leslie Fay, Pierre Cardin and Evan Picone. He is a real estate speculator who owns four Chinatown buildings. He trades in silk. And he is talking about opening a bank.   But his businesses do have one thing in common. They are outgrowths of a network of family members and business contacts that spans from Chinatown to Hong Kong to China. ''I have a big family and each member goes in a different direction,'' Mr. Lam said. ''Then we all work together.''

headline: NICARAGUA SPURNS DISARMAMENT PLEA
abstract: Nicaragua's Foreign Minister, Miguel d'Escoto Brockmann, says he will reject a call by a four-nation group for regional disarmament as long as the United States continues its undercover attacks on his country.    The Foreign Ministers of Mexico, Colombia, Venezuela and Panama, which comprise the so-called Contadora group, ended 48 hours of talks on Friday by urging five Central American nations to adopt a revised version of the group's peace plan, including provisions for regional disarmament. The five are Nicaragua, Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Costa Rica.

headline: SOHIO TO BUY SOME GULF ASSETS
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said today that it would buy the Gulf Corporation's marketing and refining operations in the Southeast, where it now does little business. The sale presumably clears the way for final approval of the Chevron Corporation's $13.3 billion acquisition of Gulf, which would be the biggest merger on record.    Chevron and Sohio said their agreement in principle on the Gulf operations conformed closely to the terms of a Federal Trade Commission divestiture requirement last spring under which Chevron was conditionally permitted to acquire Gulf.    Operations in 8 States    Sohio will acquire Gulf's wholesale and retail marketing businesses, including 4,000 service stations, in eight Southeastern states. Sohio will also get Gulf's modern 200,000 barrel- a-day refinery at Alliance, La. The price was not disclosed, but Chevron's chairman, George M. Keller, said in an interview that it was ''something less than a billion'' dollars.

headline: GLOBAL BANK MEETING CITES PROGRESS
abstract: The 39th annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund opened today with general agreement that the worst of the world debt crisis has passed, but that major challenges remain before a return to sustained economic recovery.    Delegates from the 148 countries that are members of the two pillars of the world economic community were participating in the biggest economic conference of the year, which has drawn some 12,000 officials, commercial bankers and journalists.   The delegates will be officially welcomed on Tuesday morning by President Reagan, who is expected to stress the role that increased American economic growth has played in the overall improvement.    The Reagan Administration opposes an increase in the World Bank's resources. This appeared to be another in a series of conflicts with the bank's president, A. W. Clausen, an American. Last week, he said the bank would probably need about $40 billion more from its member countries, an increase of roughly 50 percent from its current capital funds.

headline: Polaroid Offer With T.W.A. Trans World Airlines and the
abstract: Polaroid Corporation said yesterday that purchasers of   Polaroid cameras and films   would receive a 25 percent fare   discount on T.W.A. round-trip   flights on both domestic and international routes. The companies said that   camera or film purchases must   be made before Jan. 31 and that   the travel periods would be   from Jan. 1 to April 3 and from   Oct. 15, 1985, to March 15, 1986.

headline: Bankruptcy Judge Debate
abstract: The Federal judiciary's chief administrative officer is considering rescinding his decision last week not to issue paychecks to the nation's bankruptcy judges, a spokesman said today.   William E. Foley, director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, may reverse himself in response to sharp criticism from Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, the spokesman said.

headline: Easco, a Toolmaker, Appoints President
abstract: Robert L. Swam has been named president of the Easco Corporation, the Baltimore-based hand tool manufacturer. The appointment is effective immediately, Easco said.    Mr. Swam, 43, succeeds Richard P. Sullivan, 51, as president. Easco said that Mr. Sullivan would continue to serve as its chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: Guyana Holds 3 U.S. Boats
abstract: A Guyanese court confiscated three United States-owned trawlers Friday and fined their South Korean skippers $32,500 each for fishing illegally in Guyanese waters.

headline: Ex-Commodore Officer Retakes Helm Abruptly
abstract: Ray J. Gans, who last month resigned as president, chief executive officer and chairman of the Commodore Corporation, a manufacturer of mobile homes, yesterday was re- elected to those positions by the company's board of directors.     At the same time, the company said that John A. Bacon Jr. and two other directors, Richard R. Christensen and Merrill Butler, had resigned. On July 17, Mr. Bacon, 56, one of the company's four directors, was named as acting chairman and president.

headline: Brooke Rejects Bid From Unilever
abstract: Brooke Bond Group P.L.C., the British tea giant, today gave a brisk ''no deal'' response to a rival $460 million takeover bid from International Food Group, Unilever P.L.C. The tea group, which had already rejected an earlier takeover offer from sugar manufacturers Tate & Lyle P.L.C., also issued a sharp rebuke to Unilever for the way the bid was handled.   Sir John Cuckney, Brooke Bond's chairman, said Unilever appeared to have broken the spirit of the takeover code when launching the offer Sunday night.

headline: SINGAPORE'S TOURISM INDUSTRY FALTERS
abstract: In trying to entice tourists, Singapore uses plenty of imagination. Two years ago, for instance, it was decided that foreign visitors might be amused to have breakfast at the Singapore Zoological Gardens with Ah Meng, an orangutan with a taste for rolls, orange juice and coffee.     ''Oh, it's perfectly safe,'' said Choy Yoke, an official at the zoo, ''and Ah Meng has excellent table manners.'' In fact, the notion of sharing the table with an ape has proven so popular that this year the zoo added afternoon tea. Ah Meng's son, Medan, is the tea sipper in the family.

headline: ISRAELI MODEL OF ENDURANCE: SHIMON PERES
abstract: Shimon Peres, who was chosen today to form a new Israeli Government, has arrived at the high point of his political career after years of bruising struggle, much of it within his own Labor Party.  The Prime Minister- designate, who turns 61 years old Aug. 16, began his work in the Government as a close aide of Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion, whom he served for 12 years, most of them in the Defense Ministry.   It was a period of rapid advancement, but it was also marked by sharp criticism of Mr. Peres, who is known as a compulsive worker who rarely sleeps more than four hours a night.   He lists books as his hobby, and delights in quoting from them in speeches.
