His opponents, on the other hand, have over the years delighted in characterizing Mr. Peres as a schemer and a man without real political convictions.

headline: FOR MEXICANS, CONCERN RISES ON CIVIL RIGHTS
abstract: Mexico, which prides itself on its image of civil liberty and social calm, has recently seen a series of events that have raised alarm among opposition groups and even some officials of the governing party.   In Mexico's modern, cavernous Legislative Palace, a group of opposition legislators and human rights activists is in the third week of a hunger strike, demanding information on ''political prisoners'' and people who have ''disappeared,'' reportedly into Government custody.   A few weeks back, a prominent critic of the Government's refugee policies was kidnapped from his home by armed men in civilian dress, blindfolded and questioned for 14 hours and then released. Information provided to the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party says at least 18 leaders of peasant organizations have been killed by unknown assailants in seven states in the last few months.

headline: TRADING SLOWS
abstract: Stock prices ended moderately lower yesterday in much slower trading, with issues responding to specific or rumored news the biggest movers.     At the conclusion of the session, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 4.64 points, to 1,109.98, after advancing more than 13 points last week.    In the overall market yesterday, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored winners by 856 to 657. Turnover on the Big Board fell to 72.3 million shares, from 101.4 million shares on Friday, as institutional interest slackened.

headline: Loan Repaid By Argentina
abstract: Argentina has repaid a $300 million emergency loan from four Latin American nations and is moving forward in negotiations with the International Monetary Fund, according to reports today quoting the president of its central bank.   The newspaper La Nacion quoted Enrique Garcia Vasquez as saying that Argentina used its hard currency reserves to repay $100 million each to Venezuela and Mexico and $50 million to Brazil.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Georgia-Pacific Issues $100 Million in Notes
abstract: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation became the second high-grade industrial company to enter the bond market this week with a 10-year issue of fixed-rate notes. The company's $100 million issue of 13 1/2 percent notes due in 1994, rated A-2 by Moody's and A- by Standard & Poor's, was offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.    According to data compiled by Salomon Brothers, there were only about $1.27 billion of bond financings by manufacturing and mining companies in the first half of the year, with no issues in May and June.

headline: Some Dockworkers Defy British Strike
abstract: Longshoremen at the port of Immingham in Lincolnshire voted to defy a strike call today, creating the first rebellion against a two-day-old nationwide dock strike.   The workers at Immingham, where an 11-day strike was held last month, backed their union's orders on Friday to strike.

headline: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE ACCORDS
abstract: Following are highlights of the agreement on Hong Kong:    Name - In 1997, Hong Kong will become the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China, with a high degree of autonomy except in foreign affairs and defense. Laws - Hong Kong will have its own executive, legislative and independent judicial power.

headline: THE NEW SUPERMARKET TAKES SHAPE
abstract: AT the Edwards Food Warehouse along Route 1 in Orange, Conn., lines form at the deli, the fresh fish counter and the bakery. Shoppers wander through the aisles, where the merchandise sits in unpacked cartons on the shelves. Others migrate to the bulk-foods section where they scoop up everything from grits to cat litter from wooden cracker barrels. At the check-out counter they bag their own purchases.   ''I hate it,'' Cynthia Ostroff says as she crams the week's groceries into brown paper sacks. She has driven 12 miles from New Haven to shop for her family, which includes a husband, three children and a live-in housekeeper, and although she doesn't like the longer drive and the extra work at the check-out counter, she does like the lower prices. ''My grocery bill used to run $175 a week, but I can save $30 a week here,'' she says.

headline: A DEFICIT DECLINE IN FISCAL '85 SEEN BY ADMINISTRATION
abstract: The Reagan Administration, in its midyear budget review, projected today that the Federal deficit for the fiscal year 1985 would be $172.4 billion, just $1.9 billion less than the projected figure for the current 1984 fiscal year.   For the rest of the decade, the Administration projected a small rise in the deficit in 1986 and 1987 and then a decline, to $161.7 billion, by 1989.   Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic candidate, immediately charged that the projections, which show significantly lower deficits than those predicted recently by the Congressional Budget Office, were ''cooked'' and intended to aid President Reagan during his re-election campaign. (Page B12.)

headline: Briton's Moscow Visit Criticized by Laborites
abstract: Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Foreign Secretary, who returned Tuesday from Moscow, was branded here today as an election-year cheerleader and messenger boy for President Reagan.   Sir Geoffrey told Parliament that he had checked with the White House while in Moscow to correct what he considered a mistaken Soviet impression that the United States was attaching conditions to accepting a Soviet proposal for talks on space weapons.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Sindona Held In Murder ROME, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -   Michele Sindona, the Italian   financier who was extradited   from the United States two   days ago, was officially   charged today with the murder   of a banker. Judicial sources said two arrest warrants were served on   Mr. Sindona in his Rome prison   cell.

headline: Advertising Association Gets Washington Head
abstract: Bradley H. Roberts, 57 years old and one-time vice chairman and head of the West Coast operation of Needham, Harper & Steers, has been named to run the Washington office of the American Association of Advertising Agencies as an executive vice president in the organization. He replaces Charles F. Adams, retiring before his 57th birthday on Wednesday.

headline: CAYMANS' BANK SECRECY LIFTED FOR U.S.
abstract: The United States and Britain signed an agreement today that will give American officials investigating narcotics cases information about secret bank accounts in the Cayman Islands, a British colony in the Caribbean whose bank secrecy laws have made it a convenient place to hide drug money as well as a tax haven.    The American Ambassador to Britain, Charles H. Price 2d, said at a signing ceremony that the agreement was ''an important step in line with President Reagan's initiative against drug trafficking.'' He also called it ''the first tangible result of talks begun last November on a whole range of subjects involving conflicts of jurisdiction.''   American drug enforcement officials have complained that the spread of offshore banking and accompanying secrecy laws were tying their hands.

headline: CUTTING RISKS: OPTION VS. FORWARD CONTRACT
abstract: Although the volume of the Westinghouse Corporation's foreign exchange dealings has remained relatively steady in the past year, Lawrence J. Lanza, assistant director of international treasury operations, said his trading activity had doubled as he tried to keep up with the dollar's fluctuations. Although the dollar has generally risen, the pattern has been saw-toothed, requiring constant adjustments in Westinghouse's positions.   ''We are at the point of moving into options,'' Mr. Lanza said.

headline: U.S. POLICY ON ABORTION: A LIKELY TARGET NAMED
abstract: A Reagan Administration official today identified the International Planned Parenthood Federation as the likely first target of a new Administration policy that would deny family planning money to organizations that support abortion overseas.    The official, a member of the Agency for International Development, said the International Planned Parenthood group, which describes itself as the world's second largest private charitable organization, will lose its $11 million a year in American aid unless it changes its policy. The aid amounts to one fifth of the foundation's budget.

headline: JAPANESE GALLOWS: CASE OF THE 'WRONG MAN'
abstract: In the third recent case of its kind, a man sentenced to death for murder has been freed by a Japanese court after being found innocent at a retrial.    As with the previous two acquittals, Yukio Saito's release from prison after 24 years on death row brought complaints about police procedures.   The three highly publicized ''wrong man'' cases over the last year, however, have not led to a significant debate about capital punishment.   The reaction contrasts sharply with what might be expected in the United States under comparable circumstances. In fact, Japan is virtually alone among the major industrial countries in its lack of a strong movement to abolish the death penalty.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: TOMATOES, SHEKELS, VOTES
abstract: It all began with tomatoes.   In an effort to demonstrate to voters how severely runaway inflation has eroded buying power in the last seven years of Likud Government, Israel's Labor Party set up a stall in Haifa several weeks ago to sell tomatoes at their 1977 prices.   For a mere shekel - the equivalent of less than half a cent today - for two pounds of tomatoes, voters were invited to stock up.   The Likud bloc did not find the sale funny and responded by filing a complaint with the election board asserting that Labor was effectively buying votes by selling cut-rate tomatoes, because two pounds of tomatoes today cost roughly 100 shekels, or 40 cents.

headline: Scholastic, Two Others Join Computer Project
abstract: Scholastic's Family Computing magazine has gotten itself involved in a pair of capers with magazines of other publishers. Both involve inserts and in both cases the ad sales staffs of both publications will be out peddling space.

headline: THRIFT UNIT REPORTS BIG LOSS
abstract: The Financial Corporation of America, forced by the Securities and Exchange Commission to revise accounting methods concerning $2 billion of mortgage-backed securities, today reported an unanticipated loss of $107.5 million for the quarter ended June 30.   Financial Corporation decided to accept the changes late Tuesday, as the deadline for a quarterly report to the commission approached. The company had been prepared to report a quarterly profit of $31.1 million. The loss is believed to be the largest ever reported for one quarter by an American thrift institution.   One result is that Financial Corporation's net worth at the end of June dropped to 2.3 percent of its total deposits and other short-term liabilities. That amount is barely half the 4 percent minimum that the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has required the company to have by the end of 1984.

headline: A.& P.'s Net Rises Sharply
abstract: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company announced today a huge earnings gain for its first quarter and said it would be in a position to resume paying dividends in fiscal 1985. The company said it earned $151.3 million, or $4.03 a share, in the quarter ended June 16, up from $13.1 million, or 35 cents a share, in the year-earlier period.

headline: Pakistan Seizes Heroin
abstract: Pakistan's Narcotics Control Board said today that it had seized 100 pounds of heroin worth an estimated $30 million at the Karachi Airport.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Dillon, Read Fills New Research Post
abstract: John F. Hindelong, formerly managing director and director of research at Becker Paribas, has accepted the new post of director of research at Dillon, Read & Company. The appointment is effective today.    Mr. Hindelong, who spent five years at Lehman Brothers as a health care analyst before he went to Becker two years ago, will be building the in- house research department at Dillon, Read essentially from scratch.

headline: People
abstract: *  Lynda Bardfield has rejoined Foote, Cone & Belding Communications as senior vice president, regional creative director, in the Multinational Business Group.     *  Cody Dalton promoted to senior vice president, management supervisor at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample.

headline: Pillsbury Proposal
abstract: The Pillsbury Company said in a proxy for its annual meeting that it would ask shareholders to approve a proposal guaranteeing fair pricing for stockholders in the event of an unsolicited two-tier tender offer.

headline: CARE INCREASING EFFORTS TO EXPAND ITS INTERNATIONAL BASE
abstract: In recent months, CARE, the private relief organization that was established to help postwar Europe and evolved into a development agency active around the world, has been increasing its efforts to expand its international base, according to the organization's executive director.   By ''internationalizing our outlook,'' Dr. Philip Johnston, the executive director, said in a recent interview, CARE hopes to overcome some of the limitations that a United States development group faces,   In addition, he said, it hopes to develop ''an international organization that is seen as not being politically tied to one country but sharing the views of several.''   The vehicle for broadening the base of support is CARE International, an outgrowth of the original postwar relief agency. CARE International was incorporated in 1982, bringing together CARE organizations in several nations, each with a full say in forming policy and setting goals, according to Patrick Carey, director of the organization's international services unit.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Soviet Bloc Maneuvers On
abstract: Troops from six Warsaw Pact countries began military exercises in Czechoslovakia today, the Tass press agency reported from Prague.

headline: DOUBT NOW CAST ON REPORT ABOUT SAKHAROV
abstract: Friends of Andrei D. Sakharov said today that two letters received from his wife had cast doubt on their report Monday that he had ended his hunger strike, was ''well'' and was being held against his will at a Gorky hospital.    The earlier information was attributed to Dr. Sakharov's wife, Yelena G. Bonner. But today the friends said the information had not originated directly from her and that they doubted its veracity.   They said separate reliable sources had now told of two letters just received from Miss Bonner, who is also in Gorky. In the letters, she is quoted as having said that she has not seen Dr. Sakharov since May 7. This made the friends doubt the earlier report about his condition, which was said to have come indirectly from Miss Bonner.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ; Interest Rates Rise Modestly
abstract: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday in quiet trading, as major investors remained on the sidelines and traders were cautious in the face of rising short-term rates.     ''A lot of people spent the day in meetings,'' said one government securities dealer, ''but the real cause of the inactivity is the lack of conviction about future rate changes.''    The lack of conviction stems from the ambiguous nature of recent economic data, which show that economic growth is slowing, but not necessarily enough to bring about lower interest rates.    ''It would be a mistake to assume that overall business credit demands are on the wane'' just because the economy is less robust than earlier in the year, said Abraham Gulkowitz, vice president at the Bankers Trust Company. In the latest issue of Prospects for the Credit Markets, Mr. Gulkowitz said business credit demands should continue to expand, particularly in the commercial paper market, while consumers are still in good financial condition. ''All in all,'' he said, ''business, consumers and government should continue to keep upward pressure on interest rates through the remainder of the year.''

headline: Shultz Mourns Bunker
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today mourned the death of Ellsworth Bunker, saying he was responsible for ''remarkable achievements that have few parallels in American history.'' Mr. Bunker, who served as a diplomat under seven Presidents and was Ambassador to South Vietnam at the height of United States involvement there, died Thursday night.     Please use only with BUNKER OBIT. It can be used all editions. Thanks.

headline: Jailed Basques Fasting In France Said to Fail
abstract: Eight Spanish Basque exiles on hunger strike for a month at a prison near Paris are no longer able to speak or hear, according to their support committee.

headline: Prices in Denmark Up
abstract: Danish consumer prices climbed four-tenths of 1 percent last month from July and 6.6 percent from 12 months before, the Government said today. In another report, it said that Denmark's trade deficit in August narrowed to 400 million kroner, or about $36.8 million, from 703 million kroner in July.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN RITE: OLD LEADER, NEW POWERS
abstract: P. W. Botha was sworn into office today as South Africa's first President under a new Constitution that gives him potentially authoritarian powers.     As he was inaugurated at a ceremony in Cape Town, the police fired tear gas and rubber bullets at protesters outside the city and in Soweto, the black township outside Johannesburg. In Durban, six prominent political fugitives remained in the British Consulate to press demands for the annulment of Government orders for their detention without trial.   There was a perception here that the violence and the Government's continuing confrontation with opponents of the Constitution were undermining Mr. Botha's new authority as well as the visions of the Afrikaner role in Africa that were evoked at the inauguration.

headline: Northwest Halts Sale of Universal
abstract: Northwest Industries said it had terminated the previously announced sale of the Universal Manufacturing Corporation, a wholly owned operating company.

headline: Braniff Plan Draws Mixed Reviews
abstract: Braniff Inc. officials said yesterday that the company has had a ''phenomenal response'' to its plan to transform itself into a discount carrier, offering low-cost, unrestricted fares on all flights.    However, travel agents in the Dallas-Fort Worth area and airline analysts questioned the move's impact, and some expressed concern about the company's ability to survive.    The discount plan, announced last week, is the airline's second marketing strategy since it resumed service on March 1 after nearly two years in bankruptcy proceedings. Braniff filed for protection from its creditors in May 1982, and was bought last year by an investor group headed by Jay Pritzker, chairman of the Hyatt Corporation. Under the original revival plan, the carrier's service was aimed at business travelers.

headline: SOVIET DISMISSAL NOW BEING LAID TO A POLICY SPLIT
abstract: A senior Soviet diplomat has told United States officials that Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov was dismissed as chief of the General Staff because he was showing ''unpartylike tendencies,'' Administration officials said today.   They said the comment was made Friday, when the Soviet press agency Tass said that Marshal Ogarkov had been replaced by his deputy, Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev.   The officials said similar remarks had been heard earlier from other Soviet diplomats about Marshal Ogarkov. The officials said they did not know whether the comment on Friday was made on instructions from Moscow or on the diplomat's own speculation.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: Alberta Municipal Financing Corp. , a Crown corporation that provides financing to municipalities in Alberta and British Columbia, has begun a $150 million (Canadian) five-year debenture offering through Merrill Lynch Canada Inc. The 13.5 percent debentures due 1989 were priced at 99 1/4 to yield 13.71 percent.     * Preway Inc., a gas and oil heaters company in Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., filed for an offering of 40,000 units through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Each unit consists of $1,000 principal amount of debentures, 20 shares of common stock and 40 common stock purchase warrants.      Debt Ratings    *  Bank of New England Corp.'s $75 million issue of floating-rate subordinated notes, due 1996, were assigned an A- rating by S.&.P.     * Castle & Cooke Inc. , a diversified sugar and pineapple company in Honolulu, had its senior debt downgraded to BB from BBx, its subordinated debt downgraded to Bx from BB- and its preferred stock ratings downgraded to B from BB- by S.&.P., which said the actions affected about $75 million of debt and $55 million of preferred stock.

headline: ACCORD SEEMS NEARON TERMS FOR NORTH KOREA TO AID SOUTH
abstract: After several turnabouts and unexpected moves, North and South Korea appeared today to have settled their differences on how the North could send relief supplies to flood victims in the South.     If the material is brought across the border between the two implacable enemies, it would be the first such exchange since before the Korean War.   But whether a delivery of goods would actually be made remained a question. The history of relations between the countries suggests a good possibility that fresh impediments will arise or that new details will emerge, requiring resolution and delaying final agreement.

headline: ITT Unit Is Sold
abstract: The ITT Corporation said it had sold its German household products company, Leifheit A.G., to the Deutsche Bank for about $40 million.

headline: Japan's Steel Output
abstract: Japan's production of steel in the fourth quarter will rise six-tenths of 1 percent, to 26.7 million tons, from the current quarter, and 3.7 percent from the period a year earlier, the Government predicted today.

headline: INTERNORTH'S GAS FOR TEXAS EASTERN
abstract: Internorth Inc.'s Northern Natural Gas Company said it had signed a 15-year contract to sell natural gas to the Texas Eastern Corporation's Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation.

headline: JERSEY PROJECT SELLS OUT IN A WEEKEND
abstract: Selling homes from a trailer, with no models to show would-be buyers and only empty ground for a view, is not the easiest of propositions. But in this area of central New Jersey, which has experienced a rapid influx of companies, the demand for new housing is strong enough to make such weak selling tools all that are needed.     Of course, requiring only a $250 refundable deposit and a minimum down payment of only 5 percent can be a big help.   For the K. Hovnanian Companies, a large residential builder based in Red Bank, N.J., the combination has worked before. A few weeks ago, the company began its seventh Society Hill development in New Jersey in this Somerset County community southeast of New Brunswick. The 264 units of the condominium project were sold in just one weekend.

headline: SHORT-TERM RATES DROP SHARPLY
abstract: Short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday amid signs that the Federal Reserve could be encouraging lower interest rates, or at least discouraging further increases in rates.     Although many economists who scrutinize Federal Reserve actions said it was too soon to declare that that the central bank was easing monetary policy, traders were more optimistic and were aggressive buyers of short- and long-term securities. By late in the day, rates on Treasury bills were lower by nearly a fifth of a percentage point in cases, with the six-month issue bid at 10.50 percent, down from 10.68 percent.   The drop in short-term rates spilled over into the long-term bond market, where the bellwether 12 1/2 percent Treasury issue due in 2014 rose 3/4 point, to an offered price of 101 10/32, to yield 12.33 percent, down from 12.42 percent Friday.

headline: West Bank Settlement Is Released to Civilians
abstract: The Israeli Army today turned over a paramilitary settlement in the occupied West Bank to civilians.   The Labor opposition charged that the action was an election ploy by the Government parties and asked Justice Gabriel Bach, chairman of the Elections Committee, to ban it.

headline: APOLLO IS FULL OF HOPE AFTER A DREAMLIKE START
abstract: When John W. Poduska was unable to get the research funding he wanted at the company he co-founded, Prime Computer, he stormed out in 1979 and headed for a skiing vacation. But, as computer-industry aficionados tell the story, on the way to ski he took a detour to San Francisco.     Flying there, he wrote a business plan for making a microcomputer that engineers and other scientists could use at their desk to do graphics- oriented design work. Within a week of landing, he raised $1.7 million in venture money - the seed capital for what came to be called Apollo Computer Inc.

headline: Exxon U.S.A.
abstract: The Exxon Company U.S.A. said it had raised its wholesale distillate prices, covering such products as heating oil, diesel fuel and kerosene, in the Northeast, a spokesman said. The company, a unit of the Exxon Corporation, said it had raised the price of truckload quantities of distillate 1.25 cents a gallon at many terminals and the price of bargeloads 0.75 cent a gallon.

headline: FINANCIAL CORP.'S BIG GAMBLE
abstract: Rising interest rates have caused most thrift institutions to turn cautious, but the high-flying Financial Corporation of America is continuing to chase rapid growth.   Some financial advisers and investment analysts have expressed concern about this growth, saying Financial is likely to face an increasing burden of costly short-term borrowings and rising loan delinquencies unless interest rates retreat in coming months.   But for Charles W. Knapp, a charismatic alumnus of the worlds of investment banking and real estate development who is Financial's chairman and chief executive, these doubts are not a surprise.    'Everyone Is Taking Their Shots'    ''It's that time in the rate cycle and everybody is taking their shots at us,'' he said.    Mr. Knapp is counting on rates to ''stabilize'' shortly and then decline gradually. That was the same prediction he offered six months ago, but rates since then have risen.

headline: IRAQ CLAIMS IT HIT BIG 'NAVAL TARGET'
abstract: Iraq said its warplanes hit a ''large naval target'' - the usual term for an oil tanker - south of Iran's Kharg Island today. There was no independent confirmation of the attack, the first reported in two weeks.    A military spokesman said on the Baghdad radio that the Iraqi planes returned safely to base. He gave no further details.

headline: Vernitron Promotes Officer to President
abstract: Albert Diamond has been named president of Vernitron Inc.   Based in Lake Success, L.I., Vernitron makes electro-mechanical and electronic parts used in automatic controls, the aerospace and military industries and the medical electronics industry.

headline: Turkish Cypriot Accuses Greeks of Arms Buildup
abstract: Rauf Denktash, the Turkish-Cypriot leader, said today that Greece was engaged in a secret military buildup on Cyprus and that he had asked the United Nations to stop such ''craziness.''   Mr. Denktash said he could confirm Turkish press reports that Greece was sending military personnel, arms and ammunition to the Greek-Cypriot southern part of the divided island.

headline: Yugoslav Tells of Plot To Topple Communism
abstract: A senior Yugoslav leader said today that opponents of the Government were trying to overthrow the country's Communist system and create a Western-style democracy.

headline: AFRIKANER'S CREDO: DON'T JUDGE US ALL TOGETHER
abstract: Once, says Ora Terblanche, a couple from Britain who boasted some small nobility came to stay at her place, the Highlands Guest Farm, in South Africa's Orange Free State.    The woman, she remembers, took her to task, asking whether she ever invited her black servants to dine at her table.   Certainly not, came the reply, with the rejoinder: and would Her Ladyship entreat her domestic help to share high tea. The answer, Mrs. Terblanche recalls, was equally emphatic, and equally negative.   The anecdote, the visitor to the Highlands Guest Farm suspects, is one from a catalogue of memories that help define a white South African's attitudes not only to race but also to those who deride her country's relationship with its black majority. The contradictions, Mrs. Terblanche seems to be saying, are only in the eyes of an outsider.

headline: Salomon Assisted With CATS Issue
abstract: To meet growing investor demand, Salomon Brothers announced yesterday that it would be joined by three other major financial institutions in originating Certificates of Accrual on Treasury Securities, known as CATS. The others are Shearson Lehman/ American Express, Paine Webber Inc. and Citibank.

headline: Basque Separatist Is Force-Fed by French
abstract: A Spanish Basque separatist who has been on a hunger strike with seven compatriots for more than four weeks is being force-fed by doctors, a senior official of the French Justice Ministry said today.   The official, Jean Favart, said staff members at the Fresnes Prison hospital near Paris decided to start feeding the 29-year-old separatist, Francois- Javier Lujambio Aldeano, Friday night because his condition was worsening.

headline: FROM TOBACCO TO INSURANCE
abstract: LONDON     Under Patrick Sheehy, B.A.T Industries, the world's largest tobacco company, has set out to build a financial services operation. Mr. Sheehy, who is 53 years old, became chairman of the company in 1982. At the time, B.A.T (formerly British Tobacco) had already diversified into retailing and paper.   The move into financial services started with last December's $1.27 billion takeover of Eagle Star Holdings, Britain's sixth-largest life insurance company. It was the largest bid in British history.

headline: Texaco Sells Unit
abstract: Texaco Inc. said it had completed the sale, for $1.075 billion in cash, of the Getty Oil Company's Employers Reinsurance Corporation to the General Electric Company. Texaco acquired Employers Reinsurance in its Feb. 17 purchase of Getty Oil for $10.1 billion. General Electric said separately that it had formed a new subsidiary, General Electric Financial Services Inc., as a holding company to facilitate G. E.'s expansion into financial services businesses.

headline: SPAUDING, 2 OTHER UNITS ARE SOLD BY Q HOLDINGS
abstract: The A. G. Spalding Company, the 108-year-old producer of sporting goods, has been sold to a group of investors that includes two top officers of its parent company.     The parent, the Q Holdings Corporation of Tampa, Fla., said yesterday that it had sold Spalding and two other units, Evenflo Infants Products and Questor Juvenile Furniture, to the investor group. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: SHAMIR PARTY, LAGGING, IS URGING CABINET UNITY
abstract: The governing Likud bloc, trailing badly in the polls with three days to go before the elections, has begun an all-out effort to woo Israeli voters by emphasizing that it will try to form a national unity government if re-elected.   Likud political strategists are understood to have decided that the best way to prevent a large number of their supporters from defecting to Labor at this late stage in the campaign is to appeal to the idea of a national unity government that would bring both major parties together to solve Israel's pressing economic problems. While Likud leaders have mentioned the idea several times in the last month, it has now become in effect the central theme of their campaign.   ''The national unity government idea has always been very popular with voters,'' said Zeev Chafets, an Israeli political analyst with close ties to Likud, ''and since Likud is so far behind in the polls they have to try it. But I think what the Likud may really be trying to do is to put themselves in a position to be invited by Labor to join a national unity government. They probably realize at this point that they are not going to win and they want to create some pressure and momentum on Labor to invite them to rule together.''

headline: DOWNING OF JET A YEAR AGO SAID TO LEAD TO U.S. GAINS
abstract: In reviewing the year since a Soviet fighter shot down a South Korean jetliner, Reagan Administration officials assert that worldwide criticism of the Soviet handling of the crisis has strengthened the United States in its relations with Moscow.    In interviews in recent days, general agreement was expressed that the lasting impact of the airliner disaster, in which 269 people died, had been to tarnish the Soviet image and to make it easier for President Reagan in dealings with Western allies and at home.    In particular, the officials said, the incident has helped Washington rally the alliance at a time of considerable pressure from the Russians not to go ahead with the deployment of new American missiles.    The outrage expressed at the time over the downing of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 over Soviet territory, however, provoked a furious reaction in Moscow that made it virtually impossible for any progress to be made toward a summit meeting that had been expected at this time last year. Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader who died last February, issued a statement less than a month after the plane's downing, saying it was impossible to do business with the Reagan Administration.

headline: TRYING TO FIGURE OUT THE FED
abstract: Investors and traders alike are having a difficult time these days figuring out the exact state of Federal Reserve monetary policy. Many say they are especially baffled by fluctuations in overnight interest rates, which normally provide a good sign of the central bank's intentions.     For example, the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market, which has been gradually rising over the past year, moved sharply higher in June. From a low of about 8 5/8 percent in May 1983, the rate rose over the next 12 months to 10.3 percent. Then, last month, the rate jumped to 11.49 percent in the bank week ended June 20, and stood at 11.27 percent in the week ended June 27.

headline: Buyout Offer Cited By SFN Companies
abstract: SFN Companies, a Glenview, Ill., publishing and broadcasting concern, said yesterday that an investor group led by E.M. Warburg Pincus & Company and Drexel Burnham Lambert had offered to acquire the company, in a leveraged buyout valued at about $425 million.    The group proposed to offer $35 a share in cash and $5 a share in principal amount of 15 3/8 percent subordinated notes due in 1994.    SFN is the holding company for Scott, Foresman, believed to be the nation's largest elementary school and high school textbook publisher. It also publishes the New York Law Journal. It owns four television and three radio stations, as well as a program production company.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ; Yugoslavia Accuses 6 Of Antistate Activities
abstract: A Belgrade court indicted six people today on charges of antistate activities aimed at undermining and overthrowing the Government, Tanyug, the official press agency, reported.   The charges carry a minimum sentence of five years' imprisonment and a maximum of 15 years, the agency said.

headline: Canadian Prices Rise
abstract: Canadian consumer prices climbed six- tenths of 1 percent in July from June and 4.2 percent from 12 months before, the Government said today. The Government agency Statistics Canada said the latest increase was largely a result of higher transportation and food costs.

headline: Wells Fargo Promotes Officer to No. 2 Spot
abstract: A year and a half after Carl E. Reichardt moved up a step and became chairman and chief executive of Wells Fargo & Company and its major subsidiary, the Wells Fargo Bank, the company once again has a No. 2 man. Paul Hazen, a 42-year-old vice chairman, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of the San Francisco company and its bank.    J. Richard Fredericks, an analyst at Montgomery Securities, said the appointment was not a surprise, particularly because the company's other vice chairman, Richard M. Rosenberg, resigned last month to become vice chairman of the competing Crocker National Corporation.

headline: State Dept. Contends Soviet Harasses American Tourists
abstract: The State Department said today that American tourists in Leningrad had been subjected to harassment and unlawful detention by Soviet authorities.   Alan D.  Romberg, a State Department spokesman, said there had been cases involving not only United States official personnel, but also tourists.   He said that on July 28 an unidentified American professor ''was picked up by a plainclothesman as he was going to a meeting with a Soviet scholar who specializes in 18th century literature.'' Mr. Romberg said the American had been detained for two hours.

headline: Estonian Ex-Official and Wife Are Said to Defect to Sweden
abstract: A former Deputy Justice Minister of the Soviet republic of Estonia and his wife, a pop singer, have defected to Sweden, the police said today.

headline: ; MCI Long-Distance Fee Rise
abstract: The MCI Communications Corporation announced today that it would raise its long-distance calling rates by up to 5 percent next month.   Washington-based MCI, the second- largest long-distance phone company in the nation, behind the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said it was increasing its daytime calling rates by an average 1.75 percent and its evening, night and weekend rates by an average 5 percent.

headline: Accounts
abstract: BASF Wyandotte Corp., Parsippany, N.J., to Geer, DuBois for agricultural chemicals.     * Mondale-Ferraro campaign to McCaffrey & McCall for an undisclosed project.

headline: Gas Supplier Loses Case
abstract: The United Gas Pipeline Company was found guilty today of breach of contract and was ordered by a state judge to repay to utilities $84.7 million in fuel-adjustment costs that were passed on to consumers.   The parent company of United Gas, United Energy Resources Inc. of Houston, said it would appeal.

headline: CHIEF TAKING LEAVE AT MICHIGAN BANK
abstract: Stanford C. Stoddard, the 53-year- old chairman and chief executive of the Michigan National Corporation, will take an indefinite leave of absence, the bank holding company announced yesterday. In a statement, Michigan National said: ''As previously disclosed, regulatory authorities are conducting various inquiries concerning the corporation.''

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: CP National Corp. , a San Francisco telecommunications and energy service company, completed a $20 million private placement of 11 7/8 percent convertible subordinated notes due June 30, 1999, with a group led by Prudential Insurance.     *   Provincetown-Boston Airline has established a $4 million unsecured working capital line and an $11 million revolving credit with Southeast Banks and First National Bank of Boston; the company said the revolving credit, which converts to a six- year loan, will finance the recent acquisition of four Nihon Y5-11 aircraft and other items.

headline: U.S. AND EUROPE IN STEEL CURB TALKS
abstract: The United States and the European Economic Community are discussing limits on shipments of steel pipe and tube to the United States as part of a protection plan that President Reagan may announce next week.    Etienne Davignon, the Common Market's Commissioner for Industry, made a secret trip to Washington Monday and Tuesday to discuss the surging pipe and tube exports from Europe with key members of the Reagan Administration.    The Administration regards protection for makers of steel pipe and tube as important to winning a favorable, or at least less disapproving, response from the domestic steel industry when the package is announced.

headline: THE POPE CONDEMNS 'IMPERIALISTIC MONOPOLY'
abstract: Pope John Paul II condemned inequalities between rich and poor countries today, criticizing ''imperialistic monopoly'' and declaring that the nations of ''this poor south will judge the rich north.''     Echoing an important theme of the ''theology of liberation,'' which the Vatican criticized in a detailed statement two weeks ago, the Pope called on Christians ''not to stop at an 'individualistic' interpretation of Christian ethics, since Christian ethics also has its social dimension.''    The Christian, he said in an unusually strongly worded address, has an obligation to help change ''the rigid structures'' in societies that impede peace, development and human rights.   The Pope, speaking on the ninth day of his 12-day tour of Canada, made his comments at an outdoor mass attended by up to 150,000 people on the outskirts of this city, in one of the wealthiest areas of the country.

headline: Washington Watch; A Tug-of-War Over Exports
abstract: WASHINGTON COMMERCE and Defense are still fighting a hot turf war over export licensing even though President Reagan appeared to have resolved the dispute in favor of the Pentagon nearly six months ago.     Over strenuous objections from Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, the President decided last March to give the Defense Department shared jurisdiction with the Commerce Department over licenses for export of sensitive high technology to non-Communist countries.    Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger sought the authority to prevent illegal diversion of powerful computers, digitally controlled microcircuit testing equipment, oscilloscopes and other ''leading edge'' products to the Soviet Union.    The Commerce Department had held jurisdiction exclusively and wanted to preserve it. The business community, seeing the Defense Department as the source of new licensing delays and other export obstacles, strongly backed the Commerce Department.

headline: IN ECUADOR'S NO. 2 CITY, NO DOFFING HATS TO QUITO
abstract: Larger, wealthier and more dynamic than the country's mountain capital, the port of Guayaquil has long resented being ruled from Quito. It has occasionally rebelled, it has frequently grumbled and it has always tried to use its economic power to political advantage.  But it has never shaken off its complex about being No. 2.    Today, the mood here is more upbeat. Leon Febres Cordero, a native son who personifies Guayaquil's dedication to hard work and profit, was elected President in May thanks to a huge majority in this region. And now he is in office in Quito, surrounded by secretaries, aides and not a few Cabinet ministers from the coast. ''Perhaps the central Government will change its ways,'' a local businessman said hopefully.

headline: Advertising; Changes Coming At BBDO
abstract: BRUCE CRAWFORD, president of BBDO International, the world's seventh-largest ad agency, and its chief executive since 1977, will be turning both titles over to Allen G. Rosenshine next April 1. The change-over comes in what is expected to be the company's first year in the $2 billion-in-billings class.    Mr. Crawford, 55 years old, was named president of the Metropolitan Opera Association last May. He will become chairman of BBDO after the changes next April.

headline: ATARI HEAD SUES ALLY THAT DEFECTED TO RIVAL
abstract: Jack Tramiel, the new chief of the Atari Corporation, has filed a suit for fraud against a small Silicon Valley computer company that once appeared a likely Atari ally and then said last week that it would be acquired by Commodore International Ltd., Atari's chief competitor.    The suit was filed against the Amiga Corporation on Aug. 13 in Santa Clara, Calif., Superior Court, just as news of the planned Commodore acquisition became known throughout the industry. But Atari, Amiga and Commodore said nothing about the suit until reports of its existence began circulating yesterday.   In the suit, Mr. Tramiel charges that Amiga, which is developing a personal computer similar to Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh, had been paid $500,000 by Atari to develop three microchips for Atari. But just days before Mr. Tramiel and fellow investors bought the beleaguered Atari unit from Warner Communications, the suit contends, Amiga canceled the deal, returned the money and told Atari that the chips did not work.

headline: Swiss Price Increases
abstract: Swiss wholesale prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in July and were up 3.4 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today.

headline: NEW EFFORT TO AID NICARAGUA REBELS
abstract: President Reagan called Nicaragua a ''totalitarian dungeon'' today as the Administration opened a new public offensive against the Sandinistas in hopes of gaining Congressional approval for more aid to Nicaraguan rebels.    In addition to a speech by Mr. Reagan, the Government took several coordinated steps. The United States representative to the Organization of American States accused Nicaragua of failing to honor commitments made in 1979 to respect human rights and hold free elections. And the White House made public a report describing Nicaragua as a center of Soviet-Cuban subversion.

headline: AUTO TALKS' EFFECT ON RATES
abstract: Investors and economists are closely watching the negotiations between the General Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers for clues to the direction of interest rates.     Because a strike could noticeably slow the nation's economic activity, some analysts hope that as a result upward pressure on interest rates might be reduced, if not eliminated. Others, however, caution that production lost during an auto strike could be made up after a settlement is reached, when economic activity would rebound strongly.    W. Lee Hoskins, chief economist at the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh, estimated that each week of a strike at G.M. would reduce economic growth by about one-half percentage point. ''A strike that lasts well into the fourth quarter could easily halt economic growth or even cause a temporary decline,'' he said.

headline: Woodward Backs Higher Bid
abstract: Woodward & Lothrop Inc.'s directors agreed yesterday to accept a new, higher bid of $60.50 a share for the Washington-based retail department store chain from Taubman Holdings Inc., a major shopping mall developer. The new bid, which topped a previous offer of $59 a share, was also accepted by a dissident shareholder group.

headline: SOVIET WARNS ON LONG-RANGE CRUISE MISSILES
abstract: Pravda today assailed the American development of long-range cruise missiles and said the Soviet Union was proceeding with its own tests of similar weapons.   The Soviet testing program was first disclosed in December 1982 by Yuri V. Andropov, then the Soviet leader.   The Pravda article did not indicate why it was raising the cruise missile issue at this time. However, it follows an announcement in Washington in late June that the first long-range nuclear- armed cruise missiles were being deployed on United States Navy ships.

headline: Secret Executions In Cameroon Reported
abstract: Amnesty International said today that more than 120 people may have been secretly executed this year in Cameroon because of suspected involvement in an attempted coup.

headline: LEBANESE IN AFRICE: TALE OF SUCCESS (AND ANXIETY)
abstract: Some 30,000 Lebanese have found a haven in this tiny West African nation, where, unlike the people in Beirut, they live peacefully, prosperously and as quietly as they can.    Lebanese immigrants first began arriving in Sierra Leone and other parts of West Africa just before the turn of the century, fleeing the oppression of the Ottoman Empire. The majority became traders and merchants, assuming an important role in the economic life of this region, a role they continue to play.   Yet they have remained as inconspicuous as possible.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ; Money Supply Up $1.7 Billion
abstract: The nation's basic money supply rose by $1.7 billion in the week ending July 9, the Federal Reserve Board said yesterday. The increase was slightly less than the credit markets expected, but bond prices did not move much in reaction to the report. Trading was very light all day.    ''This number is slightly under the $2 billion to $2.5 billion increase the market had been anticipating,'' said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a government securities trading house. ''But the number did not give us much excitement.''

headline: Pacific Bell to File For Rate Increase
abstract: Pacific Telesis Group's Pacific Bell operating unit said it was preparing to seek a rate increase of as much as $1.5 billion.

headline: I.B.M. Said to Be Ready To Make PCjr Changes
abstract: In an attempt to overcome flagging sales of its PCjr home computer, the International Business Machines Corporation is set to announce a new keyboard, extra memory and perhaps other changes in the machine, industry analysts said yesterday.    The giant computer and electronics concern also plans to introduce a new personal computer system that can accommodate several terminals tied to a central memory, printer and communications network, the analysts added. The system may handle up to eight terminals and could cost as little as $3,000 a user, computer experts said. The advanced system has been nicknamed Popcorn.

headline: Afghanistan Rebels Release A Captured Japanese Envoy
abstract: An official at the Japanese Embassy in Afghanistan, held captive for six weeks by guerrillas, returned here today.

headline: 3 FRENCH TOWNS GO TO EXTREMES TO BE THE CENTER
abstract: -ALLICHAMPS, France, Sept. 3 - Three hamlets in this rolling rural district just south of Bourges have become embroiled in an argument over which of them is the geographical center of France.   ''For many years, being the center of France was our trademark,'' Rene Larguinat, the Mayor of Bru eres-Allichamps, population 638, said in an interview here. ''Now, our neighboring villages are trying to take it away from us.''   The neighboring villages vying for the geographic title are Vesdun and Saulzais-le-Potier, both, like Bru eres- Allichamps, ancient towns of Berry, a historic region of wheat fields, sunflowers and stone chateaus that is reachable from Paris by car in about three hours. The argument is an old one, going back centuries; it rears its head every few years, with Bru eres holding perhaps the most persistent claim of the three.

headline: Air Florida Sued on Pay
abstract: Sixty laid- off Air Florida pilots have agreed to pay cuts while some former employees filed suit seeking back pay and benefits they assert were withheld when the troubled carrier halted operations.   Robin Cohn, a spokesman for the airline, said 61 pilots - fewer than a third of the airline's pilot crew - had voted on the pay-cut proposal Friday.

headline: 20 ACCUSED IN DEATH OF GRENADA PREMIER SEEK A COURT RULING
abstract: Attorneys for 20 people accused in the death of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop, which was followed by the United States invasion of Grenada last October, have asked for a ruling on the validity of the court system.   Most of the defendants, who were charged in February, have been in custody since their capture after the invasion on Oct. 25.   Among the defendants in the case are Mr. Bishop's deputy, Bernard Coard, a Marxist who is accused of engineering the coup in which the pro-Cuban Prime Minister died; his wife, Phyllis, and Gen. Hudson Austin, who headed the military junta that seized power Oct. 19 and was ousted in the invasion.

headline: SINGER'S SHIFT INTO HIGH TECH
abstract: After nearly a decade of selling off unprofitable business lines, closing plants and investing heavily in new lines of aerospace and military products, the Singer Company appears to have completed what some analysts call one of the most thorough corporate restructurings in recent memory.    The changes have been slow and agonizing. What started in the mid- 1970's as a gradual retreat from its old-line sewing machine business has become, during the last five years, a huge overhaul of Singer's corporate identity.   ''This is a company whose whole culture was built around the sewing machine,'' Joseph B. Flavin, the company's chairman and chief executive, said in a recent interview at Singer's headquarters here. ''As hard as we tried, that couldn't be changed overnight.''

headline: Advertising; A Charity's Unusual Promotion
abstract: T HE Cabbage Patch Kids meet    Julius Erving, the basketball   great, today for a promotion for the March of Dimes.   Coleco Industries, which sells the Cabbage Patch dolls, and Coca-Cola USA and its bottlers are using the occasion to announce a campaign to raise money for the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation, as the charity is formally named. The basketball star, known as Dr. J., owns part of the Philadelphia Coca-Cola Bottling Company.

headline: LTV Reports Smaller Loss
abstract: The LTV Corporation said today that it narrowed its second-quarter loss to $22.7 million from a $61.3 million loss a year earlier. Sales rose 59 percent, to $1.58 billion, from $993 million.

headline: Fortune Systems
abstract: The Fortune Systems Corporation said it and North Star Computers Inc. had ended merger talks. It said the decision to end the talks had been an amicable one and does not affect the terms of Fortune's loan of $3.8 million in debt financing to North Star. The debt financing is convertible into about 19 percent of North Star's common stock.

headline: CUP OF COCA: NOT SO NICE
abstract: American visitors arriving at the airport here barely set foot in the terminal before they are greeted by salesmen exhorting them to buy ''mate de coca.''    Coca tea: It is Bolivia's national drink, and the salesmen frequently offer it to foreigners first because some of them believe they are buying an exotic narcotic elixir.    Most of those people are disappointed. Coca tea, similar in taste to several other traditional teas, is a mild stimulant, not as strong as coffee. At the same time, it does produce a slight narcotic effect, a barely perceptible feeling of euphoria. But that may be as much the result of suggestion as chemical content.

headline: LEUCADIA MAKES A BID FOR AVCO
abstract: The Leucadia National Corporation, an insurance and consumer lending company, offered yesterday to pay $930 million in cash for the 88 percent of the Avco Corporation that it does not yet own.     Robert P. Bauman, 52-year-old chairman and chief executive of Avco, a big military supplier with major interests in insurance and consumer lending, immediately assailed the offer as ''entirely unacceptable.'' He said he felt shareholders would best be served if the company remained independent. Directors are expected to reject the offer at a regular board meeting today.

headline: People
abstract: Robert P. Huddilston appointed senior vice president/secretary- treasurer at Meldrum & Fewsmith, Cleveland.

headline: CAN TROUBLED TRILOGY FULFILL ITS DREAM?
abstract: CUPERTINO, Calif.    EVEN in an industry populated by   superstars, Gene M. Amdahl has   been a standout. In the 1960's, he had a leading role in the design of the International Business Machines Corporation's System/360, still one of the most successful mainframe computers ever produced. In the 1970's, he founded the Amdahl Computer Corporation, building computers that were compatible with, but usually less expensive than, I.B.M.'s - and thus pioneering an entirely new market. Indeed, for the last 20 years, Mr. Amdahl's name has been golden in computer circles.    So the response was overwhelmingly enthusiastic when, in 1980, Mr. Amdahl announced a third pass at the brass ring. What he proposed this time was nothing short of a technological revolution: a supercomputer built around giant silicon wafers, each capable of performing the work of 100 ordinary microchips.

headline: Argentina To Repay 4 WASHINGTON, July 26 -
abstract: Argentina will repay a $300 million loan from Mexico, Brazil,   Venezuela and Colombia before the end of this month,   Mario del Carril, press attache   at the Argentine Embassy, said   today.  He said $50 million had already been repaid to Colombia,   with the rest to come out of his   country's ''meager'' reserves   before next Wednesday.

headline: COMPROMISE MOVE ON ISRAEL EMBASSY
abstract: House backers of a bill to move the United States Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem have offered to make it nonbinding and to postpone a vote until next year if President Reagan will drop his opposition to it, key sponsors said today.   But senior White House and State Department officials, concerned about the impact that any such vote would have in the Arab world, said today that they were uninterested in such a compromise and would try to persuade Congress not to vote even on a resolution that was nonbinding on the Administration.   At the moment, a confrontation over moving the embassy from Tel Aviv appears likely when Congress returns from recess after Labor Day. If it comes to a vote, the House is expected to approve it easily, but it faces a more difficult fight in the Senate.

headline: Market Place; Analysts View Boeing Profits
abstract: THE Boeing Company, the world's largest producer of commercial airliners, has seen its    stock move aloft to record prices recently on the basis of favorable recommendations by several brokerage firms    In its mid-1984 forecast issue, the Merrill Lynch Market Letter picked Boeing as one of 10 issues with favorable prospects. The publication said: ''We think the stock of Boeing is an attractive value based on our expectation that rising commercial orders and a strong defense business will more than double earnings over the next few years.''    At midyear, Boeing's shares were trading around 43 on the New York Stock Exchange. During the spirited market rally of early August, they reached a record level of 54.

headline: Rates Up as Dollar Falls
abstract: Interest rates rose yesterday by a tenth of a percentage point or more for short- and long-term securities, as traders reacted to the sharp decline in the value of the dollar in foreign exchange markets.    Although developments in the domestic economy - particularly the slowdown in economic growth and the Federal Reserve's willingness to promote lower short-term interest rates - continued to point toward lower rates in the future, analysts said the drop in the value of the dollar was the overriding concern yesterday.    By late in the day, the rate on six- month Treasury bills had increased to about 10.40 percent from 10.31 percent the day before.

headline: AFFIRMATIVE
abstract: To the Editor:     In considering the impact of the Supreme Court's Memphis decision on affirmaive action (''Memphis Did Not Kill Affirmaive Action,'' Business Forum, July 1), one must first carefully define the terms.   If one defines affirmative action in what Morris Abram, Vice Chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, calls its ''original and undefiled meaning,'' then the Memphis decision has no impact on affirmative action.  Affirmative action in its original sense means increased recruiting, training, counseling and education opportunities, targeted to minoirities and women, but open to all. This nondiscriminatory affirmative action is aimed at breaking down the ''old-boy'' network in hiring and promotions and providing for equal employment opoportunity without contracting such opportunity for anyone else.

headline: U.S. Steel Layoffs
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation laid off 700 union workers in June at the Fairless Works in Bucks County and plans to eliminate 150 management jobs by the end of July, according to David Hankins, a company spokesman.

headline: T.V.A. Halt Set On 4 Reactors KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 28
abstract: The Tennessee Valley   Authority will cancel four unfinished reactors Wednesday   and write them off as a $2.7 billion waste, officials said today. The T.V.A. staff last month   had recommended dismantling   two unfinished reactors at the   Hartsville nuclear plant near   Nashville and two more at the   Yellow Creek facility near   Iuka, Miss., because the cost to   finish construction had risen   dramatically.

headline: KARAJAN LEADS BERLIN PHILHARMONIC AFTER TALKS ON DISPUTE
abstract: Herbert von Karajan conducted the Berlin Philharmonic's first concert of the season tonight, hours after he and musicians' representatives held preliminary talks aimed at settling a long dispute.    A joint statement, issued after several hours of talks between the 76-year- old maestro and the musicians' representatives, said they had agreed ''to undertake a new beginning on the basis of partnership.'' Mr. Karajan had been boycotting the orchestra's performances since June.   'Things Can Go Forward'      Rainer Zepperitz, a member of the orchestra board, said that the talks were a good beginning but that more discussions would have to follow. ''At least it has reached a point where things can go forward,'' he added.

headline: OF ARMS AND POLITICS
abstract: Four months ago, the Administration told Congress that a ban on antisatellite weapons would make little sense. But a few days ago, the Administration said it was ready and eager for talks on this very subject with the Soviet Union, and added that such talks were likely.  Then, on Thursday, Administration officials said in private that Soviet-proposed space talks for Vienna in September were unlikely to take place, and that maybe this was all to the good.    Now the issue is not one of how to get negotiations going but rather whom to blame.

headline: Korey, Kay Gets Humana Inc. Account
abstract: Humana Inc., a large health-care corporation based in Louisville, Ky., has come to New York for an agency to help introduce a new program, Humana Care Plus, which is an employee hospitalization plan that is expected to be less expensive for companies to maintain than most programs because it will utilize the more than 90 hospitals owned by Humana.     The agency selected is Korey, Kay & Partners, which will use Corninthian Communictions for broadcast media negotiations.    The concept is to be tested in Las Vegas, Nev., and West Palm Beach and Orlando, Fla., and Lois Korey, president, said that if the tests go well the program should be in 30 markets by end of the year.

headline: LATIN NATIONS SEEK A DIALOGUE ON DEBTS
abstract: Latin America's principal debtor nations today invited leading industrialized democracies to participate in a government-to-government dialogue to find ways of easing the region's debt burden.    The initiative, which came at the end of a two-day ministerial meeting of debtor nations, seemed aimed at giving a political dimension to the debt debate and at establishing the co-responsibility of Western governments in resolving the crisis.   In a statement signed by 11 Latin American governments, the industrialized nations were invited to join ''a direct political dialogue'' to be held during the first six months of 1985. The timing reflected a decision to await the outcome of the United States Presidential election.

headline: GERMANYS TRAFFICKING IN PEOPLE
abstract: Two decades ago Erich Mende started buying political prisoners from East Germany. He wanted it kept secret.   At the time, he went around to the offices of West Germany's main magazines, newspapers and television stations to explain the delicate nature of the transactions and to ask them to maintain silence.   ''We had the hope then to get a few thousand'' prisoners, said the silver- haired Mr. Mende, who was then Deputy Chancellor and Minister for German Relations. ''But only if it remained secret. A clause in our agreement with East Berlin said that any publicity would mean the end of it.''

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: Allied Stores Corp.  said it had filed a registration statement covering a proposed offering of $125 million of 25- year convertible subordinated debentures through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Co.     *  Corestates Financial Corp. , the holding company for Philadelphia National Bank, is arranging a $75 million note issuance facility through its Corestates Capital Corp. subsidiary.

headline: Bidders for Conrail Are Reduced to 3
abstract: The list of potential buyers for Conrail, the Government-owned freight railroad system, has been narrowed to three, Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole said today.   She said she has asked the Treasury and Justice Departments to review details of their offers.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; President of Gould Moves From I.B.M.
abstract: Gould Inc., which has been transformed from a diversified industrial products concern into a company specializing in electronics, yesterday tapped James F. McDonald, a key executive at the International Business Machines Corporation, to become president and chief operating officer.    Mr. McDonald, who is 44 years old, was most recently general manager of I.B.M.'s manufacturing systems products business unit in Boca Raton, Fla.

headline: F.C.C. STOPS REGULATING COMMERCIAL SATELLITES
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission deregulated the nation's commercial satellite operators today, concluding that the market was sufficiently competitive to justify an end to reviews of customer rates.   Industry observers said they were not surprised by the ruling nor did they expect to see any rate increases as a result.   The decision to ''forebear'' from regulating domestic satellite companies was unanimous. The vote means that companies such as RCA American Communications Inc., of Princeton, N.J.; the Western Union Corporation of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Satellite Business Systems of McLean, Va., are free to raise or lower their rates, offer new services or discontinue old ones without seeking F.C.C. approval.

headline: CONTINENTAL RESCUE IS ON THE HORIZON
abstract: Continental Rescue.  The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's plan to take over about 80 percent of the Continental Illinois National Bank is a dramatic and somewhat drastic step. Under the rescue plan, as outlined by those close to the situation, the F.D.I.C. would assume Continental's problem loans and would allow the rest of Continental to operate as a ''clean'' bank, with a new head to be selected by the F.D.I.C., but with little stockholder equity.     The Government's inability to find a private buyer for Continental is being taken as an indication of the poor shape of Continental - indeed, of the banking industry in general. Even a slimmer Continental was not attractive to other banks, with their own problems from excess loans to developing countries and an erosion and repositioning as other businesses offer financial services.

headline: United Is Expected To Order Jetliners
abstract: United Airlines is expected to place an order valued at more than $1.5 billion for passenger jetliners before the end of the year, industry executives and Wall Street analysts said today.   The carrier, a subsidiary of UAL Inc., is said to have narrowed its list to a choice between the Boeing Company's 130-seat 737-300 and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's 140- seat MD-80 airliner.

headline: Bobbie Brooks
abstract: The MacGregor Corporation said a letter of intent had been signed for its acquisition of Bobbie Brooks Inc. for $2 a share.

headline: CLUBMART TRIES NEW APPROACH
abstract: Last December, in a move closely watched by competitors, the founder of Korvettes joined a former vice president of the Mellon Bank and opened Clubmart of America, the first membership-only discount store in Manhattan in decades.     Seven months later, the store abandoned the attempt at exclusivity and allowed in the general public. It had run up first-half losses of $1.3 million.   What went wrong? The failure of the membership-only concept at Clubmart has generated considerable discussion among retailers about whether this ''closed'' species of discounter, successful primarily in suburban areas and smaller cities, is viable in a leading urban area.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: Connecticut yesterday made its first offering of transportation revenue bonds backed by proceeds from motor vehicle fuel taxes and various licenses and fees.

headline: New Illinois Issue All Zero Coupon
abstract: The University of Illinois has arranged an unusual tax-exempt financing consisting of $229 million face amount of zero coupon bonds to raise $55 million in current dollars. According to the underwriters, led by John Nuveen & Company, it is the first bond issue in the tax-exempt market consisting entirely of zero coupon bonds, which pay no interest.

headline: ARCO NAMES OFFICIALS IN DOMESTIC REALIGNING
abstract: Reflecting the growing importance of its holdings in Alaska, the Atlantic Richfield Company said yesterday that it was realigning its domestic oil and gas operations into two groups, and it named executives to head them.    In the move, Arco said it was removing Arco Alaska Inc. from the organization of the Arco Oil and Gas Company, a separate operating company that has been responsible for all domestic operations. Starting next January, Arco Oil and Gas will be responsible for oil and gas operations in the lower 48 states, while Arco Alaska will be independent.

headline: Soviet Assailed on Jews
abstract: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee adopted a nonbinding resolution today that directs President Reagan to urge the Soviet Union to comply with the Helsinki accords of 1975 and the United Nations Declaration Of Human Rights, ''especially as these documents relate to the emigration of Soviet Jews.'' Jewish emigration dropped from 51,000 in 1979 to 1,300 last year.

headline: INDIA POLITICS: TIME OF FURY
abstract: It appears unlikely that India will hold a general election before late September, but events of the last month suggest the campaign has already begun.    While Prime Minister Indira Gandhi appears to be trying to rebuild her former image as a strong, decisive leader, her opponents are charging her with having fashioned a high-handed coup to topple the state government in Kashmir, and of being ultimately responsible for two years of separatist violence in the neighboring northern state of Punjab.   So harsh has the verbal battle become, even before Mrs. Gandhi has named an election date, that opponents have been freely and openly accusing the Government of displaying a ''fascist mentality.''   If the pattern continues, many politicians believe, the official campaign will focus on what The Times of India, in an editorial last week, called ''Mrs. Gandhi's culpability or otherwise'' for the violent and disruptive events that have overtaken the country, particularly in the north, in recent months.

headline: AIRPORT IS NEARLY READY, BUT GRENADA IS NOT
abstract: The big airport here that the Cubans started and that the United States is finishing is supposed to go into operation in about three months, making it possible for jet airliners to fly to Grenada from anywhere in the world.   But Grenada, which has wanted a modern airport for so long, does not appear quite ready for this.   First of all, there is no place to put large numbers of visitors. Grenada is used to dealing with tourists on a small scale. When it counts all its available rooms, including 200 in guest houses and cottages, it comes up with a total of 461, which is not many more than the number of seats on one 747 jumbo jet.

headline: Quaker State Deal For First Heritage
abstract: The Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation said it would acquire the First Heritage Corporation, a California insurance concern, in an exchange of stock valued at about $38 million.

headline: LEADERS OF U.S.I.A. ASSAILED BY STAFF
abstract: Charles Z. Wick, the director of the United States Information Agency, has become embroiled in a public dispute with officers of the agency's union who contend that his leadership has led to lowered standards and sagging morale.   Mr. Wick, responding to an open letter published by the officers in the August issue of the Foreign Service Journal, said many agency professionals disputed the officers' assertions. He added that he is ''particularly proud'' of his efforts on behalf of the career staff.

headline: CHINA PURGING RADICALS AND BUNGLERS
abstract: China's Communist Party has embarked on a new phase in a drive to clean up its ranks by re-educating or expelling members who are radical, corrupt or incompetent.   The third stage of the rectification campaign, as the purge is called, was declared in a circular issued last Saturday by the Central Party Consolidation Committee.   Among other points, the directive condemns all of the contending factions in the Cultural Revolution as being wrong.   Details were published last Sunday in a long front-page editorial in People's Daily. The party newspaper said the current drive was ''aimed at enhancing the party's revolutionary vigor'' to meet China's goal of quadrupling the value of its industrial and agricultural output by the end of the century.

headline: Austria Tightens Guard At Pakistani Embassy
abstract: The Austrian authorities tightened security at the Pakistani Embassy today, two days after seizing a nine-man gang who they said they believed had planned to kidnap a diplomat.   A police spokesman said the gang, which was rounded up in raids on three hotels, had 10 guns, five hand grenades, two pounds of explosives and lengths of rope apparently meant for tying up a captive. He said the nine carried false British passports, spoke either Urdu or Pashto, and were probably Pakistanis.

headline: U.S. Limiting Libyans At U.N. to New York
abstract: The United States told Libya's United Nations diplomats today that they cannot travel outside New York City without special permission.    The note gave no reason for the stricter curbs, but a spokesman for the United States Mission cited unspecified security considerations.

headline: RATES CLIMB IN QUIET TRADING
abstract: Interest rates rose yesterday in quiet trading. Market participants were discouraged by a lack of investor demand and a Federal Reserve report published last Friday showing that the central bank is not adverse to rising interest rates so long as the economy continues to expand at a brisk rate.     Short-term interest rates rose by one-tenth of a percentage point and more, with the rate on three-month Treasury bills rising to 10.66 percent from 10.48 percent. Analysts attributed some of the upward pressure on short-term rates to the heavy supply of new Treasury bills, with $13.2 billion of bills auctioned yesterday, $8 billion of 20-day bills to be auctioned today and $8.25 billion of one-year bills on Thursday.

headline: USE OF U.S. MERCENARIES IS TERMED LIMITED
abstract: In the last few years a number of American civilians have taken part in military activities in Central America, paramilitary experts said today, but the experts said they knew of no concerted effort to recruit American mercenaries or to use them extensively in the region.    Robert K. Brown, the editor and publisher of Soldier of Fortune magazine in Boulder, Colo., said some Americans had gone to Central America as individuals while others had gone in groups.   He said in a telephone interview he had not been aware of the presence of a group of Americans with anti- Government forces in Nicaragua until two of them were reported killed in a helicopter crash over the weekend.    Mr. Brown, a former Special Forces captain in South Vietnam who, as a civilian, has operated with military forces in several countries, said he believed most of the American civilians who have served in Central America were volunteers who received little or no pay.

headline: Alcan to Close Extrusion Unit
abstract: Alcan Aluminium said it would discontinue aluminum extrusion at its Kingston plant and phase out its two obsolete presses there.

headline: Midland Seeks Rest Of Crocker
abstract: Midland Bank P.L.C. of London, which owns 57 percent of the Crocker National Corporation, offered yesterday to purchase the remaining outstanding shares of the San Francisco- based bank for $207 million in preferred stock, or $25 a share.    Analysts said Midland, which has invested $820 million in Crocker since 1981, was likely trying to take advantage of the troubled bank's low stock price to take it over just as its turnaround effort appeared to be paying off.    Crocker stock, which has traded as low as $16.25 in recent weeks, was actively traded yesterday and rose $3.375, to $21.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: SLOW REBOUND IN TROUBLED UGANDA
abstract: Just a few miles outside this capital lies a suburb known as Kababala, where there is a strip of sidewalk saloons and one- room general stores packed with canned soup and toothpaste, Scotch whisky and white bread, fresh eggs, insect spray, bathroom cleaner and cigarettes.    Kababala is a recent phenomenon. In the old days, which means less than two years ago, such goods were available only in special ''V.I.P. shops,'' or on the black market.   Now, however, trade liberalization has made it possible to import a wide variety of goods in Uganda, and Government policies favoring private initiative have encouraged local entrepreneurs to perceive demand for something and satisfy it. In this case, the demand was for a place to shop, drink and rumor-monger close to the capital's most prosperous residential neighborhoods.

headline: PATENTS;  Grounding Unit
abstract: A device for preventing static electricity buildup on humans has been invented by Harold F. Vandermark for Nu-Concept Computer Systems Inc. in Colmar, Pa. Patent 4,459,633, granted this week, describes a unit that is worn on the wrist and connected to a wire that runs to the ground. The device has a means of disconnecting the ground wire if there is danger of shock or electrocution to the wearer.

headline: ADVERTISING ; ;  Olympia's Choice
abstract: William S. Doyle, executive vice president of Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle, will head an agency team on a trip to Frankfurt to see A.E.G., a maker of office equipment. The company's American arm, Olympia, has just chosen the agency to handle its $2 million account. Olympia USA is in Somerville, N.J. The previous agency was Brouillard Communications, part of the JWT Group.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Chairman Retiring At American Hoist
abstract: The American Hoist and Derrick Company, an old-line manufacturer of large cranes and other heavy equipment, said yesterday that the retirement of Robert P. Fox, its chairman, would complete a management transition that had begun nearly two years ago.   Mr. Fox, who is 67 years old, will step down Aug. 1, and leave the St. Paul company in the hands of Robert H. Nassau, president and chief executive officer.   Mr. Nassau, 42, had become president and chief operating officer in September 1982, and took over as chief executive officer this past April. The company said the chairman's office would not be filled.

headline: BIG BOARD INDICATES G.M. PLAN IS ACCEPTABLE
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange, as part of its new effort to strengthen its competitive ability, said last night that it would like to trade a new class of shares of the General Motors Corporation. It also dismissed the possibility that it might no longer allow G.M. stock to trade on the exchange.    The exchange statement followed the announcement late yesterday that General Motors and Electronic Data Systems Inc. had reached a definitive agreement for G.M. to acquire the Dallas-based data-processing company for about $2.5 billion.

headline: Two Laotian Pilots Fly To Thailand for Asylum
