abstract: Two pilots from Laos flew a passenger plane from the Laotian capital, Vientiane, to Udorn Air Force Base in northeastern Thailand today and requested asylum in a third country, the army spokesman's office said.   A senior Thai Foreign Ministry official said the plane would be returned to Laos, but Thailand would allow the two men to seek asylum in an unspecified third country.   The men reportedly said they left Laos because of difficult living conditions there.

headline: AIRPORT TICKET MACHINES GAIN
abstract: Ten minutes before the Eastern shuttle's hourly departures at La Guardia Airport, the last-minute passengers arrive. And like many of them one recent morning, Lou Ulsch of West Milford, N.J., sprinted, billfold in mouth, over to one of the five self-service ticket machines.   He is one of an increasing number of business travelers who are buying their tickets from machines. It is a trend that disturbs travel agents who fear the devices could cost them their 10 percent commissions or even their jobs.

headline: Goulds Pumps Picks President
abstract: Goulds Pumps Inc. has elected Stephen V. Ardia president and chief operating officer. Mr. Ardia, 43 years old, was formerly vice president of sales.   R. L. Tarnow, chairman, will continue as chief executive officer, the position he assumed following Vincent A. Napolitano's death on Aug. 18. Mr. Napolitano had been president and chief executive officer.

headline: DUARTE ISSUES RULES FOR AIR ATTACKS
abstract: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that he had issued new guidelines to the Salvadoran Air Force aimed at reducing civilian casualties from aerial bombardment.    He added that he would also be issuing a general order defining the duties of government security forces and ordering them to respect both the law and human rights.   Speaking at a news conference here, Mr. Duarte said air force pilots must now be informed whether civilians are in a target area before they begin an attack. The army high command is also required to give its approval before an air strike is launched by signing an order authorizing each attack.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The U.N. Today July 3, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Commission on International Trade Law - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad Hoc Committee on the World Disarmament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: U.S. TESTS EXPLOSIVE PIPLINE TO THWART ADVANCING TANKS
abstract: The United States has been testing an antitank system in West Germany and South Korea that involves underground pipelines filled with liquid explosive, the Defense Department said today.     ''It's a concept we want to explore with our allies,'' said the Pentagon spokesman, Michael I. Burch.    Mr. Burch said that in a recent experiment by the Army at Vielseck, West Germany, a pipe 273 feet long and 6 inches in diameter, containing 3,500 pounds of explosives, dug a ditch 30 to 40 feet wide and 10 to 14 feet deep.

headline: WEAK QUARTER FOR BIG BANKS
abstract: The second quarter was a poor one for the nation's leading bank holding companies, mainly reflecting reduced earnings on their loans to Argentina and poor results from their foreign-exchange and bond-trading activities.    Indeed, the atmosphere in the banking world was particularly gloomy last week as the major banks reported their second-quarter results because of the near-collapse of one of their number - the Continental Illinois Corporation.   Continental, the nation's sixth-largest banking company two years ago and now eighth- or ninth-largest, is held together by aid from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. It has not reported its second-quarter results, expected to show a big loss.

headline: Venezuelan Repayment Pact
abstract: The Venezuelan Government announced today that it had reached an agreement in principle with foreign banks to restructure $20.75 billion of its $27.5 billion in foreign debt.    The Minister of the Interior, Octavio Lepage, said that Venezuelan debt negotiators and a 13-member bank advisory committee representing some 460 creditor banks had agreed in New York City to restructure Venezuelan debt maturing between 1983 and 1988 for 12 1/2 years at 1 1/8 percentage points over the London interbank offered rate.

headline: Canadian Stunt Man Braves Niagara Falls
abstract: A 37-year-old professional stunt man survived the 176-foot drop over the Horseshow Falls today.   Karel Soucek, a native of Czechoslovakia who lives in nearby Hamilton, was treated for minor cuts on his forehead at Greater Niagara General Hospital after his 150-pound barrel, equipped with a ship-to-shore communications system, was pulled to the bank on the Canadian side of the lower Niagara River.

headline: BIDDING IS WEAK FOR NOTES, BONDS
abstract: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, with short-term rates falling while longer-term note and bond yields rose slightly.     The weakness in note and bond prices became most evident late in the day, after securities dealers had a chance to assess demand at the Treasury's auction of $5.5 billion of new 12 5/8 percent notes. The new issue sold at an average yield of 12.65 percent, down from 13.16 percent at the previous 10-year note sale in early May. As recently as July 13, 10-year Treasury notes sold with a yield of 13 1/4 percent, down from slightly over 14 percent in late May.

headline: ICL Merger Clears Hurdle
abstract: The Department of Trade and Industry today removed an obstacle to the takeover of ICL P.L.C. by Standard Telephone and Cable P.L.C. The department said it would not refer the proposed takeover to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission for further review.   The companies were awaiting Government approval for their agreement, in which Standard Telephone would trade one of its shares for every three ICL shares.

headline: A SULLEN, DISILLUSIONED FRANCE MARKS BASTILLE DAY
abstract: Splendor and indifference: The President and the armed forces paraded down the Champs Elysees today, all brass and flags, and the thin crowds watched and applauded, without acclamation or passion or cheers.    An enormous tricolor flew in the vaulted space under the Arc de Triom phe, turning in magnificent windy spirals. Jets rushed overhead, leaving blue, white and red contrails, streamers of rainbow smoke. And President Francois Mitterrand, standing in an open command car, drove the length of the avenue, looking grave on Bastille Day, by tradition the French festival of the republic and the rights of man.   ''I don't understand why the French are dissatisfied,'' Mr. Mitterrand said a few weeks ago, acknowledging a malaise, but not its cause. The crowd at the parade today, its detachment singled out by the exquisite pallate of banners and uniforms, seemed almost anesthetized, offering Mr. Mitterrand neither explanations nor contradictions, just a fragile sense of distance.

headline: 2 BRITONS DENY A PLAN FOR A-ARMS IN '82 WAR
abstract: Two admirals in charge of the Royal Navy during the Falkland war in 1982 have denied that Britain ever considered attacking Argentina with nuclear weapons, The Times of London reported today.   The admirals, who are now retired, responded to assertions published Thursday in the weekly magazine The New Statesman that a Polaris submarine was sent to Ascension Island.

headline: Pacific Isle's Separatists Plan Own Government
abstract: Melanesian nationalists in New Caledonia say they have decided to break off autonomy talks with France and to elect their own provisional government.   Leaders of the National Kanak Socialist Liberation Front said after a weekend meeting that their bid for independence for the territory in the southwest Pacific, west of Australia, would begin with elections for a National Assembly on Nov. 11.   This body would then elect the government, to be installed on Dec. 1, which would draw up a constitution for a socialist republic to be called Kanaki.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Reality and Producer Prices    The Producer Price Index has been telling a delightful tale for the past few months. According to the Government's index of prices of finished goods, there was zero inflation in April and May.   But the June figure, due out this Friday, is expected to show an uptick - and, according to many analysts, the new number will be a better reflection of what is really happening to prices than the earlier data.  Lower food and fuel costs may have combined with abnormal weather patterns to distort the April and May statistics, said Kenneth T. Mayland, vice president and corporate economist of the First Pennsylvania Bank.  As for June, said Mr.  Mayland, ''We expect the index to be up three-tenths of 1 percent, because upward pressure on prices has been building for some time.'' The chief factor pushing up prices, he said, ''is that plant utilization is rapidly nearing capacity; output bottlenecks are already noticeable in the electrical and rubber industries.'' The key force working in the other direction, holding down producer prices, he noted, ''is the sharp rise in productivity stemming from the new technology being used on the plant floor.''

headline: Metromedia Debt Financing Metromedia, a privately held
abstract: company since its senior management arranged a leveraged   buyout in June, announced   plans for up to $1.3 billion of   debt financing secured by most   of its radio and television stations.  Proceeds of the sales would   be used to retire a large portion   of the $1.3 billion of bank debt   incurred earlier this year in the   buyout.

headline: Continental May Delay Profits Data
abstract: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company said today that it may delay its second-quarter earnings report until it reaches agreement with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on a plan to help the troubled bank.   The quarterly report will probably show a huge deficit because of large borrowings from the Federal Reserve and several commercial banks, analysts say. Continental Illinois officials are said to fear a renewed run on the bank if a loss is reported before a rescue plan is completed.

headline: Campbell Soup Profit Up 13%
abstract: The Campbell Soup Company said today that a strong performance by its major food brands helped expand its latest three-month profit by 13 percent on a 10 percent sales rise.    The company earned $41.6 million, or $1.29 a share, in the fiscal fourth quarter, ended July 29, up from $36.7 million, or $1.14 a share, a year earlier.

headline: PATENTS;
abstract: Apparatus for Handling Kidneys for Storage    Apparatus for handling an organ such as a kidney to make it suitable for storage, shipment and eventual transplantation has been invented by Raul Guibert, an industrial engineer in Los Angeles. Patent 4,473,637 is assigned to Mr. Guibert's firm, Guibert, Colman & Associates.

headline: Montana Power
abstract: The Montana Power Company said it was disappointed at the denial by the Montana Public Service Commission of any rate increase for the company's Colstrip 3 generating plant. The company, which requested a $96.4 million rate increase, said the commission voted to allow only a $4 million annual rate increase, none of which applies to construction of Colstrip 3. In view of the commission's decision, Montana Power said, ''There are many actions we will take, including long-term sale of the power or sale of the plant itself, before we would reduce the dividend payment to our shareholders.''

headline: U.S. ASSURES SOVIET IT WILL NEGOTIATE SPACE-ARMS ISSUES
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz sent the Soviet Union a message today meant to underscore that the United States had accepted a proposal to hold space-weapon talks in September, State Department officials said.   At a 90-minute breakfast meeting with the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, Mr. Shultz repeated that the United States also intended such talks to deal with ''offensive missiles that go through space.'' This was an allusion to the desire to resume the suspended negotiations on medium-range missiles and on strategic arms, officials said.   The Soviet Union said Sunday that it rejected what it described as American preconditions for the talks aimed at banning space weapons.

headline: A.T.&T. Picks Computer Marketer
abstract: In a move that may quell criticism that its computer marketing lacks focus, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would strengthen efforts to sell data processing equipment through distributors and other intermediaries.     But the company also said it would continue to sell through retail stores and its own 6,000-member sales force. This dual approach prompted some analysts to say the move will do little to allay concerns that A.T.&T.'s marketing is without direction.

headline: BBDO Net Up 35%
abstract: BBDO International reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were up 35 percent from the same period last year.

headline: Ally & Gargano
abstract: Larry Dexheimer, senior vice president and director of media services at Ally & Gargano, has been named acting chairman of the newly formed operations committee.

headline: BRIDGING THE EAST-WEST KNOWLEDGE GAP
abstract: AMERICAN managers don't have the same awestruck attitude toward Japanese management techniques that they had in the days when William Ouchi's book on Theory Z management was selling out across the land. But no realistic executive in the United States is discounting the importance of the Japanese as competitors and customers.     Now N.Y.U. is stressing the flipside of that as well: Japanese businessmen also need to understand American practices and markets. ''The diversity and plurality of the U.S. is a difficult concept for the Japanese businessmen to understand,'' explained Robert Hawkins, vice dean of N.Y.U.'s graduate business school. ''It's not only the language and cultural differences that make things difficult, but the myriad of public policies influencing U.S. business.''

headline: ANALYSTS SURPRISED BY A RISE IN YIELDS
abstract: The specter of a heavier-than-normal supply of Treasury notes and bonds in coming weeks plus concern over the implications of Friday's sharp drop in the value of the dollar helped cause a quick rise in interest rates late last week.     The drop in debt prices and increase in yields, which caught many analysts by surprise, was largely a result of heavy selling by speculative accounts at a time when investor buying was only modest, dealers in Government securities said.    In Friday's trading, Treasury bond prices fell a point, with the bellwether 12 1/2 percent issue due in 2014 offered at 102 1/8 to yield 12.23 percent, up from 12.09 percent Thursday. Three- month Treasury bills rose to 10.30 percent from 10.25 percent. Short- and long-term rates are still well below their recent peaks of Sept. 4, when the three-month bill was auctioned at a rate of 10.63 percent and 30-year bonds were yielding around 12.6 percent.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: The Price Company, a wholesale cash-and-carry membership-only business selling a variety of merchandise, filed a public offering of $75 million principal amount of 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due Aug. 31, 2009, through Shearson Lehman/American Express Inc.   The debentures are being offered at par and are convertible into shares of Price common stock at $53.75 a share.

headline: DURBALES ORDERS FELL 3.2% IN JUNE
abstract: Factory orders for durable goods slipped 3.2 percent in June - the second drop in the last three months, the Government reported today.   Economists said the report is a signal that economic growth will be slowing in coming months but should not be taken as a sign that the recovery is about to halt abruptly.   The report gives an indication that factory production is likely to fall later in the year.

headline: U.S. TELLS WARSAW IT'S LIFTING SOME CURBS IN RESPONSE TO AMNESTY
abstract: The United States has informed Poland that it will withdraw opposition to Polish membership in the International Monetary Fund and ease sanctions on economic and scientific cooperation in response to Warsaw's amnesty for political prisoners, a Reagan Administration official said today.   The official added that the charge d'affaires in Warsaw, John R. Davis, had advised the Foreign Ministry of the Administration's intentions.  Mr. Davis's action was also reported in Warsaw by the Polish press agency.  An announcement will be made here Friday.

headline: Rates Cut for City's New Bonds
abstract: Strong investor demand allowed securities dealers to slightly reduce interest rates for most of this week's $250 million offering of New York City general obligation bonds. The interest rates on the various bond issues were set after city officials and investment bankers led by Goldman, Sachs & Company agreed on an overall interest rate for the financing.

headline: COURT REJECTS REAGAN VETO ON SALVADOR
abstract: The United States Court of Appeals here ruled today that President Reagan did not have the constitutional authority to try to use a pocket veto between two sessions of Congress, as he did last November.    The effect of the ruling was to counter Mr. Reagan's asssertion that a bill linking military aid to El Salvador with progress in protecting human rights there had died because he had not signed it. The ruling means that the legislation is now law despite Mr. Reagan's effort to veto it.    The court today issued a one-page order revebsing a decision by Federal District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who ruled last March that Mr. Reagan had the authority to kill the legislation by not signing it.

headline: KUWAIT'S SOVIET ARMS DEAL STIRS UNEASE IN WASHINGTON
abstract: The State Department, reacting to an agreement by Kuwait to buy Soviet weapons, expressed concern today that the Persian Gulf nation might be moving toward increased reliance on Moscow to defend its oilfields and shipping from attack by Iran.   A spokesman, Alan D. Romberg, said the Reagan Administration had known in advance of the Moscow visit by the Kuwaiti Defense Minister, Sheik Salem al-Sabah al-Salem. He noted that the Kuwaitis earlier bought arms from a number of countries, including the Soviet Union and the United States.   ''We would be concerned,'' Mr. Romberg went on, ''were Kuwait's purchase of Soviet arms and equipment to be on such a scale as to upset possibly the existing balance which the country has traditionally maintained among its sources of military supply.''

headline: Bid by Fleming
abstract: The Fleming Companies said it had agreed to buy all of the shares outstanding of United Grocers Ltd. for $73.1 million in cash and Fleming stock. United, a for-profit cooperative, operates five centers to distribute food and related products to 1,500 stores in California and Nevada. Fleming is a distributor of wholesale foods.

headline: FLATBUSH GROUP IS CALLED FOCUS OF S.E.C. INQUIRY
abstract: A Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into possible illegal insider trading is zeroing in on a group of investors in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, lawyers close to the investigation said yesterday. The S.E.C. declined to confirm or deny those reports or that it is investigating trading in the securities of corporations involved in takeovers.    The lawyers, who asked not to be identified, said the inquiry had focused on trading that emanated from a Swiss brokerage and was conducted through several United States brokerage firms. The trading involves stocks and options of about 40 companies involved in takeovers from the late 1970's through mid-April, the lawyers said, and it resulted in profits

headline: Rate Request By Venezuela
abstract: Venezuela will propose to its creditor banks that its $34 billion foreign debt be rescheduled at fixed interest rates, the country's Planning Minister, Luis Matos Azocar, said today.   Last week Venezuela's creditor banks agreed to begin talks on July 23 to reschedule $14 billion to $15 billion of debt, but they asked the Government to speed registration of private debts and pay off interest arrears. Mr. Matos Azocar said the bankers' decision to accept Venezuela's economic program and not insist on International Monetary Fund conditions was an important step.

headline: BRITAIN WANTS TO QUERY NIGERIA ENVOYS
abstract: Britain asked Nigeria today to allow its diplomats in London to be questioned by the police about the kidnapping of a wealthy Nigerian exile politician. There was no immediate reply.   The kidnapping victim, Umaru Dikko, a former Nigerian Transportation Minister, was discovered Thursday, drugged and hidden in a wooden crate that was to be flown to Lagos, the Nigerian capital.   Mr. Dikko, who is accused by the Nigerian military Government of having illicitly amassed a fortune while he was in the Cabinet, had been abducted from his Hyde Park home. He was released from the hospital today.

headline: 2 Lebanese Killed in Turkey
abstract: Two Lebanese were killed when a car exploded in a parking lot today, the authorities said. They said the men entered Turkey from Syria on Aug. 30 and ''they were probably planning to stage some acts in Turkey.''

headline: Military Contracts
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation received $517.4 million in military contracts, the Defense Department said. The contracts included Army contracts of $250 million for 840 M-1 Abrams tanks and $92.9 million for 2,488 Stinger missiles. In addition, the Air Force gave Pan Am World Services Inc. a $115.8 million contract to operate a test range in Cocoa Beach, Fla., the department said.

headline: Debt Ratings
abstract: ANR Pipeline Co.'s ratings on first mortgage bonds were raised to Ax, from A; debentures to A, from A-; and commercial paper to A1x, from A1. The preferred stock rating was affirmed at A by Standard & Poor's.     *  Columbia Gas System Inc.'s ratings on $1.5 billion of securities were reviewed by Moody's Investors Service for possible downgrading.

headline: Verbatim Expects Loss in Quarter
abstract: The Verbatim Corporation said it expects a loss in the first quarter ending this Friday ranging between $10 million, or 43 cents a share, and $12 million, or 53 cents a share. The company, which develops and markets flexible magnetic storage disks, had 1983 first-quarter net income of $5.4 million, or 23 cents a share, on sales of $40.4 million.

headline: Military Contracts
abstract: The Air Force said it had awarded $87.8 million in contracts for various programs. It said it had given $30.8 million to Litton Industries' Amecom divison for electronic equipment; $29.6 million to Transamerica Airlines, a unit of the Transamerica Corporation, for air transportation services, and $27.4 million to the Martin Marietta Corporation for ground support work for the space shuttle.

headline: Bolivian Civil Servants Start Strike Over Pay
abstract: Civil servants in the Bolivian capital began an indefinite strike for higher salaries today.

headline: Reagan Says He Still Backs U.S. Ambassador to Vatican
abstract: President Reagan said today that he still had confidence in William Wilson, the United States Ambassador to the Vatican and a longtime friend, despite criticisms of Mr. Wilson's intervention in an international criminal case.   Officials confirmed Monday that a high-level Justice Department lawyer had admonished Mr. Wilson for trying to involve the Attorney General in a case concerning Archbishop Paul Marcinkus, head of the Vatican bank, the Institute for Religious Works.

headline: Offer For Miami Bank Company
abstract: Hugh F. Culverhouse, a Tampa lawyer and owner of the National Football League's Tampa Bay Bucaneers, offered $27 a share to acquire control of Florida Commercial Banks Inc. of Miami. Mr. Culverhouse ha been maneuvering to gain control of Florida Commercial, a bank-holding company with assets of $773 million, since late last year.

headline: GOULDS PUMP OFFICER RESUMES NO. 1 ROLE
abstract: Robert L. Tarnow, chairman of Goulds Pumps Inc., has resumed the responsibilities of chief executive officer of the company.     Yesterday's announcement followed a special meeting of the company's board of directors.

headline: Data Bank; August 19, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: THE HOT CARS COMING OUT OF DETROIT
abstract: The new Chrysler mini-van drives like a car but has the storage space of a small pickup truck and the roominess of a van. But customers do not seem to mind its hybrid nature - far from it. They have been waiting for months to buy it, and analysts say the mini-van has created an entirely new market, one that may well overshadow the all-American station wagon.     The mini-van's success is one example of how Detroit's automobile makers are honing their marketing skills. Another example is the Pontiac Fiero, a mid-engined, two-seat sporty car that has also been selling out in dealerships across the country.

headline: Japanese Output Grows
abstract: Production by Japanese factories and mines rose 11 percent in August from a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. Output grew mainly for transportation equipment, metal products and oil- coal products.

headline: GERMANS ARREST 188 ON U.S. ARMY BASE
abstract: The West German police said they arrested 188 people who entered a United States Army training area today in a protest against military maneuvers.    The United States Army said today that vandals had also broken into an Army air defense post near the East German border and sprayed paint on three Hawk missiles. An Army spokesman in Darmstadt, contradicting a West German Interior Ministry report, said the weapons were not damaged structurally and were operational.

headline: A SAUDI VESSEL IS DAMAGED BY EXPLOSION IN GULF OF SUEZ
abstract: A Saudi-registered merchant ship was damaged today, apparently by a mine, in the Gulf of Suez just south of the Suez Canal, Egyptian and shipping sources said.    The Belkis, a 3,100-ton cargo-ferry vessel, was the 19th ship to be damaged by underwater explosions in the Red Sea or Gulf of Suez since July 9. Today's explosion was the first in the region since a spate of blasts more than a month ago.   The discovery late last week by a British naval task force in the Gulf of Suez of a modern, advanced mine and the explosion today in the same area touched off concern that a new series of time-fused mines might be set to explode in the strategic waterway, Egyptian and Western officials said.

headline: Gloria Marshall
abstract: The owner of Gloria Marshall Figure Salons announced that it was closing its 165 offices nationwide.

headline: PERES IS AGAIN COURTING SMALL PARTIES
abstract: Israel's Labor Alignment, its coalition talks with the Likud bloc apparently deadlocked, turned today to smaller parties to try to end the impasse with a more narrowly based government.    Such an effort failed earlier, spurring the talks between the two major parties, and today's renewed bid seemed unpromising. Leaders of the National Religious Party, the first to be consulted, said they were holding out for a national unity government.   Two other parties, Agudat Israel and Tami, were also scheduled to confer. They have also indicated a preference for a broadly based government.

headline: U.S. Denies a Visa To an I.R.A. Politician
abstract: The Reagan Administration has refused to grant an entry visa to Gerry Adams, head of Sinn Fein, the Irish Republican Army's political wing, because of his support of violence, United States officials here said today.   Mr. Adams, who is also an absentee Member of the British Parliament, had planned to address a New York convention of an American-Irish group, the Ancient Order of Hibernians.

headline: NEW GUATEMALA ARCHBISHOP KEEPS MILITARY AT A DISTANCE
abstract: Roman Catholic Church officials say that under the leadership of its outspoken new Archbishop, the church in Guatemala has moved away from its traditional support of military governments and asserted the need for major social and political changes.     The stance of Archbishop Prospero Penados del Barrio is markedly different from that of his predecessor, the late Mario Cardinal Casariego, who urged Catholics to accept the dictates of Government leaders.   ''The previous Archbishop was very friendly to the military, even to the point of traveling under the guard of armed soldiers,'' Archbishop Penados del Barrio said in a recent interview.

headline: LIFT FOR AIRBUS FROM PAN AM
abstract: Pan American World Airways, which has lost more than $650 million in the last three years, announced yesterday that it would spend more than $1 billion to acquire or lease a total of 28 wide-body and standard-body passenger jetliners from Airbus Industrie between 1987 and 1990.     In the meantime, the agreement, announced at a news conference by Pan Am's chairman, C. Edward Acker, calls for Pan Am to lease 16 A300 series wide-body jets from the European aircraft maker until 1987. After 1990, the carrier has the option to acquire or lease a total of 47 more Airbus jetliners.    The sale to Pan Am is a coup for Airbus - a consortium of French, British, West German and Spanish aircraft makers that has struggled for a decade to penetrate the American aircraft market. The agreement also represents a defeat for the Boeing Company, which had fought Airbus hard for the Pan Am order.

headline: The U.N. Today July 18, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Trusteeship Council - 10:30 A.M.

headline: FRIDAY, JULY 13, 1984
abstract: Companies    Manufacturers Hanover's problems loans to Argentina reduced the big bank's second-quarter profits, as expected. Earnings fell 8.5 percent to $73.7 million. Other major banks with loan exposure in Latin America managed to report higher earnings. Chemical Bank's were up 10.2 percent, to $76.8 million; Marine Midland's rose 12.3 percent, to $26.4 million, and Irving Trust's climbed 10.5 percent, to $26.3 million. Profits at Interfirst of Dallas, hurt by bad energy and real estate loans, fell 57.9 percent. (Page D1.)   Teledyne's profits rose almost fivefold to $355.7 million, reflecting the sale of major stock holdings. (D4.) United Technologies earnings increased 21 percent. (D4.) Westinghouse gained 32.9 percent, and Intel said its profits more than doubled. (D15.)

headline: Penn Central Bid
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation said 8,123,000 shares of its common stock had been tendered under its self-tender offer, and that it had amended the offer to allow it to buy all the shares tendered for $47 each.

headline: Sears Project To Thompson
abstract: in Chicago confirmed yesterday that it had retained The J.    Walter Thompson Company,   Chicago, to assist it in exploring ways of using its Sears   Credit Card as an entree to other   areas of the financial services   field.  Robert Wood, vice president,   marketing, of the giant retailer, yesterday stressed the point   that the assignment does not at   this time involve advertising.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Sallie Mae Sets Price Of Floating Notes at Par
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association announced that it had priced $200 million worth of floating-rate notes yesterday.    The notes, which mature on Jan. 10, 1985, were priced at par to yield a variable rate equal to 30 basis points - hundredths of a percentage point - above the bond equivalent yield of the three-month United States Treasury bill auction rate.

headline: Proposal For City Investing
abstract: Tamco Enterprises Inc., one of two partners in a bid for the City Investing Company, has said that if the partnership acquires the company, Tamco would then buy for itself two of City's major subsidiaries, analysts said yesterday.   They said the proposal could indicate there are problems in persuading banks to lend enough money to finance the deal.   Tamco said it would buy the Motel 6 lodging chain and the Home Insurance property and casualty subsidiaries from City Investing, if City accepted the partnership's offer of $50 a share, or $2.3 billion. The other partner is Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: UPPER VOLTA, AT FETE, VOWS TO DO BETTER AS BOURKINA FASSO
abstract: The military leaders of Bourkina Fasso, formerly Upper Volta, celebrated their first year in power today with a pledge to break with their West African country's colonial past and to better feed its population, among the world's poorest.   The former French colony, which changed its name Friday, also gave itself a new national anthem and flag.   Its leader, Capt. Thomas Sankara, said his seven million countrymen were involved in a major revolution. Captain Sankara, a 34-year-old paratrooper, said his ruling National Revolutionary Council would strive to eliminate all traces of what he called petty bourgeois ideology.

headline: FMC WILL BUY SHARES
abstract: The FMC Corporation, an agricultural products company in Chicago, began a tender offer yesterday for 6 million of its common shares.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Rumrill-Hoyt Titles Change      Rumrill-Hoyt Inc, Gary D.   Landis has been promoted to   chairman. His president's title   has been conferred on Paul J.   Goldsmith, who had been executive vice president. Mr. Landis, who is 43 years old, continues as chief executive, and Mr.

headline: BEIRUT PUBLISHES LIST OF HOSTAGES
abstract: Under growing pressure from the relatives of thousands of missing people, the Government published a list today of more than 700 people described as being held in military or police jails.    The list makes only a small dent in the number of people who have disappeared here in the last two years - abducted by armed militias and, in some cases, by military intelligence or other official agencies.   The abductions, often merely because of the Moslem or Christian affiliation printed on identity cards, has been one of the uglier aspects of the strife in this country.   In both predominantly Moslem West Beirut and the Christian eastern sector, relatives of the missing have become increasingly vocal in trying to learn the fate of the missing.

headline: E.E.C. Steel Output Off
abstract: Crude steel production in the European Economic Community declined in July and August from June, the Common Market's statistical agency said.

headline: RYDER/P-I-E APPOINTS CHAIRMAN AND CHIEF
abstract: Ryder/P-I-E Nationwide Inc., one of the nation's largest general freight carriers, yesterday announced the appointment of Jack E. Schang as chairman and chief executive officer.     Kinzey Reeves, Ryder's executive vice president, was named to succeed Mr. Schang as president and chief operating officer.

headline: Bank Reopens In Philippines
abstract: The Philippines' largest savings bank reopened today after a nine-day ''holiday'' and was besieged by thousands of customers seeking to withdraw their deposits.

headline: T.W.A. Registers $100 Million Offer
abstract: Trans World Airlines Inc. has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $100 million public offering of senior exchangeable variable-rate notes due in 1994.   The interest rate on the notes will be adjusted quarterly, unless T.W.A. chooses to covert the issue into senior fixed-rate notes due in 1994. Conversion from a variable rate to a fixed rate may occur on any quarterly interest payment date on or before September 1989.

headline: SIKHS, IN RALLY, PRESS THE ARMY TO QUIT TEMPLE
abstract: Under a steady downpour and the watchful eye of hundreds of armed soldiers and policemen, tens of thousands of Sikhs jammed a shrine here today for an anti-Government rally at which religious leaders called for a mass march to liberate their holiest site from the army occupation.     Thrusting their arms into the air, the Sikhs also shouted their approval for a merger of conflicting Sikh political factions into a unified party, the Akali Dal.    The meeting here in Punjab state, described as a world Sikh convention, was designed to ratify a broad anti- Government program that many here believe could lead to sharper confrontations with supporters of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. In June, Mrs. Gandhi ordered an army assault on the Golden Temple, the Sikhs' holiest shrine, to dislodge a group of Sikh militants.

headline: Herman Shoe
abstract: The Joseph M. Herman Shoe Company said it would close its factory here in 60 to 90 days, leaving 125 employees without jobs.

headline: Bass Brothers
abstract: Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. and Perry R. Bass Inc. told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had sold their holdings in Mattel Inc.'s $2.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock, series A. The group said it sold 143,600 of the preferred shares on the New York Stock Exchange between June 25 and July 10. The two companies said they also eliminated a short position they had held in the common stock of the toy maker.

headline: A NEW SHINE ON MONEY MARKET FUNDS
abstract: WHEN the nation's banks and thrift institutions began offering high-yield money market deposit accounts in the fall of 1982, they drew billions of dollars out of the money market funds. But the funds hung on, and according to Steven Norwitz, vice president of T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, ''the money market funds are coming back this year.'' The decline in their assets bottomed out about a year ago, and since 1984 began, Mr. Norwitz noted, money market fund assets have risen to $175 billion from $160 billion.     What a T. Rowe Price vice president, Edward A. Taber 3d, called ''the renaissance of the money market funds'' reflects a growing recognition that money market funds and money market deposit accounts each have advantages and disadvantages. A particular individual may find one suits his or her needs better than the other, and those who have the cash will often find they will want both a money market fund and a money market deposit account.

headline: NICARAGUA LINKS SEARCH FOR JETS TO A PEACE TREATY
abstract: A Sandinista official said today that Nicaragua might be willing to stop seeking jet fighters for its air force if the Central American draft peace treaty it has said it will accept were to take effect.    A provision of the draft agreement forbids the introduction of new arms systems into the region.   ''If the United States were to live up to its obligation under the treaty to stop its aggression against Nicaragua, then we would have an entirely new situation,'' said the official, Alejandro Bendana, Secretary of the Foreign Ministry. ''We would not necessarily exercise our right to have such planes.''

headline: EGYPT SAYS LIBYAN ROLE IN BLASTS IN RED SEA IS 'ALMOST CONFIRMED'
abstract: A senior Egyptian military official said today that Egypt's suspicions that Libya was responsible for the mining of the Red Sea and Gulf of Suez were now ''almost confirmed.''    He said speculation continued to focus on one Libyan ship in particular that was believed to have dropped the mines.   Gen. Ibrahim el-Orabi, Chief of Staff of the Egyptian Armed Forces, said in a briefing for Egyptian reporters that the belief that Libya was almost certainly responsible was based on new information that could not be fully revealed at this time. Libya has denied that it is behind the mining.

headline: Advertising; The Art Of Selling Nothing
abstract: DO you suppose that the ultimate in the practice of advertising is using it to sell nothing?     Don't laugh. What else is that ''perceived value'' that the packaged goods geniuses are always trying to impart into parity products? Real value is something. Perceived value, well. . . .    A step in the right direction was the Pet Rock, the 1975 phenomenon. Is it any surprise that that was the brainstorm of an advertising man? His name is Gary Dahl and he has since returned to his job as vice president, creative director of Darien, Russell, Hill & Dahl of San Jose, Calif.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Rating    * Montana Power Co.  of Butte, Mont., had its ratings on $650 million of senior debt lowered to BBB-, from A; subordinated debt to BBx, from A-; preferred stock to BB, from BBBx, and its commercial paper to A3, from A2, by Standard & Poor's.  Corporate Notes    * Lear Petroleum Corp. of Dallas registered an offering of $125 million of senior exchangeable variable-rate notes through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: THE WINE INDUSTRY TURNS TO BUBBLES
abstract: NAPA VALLEY, Calif.    The harvest has begun in the  vineyards here, and the scene is  postcard perfect. Green and purply blue grapes hang heavily on the vines, and rolling hillsides frame the valley. A good-sized crop is expected and, with the worldwide glut of table wines in its third year, chances are that more of those grapes than ever before will find their way into champagne.   Indeed, champagnes and other sparkling wines are the wine industry's bright spots these days. It may be a natural outgrowth of the recent white wine craze or, as one vintner suggested recently, Americans may just like bubbles in everything. Whatever the reason, the standard 750 ml bottles of sparkling wines are showing up at even the most informal gatherings. ''Sparkling wine has gone from being a June celebratory beverage to a year-round good-time beverage,'' said Marvin R. Shanken, editor and publisher of Impact, a New York wine and spirits newsletter.

headline: TRYING TO ENGINEER
abstract: Richard D. Pearson had been running Trans World Airlines's huge maintenance operation out of Kansas City, Mo. for six years, sorting out the problems of engineers and mechanics, and trying to keep operations running smoothly. It was an important job - but one that hardly made Pearson a household word.     Now, however, he has been thrust out of the obscurity of Kansas City into the second most important job at the airline and one of the toughest in the industry. Catapulting ahead of seven other vice presidents - two of them senior to him - the 49-year-old Mr.  Pearson was named last month to the newly created post of executive vice president and chief operating officer at T.W.A., one of the nation's largest carriers. His mandate: to turn it around.    ''He was completely unknown, and on paper he doesn't have the background for the job,'' said Mike Derchin, airline analyst at the First Boston Corporation, the investment house. ''But he still could be a fantastic manager.''

headline: Iran Reports Downing Iraqi Plane Over Gulf
abstract: Iran reported it shot down an Iraqi plane over the Persian Gulf today, and both sides said they inflicted heavy casualties in ground fighting.   The Iranian press agency said the Iraqi aircraft was downed by a jet fighter when it intruded into Iranian air space.

headline: Zimbabwe Re-estimates Guerrillas in Grave Site
abstract: At least 10,000 black nationalist guerrillas who fought against white rule when this country was known as Rhodesia were buried in shallow graves southeast of here, Information Minister Nathan Shamuyarira said Sunday night.   He said on state-run television that earlier estimates of 4,000 guerrillas buried at Rusape, 90 miles southeast of Harare, were proved incorrect recently after the Government was shown army records of those killed.

headline: CHERNENKO STATEMENT URGES TALKS WITH U.S. ON DISARMAMENT ISSUES
abstract: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, was quoted today as saying that an agreement with the United States on banning weapons in outer space would ease the way for discussions on other disarmament issues.     The comment, in the form of answers to questions put to him by Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, was the first major statement attributed to him since he left for a vacation July 15. It was not clear when or how the interview with Mr. Chernenko had been conducted. .    The absence of the Soviet leader from public view has aroused rumors about his health and political standing. In the last week, his name has reappeared prominently in the official press on a number of minor statements.    In the Pravda article Mr. Chernenko was quoted as repeating the Soviet position that the United States was scuttling the possibility of space-weapons talks because of its insistence on raising questions about stalled nuclear-weapons negotiations.

headline: 5 Haitians Are Sentenced For Bombings in 1983
abstract: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 22 (AP) - Five Haitians have been sentenced to life imprisonment at hard labor for terrorist bombings in 1983 that killed five people.   Frantz Hereaux, Eug ene Nazon, Fred Esper, Frantz Joachim and Schneider Merzier pleaded guilty Friday to charges of activities against the security of the state.

headline: ANALYSTS CAUTIOUS ON RATES
abstract: Evidence of a weaker economy and signs that the Federal Reserve would tolerate, and perhaps encourage, lower interest rates have helped push rates down since Labor Day.     Economic developments that could point to lower interest rates have been accumulating all summer: Two months of declining retail sales, smaller increases in industrial production and the number of employed workers, declines in the index of leading economic indicators, low inflation and slow money supply growth.    But the economic developments were not enough to bring on lower short-term interest rates until there were signals that the central bank was heeding the same data. Since Labor Day the Fed seems to have flashed the green light to the credit markets, through purchases of securities that exceeded the amounts analysts estimated would be necessary for a stable monetary policy.

headline: Kentucky Bonds To Yield 10.557%
abstract: A $62.3 million financing by Owensboro, Ky., was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 10.557 percent for 10 1/2 percent bonds due in 2004 offered at a price of 99 1/2 through underwriters led by Matthews & Wright.

headline: 10.25% Top Yield On M.A.C. Bonds
abstract: A $185 million financing for the Municipal Assistance Corporation was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 10.25 percent for bonds due in 2008 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.    For shorter maturities, the bonds, rated A by Standard & Poor's, were tentatively offered with yields ranging from 7.5 percent in 1988 to 9.75 percent in 1998.

headline: India to Try 431 Sikhs Over Battle at Temple
abstract: A total of 431 Sikh extremists captured in a battle between separatist guerrillas and the Indian Army at the Golden Temple in Amritsar in June will go on trial next month, the Press Trust of India reported today.   The news agency quoted security officials as saying the Sikhs would be charged with waging war against the Government and could be sentenced to death if convicted.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Chilton Corp. , a consumer credit reporting and collection service concern, said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the Credit Bureau of Portland Inc., in Maine. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Idaho Natural Gas
abstract: Intermountain Gas Industries and the Idaho Natural Gas Company said they had entered into a definitive agreement under which Idaho Natural Gas would begin a $32-a-share tender offer for all of Intermountain's common shares.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Liquid Air Names Official to 2 Posts
abstract: The Liquid Air Corporation yesterday named Mike V. Breber, 57 years old, president and chief executive officer. Mr. Breber had been executive vice president and chief operating officer.     He succeeds Pierre A. Salbaing, who has been named vice chairman of the industrial gas producer's board of directors and executive committee. Mr. Salbaing takes the place of Jean Pianeau, who continues as deputy chairman of Liquid Air's French parent, L'Air Liquide S.A.    Mr. Salbaing was instrumental in the French company's formation of Liquid Air in 1972.

headline: SUNKEN SHIP WITH RADIOACTIVE CARGO BREAKS UP
abstract: A sunken French freighter with 30 cannisters of radioactive material inside broke up tonight in heavy seas, maritime and salvage officials said.   Marc Claus, nautical director of the pilot service here, said he had no information on the fate of the containers of uranium hexafluoride, a radioactive material that was being shipped to the Soviet Union, but he did not exclude the possibility that they might be strewn on the seabed.    He said the hull of the freighter, the Mont Louis, broke under the ''continuous attacks of the waves,'' whose height was put at 12 feet in gale-force winds.   ''The hull broke but the parts of the wreck are still attached by the bow,'' said Henk Drenth of the Dutch salvaging company Smit Tak International.

headline: A DUEL ON ECONOMICS SHAPES UP
abstract: President Reagan is assured of running on one of the strongest election year economies ever. Interest rates are holding steady. Inflation is 4 percent, far below the levels of the Carter Administration, and unemployment has dropped by 3.2 percentage points from the recession high of 10.6 near the end of 1982.    Nonetheless, Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic challenger, is indicting Reaganomics. He will press his claim that the prosperity the President sees in these numbers is illusory, and threatened by future Federal budget deficits that could reach $200 billion before the end of the decade.

headline: Kudlow Firm Sold
abstract: Lawrence A. Kudlow, the former Wall Streeter who left his post last year as chief economist at the Office of Management and Budget to set up a consulting firm, has cashed in by selling it to the Rodman & Renshaw Capital Group Inc., a Chicago securities house. Mr. Kudlow, one of whose financial backers is Saul P. Steinberg, says he has been somewhat ''lucky'' to gain 53 bank and other institutional clients and first-year revenues of about $1 million. He declined to disclose the sales price.

headline: Chemical Names Head For British Operations
abstract: James M. Frost, a senior vice president at Chemical Bank, has been named country manager for Britain, the bank's largest overseas operation, it was announced yesterday. In his new position, Mr. Frost, 41 years old, will be the senior country officer in a country where Chemical Bank has 850 employees.

headline: Sweden Surplus Down
abstract: Sweden had a current account surplus of 400 million kronor, or about $48.1 million, in June, down from a revised 500 million kronor surplus in May and 1.9 billion kronor surplus in June 1983, the central bank said today. The current account measures a country's international dealings in merchandise and services.

headline: Takeover Reports Cited in Carnation Trading
abstract: Reports of a possible takeover move yesterday touched off heavy trading in the common stock of the Carnation Company, the large California-based dairy and grocery products company. More than 856,000 of the company's 34.8 million common shares have changed hands in the last two days.     Analysts, who consider Carnation a prime takeover target because of its high cash flow and low debt, cited reports that Carnation's stock was being accumulated by another company. Other reports indicated that a member of the company's founding family may be planning to sell his stake of more than 20 percent.

headline: Women's Day Plans 17 Issues a Year
abstract: At the Doral Hotel in Miami Beach yesterday, where they were enjoying hurricane season rates, the advertising sales force of Women's Day magazine got the battle plan from Thomas M. Kenney, their publisher of a year.    Come May the magazine will go to a frequency of 17 issues a year from 15, its sales force will sell the so- called store books (Women's Day and Family Circle, available only at checkout, not by subscription) against the rest of the women's service field; the magazine will introduce a new rate card, and it will institute an advertising response guarantee that can include Family Circle, but does not have to.    Asked to respond to the intelligence from the Sun Belt, David G. Ferm, executive vice president and general manager of Family Circle, commented, ''The fact that we've had an advertising response guarantee for 10 years and a 17-issue frequency for six years would seem to eliminate much of the risk for this latest innovation.''

headline: SHAMIR WOULD SEEK COALITION WITH LABOR PARTY IF ELECTED
abstract: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that if his Likud bloc won the elections on July 23, he would try to form a national unity government with the opposition Labor Party to deal with economic problems.   His remarks appeared to be the most explicit public indication of plans for such a coalition, aimed at reducing Israel's 400 percent inflation rate through wage, price and tax measures.   Speaking in an interview in his modest, wood-paneled office, Mr. Shamir also said that his Government no longer accepted the old negotiating formula of trading land for peace with the Arabs, and that as long as he was in power, Israel would not halt the building of settlements on the West Bank.   ''We will build without any pause,'' he said, when asked whether he would agree with Labor's proposal that no more settlements be built near densely populated Arab areas. ''We will not stop it. We have to build. It is our mission in this land. We have to have more cities, more centers of population.''

headline: KAHANE BARRED FROM ENTERING AN ARAB TOWN
abstract: Rabbi Meir Kahane and three busloads of armed supporters were blocked by the police today when they tried to enter Israel's largest Arab town as part of a campaign to drive Arab citizens from the country.     The Brooklyn-born rabbi, who selected this community of 25,000 in the Galilee region to begin the campaign, was detained by the police at a roadblock two miles away and then released.    The police did not explain their actions, but the state radio said tonight that Rabbi Kahane's visit could have led to violence that might have spread throughout the area, which is heavily populated by Arabs.  11 Officers Are Injured      There was violence in this town, nevertheless, as Arab youths threw stones at soldiers and policemen, who fired tear gas and smoke pellets into the crowd. Eleven officers and some youths were injured.

headline: AT THE FRONT, IRAQIS ADAPT TO THE WAR
abstract: This port city, near the front lines of the Persian Gulf war, is up to its ears in sandbags.    Head-high walls of the bags line the banks of the Shatt al Arab waterway, the perimeter of the market area, the sidewalks of the main streets and the Government buildings. They also surround the local headquarters of the ruling Baath Party and filling stations in Basra, Iraq's main port.   But for the most part, after nearly four years of war with Iran, Basra seems to have adopted its own, somewhat somnolent, routines to deal with the effects of the fighting.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1984
abstract: Companies    New car sales rose 11.6 percent, on a daily selling rate basis, in the Aug. 21-31 period, the six major American manufacturers reported. G.M.'s sales were up 6.6 percent; Ford's, 19.5 percent; Chrysler's, 11.5 percent, and A.M.C.'s, 18.2 percent. For the entire month the seasonally adjusted rate was 7.7 million, the lowest monthly rate this year, because of low inventory levels and spot shortages. Imports rose slightly in August. (D1.)   Braniff said it was going to become a low-cost carrier with unrestricted fares. The airline said some fares would be reduced Saturday and added that it would have to cut its labor force. (D1.)

headline: A SILENT BEGIN CASTS SHADOW ON ISRAELI VOTE
abstract: Mina Zemach, a well-known Israeli pollster, bumped into her office maid the other morning and could not resist asking her who would get her vote in Israel's approaching election. Without hesitating for a moment the maid responded, ''Begin.''   The maid's answer was not unusual here. Although Menachem Begin is not running for elective office for the first time in Israeli history, and although he remains a recluse in his Jerusalem apartment, his shadow continues to hang over the Israeli election campaign.   His successors imitate him, his followers still shout his name at rallies and his opponents are doing everything possible not to provoke him out of his self-imposed exile and into the campaign.

headline: Deficit Adds $33.5 Billion
abstract: The Federal budget deficit soared to a near-record $33.5 billion in August, putting the total for the year well above the shortfall forecast by the Reagan Administration, the Treasury Department reported today.   However, officials said an expected $18 billion surplus in September, the last month of the fiscal year, would bring the deficit for the fiscal year 1984 back down to the Administration's predicted level.

headline: Jewish Group Voices Support for Nicaragua
abstract: A Jewish group that monitors human rights said today that it had found no evidence of an ''official policy'' of anti-Semitism in Nicaragua during a week-long visit.   ''We believe that no anti-Semitic or anti-Jewish policy exists on the part of any official organization,'' the New Jewish Agenda said in a statement.

headline: SENATE PASSES MEASURE TO DEREGULATE BANKING
abstract: The Senate late tonight overwhelmingly approved major banking deregulation legislation that would give banks broad new powers to expand into other financial services. Passage came after six days of debate and protracted attempts by opponents to derail the measure.   By a vote of 89 to 5, the Senators adopted the bill and rebuffed efforts by both New York Senators, Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican, and to a lesser extent, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat, who had objected to a provision that would authorize states to enter regional banking pacts under terms that would keep out the New York banks.

headline: Calvin Klein, Kayser-Roth
abstract: The Kayser-Roth Corporation has acquired the women's underwear division of Calvin Klein Industries and the use of the designer's name for that business, the companies said.

headline: THE POINT OF THE MEETING
abstract: The throngs of reporters and television crews at the White House today attested to the worldwide interest in President Reagan's meeting with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko. But two audiences were described as uppermost on Mr. Reagan's mind: the Russians and the Americans.   Administration officials quickly characterized the meeting as successful in communicating the President's message of readiness to have a new relationship with Moscow.   Yet they acknowledged that it would take time for it to become clear that reduced tensions are possible.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
abstract: A $504 million financing by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10 3/4 percent for bonds due in 2003 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.    The financing also includes 12 percent bonds due in 2005, tentatively priced at 111 1/4 to yield 10 5/8 percent, and 6 3/4 percent bonds due in 2009 at a price of 68.03 to yield 10 3/8 percent.

headline: Hallmark Filing
abstract: Hallmark Cards Inc. has increased its stake in Binney & Smith Inc., a crayon and art supplies manufacturer, to 1,631,951 common shares, or 38 percent of the shares outstanding, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. From June 14 to June 28, Hallmark bought 146,100 shares at prices ranging from $54 to $54.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. On June 11, Hallmark gained the option to purchase 672,000 shares, or 22 percent of the 3,634,535 shares outstanding, from 15 Binney & Smith shareholders.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: *  Beneficial Tax Centers Inc., a subsidiary of Beneficial Corp., said it had signed an agreement with Montgomery Ward to operate income tax preparation services in about 175 Montgomery Ward stores.     * Color Tile Inc., a floor and wall tile company in Fort Worth, said it had signed a definitive agreement with Color Your World Inc. of Toronto to acquire the company for about $27 million.     * General Signal Corp. , an instrumentation and control equipment company in Stamford, Conn., said its New York Air Brake Co. and General Railway Signal Co. divisions had received orders worth $18.4 million for transportaton control systems.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Tourist Time    The Fourth of July holiday weekend traditionally marks the beginning of the peak summer vacation season, and this should be a strong summer for the tourist industry.   The much-improved economy, the Olympics in Los Angeles and the World's Fair in New Orleans will boost tourist traffic nationwide by about 5 percent this summer, says Saul F. Leonard, national partner in charge of leisure time and gaming industries at the accounting firm of Laventhol & Horwath. Not only will there be more tourists, he predicts, but they will be ''spending more money on their vacations this year because the economy has improved so much.''   Because of the strength of the dollar, many Americans are likely to invade European vacation spots. The United States is not expecting many foreign visitors, however, because the strong dollar has made this country a relatively expensive spot to sojourn.

headline: A Rally for British Miners
abstract: Thousands of wives of striking coal miners marched through London today to demonstrate their support for the 22- week-old walkout. The women, many with their children, silently laid black flowers along Whitehall, Britain's street of government, before staging a rally in a London park.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
abstract: The Chrysler Financial Corporation is offering $200 million of subordinated exchangeable variable-rate notes through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.    Interest on the notes was set at 14 percent through Oct. 31, and will thereafter be adjusted quarterly at the highest of three percentage points over the three-month Treasury bill rate, 1.75 percentage points greater than the rate for certain interbank deposits in London, or 104 percent of the yield on 10-year Treasury notes.    On July 15, 1989, or sooner if the company elects, the variable-rate notes will be exchanged for fixed-rate notes due in 1994 with an interest rate set at 124 percent of the yield on Treasury notes.

headline: NEIGHBORS OF EMBASSY SAY THEY'RE IN DANGER
abstract: Residents of this tiny hilltop village say the opening of a United States Embassy here this summer has placed them in mortal danger.    Embassy operations were moved here in July because American officials felt that this Christian suburb of East Beirut was safer from terrorist attack than West Beirut. On Thursday the six-story building was devastated by a suicide car bomber.    ''All the time we felt threatened,'' Bechara Khachan, a teacher living some 100 yards from the embassy building, said of the period since the embassy opened. ''We were afraid that somebody would set off a bomb, and that is exactly what happened.''

headline: Soviet Bank Tries Eurobond Market
abstract: The London-based Moscow Narodny Bank offered a $50 million bond issue today in what is thought to be the first foray into the Eurobond market by a Soviet borrower and the first such issue for foreign investors since the Russian Revolution of 1917.   The interest rate on the seven-year bonds was set at 3/16 percent over the London interbank offered rate.

headline: SAUDIS SEEKING U.S. MISSILES
abstract: The United States and Saudi Arabia have had informal discussions about Saudi interest in purchasing large numbers of additional American made Sidewinder air-to-air missiles, a senior United States official said tonight.   The official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said the Saudis have not made any formal request to purchase the AIM-9L Sidewinders, advanced missiles that are currently used by both the United States Navy and Air Force.

headline: CITY SAVINGS BANKS IMPROVE
abstract: The financial condition of New York City's savings banks improved substantially in the second quarter, according to figures released yesterday by the New York State Banking Department.     During the three-month period, the 22 state-chartered savings banks in New York City suffered an operating loss of $21.8 million, down from a loss of $41.3 million in the first quarter, and from $44.1 million in the fourth quarter of 1983. The latest quarter's results were also an improvement over the $27.5 million operating loss in the second quarter of 1983, when interest rates were considerably lower.   Income at Many Banks    In addition, the majority of the city's state-chartered banks - 13 of the 22 - reported net operating income, not losses. Outside New York City, the state-chartered savings banks reported aggregate net income of $978,000, compared with a loss of $16.6 million in the first quarter.

headline: Volcker Backs Bank Powers
abstract: Problems at the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company should not be used as a reason to oppose legislation granting banks broader powers, according to the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker.   In a letter released today, Mr. Volcker told Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah and chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, that Continental's problems were unrelated to any activities that would be allowed under the pending Congressional legislation.

headline: COLPATENTS; Television Picture
abstract: WASHINGTON   A new memory system, patented this week for the RCA Corporation, will store television pictures in receivers so that interference and distortions can be eliminated, and the viewer will also be able to freeze a picture for a long period.   Patent 4,460,958 was granted to Lauren A. Christopher, Glenn A. Reitmeier, Terrence R. Smith and Christopher H. Strolle of the RCA technical staff in Princeton, N.J. Miss Christopher did her work on the case during internship with RCA while she was a college student.

headline: SELLING WAVE SWAMPS ITT
abstract: IN the wake of a shocking dividend cut announced    late Tuesday by the ITT Corporation, a selling   wave flushed nearly one-third of the market value from the company's common stock yesterday and helped to rock the entire equity market.    Essentially, ITT's stock fell victim to a marketplace increasingly oriented to high dividend yields and with a low tolerance for any surprises in the form of bad news - the telltale sign of a skittish bear market.   The dividend cut - labeled ''a shocker'' by Herbert E. Goodfriend, an analyst at Prudential- Bache Securities - saw ITT's directors slash the quarterly payment to 25 cents a share from the former rate of 69 cents.    On Tuesday shares of the telecommunications and insurance conglomerate had closed at 31, thereby providing a comfortable cushion in the form of an annual dividend yield at 8.9 percent. But the swiftly changing fortunes of ITT saw its shares finish yesterday at prices to yield just under 5 percent. ''The 5 percent level is a sort of magic number, a time-tested rule of thumb, for all types of institutional investors, ranging from mutual funds to pension funds and college endowment funds,'' Mr. Goodfriend said.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Coastal Corp. Offering $600 Million of Notes
abstract: The Coastal Corporation is offering $600 million of subordinated exchangeable variable-rate notes through Drexel Burnham Lambert as sole underwriter.    The notes will bear a 14.6 percent interest rate until Nov. 14, after which the rate will be adjusted quarterly so that it is either 3 percentage points above the bond equivalent yield on 91-day Treasury bills, or 1 3/4 points above the offered rate for three-month interbank deposits in London, whichever is higher.

headline: LETTERS
abstract: AUTOMATION    To the Editor:   Richard M. Cyert has made the strongest possible case for ''unmanned factories.'' Unfortunately, his acceptance of dubious economic history and misleading definitions of ''efficiency'' mar his presentation.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: CANADIAN LEADER SEE NO U.S. SHIFT ON ACID RAIN
abstract: Brian Mulroney, Canada's new Prime Minister, said today that he made no progress this week in persuading President Reagan to move swiftly to curb acid rain.     Mr. Mulroney, who visited the White House on Tuesday, told reporters here that ''I can't tell you in fairness that I detected any major departure in his attitude.''   The Reagan Administration has opposed moves in Congress to take such steps as limiting smokestack pollutants, arguing that more study is needed on the causes and effects of acid rain. Many legislators and public officials in the United States, pointing to dying forests and toxic levels of acidity in lakes and streams, have called for swift action by Mr. Reagan to reduce the pollutants that they believe to be the cause.

headline: U.S. IS WEIGHING STATUS OF KAHANE'S CITIZENSHIP
abstract: The State Department has begun a review into whether Rabbi Meir Kahane should lose his American citizenship after being sworn in Monday as a member of the Israeli Parliament, a spokesman said today.   Rabbi Kahane, leader of the tiny Kach Party, is a hard-liner who seeks the expulsion of all Arabs from Israel. He was born in New York, where he founded the militant Jewish Defense League, and immigrated to Israel in 1971.   Under United States law, a person serving in a foreign government risks losing his American citizenship in certain circumstances.

headline: CHURCH AND UNION URGE POLES TO SHUN VODKA
abstract: Underground committees of the Solidarity movement, active in at least 20 of Poland's largest factories, have joined in a church-sponsored boycott of vodka in the hope of depriving the Government of its largest source of revenue, as well as saving the health of the Polish people.   The Roman Catholic Church's sobriety campaign, which has been growing steadily over the last two years, reached a high point today, when priests in parishes all over the country led men and women in oaths pledging not to buy or drink vodka for a month.   A welder close to some of the factory committees reported that he considered the two-week period a test run that he hoped would lead to longer boycotts.    'All Change Takes Time'    ''You know, asking Poles to stop drinking is not so easy,'' the worker said. ''It is easier to get them out to throw stones. All change takes time.'' The man said that in addition to the appeals and church sermons, individual workers with what he called ''recognized authority'' would urge their co-workers to join the boycott.

headline: More Fighting Reported In Northern Sri Lanka
abstract: A Government official said today that there had been an attack in the northern coastal town of Valvettiturai, where rebels are fighting for a separate minority Tamil state, but he refused to comment on a report of more than 100 civilian and guerrilla deaths.   The Times of India reported from Colombo that the Sri Lanka Navy shelled the town Monday, killing more than 100 people.

headline: Walesa Appeals for Halt To Protests in Poland
abstract: Lech Walesa said today that the outlawed Solidarity union was reassessing its role and that it would be unwise to stage demonstrations or provoke authorities after a Government amnesty last month freed hundreds of political prisoners.   ''The amnesty is a step in the right direction by the Government,'' Mr. Walesa said.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Federal Reserve All data in millions of dollars  LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo  Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Sept. 17  215,200 214,600 n.a.   Reserve Position, Eight New York Banks Daily averages for two weeks ended Sept. 26 Excess (Deficit) Reserves (Incl. carryover) 39 37 n.a.  Borrowings at Federal Reserve 0 0 n.a.
