headline: SISTER CALLS CASTRO A TRAITOR
abstract: Juanita Castro, brother of President Fidel Castro of Cuba, denounced him as a traitor today for breaking his promise to restore democracy to their homeland.   ''His revolutionary promises are recorded,'' Miss Castro, who left Cuba in the early 1960's, said at forum sponsored by the White House.

headline: ADVANCE OF 5.30 FOR DOW REDUCES WEEK'S LOSS
abstract: The stock market, bolstered by signals of a moderation in economic growth, moved modestly higher yesterday. The rise followed three days of declines that saw the Dow Jones industrial average sink nearly 30 points.    The Dow rose 5.30 points yesterday, to 1,109.87, and closed the week with a net loss of 12.70 points after plunging 18.33 points on Wednesday for its biggest drop in more than four months.

headline: NEW DELHI SEEKS EXTENDED PUNJAB RULE
abstract: The Indian Government, troubled by terrorist activity in Punjab, will propose a constitutional amendment to maintain direct control over the northern state for one more year, officials said today.   The amendment requires a two- thirds vote in Parliament. It would extend the emergency law, adopted last October, through October 1985.

headline: Dataram Layoffs
abstract: The Dataram Corporation said it was laying off 74 employees because of a decision to discontinue certain product lines.

headline: Dun's Business Month
abstract: Dun's Business Month, a subsidiary of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, said yesterday that it had named Arlene Hershman editor. Formerly assistant managing editor in charge of coverage of financial markets, she succeeds Clem Morgello, who assumed the new position of editorial director at the publication, which has a circulation of 304,000.

headline: Texas American
abstract: A group consisting of the Threshold Development Company and William Fuller told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it holds the equivalent of 479,652 shares, or 7.2 percent of the total outstanding, of the Texas American Energy Corporation.

headline: MALAYSIA'S REACH FOR INDUSTRY
abstract: For any country to make the transition from producer of raw materials to producer of finished goods is a formidable task. But this country, which wants to be industrialized by the end of the century, intends to try.    The basis of its aspiration is its most important natural resource: rubber. Malaysia, the world's largest producer of natural rubber, has decided to make a strong push to become a leading producer of tires.

headline: Duarte Arrives in New York En Route to Reagan Meeting
abstract: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador arrived in New York yesterday from Europe en route to a scheduled meeting with President Reagan this morning in Washington.

headline: Horse Bolts Near Princess
abstract: A runaway horse charged through a crowd today, injuring a woman a few yards from the Princess of Wales, who is expecting her second child in September. The Princess, who was 23 today, and her husband, Prince Charles, were watching a polo match in Cirencester in western England.

headline: Peugeot Head Resigns
abstract: Jean-Paul Parayre, a prime architect of the Peugeot auto group's expansion, resigned today as chairman.

headline: AT CAMP 'HILTON,' VIETNAMESE LEARN WAYS OF U.S.
abstract: When Diep Hai Ki mentions San Diego, his weathered face lights up. Mr. Diep, 64 years old, a Vietnamese refugee, has never seen San Diego - or, for that matter, any part of the United States.     But that is where he and six members of his family who arrived at the large refugee center here last month are headed, to join relatives.    Mostly, Mr. Diep says, ''I am very, very happy to get out of Vietnam.''   Among all the refugee camps in the region, the Morong center is known as ''the Hilton,'' boasting the top accommodations. The refugees live in long wood-framed houses with concrete floors and corrugated steel roofs. Each building has 10 units separated by walls, with 7 to 10 people living in each unit.

headline: Iberia Airline Strike Goes On
abstract: A maintenance workers' strike against Iberia Airlines, originally scheduled to last only two days, entered its third day today with more than 200 domestic and foreign flights canceled so far, a company official said. The official said he was not optimistic of a quick resolution of the strike. The workers, who are seeking union recognition and more training, decided to extend the stoppage after management refused to rehire 14 dismissed strikers.

headline: No Nonsense Consolidates at Grey
abstract: No Nonsense Fashions, the pantyhose provider, is consolidating all of its advertising in one agency, moving the Comfort Stride Light Support brand into Grey Advertising from Ogilvy & Mather.

headline: HANOI TO TALK ANEW ON LOST AMERICANS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Hanoi Government had agreed to meet again next month on the issue of the nearly 2,500 Americans unaccounted for from the Vietnam War.   He made the disclosure in a speech to the Honolulu Council on Foreign Relations. Mr. Shultz arrived on Tuesday at the end of a 10-day trip to Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Australia and New Zealand.   On Tuesday, Vietnam handed over the remains of what it believed to be eight Americans, and they arrived today at Hickam Air Force Base here from Manila. A special armed forces center here will try to confirm the tentative identifications.

headline: Ratings Review
abstract: * City Investing Co.'s senior notes and sinking fund debentures, rated Ba1, and the $2.875 convertible exchangeable preference stock, rated ba2, are under review by Moody's because of City Investing's recently announced agreement to sell three units to an investor group for $1.25 billion in cash.     *   Duke Power Co.'s first mortgage bonds, secured pollution control bonds, preference stock and promissory notes are being reviewed for possible upgrading by Moody's. The company's commercial paper is not under review. Moody's said about $3.3 billion of securities are under review.

headline: South Africa Black Dies After Jailing in Riot Area
abstract: The South African police said today that a 24-year-old black man died while in their custody early Monday in the town of Parys, a small settlement south of here that had been gripped the day before by riots.   But police officials denied assertions by civil rights activists and lawyers that the man, Johannes Ngalo, had been detained in connection with unrest set off by rent increases in the black township of Tumahole.

headline: Rohr in Deal With Airbus
abstract: Rohr Industries said it had been selected by Airbus Industrie to coordinate the design, manufacture and support of the total nacelle system for the Airbus A320 commercial transport.

headline: Decision Soon On Debt Issues WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 - A
abstract: senior Treasury official said today that the Reagan Administration was close to deciding   whether to offer new types of   securities to finance the national debt. ''We hope to have our papers   finished in the next week or   so,'' Beryl W. Sprinkel, Undersecretary for Monetary Affairs, said in announcing the   Treasury's quarterly refunding. Mr. Sprinkel said that after   getting the staff recommendation, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan would decide   whether to offer the new securities. Mr. Regan would probably   make a decision soon, Mr.

headline: Caracas Debt Progress Seen
abstract: Foreign banks are willing to restructure $19.7 billion of the Venezuelan Government's foreign debt, two Caracas newspapers reported.    Citing sources on Venezuela's Government debt negotiating team, the dailies - El Universal and El Nacional - said on Friday that terms of an agreement on Venezuela's debt would be similar in many ways to the accord reached recently between foreign banks and Mexico.

headline: PROFIT TAKING EASES PRICES
abstract: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday as last week's sharp rise in Treasury note and bond prices was partly reversed when traders began to take profits.     Although investor demand has been strong as interest rates declined the past month, securities dealers said some increase in rates was probably needed to attract more buyers to this week's auctions of Treasury notes and bonds totaling $16.75 billion. In advance of today's sale of new three- year Treasury notes, dealers offered the issue with a yield of 12.48 percent, up from 12.34 percent late Friday.    Because the three-year issue offers a yield nearly as high as 10- and 30- year Treasury issues, but is less likely to suffer a severe drop in price if interest rates rise, it has attracted more invesvtor demand than the two longer-term issues, securities dealers said. The 10-year Treasury notes to be auctioned tomorrow were offered late yesterday at 12.70 percent, up from 12.54 percent, while the 30-year bonds to be auctioned Thursday were offered at 12.63 percent, up from 12.50 percent. Among outstanding issues, the 13 1/4 percent bonds due in 2014 fell 1 1/4 points, and were offered at 104 5/8 to yield 12.64 percent.

headline: Article 082461 -- No Title
abstract: Two offerings of shorter-term Treasury issues highlight this week's activity in the Government securities market.   Today, the Treasury is scheduled to hold its weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, for a total of $13.2 billion. And on Wednesday, $8.5 billion of two-year Treasury notes will be auctioned.

headline: Dealers Awaiting Word on U.S. Sale
abstract: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, though securities dealers expect the Government to announce on Wednesday a major note and bond financing for next week.    In advance of today's regular auction of Treasury bills, the outstanding three-month bills were bid late Friday at 10.31 percent, while the six- month bill was 10.58 percent. In advance of Thursday's auction of $8.25 billion of new one-year bills, dealers bid a rate of 10.73 percent for outstanding one-year bills.

headline: SOVIET AGAIN ATTACKS GERMANYS FOR CLOSER LINKS
abstract: The Soviet press asserted today that West Germany was moving away from the ''letter and spirit'' of the Moscow Treaty signed 14 years ago, which laid the foundations of West German-Soviet detente.   A dispatch carried by the Soviet press agency Tass on the eve of the anniversary of the signing charged that Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Government had called into question the central principle of the treaty, the inviolability of the postwar European borders.   Tass said that ''realistically minded circles,'' along with the West German public, ''being deeply alarmed with this course, which is fraught with extremely dangerous consequences for the European peoples, above all for West Germany itself, declare for the return to the policy of detente, for the observance of the principles of the Moscow Treaty, for discarding the policy of militarism and revanchism.''

headline: Fair Wages
abstract: To the Editor:   In your Forum piece on labor negotiations (''The Need for Even More Cooperation,'' Sept. 16), Jerry Jasinowski gave figures on wage increases versus inflation for 1975 through 1984. He failed to give comparable figures showing executive salary increases, including bonuses and stock options, versus inflation for that same period.

headline: Former Nigerian Official Kidnapped in London
abstract: A former Nigerian Cabinet minister who is a leading opponent of his country's six-month-old military Government was kidnapped here today. Two British television stations said later that the former official, Umaru Dikko, was found drugged but alive in a crate labeled ''diplomatic baggage'' in an airport cargo terminal.

headline: DISCUSSIONS START ON FALKLAND ISSUE
abstract: Argentina and Britain said today that they had begun talks to settle their dispute over the Falkland Islands.    The talks, which began in Bern, Switzerland, are the first public negotiations between Argentina and Britain since the two fought an 11-week war over the South Atlantic islands in 1982.   But while British officials quoted in reports from London played down the range of the talks, saying the central question of sovereignty over the islands would not be discussed, Argentine officials said otherwise.

headline: Money Funds Continue Rise
abstract: Assets of the nation's 335 money market mutual funds jumped for the second consecutive week, reaching their highest level in 18 months, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.   The increase of $857 million brought the assets to $182.39 billion for the week ended Wednesday.

headline: U.P.I. LOOKING FOR NEW CASH
abstract: United Press International Inc., the financially troubled news service that changed hands in 1982 after many years of unprofitability, is seeking investment capital to meet a projected operating deficit of nearly $7 million in 1984, according to confidential company documents being circulated to prospective investors.     Since May, U.P.I. has been circulating an investment memorandum prepared by G. William Miller & Company of Washington and offering 30 percent ownership in U.P.I. for $12 million in new equity capital. According to the financial data included in the memo, U.P.I. had before-tax operating losses of nearly $23 million in 1982 and 1983.    Douglas F. Ruhe, U.P.I.'s managing director and one of two principal owners, confirmed yesterday that the company has been in a ''tight cash mode'' in the past seven months, and added that U.P.I. has been unsuccessfully seeking equity capital for two years. But Mr. Ruhe, who would not comment directly on the documents, said that finding new equity capital was not essential to U.P.I.'s survival, which, he said, the two owners were determined to insure.

headline: MORE 'TEMPS' ARE STAYING ON
abstract: The temporary-employment industry, which traditionally provides trained personnel for short-term work, is increasingly finding itself a matchmaker for permanent business relationships.   The current economic recovery is credited, at least in part, for spurring the shift. Some in the industry report that business is up as much as 60 percent from last year, and with more temporary employees, or ''temps,'' in the market place, more are being hired away for permanent jobs.   In an expanding economy, explained Herbert H. Bienstock, director of the Center for Labor and Urban Programs Research at City University in New York, ''temporary workers are used to test the market, to see if the expansion will be permanent.''   ''And it makes sense,'' Mr. Bienstock added, ''that the people who pinch hit will be offered a permanent place in the lineup.''

headline: Rates on Loans Up in Britain
abstract: Major British commercial banks raised their base lending rates today to 10 percent, from 9 1/4 percent, despite a warning by the Bank of England that an increase in interest rates was not needed.   The British pound has been under increasing pressure since the Bank of England, the British equivalent of the Federal Reserve System, advised banks last week to hold the line on interest rates.

headline: WARNER LOSES OVER $400 MILLION
abstract: Warner Communications Inc., the financially troubled entertainment and communications company, yesterday reported that its second quarter loss had widened to $437.5 million from $283.4 million in the period last year. Revenues rose 28.3 percent, to $475.5 million, from $370.5 million.    The company's announcement of a substantial loss, which was expected, came as Warner began another round of dismissals of hundreds of employees at its New York headquarters.

headline: Smith Extends Gearhart Deadline
abstract: Smith International Inc. said it is extending to July 20 the expiration date and proration period for its $31-a-share offer for 3.7 million shares of Gearhart Industries. Smith also said that as of Friday approximately 7 million Gearhart shares had been tendered and not withdrawn.

headline: Chapter 11 Filing
abstract: Unioil Inc said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

headline: The U.N. Today July 6, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Commission on International Trade Law - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad Hoc Committee on the World Disarmament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: PATENTS; AUDIBLE TEACHING MACHINE
abstract: WASHINGTON A teaching machine that can recognize a student's voice in answers to questions and respond orally was patented this week for the Scott Instruments Corporation of Denton, Tex. The machine, which uses a digital computer, is being manufactured and sold under the trade mark V.B.L.S., for Voice-Based Learning System.

headline: MONDALE'S TAX CHALLENGE
abstract: In his budget proposals, Walter F. Mondale, the    Democratic Presidential candidate, has presented the American people with a difficult and unpleasant choice: to accept higher taxes or risk the effects of widening budget deficits, projected by the Congressional Budget Office to reach $263 billion in 1989.    Mr. Mondale is gambling that the American people will respond favorably to his painful message. He has now, as he said, ''laid his cards on the table, face up,'' and challenged Mr. Reagan to do the same. The President and his aides have continued to insist that they will do no such thing until after the election.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Franc Option In Philadelphia The Philadelphia Stock Exchange said yesterday that it   would begin trading its sixth   currency option contract,   based on the French franc, on   Sept. 17. Arnold Staloff, the exchange's director of new products, said the specialist that   would make the market in the   contract is a venture equally   owned by Banque Indosuez and   Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. He said the contract, which   has been approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission, would have a face   value of 125,000 francs.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.   Monday    Construction SpendingMay    Factory OrdersMay Tuesday    None Wednesday    None Thursday    New-Car SalesJune Friday    Unemployment June

headline: Curfew Called in Punjab To Prevent Sikh March
abstract: Authorities have imposed an eight-hour curfew on this city to prevent a march scheduled for Monday by Sikhs to the Golden Temple, scene of a fierce battle last month between Indian Army troops and Sikh militants, the Punjab radio said today.   The main Sikh party, the Akali Dal, has called on Sikhs to march to the temple to demand withdrawal of the army from the shrine and Punjab, home of most of India's 12 million Sikhs.

headline: Kodak-China Deal
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company said it had signed a contract with China to help establish a factory there for color photographic film and paper.

headline: STOCKS END HIGHER AFTER 4 DOWN DAYS
abstract: Stock prices, buoyed by a strong bond market, advanced moderately yesterday after four days of declines.    The Dow Jones industrial average, up almost 15 points at 3 P.M., faded in the last hour and ended the day ahead 10.16 points, to 1,209.14. Gaining issues outnumbered those that declined by 1,001 to 596.

headline: Iraq Studies Bonn Bid To Inspect Chemical Site
abstract: Iraq has informed the West German Government that it is considering a request that Bonn be allowed to inspect the site of a chemical laboratory being built near Baghdad, a a Government official said today.   But Foreign Minister Tareq Aziz of Iraq, who ended a two-day visit to Bonn today, said details and the date of such a visit had not yet been agreed upon, according to the German official.

headline: Hungary Gets Western Loan
abstract: The Hungarian National Bank signed an agreement today for a $385 million credit with representatives of four Western banks and the World Bank.   The signing came nine days after the World Bank announced in Washington that it had agreed to participate in two commercial loans to Hungary totaling $487 million.

headline: IRAQ SAID TO HOLD ADVANTAGE IN WAR
abstract: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee issued a staff report today that said the military balance in the Iranian-Iraqi war had shifted in recent months to Iraq.    The shift is a result, it said, of ''massive arms sales'' to Iraq by France and the Soviet Union and an effective American-led boycott on military sales to Iran.    The report said that if Iran went ahead with a much-discussed ground assault against Iraq, this would ''probably lead to a defeat for Iran.'' If Iran failed in its attack, it went on, ''its munition stocks would be almost depleted and the risk of a counteroffensive would exist.''

headline: Business Coalition Opposes a Tax Increase
abstract: A coalition of five major business organizations, raising the curtain on its 1985 tax strategy, declared today that raising individual or corporate taxes next year would jeopardize continued expansion of the economy.    ''Our message is simple and bipartisan,'' said John M. Albertine, president of the American Business Conference, which represents some 100 medium-sized growth companies.

headline: ALLOWING BOND OWNERS TO REMAIN ANONYMOUS
abstract: The Treasury Department, exploring new ways to reduce the cost of financing the nation's huge debt, is considering reviving bearer bonds to elicit greater demand from foreign investors who have a penchant for anonymity.     Such a change would come a year after Congress, seeking to curb tax evasion, outlawed the issuance of bearer bonds in the United States by requiring that all securities be registered in the owner's name.   With bearer bonds, no record of ownership is listed on the certificate or maintained by the issuer. Holders of the bonds are presumed to be the owners. On presenting the certificates to an issuer or paying agent, the holders are entitled to receive interest and principal payments without identification. The Treasury has not issued bonds in bearer form since the 1960's, a spokesman said.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Belgian to Head Settlements Bank
abstract: Jean Godeaux, governor of the National Bank of Belgium, has been elected president of the Bank for International Settlements, the bank announced today. Mr. Godeaux succeeds Fritz Leutwiler, the president of the Swiss central bank, who steps down as head of the B.I.S. at the end of this year.    Mr. Godeax, who turned 62 last week, has broad experience in both public and private banking.

headline: 204 From Hijacked Jet Questioned in Baghdad
abstract: The Red Cross was reported today to have questioned the 204 passengers and crew members of a hijacked Iranian jetliner to determine if they want to return to Iran.   Iran has charged that the passengers and crew are being held against their will.

headline: Yugoslav Court Convicts A University Lecturer
abstract: A district court today convicted a suspended university lecturer of counterrevolutionary activities and sentenced him to eight years in prison.

headline: Caterpillar Buys Stake in Robotics
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, in an attempt to stay competitive, has bought 20 percent of the Advanced Robotics Corporation, a maker of sophisticated industrial robots in Columbus, Ohio. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Guilford Picks Chief Of Finance
abstract: Daniel O. Anderson has been named chief financial officer at Guilford Transportation Industries, the privately held railroad holding company that earlier this week lost out in the bidding for Conrail, the Government-owned freight railroad system.    Mr. Anderson, who is 56, has spent much of his career in high-technology businesses. From 1978 until 1983, Mr. Anderson was executive vice president of Itek and president of its graphics systems and communications industries. He joined Itek, a high-technology manufacturer for business and the military, in 1975.

headline: CORPORATE PHONE LISTS TO BE AUCTIONED BY MAIL
abstract: How valuable are the telephone directories of some of the nation's top banks, investment and accounting firms, insurance companies and corporations - especially those that include not only direct office numbers for managers, but also home addresses and phone numbers and, in at least one instance, such data for summer homes?     Steven Olsen is counting on their being worth a great deal.    Mr. Olsen said his firm, Corporate Information Services, plans to sell copies of directories for such companies as the General Motors Corporation; the RCA Corporation; Chase Manhattan Bank; Goldman, Sachs & Company; Arthur Andersen & Company, and Booz, Allen & Hamilton, the management consulting firm.    Semiannual Auctions Planned    Prospective buyers are told to write to a box number and ask for a catalog detailing what Mr. Olsen said would be a package of directories for 250 companies from around the world. They must then submit bids through the mail for the package.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Sept. 21, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 3 P.M.

headline: South African Trade
abstract: South Africa's foreign trade surplus in the first eight months of the year was more than halved from the period a year ago, the Government said today.

headline: Italy Increases Discount Rate
abstract: Italy raised its official discount rate today to 16 1/2 percent from 15 1/2 percent in an effort to curb strong domestic demand for loans and to keep inflation in check.   Unexpectedly high private credit demand, which rose at an annual rate well above Government targets in the first seven months of this year, made the increase necessary, the Treasury said.

headline: LABOR PARTY WINS EASILY IN SOUTH AFRICAN MIXED-RACE VOTE
abstract: The Labor Party, led by a clergyman who has opposed apartheid, emerged today as the overwhelming victor in elections for the mixed-race chamber in South Africa's new three-chamber parliament. The body offers a limited political role to some nonwhite South Africans but not to the black majority.    However, a low turnout and other factors indicated the obstacles facing the Labor Party leader, the Rev. Allan Hendrickse, in defending his participation in the South African political system. Critics assert the new Constitution upon which the parliament is based institutionalizes the ostracism of blacks and entrenches the official system of racial division.

headline: A Sunday Supplement For Academy Awards
abstract: Gerald H. Gogol, president of North South Communications, who has been creating ''advertorial'' newspaper inserts for the last four years, will have a new entry next year. A Sunday supplement in an estimated 19 newspapers with a collective circulation of 9.5 million is scheduled to run on the eve of the Academy Awards.

headline: Sallie Mae to Sell Nonvoting Stock
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association said it would accept 2.9 million shares of the 21.5 million shares of voting stock that were tendered to it and would make a public offering of 2 million nonvoting shares through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: U.S. CAR SALES UP 32.1% IN AUG. 10-20 PERIOD
abstract: Sales of new American-made automobiles bounced back in the second 10 days of August, with the six major manufacturers today reporting an increase of 32.1 percent, on a daily selling rate basis, from the same period last year.   The daily rate of 23,651 sales was the highest since 1979.   Sales were down slightly in the first 10 days of this month, as inventory levels continued to fall below desired levels. Most of the auto makers have closed some operations to change over to 1985 models. The annual rate of sales, seasonally adjusted, rose to 8.1 million domestic units, from 7.4 million in the Aug. 1-10 period, and up from a 6.6 million rate last year at this time.

headline: Penn Central Bid To Buy Sparkman
abstract: The Penn Central Corporation said it had signed a memorandum of understanding to acquire all of the securities outstanding of the Sparkman Energy Corporation for about $90 million. That includes paying $15.25 a share for Sparkman's 4.5 million common shares outstanding.

headline: Federal Reserve
abstract: All data in millions of dollars  LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo  Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Aug. 13  211,700 R 213,400 n.a.   Reserve Position, Eight New York Banks Daily averages for two weeks ended Aug. 15 Excess (Deficit) Reserves (Incl. carryover) R 18 (61)n.a.  Borrowings at Federal Reserve 287 70 n.a.  Net Federal Funds Purchases R 10,870 7,081 n.a.  Basic Reserve Surplus (Deficit) R (11,139)(7,212)n.a. headline: Corporate Notes
abstract: Midlantic Banks Inc., Edison, N.J., said it plans to offer $50 million in convertible subordinated debentures due 2009 through a syndicate of underwriters.     *  Ohio Edison Co., Akron, Ohio, filed an offering of $75 million in first mortgage bonds due 1994 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co.     *  Westinghouse Electric Corp., Pittsburgh, is raising $200 million through a public offering of 25-year, 9 percent convertible subordinatd debentures through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman/American Express.

headline: GM Rehires 2,000
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said it had recalled 2,000 hourly workers effective Monday for assignment to various parts operations in its manufacturing system. G.M. said the recalls would reduce to 30,000 the number of hourly workers on indefinite layoff with rehire rights. Another 21,400 workers are on temporary layoff, the auto maker said.

headline: MITTERRAND'S CHANGES: GIVING SOCIALISM A NEW, CENTRIST LOOK
abstract: Within hours of the Communist departure from Government here, President Francois Mitterrand began a campaign that seems aimed at creating the impression of movement toward the political center, an attempt to give French Socialism the look of moderate Social Democracy.  Like a judge admonishing a jury, Mr. Mitterrand told Prime Minister Laurent Fabius and his new Socialist-led Cabinet at their first meeting Thursday that ''they represent no political party.'' Then the Government announced cuts in corporate and personal income taxes - not just one-shot deals, Mr. Mitterrand said, but reductions that would become a pattern for the rest of his presidency.    At a time when the country was listening for guidelines, there was no more talk of ''socialisme a la fran,caise,'' or the wonderful changes in society to come, or the politics of joy and self-fulfillment. The warm, enveloping verbal embrace of the French left in 1981 was shed in favor of tax cuts aimed at the middle class and people in business.

headline: DIVERS OFF BELGIAN COAST RECOVER ONE-THIRD OF A RADIOACTIVE CARGO
abstract: Salvagers retrieved nine more barrels of uranium hexafluoride from a sunken French freighter today, bringing the total to 10 - a third of the ship's radioactive cargo.   A 30-member salvaging team, taking advantage of a second straight day of mild weather in the North Sea after a week of storms, worked virtually around the clock starting Thursday morning to recover the containers.   Ten of the sunken freighter's 30 steel containers of uranium hexafluoride have been placed on a pontoon anchored off the wreck, said Myra Giltay of the Dutch salvaging company Smit Tak International. The first container of the radioactive material was recovered from the 4,210-ton freighter, the Mont Louis, on Thursday.

headline: Ogden Project
abstract: The Ogden Corporation said it had entered into arrangements with the Marion County, Ore., board of commissioners to design, construct and finance a $47.5 million solid-waste disposal and resource recovery facility.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; New York City Bonds Yielding Up to 11.06%
abstract: The City of New York priced $250 million worth of general obligation bonds yesterday. The issue consisted of $181.5 million of serial bonds with maturities from 1986 through 2009 and $68.5 million of term bonds maturing in 2014.

headline: U.N. PARLEY URGES BAN ON PROMOTING USE OF ABORTION
abstract: The United Nations International Conference on Population adopted a recommendation Friday night that abortion ''in no way should be promoted'' as a family planning method.   The language was accepted by the conference's main committee after the delegates, meeting here on the fifth day of their week-long conference, turned back a more restrictive proposal by the Vatican. The Vatican had unsuccessfully urged the conference to adopt a recommendation that ''abortion should be excluded as a method of family planning.''

headline: PRICE AND DELOITTE SEEK TIE
abstract: Price Waterhouse and Deloitte Haskins & Sells, two of the Big Eight accounting firms, announced yesterday that they are discussing a possible merger that would create the nation's largest accounting firm.    Confirming reports that have circulated for two weeks, the firms said the talks were ''at an early stage,'' but that they expected to recommend a merger to their partners for approval by the end of the year.   A source close to top management at Deloitte said high-level ''conversations'' regarding such a merger have been going on for several months and that materials were already being prepared for a general meeting of Deloitte partners scheduled for next month.   Should the merger be approved by partners, the combination would supplant Arthur Andersen & Company as the nation's largest accounting firm, with combined United States revenues last year of an estimated $923 million and worldwide revenues exceeding $2 billion. Arthur Andersen's worldwide revenues last year were estimated at $1.24 billion, including $903 million from United States operations.

headline: Music Director Retires At Dancer Fitzgerald
abstract: Arnold Brown has been involved in the selection of some of the century's most-often-heard melodies as music director for Dancer Fitzgerald Sample since 1967.

headline: CANADA LEFTISTS LOWER SIGHTS AND RAISE PROSPECTS
abstract: The popularity of Canada's leftist New Democratic Party had dropped so low before the current election campaign that it seemed likely to disappear as a serious force in this country's politics.     But its leaders now seem to be reviving the party by promising much less than in the past. The New Democrats' proper role, they argue, is to prod Canadian governments headed by other parties in directions the New Democrats consider progressive, rather than to lead their own government.    In April the party's popularity stood at 11 percent in the Gallup Poll, and it faced the likelihood of failing to elect the 12 members, needed to remain an official parliamentary party.

headline: VOTE ON OUSTED INDIAN STATE PREMIER PUT OF AGAIN
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's forces in the state assembly of Andhra Pradesh today postponed for the second time a vote on the reinstatement of the dismissed Chief Minister.   National opposition leaders demanded that the legislature vote without further delay on the reinstatement of the Chief Minister, or state Premier, N. T. Rama Rao. If not, they told Gov. S. D. Sharma, a Gandhi loyalist, the New Delhi Government must ''face the consequences,'' in the words of A. B. Vajpayee, one of the leaders.    Meanwhile, Mr. Rama Rao made a triumphal procession through this city on the roof of a Chevrolet van he calls his ''chariot of divine enlightenment,'' suggesting images of the Hindu gods he has portrayed as a movie actor.

headline: Kalish & Rice Acquired By Earl Palmer Brown
abstract: Kalish & Rice of Philadelphia, with 75 employees and $27 million in billings, has been acquired by Earl Palmer Brown Inc. of Bethesda, Md., but will continue to operate under its own name and mostly with its own officers.

headline: QUARRELING CARIBBEAN NATIONS MEET
abstract: The leaders of English-speaking Caribbean countries met today for the first time since the United States invasion of Grenada and raised the question whether their 12-year-old regional grouping could survive internal strife.   Four of the 13 countries in the Caribbean Community and Common Market, or Caricom, opposed the invasion of Grenada in October, and others are at odds over economic policies.   ''It is a fact that the quality of our relationships has deteriorated,'' said Prime Minister George Chambers of Trinidad and Tobago at the opening of the three-day conference at the Cable Beach Hotel.   To his mind, Mr. Chambers said, the only issue was whether the regional grouping was ''to continue and, if so, on what terms and conditions.''

headline: A NEW CHALLENGE FOR SEOUL LEADER
abstract: With the exiled opposition leader Kim Dae Jung planning to come home soon, President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea is being put to a new test of his grip on power.    Mr. Kim's announced intention to return from the United States, presumably in December, has greatly encouraged anti-Chun dissidents, who have lacked a clear focus for much of their activity. Even those who were not allied with Mr. Kim in the 1970's, when he was this country's most prominent opposition politician, now see him as a possible ''rallying point'' for all anti- Government forces.   ''It's important to have him back,'' said a Protestant clergyman. ''Either in or out of jail he will be playing an important symbolic role.''

headline: 2 Jewel Officers Resign; President Is Promoted
abstract: Jewel Companies Inc., the Chicago supermarket and drugstore company that is being acquired for $1.16 billion by the American Stores Company of Salt Lake City, has announced the resignation of its chairman and chief executive. W. R. Christopherson, 58, and of its vice chairman, Lawrence Howe, 62.   Jewel said its new chairman, chief executive and president would be Richard G. Cline, 49, who was formerly president and chief operating operating officer has not been named.

headline: Associates Corp. Sets 3-Year Notes
abstract: The Associates Corporation of North America priced $100 million worth of three-year senior non-callable notes.

headline: NIGERIA STANDOFF WITH BRITAIN ENDS
abstract: Britain and Nigeria ended a two-day diplomatic standoff today that had grown out of the bungled abduction of a wealthy Nigerian exile politician. ending     A Nigeria Airways Boeing 707 cargo plane was allowed to leave Stansted Airport, near London, this afternoon for Lagos, the Nigerian capital, and a short time later a spokesman for British Caledonian Airways said a Boeing 747 passenger plane detained by Nigeria took off from Lagos.    Nigeria's military Government has denied any role in the kidnapping. It detained the London-bound British jet and its 222 passengers after Britain grounded the cargo plane. The cargo plane was apparently to be used to fly the kidnapping victim to Lagos.

headline: U.N. CONDEMNS SOUTH AFRICA OVER ITS PLAN FOR PARLIAMENT
abstract: The Security Council voted approval today of a resolution that ''strongly rejects and declares as null and void'' constitutional changes proposed by South Africa.   Included in these changes, which are scheduled to take effect in September, is a provision for a parliament of three houses - one for whites, one for people of mixed race and the third for Indians.   Blacks, who make up the majority in the nation, are not to be represented.

headline: HIJACKED IRANIANS FLY HOME
abstract: Two hundred Iranians returned home today after a weeklong stay in Baghdad where they were flown on a hijacked jetliner. Six others, including the hijackers, stayed behind.

headline: South African Police Use Tear Gas in Melee
abstract: --The police fired tear gas at black protesters in the second day of demonstrations against rent and tax increases in a black township 50 miles south of Johannesburg.   A police spokesman here said 40 demonstrators had been arrested in the nearby township of Tumahole on such charges as public violence, theft, looting, arson and burglary.

headline: EUROPE'S COMPETITOR FOR SHUTTLE
abstract: If all goes according to plan, a white rocket named Ariane 3 will blast off from the Kourou launching ground in French Guiana next Saturday, putting two civilian communications satellites into orbit 22,500 miles above the earth.    Europe will then be firmly established in the business of launching commercial satellites, competing with the Space Shuttle for the fees companies pay to have satellites parked in space.   ''This is the shot that really must succeed,'' Roland Deschamps, secretary general of Arianespace, the organizer of the launching, said in an interview at the company's headquarters in this small town just south of Paris. ''With Ariane 3, we can make multiple satellite launches like the Shuttle. Our costs go down.''

headline: REPORT OF EXILE FOR SYRIAN DENIED
abstract: An aide to the brother of Syria's President today denied a report that the brother had been declared persona non grata in Syria.   The aide also said that Syria's Defense Minister, who was said to be the source of the report, had denied making remarks on the subject that were attributed to him by a West German magazine. An editor at the magazine, meanwhile, said the interview had been taped and that the publication stood by its account.   The aide to Rifaat al-Assad, the brother of the Syrian President and one of the country's three Vice Presidents, issued a statement here today saying that Rifaat Assad had been in Geneva since June for health reasons and that he intended to return to Syria soon to resume his duties in the Government.

headline: No Headline

I.B.M. MOVES INTO SOFTWARE MARKET In its first major thrust into the business software market, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced 31 programs for its Personal Computer that create electronic spreadsheets, draw graphs and create reports.
abstract: The programs, which were developed internally by I.B.M., are similar to the Lotus Development Corporation's popular 1-2-3 program, and Ashton-Tate's line of dBase data management software. Analysts said that both companies could be hurt by the introduction, but found I.B.M.'s own aggressive entry into the software market - where the company has never been a major presence - more significant than the products themselves.   ''This was the first time that I.B.M. has said that it is going into software in a big way,'' said Kathleen Lane, who follows software products for Dataquest, a California market research firm. ''They have picked the jewels: the business software that nearly every company needs.''

headline: Boesky Raises Midlands Stake
abstract: A group controlled by the New York investor Ivan F. Boesky told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in Midlands Energy Company common stock to 612,800 shares, or 7.1 percent of the total outstanding. The Boesky group said it made net purchases of 137,500 shares between Aug. 1 and Sept.  17.

headline: Moroccans Vote
abstract: Moroccans voted today for their fourth Parliament since independence from France in 1956. The election is expected to produce another center-right majority loyal to King Hassan II.

headline: LATE JUNE AUTO SALES UP 10.9%
abstract: New car sales by the major American auto makers continued strong in the last 10 days of June, finishing 10.9 percent ahead of robust sales at the same time last year, the companies reported here today. The selling rate during the period was the highest since 1978.   Sales for all of June were up 8.9 percent for the major domestic producers, putting the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate at 8.3 million, compared with 7.5 million for last June.   Held down by the recent metalworkers' strike in West Germany and supply problems in Japan, imported car sales slipped 4.1 percent in the month, to 223,690 units, from 233,205 last year. That resulted in an annual rate of 2.6 million, the same as last June.

headline: Danish Price Increases
abstract: Danish consumer prices rose six- tenths of 1 percent in June from May and were up 6.9 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today. Wholesale prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in June and were 9.7 percent higher than a year ago, the Government said. It added that fruit and vegetables topped the list of increases in consumer goods.

headline: Bank of Indiana
abstract: The Money Management Corporation, a bank holding company, said its board had approved a proposal that the company's employee stock ownership plan should take control of Money Management and its Bank of Indiana subsidiary. The company said that each three of its approximately 1.5 million common shares outstanding, other than common stock owned by the stock ownership plan, would be converted into $12.50 cash plus two shares of a newly authorized 12 percent cumulative preferred stock. On the American Stock Exchange today, Money Management rose 12.5 cents, to $10.25.

headline: 14 South Pacific Nations Seek Nuclear-Free Zone
abstract: Leaders of 14 South Pacific nations unanimously agreed today that their region should become a nuclear- free zone.

headline: STRICTER RULES FOR BANKS PROPOSED
abstract: Federal banking regulators have proposed new rules that could make about 700 of the nation's approximately 15,000 commercial banks raise hundreds of millions of dollars in new capital.    If the rules are made final, they would require banks, for the first time, to maintain a ratio of primary capital to assets of 5.5 percent.    The action is in response to Congressional concern about the stability of banks with large outstanding loans to underdeveloped countries that are having trouble repaying them.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ; East German Defends Talks With the West
abstract: East Germany published a top-level defense of discussions with the West today, despite Soviet attacks on its efforts to improve relations with Bonn.   Herbert Haeber, East Germany's senior expert on relations with West Germany, was quoted by the Communist Party newspaper Neues Deutschland as calling for a return to ''peaceful economic and political relations through dialogue.''

headline: CHERNENKO, UNSEEN SINCE JULY 15, RUMORED TO BE IN SOVIET HOSPITAL
abstract: Rumors have surfaced in Moscow about the standing and health of the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko.   One rumor among Russians is that Mr. Chernenko, who will be 73 years old next month, interrupted his vacation in the south this month for medical treatment in a Moscow hospital.   According to these rumors, which Western diplomats have been unable to verify, Mr. Chernenko's condition is not serious.

headline: United Increases Depository Issue
abstract: The United Illuminating Company increased its offering of depository preferred stock to 3.3 million shares from 2.5 million shares.

headline: Itel Is Planning Note Exchange
abstract: The Itel Corporation said it plans an exchange offer for its 10 percent notes, and will seek approval of amendments to the terms of its 10 and 14 percent notes.

headline: FRIAR DEFENDS VIEWS AT VATICAN SESSION
abstract: A Franciscan friar, summoned from Brazil by the Vatican, defended his advocacy of the doctrine known as liberation theology today in a four-hour session with church authorities.     Afterward the Vatican said in a statement that the Sacred Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith would study, ''according to customary methods,'' what came out of the session.    The 44-year-old Brazilian theologian, Friar Leonardo Boff, emerged smiling from the closed-door session and told a throng of reporters that he had not been asked to recant.    The statement, approved jointly by Friar Boff and the Sacred Congregation, described the meeting as a ''conversation'' between the theologian and Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger, the Congregation's head.

headline: ALLIES WELCOME REAGAN'S PROPOSALS
abstract: Allies of the United States today welcomed President Reagan's proposal to open negotiations with the Soviet Union and awaited Moscow's response.    East European delegates commented on the ''mildness'' of the speech and showed interest in Mr. Reagan's expressed desire to lower trade barriers.   Reactions from countries that profess nonalignment varied. There was praise from Mexico for the move toward greater understanding with the Soviet Union, particularly in the arms field.

headline: Sri Lanka Forces Battle Tamil Separatists
abstract: Government forces battled two groups of Tamil separatists who attacked a police station and blew open a bank in northern Sri Lanka today, the police said.   Casualties among the separatists were reportedly heavy in both incidents.

headline: BONN PLANS TO RELAX JOB-PROTECTION LAWS
abstract: The West German Government announced a legislative package today that is intended to generate new jobs by dismantling some of the country's rigid hiring-and-firing regulations.    By American standards the proposals, expected to pass Parliament in the autumn and take effect Jan. 1, represent only a modest easing of Germany's strict labor practices. But they would eliminate an array of regulations that have heightened labor costs and hindered layoffs by troubled German companies, thus encouraging increased automation over the creation of new jobs.

headline: Ethyl Estimates Lead Ruling Costs
abstract: The Ethyl Corporation estimated that it would have to make a $20 million to $25 million after-tax charge against 1984 earnings if the Environmental Protection Agency prevailed in its proposal to reduce the lead content in gasoline. The E.P.A. has proposed that the lead content be reduced to 0.10 gram a gallon effective Jan. 1, 1986, from the current level of 1.10 grams a gallon.

headline: ; . . . Georgia Counterpart With a Regional View
abstract: Robert Strickland, chairman of the Trust Company of Georgia, sees more than just a big merger in the new Suntrust Banks Inc., of which he will be chairman. He says it will give him more opportunity to take his 15- year-old son, Walter, to Disney World.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Integrated Resources Inc., an investment company, has elected Richard M. Rosenbaum special counsel to the chairman of the board and director of government relations and public affairs.     * Mutual Oil of America Inc., Santa Fe, N.M., has elected Lewis M. Eslick president of the company and Raymond M. Gray chairman.

headline: Trade Deficit Sets a Record
abstract: The United States foreign trade deficit set another record in the second quarter as farm sales dropped sharply and the country's appetite for foreign oil picked up, the Government said today.   The deficit for the period from April to June was $26.3 billion, slightly above the old record of $25.6 billion posted in the first three months of the year.

headline: WALESA IS HARSH AND HOPEFUL ON POLISH SITUATION
abstract: Lech Walesa, the founder of the banned Solidarity union, assailed Poland's leaders today for what he called their failure to abide by the accords on free speech, free press and independent unions that were signed here nearly four years ago.   In his apartment in this port city, beneath a large portrait of Pope John Paul II, Mr. Walesa read a prepared statement that said ''continuing to ignore the will of the nation brings on the threat of conflict.''    He accused Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, of ''betraying the trust of the Polish people'' by declaring martial law in 1981 and by paying only lip service to the 21 points of the Gdansk agreement of Aug. 31, 1980, under which Solidarity became the only independent union in the Soviet bloc.    Winner of Nobel Prize      Mr. Walesa, the winner of the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize, said he hoped to read the statement here to mark the Aug. 31 anniversary, ''if I am not surrounded by a sea of blue,'' an allusion to the riot police.

headline: FED WON'T TIGHTEN ITS POLICY
abstract: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board said today that the nation's central bank, at its policy meeting last week, decided not to tighten its monetary policy, a move that was welcomed by Wall Street and could mean that interest rates will hold steady, instead of rising, for the next several months.     Testifying before the Senate Banking Committee, Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, would not predict whether interest rates will fall later this year, although he said he expects the current rapid pace of expansion to slow down in the last half of the year. If the economy continues to grow rapidly, he said that rates could rise.    Investors responded positively to Mr. Volcker's statements. Note and bond prices rose and interest rates showed a sharp decline on the news, and the reaction spilled over to the corporate and tax-exempt markets. (Page D16.)

headline: A Surplus for Sweden
abstract: Sweden's current account posted a $362 million surplus in the first quarter, swinging from a $205 million deficit in the first quarter of 1983, the central bank said today. The current account measures a nation's international trade in merchandise and services, such as tourism and shipping.

headline: Singapore Work Rules
abstract: Singapore will refuse work permits to foreigners who earn less than 1,500 Singapore dollars a month - about $700 - or are not graduates of recognized universities, the Government said today.

headline: SHULTZ AND GROMYKO TO MEET LATE THIS MONTH
abstract: The State Department announced today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz would meet in New York on Sept. 26 with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union for a discussion of all outstanding Soviet-American issues. The two men will be in New York for the fall session of the United Nations General Assembly.   Administration officials said that they also planned to invite Mr. Gromyko to Washington for further talks with President Reagan after his meeting with Mr. Shultz, but that it was premature to say anything official about this now. Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said that ''it hasn't been determined'' whether Mr. Reagan would meet Mr. Gromyko.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, AUGUST 3, 1984
abstract: The I.B.M. Settlement    I.B.M. and the Common Market settled antitrust complaints in the first case of such scope and complexity. Under the agreement, I.B.M. will disclose to its rivals some advance information about its mainframe computer models that hold about 70 percent of the European market. The agreement, which is intended to give compeptitors a chance to catch up with I.B.M., can be repudiated after 1990, however. (Page A1.)

headline: Advertising; Polaroid Shuffles Agencies
abstract: ALLY & GARGANO has picked up the domestic advertising for all of Polaroid's consumer instant photographic products, which have been handled by Doyle Dane Bernbach for 30 years. D.D.B., however, will continue to do Polaroid's ads in the rest of the world and its industrial and professional photographic systems in North America.    Since June, Ally has handled Polaroids Perfectdata floppy disks, but the company will assign the product to Ogilvy & Mather, along with its supercolor video cassettes and 8 millimeter home video recording system, a new product.

headline: BEIRUT PAPER REPORTS ANTI-U.S. THREAT
abstract: As American security officials continued to sift through debris at the the bombed United States Embassy building near East Beirut, a local newspaper reported a new threat today against American installations here.    The leftist daily As Safir said an anonymous caller, identifying himself as a representative of the Islamic Holy War group, which took responsibility for the embassy attack Thursday, warned of ''a big operation'' against Americans.    There was some question, however, whether the call was genuine, since previous calls from Islamic Holy War were made to a Western news agency and never to a local Arabic newspaper.

headline: F.T.C. Inquiry On St. Regis Bid
abstract: The Champion International Corporation said it had been served with subpoenas by the Federal Trade Commission seeking additional information relating to its proposed takeover of the St. Regis Corporation.    Champion said the action does not affect a previously announced agreement with the F.T.C. to extend to Oct. 8 a holding period during which Champion will not exercise control of St. Regis. The company added that it does not believe that the combination of the printing and writing papers businesses of the companies would violate antitrust law.

headline: Paper Says Videotape Shows Sakharov Is Fit
abstract: A West German newspaper said today that it had a 20-minute videotape of Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife in Gorky that is ''unmistakable evidence'' that the Soviet physicist and dissident is alive and has ended his hunger strike.   Bild Zeitung, a mass-circulation daily, said in a statement that it had acquired the videotape from the same source that provided the newspaper with two photographs of the couple in June.

headline: Assets of Money Market Funds Up in Week
abstract: Assets of the nation's 332 money market mutual funds rose $1.33 billion, to $175.39 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.    Yields on both short- and long-term products have, as of this week, broken the 10 percent level, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report.

headline: TRILOGY DROPS 'WAFER-SCALE' CHIP
abstract: Trilogy Ltd., which gave up on its effort to produce a super computer last June, said today that it had abandoned its plans to design, build and market a high-speed ''wafer-scale'' computer chip.   Gene M. Amdahl, Trilogy's chairman, said the company would instead attempt to design and assemble circuit packages for computer manufacturers from conventional semiconductors.   The decision to drop the wafer- scale chips, which aimed at packaging circuitry on one larger chip to equal the power of 100 smaller chips and thus speed data processing, was not entirely a surprise. In June, a few days after it dropped plans for an innovative mainframe computer, Trilogy said it would not be able to bring the new wafer chips to market until at least 1986.

headline: WITH A 'SIR' AT STAKE, FLORIDAN WINS THE DAY
abstract: To hundreds who have not actually met him, he is the frail, white-haired steward who on a Saturday or Sunday once showed them to a seat in Canterbury Cathedral. He has been a banker and a British Army officer. In childhood, his mother introduced him as ''the little baronet.''    This week, 91 years into his life, he finally had to concede that he would never be a baronet, only William Henry George Dunbar of Kilconzie.

headline: Michelob Tests
abstract: It became known a month ago that Anheuser-Busch, the nation's largest brewery, was testing Michelob commercials made by Ted Bates Worldwide and Needham, Harper & Steers, already one of its agencies. Asked Friday whether there had been any decision on the future of the brand, Fleischman-Hilliard, St. Louis, the brewery's public relations firm, said, ''No comment.''

headline: Beech-Nut Baby Food Campaign
abstract: THE problem that the people from Nestle S.A. inherited when they acquired Beech-Nut baby food was a declining consumption pattern - the average American child had cut back from 54 dozen jars to 44 dozen. And that's not good for business.    The major reasons for the decline, according to Steven B. Most, vice president, marketing, who has changed ends of the consumer pipeline since he sold Pampers for the Procter & Gamble Company, is that pediatricians are urging young mothers to continue breast-feeding longer, and if not that, to keep the child on formula longer. The formula makers, Mr. Most maintained, aim all of their promotion effort at physicians.

headline: ECONOMISTS PLAN WAYS TO SWAP IDEAS FASTER
abstract: In a world of new markets and proliferating financial services - with rapid changes in banking, accounting, financial theory, government regulations and marketing - academic economists are saying that the publishing of research can no longer keep pace with the times. They complain that the latest and best ideas of researchers are unknown to their colleagues and the business community.   ''The economy is more volatile, changing faster,'' said Frank Reilly, dean of the College of Business Administration at the University of Notre Dame, ''and the publishing lag is getting worse.'' By the time much research in economics gets into print, he added, ''the data you used are three or four years old.''

headline: Houston Gas
abstract: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation said its board had authorized the repurchase of as many as 3 million shares of its common shares on the open market. The company said the stock purchase would be an alternative to using available capital to expand its pipeline and exploration businesses. The board will continue to evaluate that option, it added.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Federal Reserve All data in millions of dollars  LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo  Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Sept. 10  214,600 R 216,400 n.a.   Reserve Position, Eight New York Banks Daily averages for two weeks ended Sept. 12 Excess (Deficit) Reserves (Incl. carryover) R 37 (8) n.a.  Borrowings at Federal Reserve 0 0 n.a. headline: Indian Protesters Accuse C.I.A. in Sikh Unrest
abstract: About 100 demonstrators marched on the United State Embassy today to criticize what they said was involvement by the United States Central Intelligence Agency with Sikh extremists.   The police erected a rope fence in front of the embassy gate as speakers said the United States Government was trying to destabilize India and encourage Sikh separatism.   Indian press reports have alleged that the C.I.A. supervised training camps in Pakistan, but the embassy in India and the State Department have issued strong denials.

headline: SUCCESS STIRS BRITISH DISPUTE
abstract: Inmos International P.L.C., Britain's state- owned venture into manufacturing microchips, has proved a success - so much so that the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher sees an opportunity to sell the company, while the opposition Labor Party argues that it proves the viability of state participation in business.    ''To abandon public ownership now would be no more than ideological spite,'' said Peter Shore, the Labor Party's spokesman on industrial matters, during a recent debate on Inmos's future in the House of Commons. As Labor sees it, the Government, venturing where private industry feared to tread, made Britain the only European nation with an independent, domestically owned mass producer of microchips.   Nevertheless, the question is not whether Inmos will be sold to private investors, but when and how. The Government sees selling its 75 percent stake in Inmos as the best way to recoup Britain's $88 million direct investment and $47 million in loan guarantees. A sale would also free Inmos to raise the money it needs for further expansion without placing new burdens on Britain's taxpayers.

headline: DEPARTURE OF A CHINESE RAISES SOME QUESTIONS
abstract: A lawyer for a Chinese businessman who sought political asylum in the United States last spring has questioned the State Department's contention that his client returned to his homeland voluntarily.   The businessman, Zhang Zhenggao, a 46-year-old engineer, asked for asylum last April after making a dramatic escape from the Chinese Consulate in New York.    State Department officials said Saturday that the United States was satisfied that Mr. Zhang left for China ''of his own volition.''    But his lawyer, Robert Belluscio of Flushing, Queens, said today that the Federal agency handling the case told him it had no idea why Mr. Zhang suddenly left the United States on July 19.

headline: NICARAGUA REBEL AID SHELVED
abstract: House Republican leaders decided today to give up any immediate effort to gain House approval for aid to Nicaraguan rebels, aides to the lawmakers said.   In a morning leadership meeting, the aides said, Robert H. Michel, the minority leader, and other senior Republicans concluded that they could not win a vote on restoring money for the rebels in the intelligence authorization bill for the 1985 fiscal year that is scheduled to come up for floor debate on Thursday.

headline: Division Chief Leaves Becker John Ward, the executive in
abstract: charge of the commercial   paper division of Becker Paribas, joined Paine Webber yesterday afternoon, a Paine Webber official said.

headline: 'VOLUNTARY' IMPORT RESTRAINT
abstract: President Reagan's decision Tuesday to ask other countries to limit their steel shipments to the United States was presented by the White House as upholding the principles of free trade. But the recent history of ''voluntary'' export restraint suggests it is potentially the most protectionist action this Administration has yet taken.    Although the White House said the President was rejecting the mandatory quotas sought by American steel producers and the United Steelworkers, the practical effect of Mr. Reagan's decision will be little different.    ''We are moving toward globally managed trade in steel, similar to what already exists in textiles,'' commented Robert Z. Lawrence, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.   Barely noticed among documents handed out by the White House Tuesday in connection with the Presidential decision was a 12-page list of all the ''unfair'' trade practices of just about every steel-producing nation.

headline: THE DOLLAR RESUMES ITS BOLD ASCENT
abstract: The mighty dollar staged a major surge last week after a quiet August, establishing new highs against many of the world's biggest currencies. On Friday, the dollar had one of its biggest single-day gains. Bolstered by expectations of higher U.S. interest rates and an unwillingness by investors to sell dollars, the currency rose to record highs against the British pound, French franc, Italian lira and an 11 1/2- year high against the West German mark. Analysts had expected the dollar to weaken during August. ''The correction that was in all the charts didn't happen,'' one trader said, and many now expect the dollar to maintain its current high level for a long time. Much of the buying that continued to push the dollar higher evidently came from major corporations that will need dollars for their operations later this month. And that buying is expected to continue to keep the currency high.      Car prices are edging upward again. Ford and Nissan joined General Motors, Chrysler and American Motors in increasing the average sticker price of its 1985-model cars. Ford announced tentative plans for a 1.9 percent, or $225 per car, increase, and Nissan announced a $113 per car rise. The total increase for 1985 cars will come close to the 2 percent markup predicted by analysts for the model year that starts Oct. 1. Meanwhile, new car sales for the middle August period rose 11.6 percent over a year earlier.

headline: No Headline
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: I.C.L. Agrees To Be Acquired LONDON, Aug. 16 - International Computers Ltd. P.L.C., the largest British computer maker, agreed today to a $552.5 million takeover bid from Standard Telephones and Cables P.L.C., a leading producer of telecommunications systems.
abstract: The merger would create a company with 51,000 employees and total sales of about $2.6 billion.

headline: New Leader Is Elected With Ease in St. Vincent
abstract: Election officials said today that the New Democrats, led by James Mitchell, had routed the incumbent Labor Party and replaced Milton Cato as Prime Minister in elections held Wednesday. The New Democrats won 9 of the 13 seats in Parliament, they said.

headline: Futures/Options; Credit Risk And Ways Of Hedging
abstract: ECONOMISTS may debate whether interest rates will rise or fall, but professional traders of financial futures are far more concerned with the risks being assumed by today's lenders, rather than what they charge borrowers.    The reason is that while interest rates can be increased to cover risks or hedged in spot, forward or futures and options markets, the ability to collect owed funds from borrowers can not be thus insured.    ''This helps explain why bankers keep raising their prime and other lending rates while the inflation rate, if not actually falling, has been pretty much under control,'' said John M. Blin, partner in Shatkin Investing Inc., Chicago. He is an architect of several financial futures markets and a former professor of economics at Northwestern University.

headline: Polish Spokesman Rules Out An Improvement in U.S. Ties
abstract: A Polish Government spokesman today ruled out any improvement in relations with the United States until there was a change in the ''illogical, absurd and unjust'' policies toward Poland.   The spokesman, Jerzy Urban, spoke in an interview after publication of a critique of United States policies in Trybuna Ludu, the party daily.    Trybuna Ludu indicated that Poland would be willing to upgrade relations by exchanging ambassadors, but Mr. Urban said United States policies would have to change first.

headline: LETTERS ; Mortgage Money
abstract: To the Editor:      Stephen Roach's article (''In Fact, Assets Balance Out Liabilities,'' Forum, Aug. 19) depicting adjustable-rate mortgages as a financial godsend for consumers is an example of how an economist using bad statistics can make good business sense. Mr. Roach says that almost everyone (83 percent) has switched to some form of money market savings account, which adds up to $1.8 trillion. He says that 12.5 percent, or $1.6 trillion, of mortgages are A.R.M. mortgages. Mr. Roach's conclusion: Consumers' assets outnumber their liabilities even when interest rates rise.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; 2 Vice Chairmen At Arthur Young
abstract: Alfred W. Roberts and Lawrence D. Behm, two senior partners at Arthur Young, the Big Eight accounting firm, have been named to the new positions of vice chairmen, William L. Gladstone, managing partner, announced yesterday.     The creation of the new posts was characterized by Mr. Gladstone as representing a significant organizational restructuring of top management responsibilities.    The vice chairmen will report directly to Mr. Gladstone.

headline: ZIMBABWE PLANS ONE-PARTY RULE BUT DOES NOT SEEK HASTY CHANGE
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's ruling party adopted a new party constitution today calling for the creation of a Marxist-oriented, one-party state in this Western-modeled democracy.    The party decided that the transformation would take place ''in the fullness of time and in accordance with the law and the Constitution.''    The formula appeared to have been designed by the congress to assuage fears among Western aid donors, potential investors and the nation's economically pivotal white minority that single-party rule was imminent. The party congress, the first in 20 years, ended tonight. Some 6,000 delegates attended.

headline: Vietnam Accuses China
abstract: Vietnam said today that Chinese gunners fired 5,000 rounds into the northern Vietnamese province of Ha Tuyen over the last 10 days, killing or wounding 10 people in the most serious incident last Tuesday.

headline: Assets of Money Funds Drop $540 Million
abstract: The assets of the nation's 340 money market mutual funds continued to decline in the week ended Wednesday, dropping $540 million, to $179.27 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   Yesterday's report marks the third consecutive weekly decline.

headline: The U.N. Today July 12, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Market Place; Best Month Since Late '82
abstract: The opening days of August served up a sizzling rally for the stock market. Groups that   went on to excel for the entire month ranged from semiconductors and paper containers to toys and hospital management.    Blue-chip stocks generally were in vogue, sending the Dow Jones industrial average ahead 9.78 percent during August. ''It was the best one-month advance since the industrials rose 10.65 percent in October 1982,'' said Richard Anstett, technical analyst for the Toronto Stock Exchange.

headline: Syrian Soldiers Move Into Lebanese Villages
abstract: Syrian Army troops moved into several Christian villages in northern Lebanon today to enforce a cease-fire between two pro-Syrian militias fighting for dominance of the region's farmlands, the state television said.   Leaders of the rival militia groups agreed in Damascus to withdraw from the battle zone after President Hafez al-Assad threatened to use Syrian troops against both of them.

headline: Chinese Party Official Jailed
abstract: Yi Yaowen, a Communist Party deputy secretary from Shanxi province, has been jailed for six years for raping a 19- year-old woman in 1977, the New China News Agency said today.

headline: UTAH TO OFFER NO-CERTIFICATE BONDS
abstract: New issues in the debt markets this week will be highlighted by a sale of what is likely to be a harbinger of things to come: the paperless municipal bond.    On Wednesday Utah will offer for competitive bidding $10 million worth of general obligation bonds. Sealed bids will be received in book entry form.

headline: No Milwaukee Road Buyer Named
abstract: The Interstate Commerce Commission failed today to recommend to a bankruptcy court which of four companies should be permitted to purchase the financially troubled Milwaukee Road.   A spokesman, Dennis Watson, said that because the four-member regulatory agency could not unanimously agree on a purchaser, a bankruptcy court in Illinois might have to act on its own.

headline: BRITON BUYS THE MIRROR CHAIN
abstract: The publisher Robert Maxwell completed negotiations today to buy the Mirror Group of newspapers from Reed International Ltd. for $148 million.   The Mirror Group comprises The Daily Mirror, one of Britain's largest circulation tabloids, as well as The Sunday Mirror, The Sunday People, The Sporting Life, The Scottish Daily Record and Sunday Mail, and a 5.8 percent share in Reuters. Mr. Maxwell has been trying for 15 years to buy a major national newspaper.

headline: NICARAGUA CONFIRMS IT IS BUILDING MILITARY AIRPORT
abstract: Nicaragua officially acknowledged today that it is building a large military airport, as the Reagan Administration has asserted, and took journalists on a tour of it. Officials said it could be operational by the end of next year.   The head of the Nicaraguan Air Force, Comdr. Raul Venerio, said he was ''awaiting new combat planes from various countries.'' He did not specify the types of aircraft.

headline: Mozambican Guerrillas Report Military Gains
abstract: Right- wing Mozambican rebels said they killed 143 Government soldiers, wounded 119 and captured 37 in operations between June 22 and 30.   A communique issued here Sunday night by the Mozambican National Resistance also said a bridge over the Pungu e River near the port of Beira was blown up, electricity lines between the capital, Maputo, and South Africa were sabotaged and a train was destroyed.

headline: P.L.O. Factions Are Planning Council Meeting Next Month
abstract: Representatives of the five main factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization agreed today to call a meeting of the Palestine National Council by mid-September to try to end their disputes.   The meeting would bring together for the first time in more than two years the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, and some of the rebel leaders who forced him and his Fatah guerrillas to leave the northern Lebanese port city of Tripoli after heavy fighting last December.

headline: LIMITING TAX BREAKS FOR COMPUTERS
abstract: FIVE years ago, Harvey Horowitz, a partner    with the New York law firm of Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent & Lehrer, purchased a Radio Shack TRS-80 computer for his home.    Mr. Horowitz paid $1,000 for the basic computer. He spent another $2,000 to upgrade it by adding memory capacity and buying a printer and a modem, a telephone connection device.   The Internal Revenue Service subsidized a portion of his cost because he used the computer at times for investment purposes and for law firm business.

headline: SOUTH AFRICANS HONE THEIR TACTICS AND ATTITUDES
abstract: Summer is stirring in South Africa now, a season, this year, of omens and unrest.    The economy, brought low by fallen gold prices, drought and spending by Government agencies, is in its worst recession in years.   Labor unrest has provoked confrontation between armed policemen and black gold miners and seems unlikely to abate.   And, most strikingly of all, the country has entered its most prolonged conflict between the white authorities and disaffected blacks since the uprisings of 1976 that started in Soweto and claimed, in the end, more than 500 lives.   In the arithmetic of unrest, the latest contortion of violence has been smaller than that in 1976. So far, fewer than 60 people have died in a month of conflict that has not, to date, spread across the land in the manner of the upheaval eight years ago.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLLE ; ;  Pharmacia of Sweden In Management Shifts
abstract: A number of top management changes were put into effect yesterday at Pharmacia A.B., the diversified health-care company that was the first Swedish company to issue shares in the United States.   The changes, which were approved by the board of directors at the company's annual meeting last May, are led by the appointment of Gunnar Wessman, 56, as chairman. Mr. Wessman, who has served as president and chief executive at Pharmacia since May 1980, succeeds Kurt Mark, 55, who resigned.

headline: Dealer Testifies In 'Hitler Diaries' Trial
abstract: A dealer in Nazi memorabilia, Konrad Kujau, testified today that a journalist talked him into forging 62 volumes of ''Hitler diaries'' by offering him money and treasures from Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy.   The West German magazine Stern paid $3.6 million for the diaries.

headline: Six Flags in Baltimore
abstract: The Six Flags Corporation, a subsidiary of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, operates family entertainment parks out in the countryside in five states. Now it is moving into an urban location, opening Six Flags Power Plant in a building near downtown Baltimore. It plans to spend $1 million to promote it and has selected a local agency, Richardson, Myers & Donofrio, to handle it.

headline: Liberia Links Speaker of Assembly to a Plot
abstract: The Speaker of Liberia's interim National Assembly, Maj. Gen. Nicholas Podier, has been detained in connection with a plot to overthrow the Government, the Justice Ministry said tonight.

headline: MAY GAINS
abstract: Six major retailers yesterday reported mixed earnings results in the second fiscal quarter as booming retail sales began to cool off.     Earnings rose 8.3 percent at the Dayton-Hudson Corporation, 19.4 percent at the May Department Stores Company, 5.7 percent at the Associated Dry Goods Corporation and 3.7 percent at the Allied Stores Corporatio. However, they fell 10.9 percent at the J. C. Penney Company and 13.8 percent at Federated Department Stores.    Despite the positive record over all, retail stocks fell sharply on Wall Street in response to a Department of Commerce report that nationwide retail sales slipped by nine-tenths of 1 percent during July.

headline: CHIP MAKERS UNDER PRESSURE
abstract: In the antiseptic ''clean rooms'' of semiconductor manufacturers, the pressure on employees to work quickly is palpable. With demand booming, an extra step or delay in the enormously complex process of fabricating microchips can cost the company hundreds of thousands of dollars in profits.
