This week, the perils of success were brought home to the industry.    On Monday, Texas Instruments Inc. acknowledged that some chips leaving its Midland, Tex., plant might not have been tested in accordance with the rigid specifications of some of the Defense Department's leading contractors.   While no equipment failures have yet been traced to the chips, the parts are now embedded in some of the nation's most sophisticated weaponry. It was the second case of its kind this year; in March, the National Semiconductor Corporation pleaded guilty to a similar charge.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Trinidad Buys Texaco Assets PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad   and Tobago, Sept. 2 (AP) -   The Government of Trinidad   and Tobago has purchased   major assets of Texaco-Trinidad Inc., an oil company, for  $175 million after two years of   negotiations, Prime Minister   George Chambers reported.

headline: Export-Aid Loans Set
abstract: The Export-Import Bank and the Small Business Administration announced today a program of loans to increase exports by small American business.   The Federal agencies said they would guarantee bank loans of up to $1 million each for small American business export projects.

headline: PAKISTAN RULE SAYS U.S. AND WEST ARE TOO SOFT ON DRUG DEALERS
abstract: President Mohammad Zia ul- Haq, said today that he is willing to introduce the death penalty in Pakistan for drug traffickers but that he feels hampered because of ''soft laws'' for drug offenses in the West.   General Zia said in an interview that the United States and Western Europe must adopt more stringent laws if the drug problem is to be eliminated.    General Zia acknowledged that Pakistan is a major supplier of heroin, but he said efforts to eradicate the trade are useless as long as countries continue giving ''two-month jail terms for selling heroin on the open street.''   ''I must be given a full hand by all those involved in this,'' he said. ''But your laws are not severe at all. Until this gap of a man buying a kilo of heroin for $100 and selling it for $1 million is reduced and the punishments are enhanced, this business will carry on.''

headline: U-Haul Layoffs
abstract: U-Haul International Inc. will lay off approximately 4,000 workers nationwide - up to a quarter of its work force - because of an inability to market new rental-line products, company officials said. U-Haul, the nation's largest truck and trailer rental company, expanded two years ago into renting a variety of different items, including party goods, sporting goods, recreational equipment and vehicles, as well as construction equipment and other items.

headline: Gasoline Prices Decline Again LOS ANGELES, July 29
abstract: Gasoline prices have   dropped for the 11th consecutive week, to one of the lowest   levels in the past five years, an   oil industry analyst, Dan Lundberg, said today. The average price as of July   27 for all brands of gasoline, including taxes, was $1.1835 a   gallon, a drop of 2.9 cents since   May 11, when it was $1.2128,   Mr. Lundberg said. The last   time prices were this low was   in February and March 1983.

headline: PENTAGON ISSUES NEWS GUIDELINES FOR COMBAT ZONES
abstract: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger made public today a panel's recommendations to provide access to military operations for news organizations, and he gave orders to put the recommendations into effect.   But Mr. Weinberger made it clear that military security would remain the paramount consideration in guidelines for news coverage.    The panel, composed of officers and journalists, was headed by Maj. Gen. Winant Sidle, a retired chief of information for the Army. It was convened after the United States invasion of Grenada in October 1983.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Docutel/Olivetti Shift
abstract: The Docutel/Olivetti Corporation said yesterday that B. J. Meredith had resigned as chairman. Mr. Meredith will be succeeded by Giovanni Fei, 59 years old, who is currently chief executive officer. Mr. Fei will retain the title of chief executive.

headline: Polish Zloty Is Devalued
abstract: Poland's central bank today announced a 10.6 percent devaluation of the zloty against the dollar as a way to increase exports.

headline: BEHIND BECKER'S UNHAPPY BREAKUP
abstract: On Monday morning, Aug. 6, the denizens of Wall Street arrived at work with a sense of glee. Only a few days earlier, the stock market - finally - had snapped out of its year-long slump and had started to generate the heady gains that reminded brokers of the glory days of August 1982. There was money in the air that morning and everyone felt it.     But at 55 Water St., in the three upper floors that made up the headquarters of Becker Paribas Inc., there was only apprehension. For days it had been abuzz with rumors that its French banking parent, the venerable Compagnie Financi ere de Paris et des Pays-Bas, was preparing to bail out because of Becker's heavy losses.    By 9:30, Becker employees watching the Dow Jones news wire spotted the announcement: Merrill Lynch would acquire Becker Paribas for $100 million in Merrill shares but would absorb only a few hundred of the firm's 2,000 employees. As the rest of Wall Street scrambled to begin trading at 10 A.M., with the delight of children on a Christmas morning, Becker's brokers and traders were staggered.

headline: Shutdown At Midland Is Ordered
abstract: The Consumers Power Company said today that it would shut down its $4 billion Midland nuclear power plant, after failing to reach agreement on rates with its biggest industrial customers.    Officials of Consumers said that, while it would be physically possible to revive the project, the economic forces that set off the shutdown would most likely prevent its resumption. The resistance by the utility's industrial customers, led by the General Motors Corporation, ''puts us in a nonfinancial position with regard to getting the money to finish the plant,'' said John S. Selby, the chairman of the utility. He added that the board of directors had unanimously approved the shutdown and that no further negotiations were scheduled.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Aug. 9, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Special Committee Against Apartheid - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: NEW FRENCH GOVERNMENT UNVEILS A SURPRISE PACKAGE OF TAX CUTS
abstract: France's new Socialist Cabinet announced a surprise package of income tax cuts within hours of taking office today and promised futher tax cuts in the years ahead.    The tax cuts, approved at a Cabinet meeting immediately after the Government was formed, will take effect next year and should reduce the average French worker's bill for income tax and social security by about 8 percent, a Government spokesman said.   The reductions are intended to start fulfilling President Francois Mitterrand's earlier commitment to reduce the burden of direct taxation in France. From enjoying one of the lowest direct tax burdens in the West, France has become one of the most highly taxed countries since the Socialists came to power three years ago.

headline: Allnet Contract
abstract: Allnet Communication Services Inc. said it had signed a one-year agreement with five telecommunication companies of Ameritech for selective billing services. The companies - Illinois Bell, Indiana Bell, Michigan Bell, Ohio Bell and Wisconsin Bell - will bill Allnet customers who use the company's long-distance network.

headline: 19 in Grenada Face Trial In Slayings
abstract: A Grenada magistrate ordered 19 former Government and army officials today to stand trial in the slayings of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop and seven supporters.   The magistrate, Lyle St. Paul, who heard testimony for six weeks in a preliminary inquiry, ordered one defendant, Ian St. Bernard, the former Commissioner of Police, set free.

headline: TIMERMAN JOINS ARGENTINE PAPER BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 15 (AP) - Jacobo Timerman, the journalist and best-selling author who was jailed, tortured and expelled by Argentina's former military regime, said today that he is taking over as editor of the Buenos Aires daily La Razon.
abstract: He said he also plans to restart La Opinion, the newspaper he owned and operated until its seizure by the military regime when he was arrested in 1977. Only a few details need to be resolved with printers before publication resumes, Mr. Timerman said.

headline: Basques Protest in France
abstract: Supporters of seven Spanish Basque refugees threatened with extradition from France today occupied two town halls in the French Basque country in a peaceful two-hour protest, witnesses said. They said 25 people at Ispoure and about 30 in Hendaye entered the town halls with anti-Government posters to protest against court rulings that France should extradite the seven, who are wanted in Spain to face charges of murder and assault.

headline: FED ROLE IN FUNDS RATE RISE DENIED
abstract: A governor of the Federal Reserve Board said that nothing in the Fed's current policies could explain rises since late August in an important interest rate that influences all other rates.    The governor, J. Charles Partee, left the impression that the central bank's policy-making committee agreed at its meeting Aug. 21 and 22 to maintain its current posture on interest rates, bank reserves and the money supply.    The early-August rallies of the stock and bond markets fizzled partly because investors interpreted minutes of the July meeting, published Aug. 24, as signaling a tougher Fed policy. Minutes of the August meeting are not expected until early next month.

headline: BULGARIAN LEADER CALLS OFF BONN VISIT
abstract: The leader of Bulgaria has called off a scheduled visit to West Germany, a Bonn Government spokesman disclosed today.    The move by the Bulgarian leader, Todor Zhivkov, became known five days after the East German leader, Erich Honecker, canceled a trip here, apparently in response to heavy Soviet pressure.   The West German spokesman, J"urgen Sudhoff, said Bulgaria had informed Chancellor Helmut Kohl that the Zhivkov visit, scheduled for Sept. 19 to Sept. 22, would have to be postponed. Bulgarian diplomats were said to have attributed the decision to the deployment of new American medium-range missiles in Western Europe and to current North Atlantic Treaty Organization maneuvers.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Steel Output
abstract: Shows Drop By The Associated Press Steel production fell to 1.523   million tons in the week ended   last Saturday, a decrease of 3   percent from the previous   week's 1.570 million tons, the   American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

headline: U.S. Sub Visits Singapore
abstract: The United States nuclear-powered submarine Omaha has arrived in Singapore for a five-day visit after routine operations in the Pacific, the United States Embassy said today.

headline: Daon Sells Land
abstract: The Daon Development Corporation said it had sold 2,050 acres of citrus and avocado farmland in Riverside County, Calif., to Foothills Properties for $25 million. Daon said most of the land, acquired in 1981, is within the city limits of Corona. Under the sale agreement, Daon said it would begin proceedings to obtain subdivision approvals and would be compensated for the work.

headline: Louisiana Banks Agree to Merge
abstract: Three Lousiana banking companies have agreed to merge, creating the biggest banking organization in the state, it was announced yesterday.

headline: THE DOLLAR'S OVERSEAS ROLE
abstract: THE continued strength of the United States    dollar in relation to other world currencies   bites into the earnings of domestic corporations that conduct a substantial portion of their business overseas. Manufacturers of drugs and cosmetics have been affected adversely by a strong dollar. Other companies deriving a significant portion of their revenues from abroad range from electronics test equipment manufacturers to producers of oil well equipment.    Money managers in this country who supervise international portfolios would generally welcome weakness in the dollar, since that would provide a fillip to their securities holdings abroad. During the past year or so, however, repeated forecasts of a downturn in the dollar have not materialized.

headline: Uruguay Vows to Free 154 Political Prisoners
abstract: The military Government has said that it will release 154 political prisoners, delivering on a promise it made to political groups during recent negotiations on returning the country to civilian rule.   A Government communique issued late Friday said the Supreme Military Council had decided to free 154 of 400 people imprisoned for subversion whose cases had been reviewed. But it said it would keep another 181 in jail and did not make a final decision in the other 65 cases.

headline: Korean Car Exports
abstract: South Korea exported 25,816 cars in the first seven months of this year, surpassing the 24,510 units exported in all of 1983, the Trade and Industry Ministry said. Domestic sales in the seven months rose 8.5 percent to 122,342 vehicles from 112,780 in the 1983 period, it said. Ministry officials said 1984 car exports would exceed 40,000 units.

headline: Advertising; Needham Is New All Over
abstract: largest ad agency, last week got a new chief executive, a new name, a new board and a new corporate structure.     Keith Reinhard, 49-year-old former copy writer, was elected chairman and chief executive, stepping in behind Paul C. Harper Jr., 63, the chief executive for 20 years.    ''What Keith and I agreed to,'' said the latter, ''was that we would work for a seamless management transition with a view that it should come as no surprise to our people, our clients or anyone else.''

headline: Norway Exports to U.S.
abstract: The value of Norway's exports to the United States surged to 5.6 billion kroner, or $676 million, in 1983, an 80 percent jump from 3.1 billion kroner in 1982.

headline: Iranians Accuse Swede Of Favoring U.S. Claims
abstract: Two Iranian judges who hit a Swedish fellow judge this month at the tribunal settling American and Iranian financial claims defended their actions today and accused the Swede of favoring American claimants.   The United States has demanded that Iran replace the two judges, Mahmoud M. Kashani and Shafey Shafeiei, but Teheran has not replied.

headline: Sallie Mae Notes
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association is offering, through various securities dealers, $200 million of floating-rate notes due Feb. 14, 1985. Interest on the notes is paid at maturity but is adjusted weekly at three- tenths of a percentage point above the average bond equivalent yield for 91- day Treasury bills set at the Treasury's weekly auctions. At yesterday's auction, the average bond equivalent yield was 10.99 percent.

headline: PROTESTS INCREASE IN THE PHILIPPINES
abstract: Anti-Government demonstrations are increasing in frequency as the first anniversary of the death of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. approaches, and the protest leaders seem to have ambitious goals.    For the last month, demonstrations, ranging in size from a few hundred to more than 20,000 marchers, have been staged in Manila at roughly weekly intervals. Some of the protest leaders have demanded the resignation of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, and others say their purpose is to force Mr. Marcos to hold presidential elections before his term expires in 1987.   Frequently, the police have dispersed the demonstrators with tear gas, riot sticks and fire hoses, and the Government has been widely criticized for the methods it has used. On Monday, these tactics were used to break up a rally of about 2,000 marchers, with 16 people reported injured.

headline: 'THINGS ARE SIMMERING NOW' FOR THE PHILIPPINES
abstract: Soon after 7 A.M. each day, Cabinet ministers, politicians, corporate executives and newspaper columnists begin filing into the coffee shop of the Hotel Inter- Continental here.  Seated in wicker chairs around a few circular tables, they discuss yesterday's news and today's gossip. This high- powered kaffeeklatsch is called the 365 Club, so named for the regularity of its sessions. Its entirely informal deliberations are generally lively, but recently the decibel level has risen and the debates have become more spirited.    ''We are heading for a confluence of important events'' in the Philippines, Blas F. Ople, the Minister of Labor, explained during a pause in the oratorical fray the other morning. ''Things are simmering now.''

headline: Levine, Huntley Gets Telecom Plus Account
abstract: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver has picked up the Telecom Plus International account, and the client reports it will bill $3 million.

headline: 2 Iranians Fly to Iraq In an F-4 Fighter Jet
abstract: Two Iranians flew their F-4 fighter jet to an Iraqi airport today and were granted political asylum, a military spokesman said. It was the first Iranian military plane known to have landed here in four years of war between the two countries.   The American-made Phantom jet arrived a day after the Minister of ture and Information, Latif Nsayyef Jassem, announced that Iraq was ''ready to receive any Iranian plane.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: An Unusual Fund    Among all 320 money market mutual funds, one of the most unusual is the Working Assets Money Fund, based in San Francisco. Founded a year ago, it includes among its investment criteria a social and economic impact test.

headline: CORSICAN VOTE: NEW MEETS OLD BUT THEY SELDOM MIX
abstract: There were 10 parties and 610 candidates, but as he shook hands with voters at their polling place here this morning, Clement Biggi seemed unconcerned.    Mr. Biggi is the son of the Mayor of this town of stone houses cut into the mountainside about 10 miles from the Mediterranean city of Ajaccio. He knew everyone, it seemed, and did not have to say a word or hand out a leaflet to the voters know he expected them to vote for the main conservative opposition slate, on which his father was a candidate. ''Good morning'' was enough.   The voters seemed ready to oblige. To cast a ballot, they collected the lists of the 10 parties in competition, went into a polling booth, put one of the lists into the envelope, threw the rest away and put the envelope into an urn.

headline: EX-HEAD OF F.A.A. IS CHARGED
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged J. Lynn Helms, the former head of the Federal Aviation Administration, and a business partner with diverting $1.2 million from an issue of tax-exempt municipal bonds to their personal use.    The complaint, and a consent order signed by Mr. Helms, were filed simultaneously in Federal District Court in Philadelphia, settling the case against him.    The consent order did not require Mr. Helms to return any of the money that he was said to have funneled either to companies he owned or to his personal use.    A S.E.C. official said that today's filing and subsequent settlement ended its action against Mr. Helms. However, two Federal grand juries and the Justice Department are reportedly investigating his dealings.

headline: ADDENDUM
abstract: * Doyle Dane Bernbach International has acquired a minority interest in Brown, Christensen & Associates in New Zealand.

headline: MOSCOW GOSSIP: EMBASSY JOGGING AND NEWS OF CRIME
abstract: This has been an autumn of political mysteries in Moscow. How sick is Konstantin U. Chernenko? Why is Andrei A. Gromyko meeting with President Reagan? Why was Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov dismissed as Chief of Staff?    Diplomats whose job it is to explain such events to their governments have played out endless variations on the facts: a weak leadership floundering under an ailing leader . . . A strong leadership relegating its senior member to a ceremonial role . . . A power struggle between the Old Guard and Young Turks . . . A power struggle already concluded, with the baton passing to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the leadership's youngster at 53 . . . Or to Grigory V. Romanov, 60.   The buzz at diplomatic receptions has been: Who is mentioned how often in the press? Who might have gained or lost by the dismissal of Marshal Ogarkov? Whose programs are being promoted or criticized?   Award to Chernenko at 73      The focus today was the award of an Order of Lenin to Mr. Chernenko. It appeared keyed to his 73d birthday today, although the occasion was not mentioned. The timing seemed unusual since decorations are generally presented on ''round dates.'' For example, the Moscow city leader, Viktor V. Grishin, who is also a Politburo member, got his Order of Lenin when he became 70 last Tuesday.

headline: 3 HIJACKERS IN IRAN TAKE HOSTAGES OFF JET, BLOW IT UP AND SURRENDER
abstract: Three hijackers holding a French jetliner at the airport here took their hostages off the plane today, set off an explosion in the plane and then surrendered.   Security men surrounding the plane since it landed here early Wednesday said the hijackers had first taken the approximately 45 passengers and 5 crew members about 200 yards from the Boeing 737 and ordered them to lie down.   Then a blast shook the Air France jet, causing damage to the cockpit, and the hijackers gave themselves up with hands held high in the air.

headline: WEST GERMANS HOLD A BIG ARMS PROTEST
abstract: A week of protests designed to disrupt North Atlantic Treaty Organization maneuvers ended today with an antin uclear arms demonstration by tens of thousands of people here.     The police estimated that 20,000 to 30,000 people formed four human chains along roads linking Fulda with nearby United States military bases. Organizers had predicted that as many as 120,000 people would take part in the protest today.

headline: People
abstract: *  Alan Pando was named a partner in Della Femina, Travisano & Partners.     *  Leonard H. Habas was named president of Carnegie Publications.

headline: Boston Stock Exchange Tie
abstract: The Boston Stock Exchange said today that it had agreed to link its trading floor electronically with the Montreal Exchange.

headline: INSURANCE SALES BEGIN AT 2 CITIBANK BRANCES
abstract: Citibank, which has said that it wants to add insurance to its array of financial products, began offering life insurance policies yesterday through an insurance company at two of its New York City branches.    Under the arrangement, term, universal and whole-life policies will be sold at Citibank by salaried employees of the American International Life Assurance Company of New York. The company, a member of the American International Group, which took in more than $1 billion in life insurance premiums last year, has leased space in Citibank branches.

headline: Bid by Rumasa Ex-Chief
abstract: Jose Maria Ruiz Mateos, sought by Spanish authorities on fraud charges stemming from the near-collapse of his Rumasa conglomerate, has applied for political asylum in West Germany, his attorneys said today. Fraud charges were filed against Mr. Ruiz Mateos after the Spanish Government nationalized Rumasa, Spain's biggest conglomerate, last year, saying the move was necessary to stave off a financial failure. The attorneys said that the asylum petition cited politically motivated ''persecution'' at home and added that the charges did not warrant extradition.

headline: Dow Loses 12.03, Closing at 1,212.35
abstract: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in sluggish trading, as investors continued to display growing apprehension over interest rates.    The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout the session, ended off 12.03 points, at 1,212.35. Reflecting the market's weakness, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose by more than 2-to-1.

headline: MOVE BY HONDURAS ON REBELS?
abstract: Honduras has ordered Nicaraguan exiles to shut down their guerrilla command center, a high-ranking military official said today.   The official said the exile group, the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, had also been told to close a training camp and a 120-bed hospital.

headline: PATENTS ; 3 at N.Y.U. Develop New Malaria Vaccine
abstract: A malaria vaccine was patented this week for New York University.

headline: Moslem Group Asserts It Is Holding Reporter
abstract: A group calling itself the Moslem Socialist Revolutionary Organization said today that it was holding Jonathan Wright, a Reuters correspondent who disappeared in Lebanon six days ago.   The group telephoned a statement to the office of Al Arab, an Arabic-language newspaper here.

headline: BOND PRICES OFF MODERATELY
abstract: Bond prices slipped in light trading in the credit markets yesterday, amid profit taking and Government reports showing that the economy continues to expand at a rapid clip.    ''The market turned in a pretty good performance, considering all the bad news it got,'' said William N. Griggs, of Griggs & Santow Inc., financial consultants. ''The economic figures that were released seem to argue for an upward revision in the second-quarter gross national product figures.''    In its initial ''flash'' estimate of growth in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said that, on an inflation-adjusted basis, the economy expanded by 5.7 percent. A revision of that figure is scheduled to be released on Monday.

headline: The U.N. Today July 19, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: 40 DIE AFTER RESCUE OFF BRAZIL
abstract: Forty people escaped a fire on an offshore oil platform today but then drowned when a rescue boat carrying them to safety capsized in heavy seas.   A spokesman for Petrobras, the state oil company, said at least 16 others had been injured, 6 seriously, in the fire aboard the Enchova platform 60 miles off the coast.

headline: Amcast Contract
abstract: The Amcast Industrial Corporation said it had received a three-year agreement valued at $100 million to supply aluminum parts for air-conditioning compressors for the Harrison Radiator division of the General Motors Corporation. Amcast said the supply contract is for the complete line of air-conditioning compressors that Harrison assembles for all G.M. cars and trucks.

headline: Securities Firm Censure
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had censured and limited the operations of the Manhattan securities firm of Verrilli, Altschuler, Schwartz Inc. It also prohibited the firm's principals, M. Richard Verrilli, Stanley Altschuler and Stephen Schwartz, from associating with any broker-dealer for six months.   The commission said the firm and its principals sold unregistered shares of Massive Energy Ltd., a Canadian corporation, in 1981 and 1982, and failed to disclose to customers that they controlled the company.

headline: SOVIET UNION, CITING INEFFICENCY, GROUNDS ITS SUPERSONIC AIRLINER
abstract: The Soviet Union's supersonic jetliner, which opened its passenger service with an ear-splitting roar from a snowy airfield six and a half years ago, has been grounded, a Soviet official confirmed today.    A senior official of the Soviet airline, Aeroflot, said development and operations of the TU-144 had been abandoned ''for the present.''   ''We are not going to use it,'' said Nikolai Poluyanchik, head of Aeroflot's international traffic division, at a news conference. ''We are simply not prepared to use an aircraft which has proved inefficient.''

headline: OFFICIAL OF UNESCO VOWS AGENCY WILL REFUND $80 MILLION SURPLUS
abstract: A senior Unesco official said today that the organization would eventually repay member governments about $80 million in unspent funds, but not before the end of this year.    The United States, which plans to withdraw from Unesco at the end of this year unless it changes its political emphasis and curbs spending, is pressing for return of the money immediately, with support from all of the other Western member countries.   As a result of the dispute, five of these countries - the United States, Britain, West Germany, the Netherlands and Switzerland - are currently witholding their contributions to this year's Unesco budget. Switzerland, although it is not a member of the United Nations, belongs to Unesco.

headline: MONDALE OFFERS HIS 'FULL SUPPORT' TO APPROPRIATE COUNTERMEASURES
abstract: Walter F. Mondale said today that President Reagan would have his support ''for appropriate countermeasures'' against those responsible for the attack on the United States Embassy in Beirut.    Mr. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential candidate campaigning here, said in a one-paragraph statement:   ''I join with all Americans in expressing my shock and outrage at this latest terrorist assault on our diplomatic personnel. I wish to extend my deepest sympathies to the families of those who have been killed or injured in this tragedy. If the perpetrators of this deed can be identified, I want President Reagan to know that he has my full support for appropriate countermeasures.''

headline: Core Repurchase
abstract: Core Industries said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 500,000 shares of its common stock.

headline: LEVI FALLS
abstract: R. H. Macy & Company yesterday reported a 4.9 percent gain in its fourth-quarter net income, a relatively small rise compared with its usual double-digit increases, while Levi Strauss & Company said its net income fell 65.3 percent in its third quarter.     In the quarter ended July 28, Macy's earnings were $44.8 million, or 88 cents a share, up from $42.7 million, or 85 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 13.6 percent, to $918.9 million, from $809 million in the 1983 quarter. In the full year, income increased 18.8 percent, to $221.8 million, or $4.37 a share, from $186.7 million, or $3.72 a share.

headline: Centex President Quits, But Will Stay on Board
abstract: Jack L. McDonald, president and chief operating officer of the Centex Corporation, has resigned to pursue personal business interests, the company announced. Mr. McDonald's resignation is effective Nov. 15, but the company said he would remain a member of its board.     Paul R. Seegers, vice chairman and co-chief executive at the Dallas- based company, said that a successor had not yet been named.

headline: MARSH & MCLENNAN REPLACING PRESIDENT
abstract: Marsh & McLennan Companies, the giant insurance brokerage firm that absorbed major bond trading losses last spring, said yesterday it would replace L. Patton Kline as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Kline, 55 years old, is scheduled to be elected a vice chairman in September at the company's next regularly scheduled board meeting.     Slated to replace him is Frank J. Tasco, 56, president of Marsh & McLennan's reinsurance subsidiary.    Asked if the move stemmed from the company's recent $90 million after-tax loss because of unauthorized bond trading, John M. Regan Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, said, ''Absolutely not. We might have made this same announcement a little earlier, in fact, if we had not had that problem.''

headline: Beatrice-Esmark
abstract: The Beatrice Companies said it had completed its $2.7 billion acquisition of Esmark Inc., making it the world's largest food and consumer products company.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECHES BY WORLD BANKS AND I.M.F. LEADERS
abstract: Following are excerpts from speeches given to the joint annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund by the bank's president, A. W. Clausen, and the fund's managing director, Jacques de Larosi ere.        Clausen Address Let me focus on some of the key issues.   1. The developing world is not a monolith. Developing countries exhibit wide differences in performance and prospects between different groups. These may intensify, and within these distinct groups starker differences are likely to emerge. For example, in Sub-Saharan Africa, it is probable that annual average growth rates will be less than 3 percent, with some nations registering no growth at all. Under optimistic assumptions, we see possible average annual growth rates for middle-income countries exceeding 6 percent. But within this group there will still be some highly indebted nations which will register a far lower growth rate.

headline: IT'S JUST A WASTELAND, BUT IT'S HOME TO GUATEMALANS
abstract: For thousands of homeless Guatemalans, the huge vacant lot on the south side of the capital was too appealing to pass up.    On the afternoon of March 12, a handful of families arrived there and started to build makeshift huts. Word spread quickly through poor neighborhoods, and within days several thousand people had settled on tiny plots. Today, 45,000 Guatemalans are living on the lot, which they have turned into a sprawling shantytown they call El Exodo, Spanish for The Exodus.   Previous squatter invasions here have been quickly dealt with by soldiers who forceably cleared the land and sent residents packing. But El Exodo grew so quickly that by the time authorities were prepared to move against it, too many people had arrived and had vowed to resist being moved.

headline: Genrad Outlook
abstract: Genrad Inc. said it expects its third-quarter earnings per share to be significantly below the 26 cents a share it earned in the same quarter of 1983.

headline: Afghan Airliner Lands After Rebel Fire Hits It
abstract: An Afghan airliner carrying 308 passengers was hit by rebel fire Friday and forced to make an emergency landing at the Kabul airport, the Kabul radio and a Western diplomat reported today. No casualties were reported.

headline: City Investing Delays Action
abstract: The City Investing Company announced that it had put off, until its next board meeting on Aug. 22, any action on two management buyout proposals: one a $2.4 billion offer by Victor Posner; the other a $2.3 billion offer by an investor group headed by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.    It said the postponement would give both bidders more time to complete financing plans and allow City Investing to evaluate other proposals related to its assets.

headline: Dollar Hits Highs in Europe
abstract: The dollar reached record highs against the Italian and British currencies today in thin trading. Gold bullion prices dropped in light trading.

headline: Real Estate; Medical Space in Manhattan
abstract: ALTHOUGH home ownership through cooperatives and condominiums has been a significant part of the residential market in Manhattan for years, commercial condominiums and cooperatives have gained ground more slowly - particularly in the medical and dental professions.     Since 1981 the New York State Attorney General's office has approved 42 plans for commercial condominiums or cooperatives in New York City.   Most of these projects were small conversions developed for a particular type of business (such as law firms, professional artists, jewelry merchants or architects) or were part of the conversion of residential buildings that already included professional space.    More recently, however, larger condominium projects aimed specifically at the medical and dental professions have begun appearing in Manhattan.

headline: ISRAEL ELECTION: A VOTE FOR INDECISION
abstract: The inconclusive results of the parliamentary elections Monday seem to have left many Israelis stunned and disappointed.   Despite the low-key nature of the campaign, there was a feeling before the election that Israel was at a crossroads, that some very fundamental decisions about the nature of the state, its size and its economic system had to be made and that this vote would determine who would get to make them. Israelis felt the stakes were very high, so high that a few talked openly about leaving the country if their party did not prevail.   This helps account for the widespread dissatisfaction with the results. On the one hand almost everybody got a piece of the pie. But in politics, when everybody wins, nobody wins. Every major party in Israel and its ideological opposite will be represented almost equally in the next Parliament. The election which was to decide everything seemed to decide nothing.

headline: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES PRESIDENT OUT
abstract: In a surprise move, the board of directors of the United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it had accepted the resignation of Robert J. Carlson, its president. Mr. Carlson was widely believed to be the heir apparent to Harry J. Gray, the chairman and chief executive officer of the Hartford-based company.     The board also announced that it had appointed a special committee to choose Mr. Gray's successor. Presumably, the person chosen would initially replace Mr. Carlson as president. Mr. Gray, who will be 65 years old in November, said in January that, at the board's request, he would remain as chief executive until the end of 1985.   Mr. Carlson, 54, had been president since May 1983, after four years as head of the company's power division, which included Pratt & Whitney, the world's largest manufacturer of jet engines.

headline: German Auto Lines Restart
abstract: West German car makers restarted assembly lines today as 25,000 metalworkers in the key Stuttgart industrial area ended a seven-week strike.

headline: Waldenbooks Chooses Grey
abstract: account to Grey Advertising,   while the new Electronic and   Technical Publishing division   of Harper & Row has been assigned to AC&R Advertising, a   subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide.

headline: 34 Dead in Ecuador As Cargo Plane Explodes
abstract: An Ecuadorean cargo plane clipped a bus and exploded on a building site while trying to take off from the airport here today, killing 34 people and injuring 50, hospital and airport sources said.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS Bond Prices Advance Broadly;  Short-Term Rates Drop
abstract: The credit markets finished their best week of the year yesterday, as bond prices rose throughout the maturity range.     Traders were buoyed by a series of economic reports that showed continued low inflation and slower economic growth, and by a prediction from Henry Kaufman, vice chairman of Phibro-Salomon Inc., that the Federal Reserve Board would not tighten its hold on monetary policy when its Federal Open Market Committee meets next week.    ''The producer price figure was a little lower than anticipated, but retail sales and industrial production were in line with Street estimates,'' said Raul Nicho, an economist at Money Market Services, an economic information service firm in Belmont, Calif. ''Those numbers and Mr. Kaufman's comments added to what was already a positive market attitude.''

headline: Bonneville Delays Seen
abstract: The Bonneville Power Administration tentatively recommended today a further delay for two Washington Public Power Supply System nuclear power plants, increasing the risk that the projects - currently mothballed - may ultimately be killed.

headline: Profit Posted At Reynolds
abstract: The Reynolds Metals Company said today that it earned $37.3 million, or $1.74 a share, in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $69.1 million a year earlier.

headline: VISICALC LAWSUIT IS SETTLED
abstract: One of the most bitterly fought lawsuits in the personal computer industry, pitting the company that developed the once-popular Visicalc program against the company that held the rights to market it, was settled out of court yesterday.    Analysts said that the suit, which went on for a year as sales of Visicalc slumped, appeared to end in a draw.   Under its terms, Software Arts of Wellesley, Mass., which developed Visicalc, the first spreadsheet program for a personal computer, would now market it.

headline: Grand Trunk-Burlington Tie
abstract: Saying that regional railroads need to cooperate to survive, Burlington Northern Inc. and the Grand Trunk Corporation today announced the signing of a 10-year freight interchange agreement. The two railroads will cooperate in the marketing and shipping of coal, grain, automobiles and other freight in the United States and Canada, officials of the companies said.

headline: Weather Halts Salvage Of Radioactive Cargo
abstract: A strong wind and five-foot seas halted the salvage today of the radioactive cargo of a French freighter that sank three weeks ago, a Government official said.   A spokesman for the Belgian Environment Ministry said three more containers of uranium hexafluoride and one empty container had been removed during the night before bad weather stopped the operations.

headline: INSURING HOME COMPUTERS
abstract: With some 10 million personal computers in American homes, and the number continuing to grow, insurance protection specifically written for computers has become an important consideration for many owners.   This insurance, known as scheduled personal electronic equipment coverage, is sold by many companies as either an endorsement to a homeowners policy or as a separate personal ''floater'' policy. In both cases, it is created to protect all risks to the computer hardware - and, if desired, software - which might not be covered by other insurance policies. And it is distinct from the warranties and service contracts intended to protect against failure and major repairs.

headline: SOVIET ACCEPTS BID TO HAVE GROMYKO MEET WITH REAGAN
abstract: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union has agreed to meet here with President Reagan on Sept. 28, a senior Administration official said today.   An announcement is expected later this week, the official said. The meeting would come after talks two days earlier between Mr. Gromyko and Secretary of State George P. Shultz,    Mr. Gromyko, who is also a First Deputy Prime Minister, sits on the Soviet Union's ruling 12-member Politburo, the top leadership group. It would be the first time Mr. Reagan has met such a high-level Soviet official.   Administration officials said the meeting would demonstrate the President's interest in building a constructive relationship with the Soviet Union and reducing the chill in relations that has marked his term in office.

headline: ARGENTINE LOANS HURT 4 BANKS
abstract: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation - the largest lender to Argentina - reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were reduced by $21.4 million as the result of its loans to that financially troubled country.     A major factor in the drain on earnings at Manufacturers Hanover and three other leading New York banks that reported net income yesterday was a stricter interpretation of accounting rules that did not permit these banks to accrue some interest payments on their Argentine loans in their second-quarter earnings.    Although Federal regulators said that the tougher approach would not be required until this quarter's earnings are reported, most banks have decided to adhere to the stricter rules in the second quarter rerports.    As a result, Manufacturer Hanover's net income dropped 8.5 percent, to $73.7 million, in the second quarter of 1984, from $80.5 million in the comparable period of 1983. But on a per-share basis, the decline was a far steeper 29.5 percent, to $1.41 per share, from $2, primarily resulting from the company's acquisition May 1 of the CIT Financial Corporation. The large drop reflected the dilution caused by the issuance of five million shares of common stock, and dividends paid on $250 million of newly issued preferred stock, both to finance the acquisition.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ; U.N. Chief Confers With Greek Cypriot
abstract: The Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar, conferred with a Greek Cypriot representative today in an effort to get talks started between Greek and Turkish Cypriots.

headline: Caracas Shifts Interest Stand
abstract: Venezuela will not be rigid in seeking fixed interest rates while renegotiating its $34 billion foreign debt, Planning Minister Luis Matos Azocar said today.   Mr. Matos Azocar said over the weekend that Venezuela would request fixed rates in refinancing $14 billion to $15 billion of public debt.

headline: Examining Problem Of Zapping TV Ads
abstract: There will be an event in Chicago today in the Hyatt Regency that should gladden the hearts of all the peddlers in the print media, because at it six speakers will examine the problem of zapping.     That phenomenon, as all in adland know, is what television viewers who are equipped with remote control tuners do when switching channels during commercials.

headline: CELLULAR TELEPHONE NAMES FIRST CHIEF
abstract: Andrew Daskalakis has been named the first president and chief executive officer of the Cellular Telephone Company of New York, the company announced yesterday.    Mr. Daskalakis, who is 50 years old, will be responsible for organizing the company's entry into the new mobile and portable telecommunications business. For the past three years he has been senior vice president of Satellite Business Systems in Washington, with responsibility for marketing, engineering and operations.

headline: Ritual Slaughter of a Sheep Provokes Protest in London
abstract: An Iranian diplomat is being reported to the British Government over an incident in which a sheep was ritually slaughtered in a London street, the police said today.

headline: Mobil, Superior In Stock Plan
abstract: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that the Superior Oil Company had granted it permission to buy more than 9.9 percent of Superior's stock on the open market or in private transactions.  A $5.7 billion merger agreement between the two, reached last March, called for Mobil to pay shareholders $45 a share in cash or securities, except for 9.9 percent that Mobil could buy in the market.

headline: Spanish Basques Protest French Court Ruling
abstract: Eight people were arrested today as hundreds of Basque youths fought with police during a protest over a French court ruling that four suspected Basque guerrillas should be extradited to Spain, the police said.    Demonstrators burned a Spanish flag and threw rocks, bottles and gasoline bombs at the police, who responded by firing rubber bullets to disperse the protesters.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Cenergy Corp.  of Dallas, an oil and gas arm of the Centex Corp., said that C. H. Mullendore Jr. had joined the company as senior vice president of pipeline operations.     *  Dart & Kraft Financial Corp., Edina, Minn., a subsidiary of Dart & Kraft Inc., named Robert B. Eckert regional vice president of the vehicle management group.

headline: NORTH KOREA GIVES IN ON AID
abstract: A North Korean official said today that his country had agreed to South Korea's conditions for delivering relief goods intended for South Korean flood victims, according to a report monitored here.    The announcement by Han Ung Shik, vice chairman of the North Korean Red Cross Society's Central Committee, was carried by the official Pyongyang radio and was monitored here by Radio Press, a Japanese agency.   If the report of an agreement is accurate, it will mark one of the few times the rival Governments of North and South Korea have agreed on an issue.

headline: President Resigns At Needham USA
abstract: Peter A. Nelson, 52, president and chief operating officer of Needham, Harper & Steers/USA, resigned to ''pursue a new career opportunity which he will announce in the near future,'' the company said.

headline: West German Coalition Urges A Ban on Chemical Weapons
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition called for a global, verifiable ban on chemical weapons today.

headline: THE BARGAINING BEGINS FOR AUTOS; A LOT MORE AT STAKE THAN MONEY
abstract: Evidence is building that the    parties to the auto industry contract talks set to open tomorrow may fail to focus on the central competitive issues facing the industry in this country. If so, the industry's struggle for renewed competitiveness will be seriously retarded.    Industry profits are now reaching record levels and more than half of the 270,000 auto workers laid off in 1982 have been recalled. Unfortunately, the current recovery presents a dangerous illusion.

headline: NORTHWEST INDUSTRIES BUYOUT SET
abstract: Ben W. Heineman, the energetic entrepreneur who heads Northwest Industries, agreed with the company's directors yesterday to a leveraged buyout offer from an investor group that is valued at more than $1 billion.     The group - led by Kelly, Briggs & Associates, a Chicago financial partnership, and Oppenheimer & Company of New York - will pay Northwest stockholders $50 a share in cash as well as one share of Northwest's Lone Star Steel Company subsidiary for each share of Northwest common stock. Northwest, a Chicago-based conglomerate, has about 20 million common shares outstanding.   Lone Star will be spun off as an independent, publicly owned subsidiary. Sources close to the transaction declined to estimate a potential per- share price for the Lone Star stock.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Banco de Mexico to Margeotes/ Fertitta & Weiss for a new one-ounce silver bullion coin.

headline: Continental's Tie To Kiewit Backed
abstract: Continental Group Inc. stockholders approved the $2.75 billion merger of the conglomerate with the Kiewit- Murdock Investment Corporation. S. Bruce Smart Jr., Continental Group chairman and chief executive, said the merger now needs the approval of the Georgia and New York State insurance commissioners.   Kiewit-Murdock is owned 80 percent by Peter Kiewit Sons Inc., a privately held construction and mining company.

headline: Kaufman & Broad Shares Bought
abstract: J.B. Haralson, a Houston investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had purchased 1 million common shares of Kaufman & Broad Inc., or 8.3 percent of the shares outstanding, for $15.9 milllion.   According to the filing, Mr. Haralson, the president and chairman of the board of the Mercury Savings Association, purchased the shares between Jan. 24 and Sept. 19 on the open market. Mr. Haralson told the S.E.C. that he had purchased the shares of the Los Angeles-based housing and life insurance firm for investment purposes only. On the New York Stock Exchange, Kaufman & Broad closed at $14.875 today, unchanged.

headline: Japan Bars Cut In Wood Duty TOKYO, Aug. 22 (AP) - The
abstract: Forestry Agency refused today   to lower Japanese tariffs for   veneer, plywood, particle   board and walnut, as the   United States had requested. Kenichi Kakudo, director   general of the Forestry Agency, turned down a request by   Michael B. Smith, United   States deputy trade representative, that the tariffs be lowered,   according to the official, who   declined to be identified.

headline: BOLIVIAN COLONEL CALLED LEADER OF PLOT
abstract: Government authorities said today that a rightist army colonel was believed to have directed the conspiracy that led to the kidnapping Saturday of President Hernan Siles Zuazo.   Officials said the plot involved several high-ranking military officials, politicians and narcotics policemen.   Mr. Siles Zuazo was freed after officials negotiated briefly with his six captors, who were seized and then reportedly allowed to enter the Argentine Embassy. The President had been abducted from his bedroom 10 hours before.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ; Sri Lanka Says 70 Tamils Died in 2 Days of Clashes
abstract: About 70 Tamil separatists were killed in clashes with security forces in the last two days, Government officials said today.

headline: Owens-Illinois Diversifying Owens-Illinois Inc. said it
abstract: had agreed to acquire all the   outstanding shares of Health   Care and Retirement Corporation for $22 a share. Based on   Health Care's approximately   4.5 million shares, the deal   would be valued at $99 million.

headline: Bomb Suspect in Ulster Killed by British Troops
abstract: An undercover British Army squad today shot and killed a man suspected of trying to plant a bomb at a village factory, the police said.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Anderson Greenwood & Co. , a Houston-based company that manufactures precision valves for the process industry, said it had acquired Prince Valve Inc., a privately held company based in Norman, Okla. Terms were not disclosed.     * Bellsouth Corp.  said two of its units, South Central Bell and Southern Bell Telephone Co., had entered into an agreement with MCI Communications Corp. under which the telephone companies would provide billing and customer services for some MCI customers, effective Aug. 27.

headline: MINING MAY OFFER LIFT FOR UPPER VOLTA
abstract: When the left-wing officers who took power here last year vowed to end foreign exploitation of their country, many economists expressed sentiments similar to those voiced by a French businessman: ''This regime has talent - for satire.''   Upper Volta, a drought-ravaged nation on the fringe of the Sahara, hundreds of miles from the nearest port, has never had much to exploit. For years, it has subsisted on foreign aid and remittances sent home by more than a million natives of Upper Volta toiling in the more prosperous Ivory Coast to the south.   Now, however, the World Bank has identified what appears to be a rich deposit of zinc and silver in Upper Volta. Just as important, the deposit is only 23 miles from the railroad that connects Upper Volta with the Ivory Coast and the Atlantic Ocean, thus making it possible to develop the site without building a big, costly system of roads or main rail lines.

headline: ATVS-First Data Deal
abstract: ATVS Systems Inc. of Santa Ana, Calif., has announced that First Data Resources Inc. of Omaha has acquired its field service arm. The manufacturer of computerized cash register systems said Monday that the total ''cash yield'' from the sale would exceed $14 million in immediate and deferred payments and royalties.

headline: ISRAELI PRESIDENT TO MEET RIVAL BLOCS INFORMALLY
abstract: President Chaim Herzog moved today to speed up negotiations on a new Israeli government by inviting the leaders of the two major political blocs to take part in separate informal talks with him.    A spokesman for Mr. Herzog said he would meet Tuesday morning with Shimon Peres, leader of the 44-seat Labor Alignment, and then with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, whose Likud bloc formed the last two governments but won only 41 seats in elections a week ago. Each of the parties has been maneuvering to win a 61-seat majority in the 120-seat Parliament.   An official in Mr. Herzog's office said he was meeting with the leaders of the major blocs informally at first - an unusual move - ''because he wants to see how it's going.'' The question has also puzzled many Israelis who have been watching the seemingly daily shifts in the fortunes of their parties.

headline: China Accuses Taiwan And Seoul on Hijacking
abstract: China said today that South Korea and Taiwan had violated international treaties against air piracy when Seoul released six Chinese hijackers and Taipei gave them asylum and cash rewards.

headline: Simon's Share Of Gibson Sale WASHINGTON, Aug. 1
abstract: (Reuters) - William E. Simon,   former Secretary of the Treasury, will receive roughly $70   million when Walt Disney Productions buys Gibson Greetings Inc., according to documents filed today.

headline: No Headline
abstract: American Cyanamid 57,400,000  x33.8  AMR Corporation 71,400,000  x80.3  Bausch & Lomb 14,800,000  x28.7  Castle & Cooke (82,700,000)   -  Chesebrough-Pond's 23,300,000  -4.9  Dun & Bradstreet 54,200,000  x18.3  Emhart Corporation 22,200,000  x23.3  Federal-Mogul Corp. 14,400,000  -15.3  General Foods 111,600,000  x86 .9  Melville Corporation 37,400,000  x39.6  Monsanto Company 145,000,000  x27.2  A. H. Robins Company 4,100,000  -69.6  Rockwell International 132,900,000  x23.2  Santa Fe Southern Pac. 143,000,000  -68.9  Scott Paper 52,900,000 x60.3  Sea-Land Corporation  27,500,000  x 37.5 Stanley Works  18,100,000  x  49.6 Stauffer Chemical  14,100,000  x 19.5 Sundstrand Corporation  15,600,000  x 52.9 Tiger International  694,000  -* Union Camp  51,300,000 x 64.4 USAir Group  39,000,000  x 39.3 Yellow Freight 12,400,000  - 1 7.9   See accompanying notes for special items.   (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

headline: PHONE BATTLE IN WALL ST. AREA
abstract: Starting today, Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., the investment banking firm, and some 35,000 other business and residential phone users in lower Manhattan can take advantage of the new equal access plan for long- distance dialing.     For the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the long-distance carriers that are bidding for A.T.& T.'s traditional business, today marks more than the extension of equal access to another part of the country. What is at stake is the financial district, a concentration of investment firms, banks, law firms and other businesses - all of them heavy long-distance users. Employees at Prudential-Bache's headquarters at 100 Gold Street, for example, make $700,000 worth of long-distance calls each month.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Science Digest magazine to Van Brunt & Co.

headline: PERES IS PREMIER
abstract: Parliament approved a Government of national unity early today that includes both the Labor Party and the Likud bloc. Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, then took the oath as Israel's eighth Prime Minister.    The Parliament voted the new Government into office after more than eight hours of debate. The vote was 89 to 18, with 1 abstention. As the debate Thursday proceeded into the night, the 12 other legislators left before the vote was taken.   The vote came after seven weeks of political wrangling, culminating in three days of round-the-clock negotiations.

headline: AUTO MAKERS SPUR PUSH FOR NEW TYPE OF STEEL
abstract: The auto industry is working with the steel industry to produce better steel for auto body panels and other components, and in the process a new line of domestic steel is emerging.    The General Motors Corporation, for example, is working with Armco Inc. and the Jones & Laughlin Steel subsidiary of the LTV Corporation, as well as with a joint venture of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Inland Steel Company. In return for installing the capacity to produce the new type of steel, these companies will be first in line to get the contracts for G.M.'s business when it develops.    The goal of G.M. - and other domestic auto makers - is to create domestic production of electrogalvanized steel, especially of steel that can be coated on both sides to improve its resistance to corrosion.

headline: Volcker Cites
abstract: -   Paul A. Volcker, chairman of   the Federal Reserve Board,   said today that American   banks raised loan interest rates   as much as a full percentage   point earlier this year because   of the banks' difficulties with   Latin American debts.  ''I don't think it's a fundamental cause of high rates,''   Mr. Volcker told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress   in discussing debt owed by   Latin American countries.

headline: Air Florida Gets Judge's Warning
abstract: A Federal bankruptcy judge threatened to appoint a receiver for Air Florida unless it came up with a ''realistic plan to get back into the air'' by Aug. 27.

headline: SHULTZ RULES OUT A TESTING FREEZE ON SPACE WEAPONS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States was ready to discuss a joint moratorium on tests of new space weapons with the Soviet Union, but he ruled out a Soviet proposal for a freeze of such tests in advance of actual negotiations.    Previously, the Reagan Administration said it was willing to engage in talks with the Russians on curbing the militarization of outer space so long as there were no conditions. The United States had not specifically addressed itself publicly to the moratorium question.   Mr. Shultz's remarks were apparently meant to convey an American readiness to discuss everything at the table, including a moratorium on future testing, but not to accept any Russian condition - in this case, a ban on tests while negotiations were taking place. The United States is expected to test an antisatellite weapon this fall.

headline: URUGUAY GOVERNMENT FREES SON OF JAILED OPPOSITION CHIEF
abstract: The military Government today freed Juan Wilson Ferreira more than two months after he was arrested along with his father, Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, the National Party leader.   Meanwhile, Adolfo Suarez, a former Spanish Prime Minister, who arrived Sunday to help in the senior Mr. Ferreira's legal defense, said the Government had asked him to leave Uruguay within 24 hours.   Mr. Suarez said Interior Ministry officials had given him written notice that he must leave by 7 P.M. on Tuesday and accused him of violating the restrictions of his tourist visa.

headline: STUDY BY CONGRESS FAULTS UNESCO AND PLACESBLAME ON ITS DIRECTOR
abstract: A six-month American inquiry into Unesco has drawn a picture of a highly centralized, badly managed organization where power is concentrated in the hands of the Director General, Amadou Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal.    The still-confidential report was prepared this summer by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of the United States Congress.   The inquiry began after the United States said it would withdraw from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization unless it tightened management, cut spending and ceased supporting anti-Western causes, including attempts at what are seen as efforts to curb press freedom.   No comment was made available from Unesco on the report, which was sent to Mr. M'Bow at the beginning of the week.

headline: BRITISH COAL STRIKE TALKS HELD
abstract: Talks between the leaders of striking miners and coal industry officials ended after two hours tonight with both sides refusing to say if they had made progress toward ending the 26-week-old walkout.   The chairman of the state-run coal board, which wants to close unprofitable mines, and miners' leaders left separately from a suburban Edinburgh hotel where they met for the first time in eight weeks.   Both Ian MacGregor, head of the National Coal Board, and Arthur Scargill, who leads the 183-member National Union of Mineworkers, have vowed not to budge over the main issue the dispute - the board's plans to close 20 unprofitable pits and shed 20,000 jobs in the industry, which has been losing $1.3 billion a year.

headline: A.T.& T. PLANNING TO CUT 11,000 JOBS
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it will eliminate 11,000 management and blue-collar jobs nationwide by early next year as part of its continuing effort to cut costs.    The cutbacks, which had been rumored for weeks, reflect the difficulty that A.T.& T. is having in adapting to the competitive telecommunications environment since the breakup of the Bell System on Jan. 1.    In the past, A.T.& T. has routinely laid off manufacturing employees temporarily during economic downturns, but the cutbacks disclosed yesterday would be the first of their kind in modern times at the company, where lifelong employment has been commonplace.    Cost-Cutting Measures      A.T.& T., which has reported earnings well below its earlier projections for its first year without the local Bell operating companies, has been struggling for most of the year to bring its high costs under control. It has already frozen wages for 114,000 management- level employees, announced the closing of four plants and cut 5,000 workers from its payrolls through attrition, resignations and special early retirement programs. A.T.& T. employs 373,000 people nationwide.  After a flurry of rumors throughout the day, A.T.& T. officials said late yesterday that the cutbacks would be concentrated in the 53,000-employee equipment maintenance and service operations of AT&T Technologies, the unregulated A.T.& T. subsidiary that is spearheading the parent's push into the highly competitive computer business.

headline: THE COMMUNIST CONNECTION
abstract: The Republican Party's campaign platform takes special note of the international drug traffickers who seem to irritate the Reagan Administration the most.    They are the ''Communist dictators,'' the platform says. ''Cuba, the Soviet Union, Bulgaria - and now the Sandinistas in Nicaragua - are international 'pushers,' selling slow death to young Americans in an effort to undermine our free society.''

headline: Canadian Output Rises
abstract: Canada's industrial production in July rose 4 percent from June, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. It noted gains for paper mills, car makers, some mines and steel mills, among others.

headline: Michelob Accounts To Bates and Needham
abstract: Anheuser-Busch, the nation's leading brewer, announced yesterday that it was moving its Michelob and Michelob Light brands out of D'Arcy MacManus Masius in St. Louis and into Ted Bates Advertising, New York, and Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, respectively.     For Bates it served as an endorsement for its recently fashioned new- business system in which stress is put on solving the prospect's problem, not selling the agency.    Although Leading National Advertisers, the media measuring company, puts 1983 advertising spending for Michelob at $33.6 million and for Michelob Light at $24.1 million, it is understood that the budget is far more than that.

headline: PROPOSED DRUG FUND A TRADE-OFF FOR 2 SIDES
abstract: In 1971, during her sixth pregnancy, Rita Noe took Bendectin, a prescription anti-nausea drug - and her daughter, Michelle, was born with a webbed left hand. Last weekend, on Michelle's 12th birthday, Merrell Dow Pharmaceutical Inc., the Cincinnati-based manufacturer of Bendectin, agreed to put $120 million into a settlement fund to pay damages to the Noes and more than 700 other families who have filed lawsuits arising out of birth defects they say were caused by Bendectin.     Mass settlements in product liability cases are a relatively new phenomenon that theoretically allow companies to put product liability claims behind them in a quick, if expensive, stroke. The proposed Bendectin fund, to be endowed over 18 years, would be the third-largest settlement fund in history.   ''We're very happy about the settlement,'' Mrs. Noe said. ''Court proceedings can be very long and drawn out, and if we can, we'd like keep Michelle from going through a trial with all the attendant hassle and media. The only reason I would want a jury trial would be to bring out the fact that the drug is unsafe, but actions speak louder than words, so I guess that's established, no matter what the company says.''

headline: ;  A Dual Offering By McCrory Corp.
abstract: The McCrory Corporation yesterday priced a two-part, $200 million offering of fixed-and floating-rate notes. The fixed-rate part of the financing package for the company's Rapid-American Corporation subsidiary consists of a $125 million offering of seven-year senior subordinated notes.

headline: BOND PRICES UP OVER A POINT
abstract: Bond prices rose by more than a point yesterday in a rally that analysts said was sparked by speculative buying of traders and an increasing scarcity of long-term Treasury bonds, which are being bought by securities dealers and repackaged as zero coupon securities.    After dropping to as low as 98 7/8 on Wednesday, the bellwether 12 1/2 percent Treasury bond due in 2014 was offered late yesterday at 100 10/32, up about one point, to yield 12.45 percent. Since the 12 1/2 percent bond was auctioned Aug. 9, it has traded in a relatively narrow range of about one point above and below a price of 100.    Money Supply Down $700 Million    All of the market's gains were achieved before the Federal Reserve's 4:30 P.M. announcement of a $700 million decline in the nation's basic money supply, to $547.1 billion, in the week ended Aug. 27. Although analysts expected a small increase in M-1, interest rates did not significantly change after the Fed's announcement.

headline: A BANK WITH THE AURA OF A CLUB
abstract: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation is not like other international banks. Its image has been streamlined in recent years as it jumped into the international arena, but it retains many of the qualities of a British colonial institution.    In its central role in the development of Hong Kong, the bank's interests extend beyond those of most other international banks. It has a major stake in an airline, a shipping group, a magazine and two newspapers. The bank is also active in real estate and insurance.

headline: Addenda
abstract: * Photo/Design, a new bimonthly magazine with controlled circulation, from Ziff-Davis Publishing.     * Cuisine magazine increasing its advertising rates 12 percent with February issue.     * Scientific American magazine increasing its advertising rates 8 percent with the January issue.

headline: SHARP SEEKING NEW LOOK
abstract: WHEN the Sharp Electronics Corporation selected Scali, McCabe, Sloves Inc. as its advertising agency last April, the consumer and industrial products marketer said it wanted a campaign that would insure that Sharp's name would be up there with the industry leaders.    On Sunday, Sharp will begin a television advertising blitz, part of a $20 million advertising effort to make Sharp a household name. ''Sharp will be seen virtually every week this fall,'' said Daniel J. Infanti, consumer electronics division marketing communications director.    Three new commercials have been produced for Sharp's television, for video cassette recorders, video cameras, microwave ovens and copiers. Two more are in the works. And a print campaign will begin with the fall and winter issues of major women's magazines.

headline: Dome-Canada Accord to Halt
abstract: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said the new Canadian Government would not renew the agreement involving the Government, Dome and Canadian bankers that is to expire Oct. 1.

headline: United Merchants To Bid for Logan
abstract: United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc. said yesterday that it intends to make a tender offer of $25 a share, or a total of $81.25 million, for 3.25 million shares of Jonathan Logan Inc., a women's apparel maker.    United Merchants, a diversified textile and clothing manufacturer, already owns 698,000 shares, which it bought earlier this year for $14.7 million.

headline: HOUSE VOTES TO DENY HELP TO NICARAGUAN INSURGENTS
abstract: The House today approved an intelligence budget for next year that included no money for Nicaraguan rebels and barred the use of any other Federal funds for them.    The action, which came on a vote of 294 to 118, was the fourth time in the last 14 months that the House had voted against supporting the rebels. In today's vote, 64 Republicans joined 230 Democrats in supporting the intelligence budget and the aid cutoff while 96 Republicans and 22 Democrats opposed the bill.   Approval of the intelligence authorization bill for the fiscal year 1985 came after the Republicans, while objecting to the lack of aid, said they could not muster sufficient votes to justify the introduction of an amendment that would have provided some money for the rebels.

headline: MADISON AVE.'S FOOTBALL WOE
abstract: When the United States Supreme Court ended the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 33-year reign over college football broadcasts, it created all the chaos of a broken play on Madison Avenue.    As a result of the decision last June, the networks are attracting smaller audiences for college football broadcasts and the schools are earning less. And the advertisers, which last year paid the networks $813 million to reach more than 100 million fans with their commercials for beer, cars and other products, are reshaping and, in some cases, drastically revising their strategies. The turmoil appears to be spilling over into professional football broadcasts, too.

headline: BROADWAY'S 1 ASTOR PLAZA IS SOLD IN SYNDICATION DEAL
abstract: Tishman Speyer Properties and the Equitable Life Assurance Society, officially designated participants in one portion of the Times Square Redevelopment Project, have purchased a key piece of Times Square property - 1 Astor Plaza, the 54-story, 1.7-million-square-foot office tower with the Minskoff Theater in the 300,000- square-foot base. The price was about $190 million.   Jerry I. Speyer, chairman of Tishman Speyer Properties, said the 13- year-old building had been purchased because his company has ''a great deal of confidence in the revitalization of the West Side, and this is a key property in that revitalization.''   Tishman Speyer and Equitable are partners with Trammell Crow, a nationwide developer based in Dallas, as the designated developers of the 2.4-million-square-foot Merchandise Mart in the Times Square redevelopment plan. Buying 1 Astor Plaza, Mr. Speyer said, was a way to ''evidence further confidence in the area.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1984   The Economy    President Reagan has ordered negotiations on steel imports in an effort to reach ''voluntary restraint agreements'' with steel-exporting countries. The White House said the move would help the domestic steel industry, which had sought protection through mandatory quotas and tariffs. (Page A1.) Reaction to the decision was generally favorable. (D5.)

headline: FRANCES'S RICHEST COMMUNIST MAKES MONEY - AND WAVES
abstract: -Baptiste Doumeng owns a stable of thoroughbred    horses, a Learjet that takes him around the world and a 1,500-acre working farm in southwestern France, complete with villa and swimming pool. In Paris, he dines frequently at Maxim's and the impeccably tailored, conservatively cut suits that cover his portly frame are obviously expensive.    These trappings would hardly draw notice in a successful executive, and Mr. Doumeng certainly fits that bill. But he is more than that. The 64-year- old son of a penniless sharecropper is also France's richest Communist, a man who has parlayed a trading relationship with the Soviet bloc into a vast personal fortune.

headline: ISRAEL LABORITES AND LIKUD AGREE ON LEBANON
abstract: Israel's two main parties, which are trying to form a national unity government, said tonight that they had agreed that Israeli troops should be withdrawn from south Lebanon as soon as possible.   Deputy Prime Minister David Levy, of the outgoing Likud Government, and former President Yitzhak Navon, of the Labor Party, met today and said they made progress toward a joint policy platform.   Earlier today, Israeli news organizations quoted Labor leaders as saying they would try to form a government without Likud if the latest attempt at a coalition made no progress by Monday. But the two parties agreed to meet again on Tuesday.

headline: 36 DIE AS YUGOSLAV TRAIN HITS EXPRESS
abstract: A freight train crashed into the rear of a holiday express today, killing at least 36 people, according to a state radio broadcast.   There were about 1,500 passengers, mostly youngsters, on the overnight express when it was struck shortly after dawn while halted on a siding, the Tanyug press agency reported.   It was the worst rail accident in the Republic of Slovenia since World War II, the press agency said. The Slovenian Railways said 16 freight cars had been damaged, 10 beyond repair.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Planned Parenthood Federation of America to Plapler & Associates.

headline: POWER OF THE INCUMBENT
abstract: With a pair of carefully balanced decisions today aimed at helping farmers and the steel industry, President Reagan has demonstrated the capacity of an incumbent to time policy actions for potential political advantage in key states.  By ordering his trade negotiator to press for a one-fourth cutback in foreign steel imports, the President has sought to improve his prospects in steel-producing states like Pennsylvania, Ohio, Illinois, Indiana and New York, where the domestic steel industry and its unions have been clamoring for protection.    Protection for steel has been opposed by some farm state leaders and farm organizations, fearful that such action would jeopardize their exports if foreign countries retaliate against the steel decision. But Mr. Reagan moved to placate the farm constituency with another decision, to set up a $630 million farm loan guarantee program to ease the credit problems of farmers.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; ;  $120 Million Issue For Texas Airport
abstract: The Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport is offering $120 million of revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 10.50 percent for bonds due in 2012. The underwriters are led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: CAPITALIZING ON HALLEY'S COMET
abstract: Maybe it seems limited. It is one thing to make a product aimed at a specific, regularly occurring event. It is another thing when that event happens once every 76 years.     But Burton Rubin, who is selling a telescope with which to watch Halley's comet, is not overly worried about that. The comet last dropped by in 1910 and will be rocketing by again late in 1985 and hang around for about six months. Anyone who misses it will have to bide his time until 2061.

headline: WRISTON 'VIEW' OF BANKING BILL
abstract: WASHINGTON WALTER B. WRISTON, the former chairman of Citicorp, would no doubt be surprised to find himself quoted as an influential foe of banking deregulation. But that is how he was portrayed on several occasions during last week's Senate debate on an Administration-backed banking deregulation bill.   At issue is a key provision in the measure that would allow bank holding companies to expand their securities operations to include underwriting and dealing in municipal revenue bonds, mortgage-backed securities and commercial paper. These new bank powers could be offered only through a separate holding company affiliate. The measure was passed by the Senate late Thursday night; action is pending in the House on a version of the bill that does not grant new powers to the banks.

headline: Rates Mixed in Light Trading
abstract: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, with some short-term rates rising by about a tenth of a percentage point, while yields fell slightly for notes and bonds due in more than five years.     Securities dealers said that trading and investment activity in the note and bond market was very light, as many participants remained on the sidelines. Although many economists expect the Federal Reserve to leave monetary policy unchanged at today's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, market particpants continue to be dismayed at the trend toward a higher rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market.    Federal funds traded at nearly 11 7/8 percent most of the day, up from the 11.63 percent average of the week ended Aug. 15, and well above the 11 1/4 percent rate that prevailed through most of July.

headline: PROTEST VOICED AT U.S. EXCLUSION OF VISITORS BECAUSE OF THEIR IDEAS
abstract: Several well-known Latin Americans and Europeans who have encountered difficulties in visiting this country joined today in protesting United States restrictions on foreign visitors for ideological reasons.
