Among them were Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the Colombian novelist and Nobel laureate; Carlos Fuentes, the Mexican novelist who is now teaching at Harvard University; Dennis Brutus, a poet who was imprisoned in South Africa for his activities against apartheid and has recently won a fight for political asylum in this country; and Leszek Kolakowski, a Polish scholar who left his country in 1968 and is now teaching at the University of Chicago.   They lent their names and views to a conference on ''Free Trade in Ideas,'' sponsored by 39 organizations, including the American Civil Liberties Union, the American Association of University Professors, Americans for Democratic Action and the Authors Guild of America.    Except for Mr. Fuentes, who spoke at a conference luncheon, the views of the foreign participants were relayed to the meeting either by television or written statements.

headline: Rooney Pace Official Adds Top Job at Norlin
abstract: The Rooney Pace Group Inc., the investment concern that said last January that it intended to ''seek significant influence'' over the Norlin Corporation, has done precisely that.     After a board meeting Friday, Norlin announced that it had restructured its board and had elected Randolph K. Pace, 38, president of the Rooney Pace Group, as chairman, chief executive and a director at Norlin. The company, based in White Plains, makes musical instruments and operates a financial printing business.

headline: AIDE HINTS U.S. MAY 'RETURN TO UNESCO'
abstract: A Reagan Administration official said today that the United States decision to withdraw from Unesco had led to the first ''serious effort toward reform'' of the organization.    The official, Gregory Newell, Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations, added that if changes within the agency were made to the Reagan Administration's satisfaction, ''we will return to Unesco.''   The United States withdrawal from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is scheduled for the end of the year. The Reagan Administration said it was leaving because of what it termed Unesco's politicalization and inefficiency.

headline: U.S. BASE IN ATHENS BESIEGED
abstract: For many Greeks and Americans, the most visible line of confrontation in the strained relations between the Greek Government and the United States has been at a traffic junction in the capital, a mile from the bustling international airport.   The scene is near the entrance to the United States air base known as Hellenikon, where for the last two weeks Greek workers have been on strike in a bitter dispute over wages and working conditions.  Strikes by Greek workers at the United States bases in Greece, a member of the Atlantic alliance, are not unusual - there have been 14 at the Hellenikon base since 1978 - and officials say the union demands do not seem insurmountable. Yet Greek and American officials agree that this strike has been the worst, in its duration, its occasional violence and its high level of mutual suspicion and hostility.

headline: FRENCH HIGH COURT SUPPORTS BASQUES' EXTRADITION
abstract: France's highest appeals court has rejected an appeal by seven Basque separatists seeking to block their extradition to Spain.    The seven, who are wanted in Spain for a variety of charges, including murder, have been on a hunger strike in French prisons for 40 days.   The decision Friday promptly stirred protests. In Bayonne, a French Basque stronghold, some 500 to 1,000 demonstrators marched peacefully, chanting, ''Mitterrand, the people will never forgive you.''

headline: SOUTHLAND FINANCIAL GETS TAKEOVER BID
abstract: The Southland Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had received a proposal to be acquired for stock and debt by a company to be formed by certain members of the Carpenter family, which holds about 30 percent of Southland's shares.    Under the proposal, each of Southland's 11.7 million shares outstanding not held by the Carpenters would be converted into $22 cash and $20 principal amount of a new issue of subordinated discount debentures of Southland Financial.

headline: U.S. MAY CLOSE MAJOR MILITARY SCHOOL IN PANAMA
abstract: A disagreement with Panama may force the United States to close a major military school in that country, the State Department says.   United States officers at the institution, the U.S. Army School of the Americas, have trained 44,000 Latin American military personnel there since 1940.   The two countries have been trying to negotiate an agreement that would permit the United States to continue its training operations at the Fort Gulick site.

headline: BERRY INDUSTRIES' CHIEF LEAVES UNDER PRESSURE
abstract: Arne Kalm has resigned as president and chief executive officer of Berry Industries, Charles B. Evans, Berry's chairman, said.     Mr. Kalm, 48, had been performing the duties of president and chief executive since 1976 but was not formally named to those positions until 1982.

headline: Florida Bank Sales
abstract: First Florida Bank Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the First Bank and Trust Co. of Belleair Bluffs, Fla., and the First Gulf Beach Bank and Trust Co.  of St. Petersburg Beach, Fla., for about $31.7 million.  First Florida, based in Tampa, said the two banks have total assets of $205 million.  The acquisition requires regulatory approval and is expected to be compleated early next year, First Florida said.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; International Paper Getting New Chief
abstract: The International Paper Company will name John A. Georges, president and chief operating officer, to the post of chief executive officer as of Sept. 1, a spokesman for the company, McClain Ramsey, said yesterday.    Mr. Georges will succeed Edwin A. Gee, who will remain chairman until he retires next April. He turns 65 years old next February.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM VATICAN STATEMENT CRITICIZING THE 'THEOLOGY OF LIBERATION'
abstract: Following are excerpts from the statement on liberation theology as issued in English by the Vatican today:    The Sacred Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith does not intend to deal here with the vast theme of Christian freedom and liberation in its own right. This it intends to do in a subsequent document.   The present instruction has a much more limited and precise purpose: To draw the attention of pastors, theologians and all the faithful to the deviations, and risks of deviation, damaging to the faith and to Christian living, that are brought about by certain forms of liberation theology which use, in an insufficiently critical manner, concepts borrowed from various currents of Marxist thought.   This warning should in no way be interpreted as a disavowal of all those who want to respond generously and with an authentic evangelical spirit to the ''preferential option for the poor.''   In revealing to them their vocation as children of God, the Gospel has elicited in the hearts of mankind a demand and a positive will for a peaceful and just fraternal life in which everyone will find respect and the conditions for spiritual as well as material development. This requirement is no doubt at the very basis of the aspiration we are talking about here.

headline: China Calls Hot Line A 'Cheap Trick'
abstract: China's leading newspaper said today that the new United States-Soviet agreement to upgrade the hot line was a ''cheap trick'' that would do nothing to reduce the danger of nuclear war.   A commentary in the Communist Party newspaper People's Daily was China's first official reaction to the accord reached earlier this month.

headline: Opposition Leader Steps Down in Greece
abstract: Evangelos Averoff, leader of the conservative opposition New Democracy Party, submitted his resignation from the leadership today.   The party announced it would elect a new leader Saturday to head its effort to unseat the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou in elections next year.

headline: Affirmative
abstract: To the Editor:   In considering the impact of the supreme Court's Memphis decision on affirmative action (''Memphis Did Not Kill Affirmative Action,'' Business Forum, July 1), one must first carefully define the term.   If one defines affirmative action in what Morris Abram, Vice Chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, calls its ''original and undefiled meaning,'' then the Memphis decision has no impact on affirmative action.  Affirmative action in its original sense means increased recruiting, training, counseling and educational opportunities, targeted to minorities and women, but open to all.  This nondiscriminatory affirmative action is aimed at breaking down the ''old-boy'' network in hiring and promotions and providing for equal employment opportunity without regard to race or gender and without contracting such opportunity for anyone else.   Preferential affirmative action seeks to reward persons for membership in a group, even if an employer did not discriminate against those persons, at the expense of innocent individuals.  The Memphis decision deals a sharp blow th this discriminatory form of affirmative action.

headline: U.S. OFFICIAL MEETS WITH SYRIAN ON ISRAELI PULLOUT
abstract: A high-ranking State Department official held talks in Damascus today with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria amid signs of a stepped-up effort to gain the withdrawal of Israeli troops from southern Lebanon.    After conferring with Mr. Assad, the American official, Richard W. Murphy, the Assistant Secretary of State who deals with Middle Eastern affairs, went on to Jerusalem, where he is to meet with Prime Minister Shimon Peres on Tuesday.    The official Syrian press agency said the two hours of talks between Mr. Murphy and Mr. Assad focused on Lebanon and ''ways to bring about an Israeli withdrawal from ocxcupied Lebanese territory.'' It did not elaborate.

headline: Stocks Fall; Dow Off 4.75, to 1,096.62
abstract: In a fourth consecutive day of decline yesterday, the stock market closed below the 1,100 mark - which some consider a psychological barrier - for the first time since June 15.     The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 1,096.62, down 4.75 points. In the last four sessions, the Dow has fallen 26.28 points.

headline: ENACTMENT DIM FOR BILL ON BANK DEREGULATION
abstract: The outlook for enactment of a banking deregulation bill appeared to dim today with reports that the chairman of the House Banking Committee may delay floor action until the very end of the Congressional session. That might leave no time to reconcile deep House-Senate differences before Congress adjourns.   By a vote of 89 to 5, the Senate approved a bill Thursday night that would give banks broad new powers to expand into other financial services. If enacted, the bill would allow banks to underwrite and deal in municipal revenue bonds, mortgage- backed securities and commercial paper.

headline: CAGED 'LEOPARDS' OF THE DRUG WAR
abstract: Clustered outside their union hall in the tiny Chapare-region village of Villa Tunari, several coca farmers could barely contain their contempt for ''the Leopards.''   That is the unofficial name for the new American- financed drug-enforcement strike force created to restore order in the Chapare, Bolivia's principal coca- growing region.    In August, the Bolivian Army occupied the Chapare, but days after the occupation the coca farmers said they knew who was really behind the operation.   ''Los americanos,'' one coca farmer said. As a result, a local journalist said, Americans have become ''the campesinos' mortal enemies.''

headline: MESA SOARS
abstract: The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company, behind the Exxon Corporation, reported yesterday that its second-quarter profits fell 9 percent, to $366 million, from $402 million a year earlier. The drop reflected the profit squeeze afflicting most of the industry's refining and marketing operations.    Merger activity during the second quarter, however, was the main factor contributing to a 7.6 percent drop in earnings for Texaco Inc. and a twelvefold increase in the earnings of the Mesa Petroleum Corporation.    Texaco, the nation's fourth-largest oil company, said its decline in earnings was largely a result of financing costs for its $10.1 billion acquisition of the Getty Oil Company. Although Mesa lost in a bidding war for the Gulf Corporation, Mesa's sharply higher earnings reflected the gains from the sale of Gulf securities acquired in its unfriendly takeover attempt.

headline: Bahama Protesters Ask Prime Minister to Resign
abstract: About 1,000 people led by opposition politicians defied a police ban today and marched on Parliament to demand the resignation of Prime Minister Linden Pindling.   A royal commission of inquiry is investigating charges that Mr. Pindling and members of his Progressive Liberal Party Government took huge payoffs to allow the Bahamas to become a haven for drug smugglers.

headline: Turner May Compete Against MTV
abstract: The Turner Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it was considering starting a rock video network to compete with MTV Networks Inc.    The announcement came the day before the scheduled initial public offering of MTV.    Arthur Sando, a spokesman for Turner Broadcasting, which operates the Cable News Network, CNN Headline News and superstation WTBS, said that his company has been considering such a plan ''for a number of months.'' He added that it hopes to make a final decision by Sept. 1 and, if it decides to proceed, begin broadcasting by Dec. 5.

headline: Iran Again Threatens New Offensive on Iraq
abstract: Iran threatened again today to open a new offensive against Iraq, saying Iranian troops stood ready ''to attack and destroy the Iraqi regime and its supporters at any time.''   The statement by the commander of Iran's ground forces, Col. Ali Sayyad- Shirazi, came two days after a Cabinet minister said Iran could attack soon unless the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, was overthrown and executed before an unspecified Iranian deadline.

headline: KRATOS PRESIDENT QUITS AFTER 5 MONTHS IN POST
abstract: Kratos Inc., the scientific and engineering instrument maker based in La Jolla, Calif., yesterday announced the resignation of Harry E. Schauwecker, its president and chief executive.   The company said Bruce Juell, 50, a director, had been elected president.

headline: BOND PRICES MOSTLY LOWER
abstract: Bond prices fell as much as a point yesterday, largely as a result of speculative selling by traders who sought to lock in profits earned when prices moved higher earlier in the week, analysts said.     Despite yesterday's decline in prices, and the intense speculation earlier in the week about Federal Reserve monetary policy, analysts said that there had been no developments significant enough to move bond yields out of the 12.65 percent to 12.06 percent range that has prevailed since early August.    One catalyst for yesterday's decline was the announcement of an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in the index of leading economic indicators. Although economists said the index was far from convincing evidence that economic growth would acclerate in coming months, many traders and speculators were sellers after the increase was announced.

headline: Equimark Capital Plan
abstract: An investor group led by the chairman of the Equimark Corporation yesterday offered to invest $25 million in the Pittsburgh bank holding company as part of a $50 million capital infusion plan.     The offer to buy common stock was intended to help achieve the company's previously announced goal of increasing the capital base of Equimark by $100 million. The company lost $29.6 million in the second quarter.

headline: FALLOUT FROM CONTINENTAL'S COLLAPSE
abstract: WAS the rescue of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company just the end of a chapter on a big troubled bank or the beginning of a new book on the woes of the American banking industry? That is the kind of question the financial community is asking in wake of the the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's $4.5 billion takover of the once mighty Chicago bank.      Was Continental a unique case, or do other money center banks also face serious trouble ahead? Does the system of deposit insurance need changing to insure both large and small depositors? How do bankers avoid the mistakes made by Continental? What will be the long-term effects of Continental's failure and the Government's action on the entire banking system?      Four prominent members of the financial community sat down last week and discussed these issues: Hans H. Angermueller, vice chairman of Citicorp; John G. Heimann, deputy chairman of the Wall Street firm of Becker Paribas Inc. and Comptroller of the Currency during the Carter Administration; Alan Greenspan, chairman of the economics consulting firm of Townsend-Greenspan and chairman of President Ford's Council of Economic Advisers, and Thomas G. Labrecque, president and chief operating officer of the Chase Manhattan Corporation.  Excerpts of their roundtable discussion with banking reporter Robert A. Bennett and Nathaniel C. Nash, an editor of the Sunday Business section, follow.

headline: Iraqi Forces and Kurds Said to Renew Fighting
abstract: Iraqi forces have been fighting Kurdish insurgents in Kurdistan in the last week, ending a nine-month cease-fire and ending hopes for an agreement on Kurdish automony, Kurdish rebel sources said today.   They said the fighting erupted a week ago when Iraqi troops ambushed a car in Pasluja, a hamlet near the northern town of Sulaimaniya. The car was carrying senior military officials of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan.

headline: SCHOOL ADS THAT URGE 'GO PUBLIC!'
abstract: Schoolchildren and their parents are going to star in a local multimedia advertising campaign aimed at getting New Yorkers to take advantage of a wonderful free offer - a public school education.     The force behind it is the five-year- old New York Alliance for the Public Schools, which two years ago began an information campaign with Geto & DeMilly that was intended to make the public mind more receptive to advertising.    Yesterday in his conference room, Harold Levine, chairman of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, said that when he was approached two years ago by Alliance representatives, who like himself have New York University connections, they said they wanted to advertise the school system. ''I said I thought it would be a mistake.''

headline: SHULTZ EXPRESSES CONCERN ON RIGHTS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz expressed concern to Indonesia's Foreign Minister today about reports of continuing human rights abuses being carried out by Indonesian forces in East Timor, an American official said.   By bringing up the issue soon after his arrival here from Singapore this morning, Mr. Shultz in effect complied with an unusual request conveyed to him last week by 123 members of Congress in a letter that was drafted by Representative Tony P. Hall, Democrat of Ohio.   In the letter, made public by Mr. Hall's office, the Congressmen said, ''We believe that it is of critical importance that the plight of the people of East Timor be accorded serious attention in the meetings that you will conduct with the Indonesian leadership on the occasion of your visit to Indonesia, the first by an American Secretary of State since the 1975 invasion.''   According to an American official, the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Mochtar Kusumaatmadja, defended his Government's actions in East Timor, a former Portuguese colony that was incorporated to Indonesia by force in 1975. Fighting has resumed since last August when insurgents killed and mutilated some Indonesian engineers.

headline: LAOTIAN MIGRATION WORRIES THAILAND
abstract: As many as 10,000 migrants may have crossed the border from Laos in the last six or seven months, according to Thai authorities. This is double the number of border crossings over the previous two years, refugee workers say.   The influx, attributed to poor economic conditions, collectivization and other problems, is a source of concern to Thai and other relief agencies.   The Laotians, who are mainly Hmong hill people, known by outsiders as Meo, have found adjustment more difficult than other Indochinese refugees. Thailand has refused to allow any more Hmong to settle among Thai hill tribes of similar ethnic background.

headline: 2 AMERICANS ASSERT U.S. ASSISTED PRIVATE EFFORT AGAINST LATIN LEFT
abstract: Two Americans involved in aiding Nicaraguan rebels said today that they received assistance from United States Embassies in Honduras and El Salvador in their effort to provide military equipment to anti-Communist forces in Central America.     Although the two maintained that they were not associated with the Government in any way and had received no money for their work, they said that United States officials in El Salvador and Honduras helped put them in touch with the Chief of Staff of the Salvadoran armed forces and with Honduran military officers who escorted them to Nicaraguan rebel leaders.    (In Washington, the State Department said it had no knowledge of any contact between the two men and United States Embassy personnel in either El Salvador or Honduras, but that checks were being made with the embassies in both countries.    (Privately, State Deparment officials acknowledged that it was conceivable that the two men could have received some assistance in getting in touch with Salvadoran and Honduran military officials. One official noted, for example, that American citizens in foreign countries often seek embassy assistance in making commercial or government contacts and that embassy personnel generally do their best to be helpful.)

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Sept. 17, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 3 P.M.   Committee on International Development Strategy - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Buyout at Brainreserve
abstract: Faith Popcorn, president of Brainreserve, has bought out her partner and creative director, Stuart Pittman. Both were creative directors at Smith/Greenland before forming their own agency 10 years ago. Miss Popcorn, who is assuming the duties of creative director, has plans to expand the agency's operations including a program to buy smaller companies.

headline: Uruguay Legalizes Leftists
abstract: The Government legalized several leftist parties today, clearing the way for broader participation in elections scheduled for Nov. 25 that are designed to end more than a decade of military rule.

headline: DOLLAR'S RISE: EXPERTS BAFFLED
abstract: The dollar traded at above 3 German marks this week for the first time since floating exchange rates were adopted 11 years ago, continuing a recent pattern of strength against the currencies of the world that has left monetary experts struggling to understand and agree on what forces control how much a nation's money is worth internationally.   The push through the largely psychological 3-mark barrier came on the heels of a climb last week that brought the dollar to record levels against the British pound, the French franc and the Italian lira, while raising its value against the Japanese yen, the major currency that has stood up best to the dollar's surge. The dollar turned in a mixed performance in European trading today and fell slightly in the United States as traders took profits. (Page D20.)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Beneficial Management Corp., Peapack, N.J., announced that James M. Browne had joined it as executive vice president.     *  Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, a subsidiary of the First Executive Corporation, has named Ronald L. Kehrli vice chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; ;  New Hospital Network Appoints Chief Officers
abstract: Two major hospital groups that have merged into what is believed to be the nation's largest group of nonprofit hospitals have named a former Arthur Young & Company health care consultant as its first president.   Associated Health Systems of Phoenix, holding company for 11 hospital groups, and United Healthcare Systems of Kansas City, Mo., parent of 15 hospital groups, combined Wednesday to form American Healthcare Systems.

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET MEET ON SURPRISE-ATTACK RISK
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States and the Soviet Union had held two days of talks on ways to enhance security and prevent surprise attack in Europe.   State Department officials said the talks, which ended today, had been useful but had failed to break a deadlock.    The talks were conducted by James E. Goodby and Oleg A. Grinevsky, who head the United States and Soviet delegations to the Stockholm conference on measures to build confidence and security.   In response to a Soviet request, the talks here were not given advance publicity, an American said.

headline: Vietnam Returns Bones Believed of Americans
abstract: Vietnam turned over bones believed to be those of eight American servicemen today.   The bones, packed in separate wooden crates, were checked briefly at Hanoi's Noi Bai Airport by United States specialists and loaded onto an Air Force cargo plane for transport to a military identification center in Hawaii.

headline: Fredericks Kullberg In Joint Venture
abstract: Fredericks Kullberg Amato Pisacane is getting into a joint venture that will do direct marketing as well as classified, recruitment and Yellow Pages advertising. The Fredericks venture with Dale Barlow & Company will be called FKAP/Barlow Direct.   Separately, D'Arcy MacManus Masius, which opened a direct-marketing unit called D'Arcy Direct in June, has opened an office of the unit in London.

headline: Talking Businesswith Alghini of Jefferies Group ; On 24-Hour Stock Trading
abstract: Jefferies Group Inc., a Los Angeles-based brokerage firm that is not a member of the New York Stock Exchange, has increasingly become a problem for the Big Board because of its off-floor trading and its willingness to stay open before and after trading hours. Yesterday, for example, during the period the St. Regis Corporation was not trading on the New York Stock Exchange because of Rupert Murdoch's takeover bid, Jefferies was actively putting buyers and sellers together off the floor in the so-called third market.     Jefferies has also been eager to court the international market, which could have played a part in the Big Board's decision a few weeks ago to consider staying open around the clock. According to Ronald A. Alghini, the 44-year-old president and chief operating officer of Jefferies, his firm may even buy into a London brokerage firm to prepare for the day when rules on the London Stock Exchange might be liberalized to allow American firms to trade there. That would put more pressure on the New York exchange to remain open and compete for the business.

headline: THRIFT UNIT REPLACING AUDITORS
abstract: The Financial Corporation of America, apparently trying to severe ties with its troubled past, said yesterday that it was replacing Arthur Andersen & Company as its auditor.    ''This decision by our board does not result from any accounting disagreement with Arthur Andersen,'' William Popejoy, chairman and chief executive of Financial, said in a statement. ''We have simply decided that it is appropriate to make a change at this time.''

headline: PATENTS ;
abstract: Rubik's Cube Inventor Devises a New Toy    Erno Rubik of Budapest, who invented the famous puzzle called the Rubik's Cube, has been granted a patent for what is designated as a logical toy.  Patent 4,471,959 indicates that a pattern of numerals or other figures is printed on a number of game pieces that can be moved about by hand. Mr. Rubik got four patents last year for various puzzle toys.

headline: Honduras Anti-U.S. Protest
abstract: Hundreds of workers marched here Friday to demand the withdrawal of United States forces from Honduras in a demonstration organized by the country's major labor unions. Many Hondurans have become alarmed by the growing United States military presence here, and Honduran officials have complained about the country's low return for being Washington's staunchest ally in Central America.

headline: WENDY'S THEME RESUMES
abstract: SHE'S back. Clara Peller, the octogenarian who uttered the now famous burger challenge, ''Where's the beef?'' will return in new television advertisements for Wendy's International Inc. this fall.     More ''Where's the beef?'' advertising may seem like overkill. But Wendy's, which sold a record number of hamburgers during the initial $19 million campaign that ended this April, is convinced that there is enough freshness in the phrase to justify a $30 million campaign the second time around.

headline: SEBASTIANI ADOPTS A PREMIUM LOOK
abstract: SONOMA, Calif.    For nearly 40 years, August Sebastiani was the living embodiment of the California vineyard that bears his name. Wearing bib overalls and affecting the demeanor of a simple but crafty farmer, he was as omnipresent in his company's marketing efforts as is Frank Perdue, the chicken king, in his. ''There is no Mr. Almaden, and Paul Masson has been dead a long time,'' Mr. Sebastiani commented a few years ago. ''But,'' he was quick to add, ''there    is    a Mr. Sebastiani.''   Thus, when August Sebastiani died in 1980 at the age of 66, many of his fellow vintners predicted that Sebastiani Vineyards would not long survive him. His son Sam, then 38 years old, had been running the business end of the winery. Sam, too, is flamboyant in his attire - his chosen persona is that of the wealthy rancher, replete with expensive cowboy shirts and boots. But until his father's death, he was the quintessential low- profile businessman when it came to marketing. Wine industry insiders doubted he would ever manifest the type of strong personality that had made Sebastiani Vineyards a smashing success.

headline: 16 Thai Communists Seized in Purported Plot
abstract: The police have arrested 16 high- ranking officials of the outlawed Communist Party implicated in a plot to overthrow the Thai Government, officials said today.   ''They have clearly been seeking support from abroad to overthrow the Government,'' the national police chief, Gen. Narong Mahanond, said.

headline: Data Bank; July 1, 1984
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: BOND PRICES UP MODERATLEY
abstract: The credit market maintained its upbeat tone yesterday, as fresh signs that the economy is slackening sent bond prices moderately higher after Thursday's sharp rally.    The Treasury's 30-year, 12.5 percent bonds rose 9/32 of a point to an offered price of 100 19/32, to yield 12.42 percent. Some short-term interest rates also slipped lower. Federal funds, the reserves that banks lend each other overnight, fell to 11 7/16 percent late in the day, from an average of 11.71 percent on Thursday.

headline: A BRAZILIAN CHALLENGER SEEKS TO UNIT THE DISAFFECTED
abstract: Amid the optimism of the tumultuous street campaign here earlier this year calling for direct presidential elections, many opposition politicians were confident they could defeat any Government-backed candidate at the polls and become Brazil's first civilian head of state in two decades.    But last month, when the departing military Government insisted that the next president be chosen in January by a 686-member Electoral College - in which the official party enjoys a 36-seat majority - opposition leaders quickly concluded that only one of their number could also beat the Government at its own game.   Now, in his crowded offices here, and in almost daily private gatherings around the country, Tancredo Neves, the baldish, diminutive 74-year-old Governor of Minas Gerais, is busily trying to seal an alliance that will insure him victory in the Electoral College. The forces he is seeking to unite include diverse opposition forces and disaffected sectors of the official Democratic Social Party.

headline: Georgia-Pacific Increases 50%
abstract: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said today that record profits in paper operations helped raise its overall profits 50 percent, to $84 million, or 78 cents a share, from $56 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier.   Revenues totaled $1.8 billion, up 5.9 percent from $1.7 billion.

headline: MILITARY COURT IN ARGENTINA DEFENDS OFFICERS
abstract: The Armed Forces Supreme Council has said in an interim report that there was ''nothing objectionable'' about the orders given by Argentine military officials during a 1970's antisubversion campaign in which 9,000 people disappeared.    The report, made public Tuesday, said the officers could be held ''indirectly responsible'' only for failing to control the actions of their subordinates.   The council's conclusions were in a report to an appeals court in which it said that it could not complete its work by an Oct. 11 deadline. The appeals court can decide to give the Supreme Council, a nine-member military court, an extension or transfer the cases to a civilian court. The council has already received one 60-day extension.

headline: EGYPT LINKS LIBYA AND IRAN TO MINES
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak said today that Iran and Libya might be responsible for the recent explosions that have damaged ships in the Red Sea. But he acknowledged that Egypt had no proof.    It was the first time that Mr. Mubarak or any other senior Egyptian had suggested openly that Iran and Libya were suspected of having planted the explosives. More than a dozen ships have been damaged, some lightly. No sinkings have been reported.

headline: HORIZON SEEKS TO OPEN BANK IN CITY
abstract: The Horizon Bancorporation, the fourth-largest bank holding company in New Jersey, will apply to the New York State Banking Department within the next month to establish a consumer bank in lower Manhattan, William J. Sheppard, Horizon's president and chief executive officer said in an interview Friday.    Last week, the banking department approved the first such application from a New Jersey bank, the First National State Bancorporation of Newark. First National, the largest banking organization in New Jersey, has assets of more than $10 billion.   ''New York is basically underbanked,'' Mr. Sheppard said. While there seems to be a bank branch on practically every corner in downtown Manhattan, he said, each downtown branch has a lot more customers than the average branch elsewhere in the United States.

headline: Hospital Corp. Pact Terminated
abstract: The Hospital Corporation of America and the Health Resources Corporation of America said that, after further discussions, they had terminated the agreement announced Tuesday for Hospital Corporation to acquire Health Resources.

headline: HARROD'S BARGAIN HUNTERS
abstract: Harrods, the elegant London department store, has always been on the ''must see'' list for tourists. But nowadays, Americans are flocking there for a different reason.

headline: TAX SHIFTS ASSAYED AS HEARINGS START
abstract: The best- known Republican proposal for a so- called flat tax would cut taxes for upper-income taxpayers by about 15 percent while raising taxes 2 to 3 percent for middle-income taxpayers, according to a preliminary analysis by the Joint Committee on Taxation released today.    The proposal is the Fair and Simple Tax, or FAST, plan backed by Representative Jack Kemp, Republican of New York, and Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin.   The analysis by the nonpartisan Joint Committee also found that the best-known Democratic proposal for tax simplification would not change the current distribution of the tax burden among income clases. This proposal, the Fair Tax Plan, is co-sponsored by Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri.

headline: TECHNOLOGY: THE JAPANESE CHALLENGE - Ninth article of a series to appear periodically; JAPAN'S COMPUTER WEAKNESS
abstract: Since the beginning of the personal computer business about seven years ago, Japanese companies have been expected to invade the rich American market and take a big share of it, as they had with automobiles and televisions.   But the invasion has never materialized. And many Japanese executives are growing increasingly pessimistic that it ever will, at least in the same way it did in autos and consumer electronics.   ''For the next 10 or 15 years, Japan has no choice but to follow the American lead,'' said Kikuo Okuda, editor of Business Computer News.   The Japanese manufacturers are a step behind because their computer technology - especially in software - and their marketing efforts lag behind America's. Analysts also cite cultural differences that exacerbate technological and marketing problems.

headline: Pullman, REDM
abstract: The Pullman Transportation Company said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire REDM Industries for $20.375 a share.

headline: T.V.A. Cancels 4 Reactors KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 29
abstract: Directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority voted today   to cancel four unfinished   nuclear reactors on which it   had already invested $4 billion. The agency said completing   the plants would have cost its   customers another estimated  $12.5 billion in rates.

headline: BOND ISSUERS HOLDING BACK
abstract: When long-term interest rates fell in July and early August while short- term rates held steady, many investment bankers and economists expected corporations to storm the bond markets for money. All year long they had been building up mountainous amounts of short-term debt because the dramatically lower rates in 90-day commercial paper or from banks were too tempting to pass up.     The expected torrent, however, turned out to be a trickle. A few big names such as Texaco, Xerox and Georgia Pacific returned to the bond market, but the vast majority of industrial corporations with balance sheets overloaded by short-term debt have elected to hold out for even lower rates. And in recent weeks, when the cost of borrowing beyond several years moved up again, the calendar of coming bond offerings has taken on a decidedly blank look.    ''Many companies are using the election as a reason to sit back and see if rates will come down,'' said David C. Batten, a managing director of the First Boston Corporation. Although there was some pickup in bond financing over the past several months, he said, ''it was relatively small considering the significant group of companies waiting for lower rates.''

headline: A SECOND BIG WEEK FOR WALL ST.
abstract: Frenzy, confusion and panic buying continued to mark Wall Street last week, as stock prices cooled down, then roared ahead and cooled down again on Friday. Volume on the Big Board broke all records for the second week in a row, with 754.5 million shares changing hands. Institutions continued to dominate the buying, apparently not wanting to miss out on a rally that has seen the Dow jump more than 100 points in two weeks, but individuals did join the action more. After torrid trading on Monday, and slower trading on Tuesday and Wednesday, Thursday looked like a slow day until trading exploded late in the day. The Dow jumped more than 30 points to close up 27.94 points on the day. Friday saw a continuation of the last hour with the Dow surging 22 points in the morning. But the rally weakened and by the end of the day the Dow had lost six points, to end the week at 1,218.01, up almost 16 points on the week.

headline: Successor to Chairman At First National State
abstract: Robert R. Ferguson Jr., president and chief executive officer of the First National State Bancorporation of Newark, has been elected chairman of the board.     Mr. Ferguson, 60, will continue as president and chief executive officer.    He succeeds W. Paul Stillman, 86. Mr. Stillman has served as chairman since the bank holding company, the largest in New Jersey, was formed in 1969. First National said yesterday that Mr. Stillman will continue to serve as chairman of the board's executive committee.

headline: No Malignancy for Begin
abstract: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin, undergoing tests for a prostate gland ailment, shows no signs of malignant disease, a spokesman for Shaare Zedek Hospital said today. She said that Mr. Begin's doctors had completed most of their tests and that they would decide later this week whether he needs surgery. Mr. Begin is feeling well and has been spending most of his time reading, the spokesman said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, JULY 25, 1984   The Economy    Factory orders for durable goods dropped 3.2 percent in June, the second drop in the last three months. The decrease indicated that factory output would slacken correspondingly in coming months, but was not taken as a sign of any abrupt halt to the economy's expansion. (Page D1.)   Consumer prices were up only 0.2 percent in June, indicating that the low inflation that has persisted since the recession may be moving even lower. The rise, equal to May's, represents a compound annual rate of 2 percent. Prices of services were up, but gasoline and clothing were off with food barely higher. (D1.) Prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose 0.3 percent. (D6.)

headline: A 7TH LIBERIAN IS LINKED TO PLOT
abstract: The acting chief of a new opposition party surrendered today to the military Government, becoming the seventh prominent Liberian arrested on charges of plotting to overthrow the head of state, Gen. Samuel K. Doe.   The politician, Dusty Wolokolie, the acting chairman of the Liberian People's Party, was accompanied to the Justice Ministry by two church leaders, according to the Anglican Archbishop, George Browne.    The church has protested reported disappearances and the sudden wave of arrests since Aug. 19, when General Doe returned home early from a European trip amid rumors of a coup plot.

headline: Intermountain Bid
abstract: Plateau Resources Inc. said it had made a tender offer of $26 a share for Intermountain Gas Industries Inc. Intermountain had about 1.5 million common shares outstanding as of April 23, which would give the offer a value of $39 million.

headline: INDUSTRY OUTPUT UP
abstract: Despite expectations that the economy's stubbornly good health would aggravate inflation, an important measure of prices held steady in June for the third consecutive month, the Labor Department reported today.     The department said its Producer Price Index for finished goods, reflecting the prices that industry charges retailers, showed no change in June and has risen only 2.2 percent over the past year. Another price index, for raw materials, fell last month by 1 percent, its third consecutive drop.   In further indications of the economy's overall strength, the Government said industrial production rose five-tenths of 1 percent and retail sales eight-tenths of 1 percent, both exceeding their gains in May. (Page 45.)

headline: General Foods Net Rises 86.9%
abstract: The General Foods Corporation said yesterday that earnings for its fiscal first quarter rose 86.9 percent, to $111.6 million, or $2.17 a share, from $59.7 million, or $1.15 a share, a year earlier.    Revenues for the quarter, which ended June 30, increased 5.6 percent, to $2.26 billion, from $2.14 billion a year earlier.   The company, based in White Plains, is one of the nation's leading food concerns and is a major producer of coffee. The results include a one-time after-tax gain of $59.8 million, or $1.16 a share, from the sale of the Gaines Pet Foods business. The figures also include a provision of $20.7 million for a restructuring of international operations, which reduced earnings 40 cents a share.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Continental Air in Black
abstract: The Continental Airlines Corporation earned $10.4 million, or 40 cents a share, in the second quarter, the airline's first quarterly profit since it filed for protection from its creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws last September.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
abstract: Grand Metropolitan Appoints U.S. Head    When the American Express Company bought Investors Diversified Services last January, it tapped Harvey Golub, a 45-year-old management consultant with McKinsey & Company, as president and chief executive officer of the big Minneapolis- based financial services company.    The appointment was logical enough since Mr. Golub had helped American Express as part of the McKinsey team that studied the company before American Express bought it.    In the aftermath, however, Walter D. Scott, 52, who had run the company as president and chief executive of I.D.S. for the previous four years, became chairman. It was no secret, however, that Mr. Scott, a former Wall Street investment banker who had also run the Lehman Brothers Chicago office, liked the idea of being boss.

headline: DRUSE LEADER ASSAILS U.S. POLICY
abstract: Walid Jumblat, the Druse leader, was quoted in an interview published today as saying the United States should change its Middle East policies ''or nothing will protect its embassy'' from new bombing attacks.   ''In principle, we have denounced the bombing,'' the conservative Beirut daily, Al Anwar, quoted Mr. Jumblat as saying, in a reference to the explosion that devastasted the United States Embassy near East Beirut last Thursday. ''But the United States naturally has to realize that nothing will protect its embassy if it persists with its current policy, no matter what precautions it will take,'' he added.

headline: Becton Dickinson
abstract: Becton Dickinson & Company said it had agreed in principle to acquire about 10 percent of Applied Biosystems Inc.'s common stock for $26 a share.

headline: Intermountain Bid
abstract: Intermountain Gas Industries said its board had unanimously rejected an unsolicited tender offer from Plateau Resources Inc. to acquire the company for $26 a share, or a total of about $39 million. Intermountain said that the price was inadequate and that the offer was not in the best interests of the company and its shareholders. In over-the-counter trading today, Intermountain was quoted at $25.50 bid, up 75 cents.

headline: MOSCOW INVITES A JOINT PLEDGE ON SPACE TALKS
abstract: The Soviet Union said today that it had proposed to the United States that the two sides issue a joint statement to demonstrate their readiness for serious negotiations on banning weapons in space.    A Government spokesman said Washington's response would show whether it is serious about accepting the Soviet offer for talks in September or whether it intends to continue what he called its ''deceptive game'' around the issue.    (In Washington, a White House spokesman said the United States was ''pleased'' that Moscow had accepted what he characterized as an American proposal that a text be drawn up for a joint statement on an agenda. But the spokesman indicated that the proposed Soviet wording fell short of what was acceptable to Washington. Page A4.)

headline: No Headline
abstract: Creditor Seizes Air Florida Jet MIAMI, Sept. 5 (AP) - One   of Air Florida's four remaining   jets has been repossessed by a   creditor, but officials at Midway Airlines said the action   would not affect its negotiations to take over the grounded   carrier. Louise Gilliam, a Midway   spokesman, said the Chicago-   based airline had been in touch   with the Great American Life Insurance Company of Cincinnati   about Air Florida's financial   problems.

headline: A BOOM THAT BURNS BRIGHT, FOR NOW
abstract: WASHINGTON WHEN the nation's banks raised the prime interest rate last week for the fourth time this year, President Reagan blamed an    unfounded ''fear of the future.'' Nothing, it seemed to him, could be more ludicrous.  Had he not orchestrated the economy's strongest recovery in more than 30 years, with the lowest inflation in more than 10? Had he not engineered a recovery that at almost every turn produced better results than many predicted? As the second half of 1984 begins, in fact, Mr. Reagan has every reason to be confident about the future - at least through the November election. Though many economists see problems after that, particularly in 1985, the economy has rarely shone so brightly on a President facing re-election.  Mr. Reagan is presiding over the recovery that wouldn't stop. Eighteen months after the expansion began, the economy is still booming, with growth soaring to 9.7 percent in the first quarter and 5.7 percent, by preliminary estimates, in the second. Despite such heated activity, inflation remains in check at 4.6 percent for the year. And unemployment, currently at 7.4 percent, is already below the 7.5 percent rate where it hovered on election day 1980. All of which apparently has made voters feel good. According to the University of Michigan's sentiment survey, confidence in the economy among consumers is the highest it has been since the mid-1960's.

headline: ASHLAND OIL SEES LOSS FROM SALE
abstract: Ashland Oil Inc. announced yesterday that it would have a one-time, $270 million after-tax loss in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 from the planned sale of non-petroleum businesses it acquired in 1981 and from the closing of an unprofitable methanol venture started in 1979.    Management has recommended that the directors maintain the common stock dividend at its current level, Ashland said. Its stock was down 12.5 cents a share yesterday, to $26.125, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: 12.8% DROP IN STARTS OF HOUSING
abstract: Construction of new houses skidded 12.8 percent in August, to an annual rate of 1,537,000 units, the lowest since December 1982, the Commerce Department reported today.    The decline, which was steeper than most analysts expected, was mainly attributed to rising interest rates that, for conventional mortgages, briefly exceeded 15 percent this summer.    August was the second consecutive month of falling housing starts, representing further evidence of an overall slowing of the economic expansion dating from late 1982.    The Commerce Department also reported today that personal income and spending rose by smaller amounts last month than in July. The department is to publish Thursday its initial, or ''flash,'' estimate of third- quarter gross national product, the broadest measure of the nation's output of goods and services. The estimate is certain to be well below the 7.6 percent annual growth rate of the second quarter.

headline: TAX CAUTION FOR PENSIONS
abstract: WASHINGTON Confronted with several proposals for a radical overhaul of the tax system, some groups with lots to lose have started to bang hard on the alarm bells.   The Employee Benefit Research Institute, for example, has invested about $150,000 in a lengthy study it will publish this month that concludes, among other things, that pension benefits go mainly to the middle class, not the rich, and that the pension tax preferences enjoyed by both employers and beneficiaries cost the Government far less than was previously believed.    The hope is that those supporting various ''flat- tax'' and consumption-tax plans will take a second look at the adverse effects these would have on benefits. Pension assets alone now total more than $1,000 billion.

headline: Money Supply Is Up $1 Billion
abstract: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply rose $1 billion in the week ended June 25. Credit markets were buoyed by the report, since the rise was smaller than the $2.5 billion increase many Wall Street economists had predicted.    Many analysts said the smaller- than-expected rise eased pressures for the Federal Reserve to immediately adopt a tighter credit stance. But they said there was the growing likelihood the Fed would soon be forced to move to a stricter monetary policy in the face of signs that the economy is continuing to expand at a strong pace.

headline: Ruling for Air Florida
abstract: Debt-ridden Air Florida was given court permission today to end a deal to sell its Miami-London route to Eastern Airlines. But Federal Bankruptcy Judge Sidney Weaver reserved until Friday a decision on whether Air Florida also could end an agreement to sell Eastern some landing slots. Air Florida asked the court to allow it to terminate the $7 million deal after reaching a tentative reorganization agreement with Midway Airlines.

headline: PATENTS; Recurving The Eye's Cornea
abstract: $ A New Jersey eye surgeon, Dr. Neville A. Baron, has devised a method of recurving the cornea of the eye with the aim of eliminating the need for glasses.   Indeed, according to Dr. Baron, who was granted patent 4,461,294 this week, his method might restore normal vision to many of the millions of people who are afflicted with near- sightedness or astigmatism.

headline: Sudan Invites Rebels To Talk Instead of Fight
abstract: The Government today urged rebels in the country's south to abandon violence and open talks with the authorities.   ''The door will always be open for the outlaws of the southern regions to return home,'' said a statement from the presidential office that was carried by the Sudanese press agency.

headline: Kroger Markets
abstract: The Kroger Company said it would close 70 supermarkets in southeastern Michigan Saturday, as scheduled, following rejection of concessions by the union representing its 4,200 clerks and cashiers.

headline: President Set to Leave Electrosound Group
abstract: Electrosound Group Inc., a record pressing and audio equipment company based in Hauppauge, L.I., announced that Richard H. Burkett will resign as president and chief executive officer, effective Nov. 1, to pursue other business opportunities.   Mr. Burkett said his successor would most likely be Richard Projain, president of IGC, a manufacturer of graphic display controllers that Electrosound agreed to acquire in July.    In a telephone interview, Mr. Burkett, 47, said Electrosound's improved performance this year and its successful product restructuring ''marked a convenient point for me to look at leveraging myself into different opportunities.''

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.81     An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds   compiled weekly by The Bond   Buyer.   Aa Utility Bonds*13.63     Salomon Brothers' estimate for   new long-term issues.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Rates After Continental    The Federal bailout of the Continental Illinois Corporation eliminated a major threat to the stability of the banking system. But that does not give the Federal Reserve a free hand to raise interest rates - a development that could bring on loan defaults that threaten other banks.    In the wake of Continental's collapse, the Fed was under pressure to keep rates steady lest it make a bad financial situation worse. But even with Continental safe again, high rates remain a threat to banking, as the Fed chairman, Paul A. Volcker, made clear in Congressional testimony last week. Banks are already suffering from problem loans to Latin countries and from weak earnings. The thrifts, too, are feeling a rates pinch.

headline: Reynolds Metals To Close Unit
abstract: The Reynolds Metals Company said it would close permanently the chemical products facility at its Hurricane Creek plant in Arkansas.

headline: OIL SERVICE CONCERN TO BUY SEDCO
abstract: Sedco Inc. and Schlumberger Ltd. reported yesterday that they had agreed to a merger of Sedco into a subsidiary of Schlumberger in a transaction valued at more than $1 billion.    The merger of the Dallas-based Sedco, an offshore drilling company,, into the Schlumberger subsidiary is subject to approval of Sedco's shareholders.   Trading in Sedco's stock was halted for much of the day yesterday; it had soared $3.375 in abbreviated activity Thursday, to $37.125, with the volume heavy. After trading was resumed yesterday, the stock rose $8.875, to $46, on the New York Stock Exchange. Schlumberger fell $1.125 a share, to $46.625.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ; Argentine Units Besiege 200 Striking Policemen
abstract: A force of 600 federal policemen and border patrolmen today surrounded the Tucuman provincial police headquarters, occupied by 200 striking officers demanding more pay and command changes.   Fifteen leaders of the strikers surrendered to a court in the city 700 miles northwest of Buenos Aires after a judge ordered their arrest.

headline: Arco Dropping Metals Division
abstract: The Atlantic Richfield Company, blocked last month by the Justice Department from selling its unprofitable aluminum operations to Alcan Aluminium Ltd. of Montreal, said it intends to shed its entire metals division.

headline: The U.N. Today July 17, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: U.S. ANALYSTS FIND MARCOS'S RULE IN DANGER
abstract: Reagan Administration and Senate staff analysts have concluded that the Philippine Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos is in serious political trouble and may not survive.    The analysts have also found that Communist insurgents are growing in strength throughout the country.    According to a Senate staff report made public today, ''many Filipinos'' see it as ''a forgone conclusion that the Marcos era is in its terminal stage.''    To the Senate staff analysts, the widespread view in the Philippines is that ''if Marcos and his group cling to the reins of government by force of arms, there will be a vastly reduced chance for the restoration'' of democracy in the country.

headline: CONGRESS VOTES STIFFER WARNINGS OF TOBACCO RISK
abstract: Congress today approved a bill that requires cigarette manufacturers to tell smokers more forcefully that they are endangering their health.     Quick passage by the House of Representatives in the afternoon followed morning approval in the Senate, the voice votes coming after a summerlong delay in which domestic politics and foreign imports played key roles.   Currently, required labels on cigarette packages and advertisements warn that ''the Surgeon General has determined that cigarette smoking is dangerous to your health.'' The bill passed today calls for four alternating warnings that would specifically express, among other things, a relationship between cigarette smoking and lung cancer, heart disease and emphysema and would warn pregnant women that smoking might result in fetal injury and premature birth.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Aug. 1, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Ad Hoc Committee on Drafting an International Convention Against the Training of Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Paying Dividends
abstract: The Enterra Corporation said its directors had voted to eliminate the company's dividend.

headline: New Talks Scheduled In British Coal Strike
abstract: The National Coal Board and union leaders today scheduled a new round of talks, but on terms that held out little hope for a quick end to Britain's six-month-old coal strike.   The mine union leader, Arthur Scargill, said he had accepted an invitation from the chairman of the National Coal Board, Ian MacGregor, for talks on Sunday, but Mr. Scargill immediately reiterated his demand that Mr. MacGregor drop plans to close money-losing pits - the crux of the dispute.

headline: MEXICO COOLING ON LATIN REBELS, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
abstract: The United States accused Nicaragua's Government of direct involvement in cocaine trafficking. Page A6.           WASHINGTON, July 18 - Reagan Administration officials say they sense an encouraging change in Mexico's policy on Central America as it seems to back away from its strong support of the Sandinistas in Nicaragua and the Salvadoran guerrillas.   Salvadoran rebels living in Mexico say they are feeling pressure from the Mexican Government of President Miguel de la Madrid to curtail their public activities.

headline: TOWER'S COSTLY GAMBLE TO SELL RECORDS
abstract: MORE than 40 years ago, when Tommy Dorsey and Glenn Miller were the rage and 78's the style, 16-year old Russ Solomon scared up $250 to start a makeshift record shop in the back of his father's Tower Drugstore, next to Sacramento's Tower Theater. Demand was high and, since overhead was virtually nonexistent, the high school entrepreneur kept beefing up inventory, tripling his floor space in just a couple of years.    Music tastes and record sizes are different today, of course, but Mr. Solomon has stuck with the approach that he stumbled on in high school. Since 1960, when he finally moved his first store to a stand-alone location across the street, his record supermarkets have grown into a chain of nearly 40 outlets, with shelf after shelf of records and tapes.    This ''deep catalogue'' approach has been rather attention-getting in many American communities. ''Solomon has the highest profile in any town he comes into with his record stores,'' says an executive with Musicland, the nation's largest chain of record stores, among them the Sam Goody outlets.

headline: Resorts Issue
abstract: Resorts International Financing is offering $200 million of 16 5/8 percent subordinated debentures due in 2004 at a price of 97.839, to yield 17 percent, through underwriters led by Bear Stearns & Company. The size of the issue, which was rated Ba-3 by Moody's and Bx by S.& P., was increased from $150 million.

headline: WHAT'S NEW AT MCDONALD's ; INTRODUCING THE MCDONALD'S COMPLEX
abstract: In November, McDonald's plans to begin construction at a 30-acre site that will house not only one of its restaurants, but also a motel, gas station and convenience store. The complex, to be called McStop, will be located near an interstate highway north of Minneapolis and will be geared to motorists.

headline: Talks by Riegel On Acquisition The Riegel Textile Corporation said it is holding talks with
abstract: an investor group that is considering the acquisition of all of   the company's stock.  On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Riegel   jumped $3.125, to $26.75, The   company has 3.7 million shares   outstanding.

headline: 3 Issues Priced For Farm Credit
abstract: Three issues of Federal Farm Credit Banks consolidated systemwide bonds, totaling $1.58 billion, were priced yesterday.

headline: A Colombian Lawmaker Is Killed by Gunmen
abstract: Two men on a motorcycle shot and killed a Liberal Party legislator today and three other gunmen shot at bodyguards of the Colombian Attorney General, the police said.   The police said the legislator, Ivan Dario Morales, was killed in the center of the northwestern city of Medellin.

headline: MRS. THATCHER HINTS SHE WILL ACT AGAINST STRIKES
abstract: Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher hinted today that her Government was prepared to use emergency powers if necessary to beat strikes in the docks and the coal industry.   ''The Government will do everything necessary to keep the country working,'' the Conservative leader said in a speech.   ''The country will not be held to ransom by a tiny minority - 200,000 at the most - who are trying to impose their will on the other 55 million of us,'' she said.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The Instructor Book Club, a division of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, to Peter Vane Advertising.

headline: COMMODORE TRADE SECRETS
abstract: A Pennsylvania judge today temporarily extended an injunction that prevents four former employees of Commodore International Ltd. from revealing any Commodore trade secrets at their new jobs with Atari Inc.   Judge M. Joseph Melody Jr., who issued the original injunction earlier this week in response to a Commodore suit, said the order would be ''extended in full force'' pending further notice.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: *  Allied Nursing Care Inc. , Oklahoma City, said it intends to buy all the outstanding common stock of U.S. Lifecare Inc. of Dallas for $50,000 and 700,000 shares of Allied's common stock.     *  Guardian Industries Corp. , Northville, Mich., a manufacturer and fabricator of flat glass products, said it plans to build a glass-fiber insulation plant in Mineral Wells, Miss.

headline: National Medical, Grace Pact
abstract: W. R. Grace & Company and an investor group including executives of National Medical Inc. have reached an agreement to buy National Medical for $19.25 a share, or $360 million, the companies announced yesterday.    The transaction calls for the management of National Medical, a leading dialysis service and product company based in Boston, and other related investors to own 51 percent of the company's stock. Grace, an international chemical company with interests in natural resources and consumer services, will own the remaining 49 percent. National Medical's management currently owns about 3 percent of the outstanding shares.

headline: THE TUMBLE IN COMMODITIES
abstract: Prices of raw materials at the nation's factories and farms, after rising last winter, have fallen sharply in the last two months even as the business expansion remains unexpectedly strong.    This development could be good for consumers to the extent that falling prices for commodities keep the inflation rate low. But broadly falling consumer prices is a worrisome economic phenomenon known as deflation, usually associated with periods of economic contraction or even depression.    Deflation, if it develops, would pose serious problems for the companies, mines and farmers that produce these commodities as well as for the debtor nations of the third world that need higher prices for their commodity exports to help pay off their huge bank debts.    'Tough Year' for Farmers    ''With commodity prices so low, it's going to be an extremely tough year for the U.S. farmer,'' said David J. Rinehimer, director of commodities research at Thomas McKinnon Securities. ''And many developing nations aren't going to be able to turn around with commodity prices working themselves lower.''

headline: Argentine Mutiny Ends
abstract: SAN MIGUEL DE TUCUMAN, Argentina, Aug. 8 (Reuters) - About 600 policemen surrendered to federal forces today after an eight-day mutiny over pay, the official press agency Telam said. The agency said the mutiny ended without violence after provincial government officials talked with policemen inside the barricaded police headquarters.

headline: ECONOMIC MEASURE OF FUTURE MONTHS DOWN 0.9% IN JUNE
abstract: The index of leading economic indicators, which the Government uses to project the economy's performance six months or a year ahead, showed a sharp decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department said today.     The index is notoriously volatile, subject to revisions that can show it moving in the opposite direction from the one first reported. But the steepness of the decline reported today appeared to confirm a trend toward slower expansion that has been reflected in the index since spring.  Analysts expressed relief that the heated economic growth of the last 19 months appeared to be cooling. ''We need a report like that,'' said Morris Cohen, an economic forecaster in Hackensack, N.J. ''Everybody's been saying we need a slowdown. And, lo and behold, here's the evidence.''

headline: Chrysler-Korea Plan Opposed DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP) -
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation and   the Samsung Industrial Group   have drawn opposition from   South Korean auto makers as   they work out details of a joint   auto-building agreement.  Executives of the two companies are holding meetings at   Chrysler headquarters in suburban Detroit on how to win the   South Korean Government's   approval for the venture, which   has been criticized by South   Korean auto makers, according to a Chrysler officer who requested anonymity. According to unidentified   Samsung officials quoted in the   South Korean press, the two   companies plan to build a $350   million assembly plant in   Changwon, south of Seoul.

headline: LONGER-TERM U.S. ISSUES EXPECTED
abstract: Treasury financing this week is confined to the regular weekly sale of new three- and six-month bills, but dealers in Government securities are looking ahead to a heavy supply of longer-term issues to be auctioned later this month.    In advance of today's bill auctions, the outstanding three-month issue was bid late Friday at 10.55 percent and the six-month issue was 10.68 percent.    Tomorrow the Treasury is expected to announce next week's bill auction. Some analysts expect the Treasury to leave room under the debt ceiling for future offerings of notes and bonds by reducing the size of the next few weekly auctions to $10 billion from the recent 13.2 billion.

headline: Asarco Cutback
abstract: Asarco Inc. said it would suspend open-pit mining at its Silver Bell copper mine on Aug. 15.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 27, 1984:  MONDAY PetrolaneRepublic CorpRio Grande IndusStandard ProductsWatkins-Johnson   TUESDAY Angelica CorpMacy (RH)Denny's Inc.New England Elec SysEDO CorpSouthwest AirlinesEasco CorpTuscon Elec PwrGannett CoWestvaco Corp  WEDNESDAY Barry Wright CorpPhilip MorrisConwood CorpReading & Bates CorpCooper LabsStanley WarnerDeere & CoTextron InE-Systems   THURSDAY American Med IntlArvin IndusAmetek IncThompson Medical  FRIDAY   Aetna Life & CasGreen Mountain Pwr

headline: Hanover Bank Gets D.&P. Rating
abstract: Duff & Phelps, a Chicago-based rating agency, assigned an initial rating of D.&P. 5 to the senior debt of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. D.&P. 5 corresponds to a rating of high single-A.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * Essence magazine raising its rate base 14.3 percent, to 800,000, with the January issue.

headline: Colombian Guerrillas End Their 20-Year War
abstract: The left-wing Popular Liberation Army signed a truce with the Government today to end 20 years of insurgency, the president of the Government Peace Commission said.   Guerrilla military commanders and Peace Commission officials signed the pact in the city of Medellin, 300 miles northeast of Bogota, the Commission President, John Agudelo Rios, told reporters.

headline: Dutch Industry Output
abstract: The Netherlands' seasonally adjusted industrial production fell 2 percent in July from June, but rose 4.2 percent from July 1983, the Central Bureau of Statistics reported on Friday. Manufacturing output, a narrower measure that excludes the natural gas sector, decreased nine-tenths of 1 percent from June but was up 4 percent from a year earlier.

headline: British Airlines in Route War
abstract: A struggle over the shape of the British airline industry is expected to be resolved soon when the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher decides whether to transfer some of British Airways' routes to other British airlines before selling control of the state-owned company to the private sector.   The route transfers were proposed in July by the Civil Aviation Authority after a lengthy study. The proposal has left the Government torn between its desire to leave British Airways powerful and attractive to potential investors for next spring's public offering and its commitment to increase competition and lower fares, on both domestic and international flights.    The Government's decision, expected by the end of the month, comes at a time of upheaval in the British and European airline markets.

headline: DENG AS OUTCAST: DAUGHTER TELLS OF THE ORDEAL
abstract: A daughter of Deng Xiaoping, in an article published on the Chinese leader's 80th birthday, today described for the first time her father's ordeal as a political outcast during the Cultural Revolution.   Mr. Deng operated a lathe in a tractor factory, lived in a brick house with no heat, grew cabbages and beans to feed his family and read Marx and Lenin late into the night, the article said.   The description of Mr. Deng's humiliation at the hands of Mao Zedong and his followers was provided by one of Mr. Deng's five children, identified only as Mao Mao. A 3,000-word article under this name filled a half-page of the Communist Party newspaper People's Daily today.

headline: A.T.&T. ACCORD
abstract: Telefonica, Spain's telephone monopoly, said that it had signed an agreement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for the production of integrated circuits in Spain and that the initial investment in the project would be $200 million.

headline: NCR OFFERS NEW PERSONAL COMPUTER
abstract: The NCR Corporation, whose personal computer has not sold well, introduced a second personal computer, which uses the same electronic brain used in the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal Computer. The new machine is thus able to run many of the popular business programs, written for the I.B.M. machine, including 1-2-3 Lotus and dBase II, NCR said.

headline: West Bank University Shut After Israeli Raid
abstract: An Arab university in the occupied West Bank was closed today for four months because of what the Israeli Civil Administration called ''hostile and inflammatory'' activity at the university.   The closing of An Najah University in Nablus came after Israeli soldiers arrested three students Sunday and confiscated ''nationalistic and provocative'' materials that were displayed in a Palestine Week exhibit, the Israeli authorities said.

headline: FLORIDA FARES CUT BY EASTERN
abstract: Eastern Airlines touched off a fare war yesterday among major carriers in the New York-Florida market.    In an effort to become the dominant carrier, Eastern announced that, beginning next Monday, its lowest round-trip fare between New York area airports and five Florida cities would be $198.    The Eastern decision had been known within the industry on Friday and both Pan American World Airways and Delta Air Lines, Eastern's two major competitors, said they would match the $198 round-trip fare.    Services Cited by Eastern    Several low-cost, no-frills New York-Florida carriers, including People Express and Northeastern International Airways, already have base fares that are lower than those announced by Eastern. But Eastern believes its new fares are fully competitive because they include such services as free baggage check-in and meal service as well as flights to Florida's largest airports.

headline: SOVIET SAID TO PRACTICE LANDINGS IN SWEDEN
abstract: A British military yearbook, Jane's Fighting Ships, says Soviet commandos have carried out scores of practice landings on the Swedish coast over the last 20 years.   The assertion was heatedly denied today by the Soviet Union.

headline: HONG KONG'S SHARED FACTORIES
abstract: The banner must seem a little strange to the 200 Chinese who work beneath it every day in the cramped factory housed in a building that looks more like an apartment house than a manufacturing center.   Swinging gently from the ceiling above the crowded floor of the Tai Hing Moks factory, the sign proclaims in sweeping red Chinese characters: ''A Warm Welcome to the Cabbage Patch.''   In a similar loft space, just down the hall and separated from the Moks factory by a thin wall on which hangs a small Buddhist shrine, employees of a very different factory, the Ka Hing Plastic Company, are stamping out thousands of buck-toothed, Chipmunks-brand soap dispensers from long sheets of bright red and yellow plastic.   Tai Hing Moks, which every month turns out 300,000 of the Cabbage Patch handbags and wallets that appeared in the wake of the celebrated dolls, and Kay Hing, which so far this year has shipped 120,000 of the soap- holding chipmunks to K Mart stores in the United States, are just two of the dozen or so manufacturers that together own the E. On, a 16-story factory building.   The E. On is one of many high-rise factory buildings in Aberdeen, Hong Kong's largest and best-supplied factory center, perched on the southwest side of Hong Kong Island.

headline: Corporate Debt
abstract: Household Finance Corp.  is offering $50 million of 12.55 percent notes due in 1992 at a price of 99.92, to yield 12.60 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The interest rate on the notes will be adjusted every two years at 45 basis points above the yield on two-year Treasury notes.     *  Northern Illinois Gas Co.  sold $50 million of 12 1/2 percent bonds due in 1994 to underwriters led by Paine Webber who did not publicly reoffer the issue.

headline: Takeover Insurance Emerges
abstract: When a company fights off an unwelcome takeover attempt, its defense can cost millions of dollars. And if the takeover succeeds, departing top executives can run up substantial legal bills trying to collect their ''golden parachute'' benefits.    To accommodate such situations, the insurance industry has devised two new policies. One provides coverage for a company's myriad defense expenses in resisting takeover attempts and proxy contests. The other pays for the legal expenses incurred by executives who must sue to enforce compliance with their separation contracts.

headline: ADS FOR HISPANIC CONSUMERS
abstract: Spurred by increasing business interest in reaching Hispanic people, the country's fastest-growing market segment, the number of advertising agencies that specialize in marketing to Hispanic consumers is growing.     Ten years ago such enterprises were scarce. But, much as black-oriented ad agencies sprang up more than a decade ago to serve that important market, companies are now forming to reach the estimated 15 million Hispanic people in the United States with spending power estimated between $70 billion and $80 billion a year.    ''Now there are more than 100 companies that feel they are Hispanic marketing experts,'' said Carlos Montemayor, president of Montemayor & Asociados, a San Antonio agency that started this year.

headline: Economic Scene; Adding Power But No Plants
abstract: THE news about power plant construction is almost all unfavorable. Nuclear reactors are    abandoned because of cost overruns, or the rate rises that would accompany their completion threaten ''rate shock.'' At the same time, evidence mounts that the alternative fuel, coal, aggravates acid rain.    Accordingly, consumer advocates, environmentalists and other utility critics are trying to reduce the need to build new plants. They are pushing for investments in efficiency, to allow existing supplies of power to be stretched further, and they are seeking new regulatory structures that remove the financial incentive of the utilities to build new plants.

headline: DATABANK
abstract: September 30,1984

headline: Profit Up 33% At Matsushita
abstract: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said today that earnings in its fiscal first half, ended May 20, rose 33 percent amid growing sales of video equipment, office automation products and semiconductor components.   The major Japanese electronics company earned $444 million, up from $334 million a year earlier. Revenues rose 20 percent, to $9.1 billion, from $7.6 billion   Overseas sales increased 27 percent and accounted for 48 percent of total sales, while domestic sales rose 14 percent.

headline: Brazil Sees Drop in Debt
abstract: The Government revised its economic projections for the year and predicted a lower foreign debt and higher trade surplus, the central bank said today.   A pamphlet entitled ''Brazil Economic Program, Internal and External Adjustment,'' shows that the foreign debt, excluding short-term loans, will be $98.8 billion by the end of the year, down from the projection of $100.9 billion.

headline: CITY INVESTING UNIT SALE MARKS A REPOSITIONING
