abstract: With the City Investing Company's announcement Thursday that it had agreed to sell three of its units for $1.25 billion, the conglomerate will be effectively out of manufacturing and printing.     The three companies - World Color Press, Uarco Inc. and the Rheem Manufacturing Company - have been described as generally mature cash generators with strong market positions.    These are the kind of companies suitable to the leveraged buyout, in which a transaction, often including the current management, is financed by borrowing and the debt paid with cash flow generated by the acquired business. Thus a dependable cash flow is vital to the deal's success.

headline: Norcen to Sell Unit
abstract: Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. said it had agreed to sell its gas utility division, the Northern and Central Gas Corporation, to the Inter-City Gas Corporation for $240 million - $163 million in cash and $77 million of Inter-City first preference shares.

headline: U.S.-CUBAN PARLEY SAID TO BE NARROW
abstract: Talks between the United States and Cuba that began in New York on Thursday will be limited to a narrow agenda of immigration issues and are unlikely to produce any major improvement in relations, senior Reagan Administration officials said today.    The talks, at an undisclosed location in Manhattan, are the first substantive negotiations on specific issues between Washington and Havana since President Reagan took office.   The primary subject of discussion, the officials said, would be the eventual return to Cuba of more than 1,000 unwanted refugees who came by boat to Florida in 1980 from the Cuban port of Mariel. These refugees, most of them criminals and mental patients, according to American officials, were among 125,000 Cubans who came to Florida during the boatlift.

headline: Yet Another Promotion For Beatrice Executive
abstract: When Anthony Luiso, 40, was named to the ''office of the chairman'' of the Beatrice Companies in March, it was a big step up for the president of Beatrice's international division and corporate senior vice president. Yesterday, Mr. Luiso got another promotion. He was named a corporate executive vice president and president of the company's United States food unit.

headline: TREASURY SALES DOMINATE SCHEDULE
abstract: The Treasury's note and bond financings dominate the credit markets' week, which will be shortened by the Fourth of July Holiday on Wednesday. Tomorrow, the Treasury will auction $5.5 billion in seven-year notes, followed on Thursday by a $4 billion auction of 20-year bonds.    The seven-year notes, due July 15, 1991, were offered on a when-issued basis late Friday at 13.84 percent, up from 13.45 percent when the issue was announced. The 20-year bonds due Aug. 15, 2004, were offered at 13.75 percent, up from 13.38 percent when it was announced.

headline: GENERIC DRUGS IN BIGGER ROLE
abstract: Many consumers will benefit from lower-priced prescriptions in the next few years as the pharmaceutical industry undergoes a fundamental change. Some of the industry's most profitable drugs will lose their patent protection, opening the way to competition from cheaper generic copies.     The American Home Products Corporation's heart drug Inderal, which had sales of $335 million last year, will lose its patent protection in September. Inderal's generic name is propranolol hydrochloride.

headline: AID FOR REBELS IN A HAMLET IN SALVADOR
abstract: Evelin, 19 years old, sat on the porch of her adobe shack, one of a handful in this tiny hamlet in the grassy hills of central El Salvador.    Guiliguiste, so remote that it is reachable only by walking for an hour and a half from the nearest town, has a population of perhaps 50 people. All of them support the rebels fighting to overthrow the United States-backed Government.   ''Here there are only supporters,'' said Evelin. who was eating sorghum seeds that were in a cup of chile water. ''There are no longer people who are of the other tendency. They left.''

headline: MOSCOW ATTACKS GERMANYS' ACCORD
abstract: The Communist Party daily Pravda issued a new attack on West German policies toward East Germany today, charging that a recent financial credit to East Berlin was an attempt by Bonn to interfere in East Germany's internal affairs and to undermine its Communist system.    An editorial, carried in advance of publication by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, was the latest in a series of Soviet attacks on West Germany. They are seen as a sign of displeasure with a projected visit there next month by the East German leader, Erich Honecker.

headline: Politicians Brawl In Kashmir Legislature
abstract: Fist fights and brawls broke out today between supporters of the governing party and the opposition in the Kashmir state legislature where the 29-day-old administration of Chief Minister G. M. Shah won a confidence vote.   The violence came after the chief minister's followers first voted to oust the Speaker of the House, Wali Mohammad Itoo.

headline: A Turkish Martial-Law Court Sentences 22 Leftists to Die
abstract: The killers of four American servicemen were among 22 leftists sentenced to death today by a Turkish court, a press agency reported.

headline: Output of Steel
abstract: Declines 2.8% By The Associated Press Steel production fell to   1,695,000 tons in the week ended   July 28, a drop of 2.8 percent   from the previous week's   1,744,000 tons, the American   Iron and Steel Institute said   yesterday.

headline: PATENTS ; A Way to Restrict Use Of Computer Program
abstract: A method of preventing unauthorized use of computer programs was patented this week for Penta Inc. of Baltimore.

headline: FIGHTING IN BEIRUT INCREASES FEARS THAT ARMY COULD AGAIN BREAK UP
abstract: Military and political sources said today that fears that Lebanon's Army could again break apart along religious lines have increased in the aftermath of the fighting Sunday along the Green Line dividing the two parts of the city.    Units of the mostly Moslem Sixth Brigade in West Beirut and the Christian Fifth Brigade stationed in East Beirut fired on each other's positions, a well-placed military source said, despite official denials issued today to the contrary.   ''Once it started, everybody became trigger-happy,'' the source said.

headline: Corporate Debt
abstract: * Citicorp sold $100 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 11.269 percent, down from 11.466 last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 11.156 percent, down from 11.413.      Common Stock    *   Direct Action Marketing , a direct- mail service, has filed an offering of 1.5 million common shares at $8.50 a share through Bear, Stearns. Direct Action will issue 450,000 of its shares and its parent company, Unity Buying Service, currently in liquidation, will sell 1,050,000 shares.

headline: U.S. LINKS AID TO ISRAELI BUDGET PLAN
abstract: The Reagan Administration has officially asked the new Israeli Government to present it with a comprehensive budget- cutting plan before requesting a sharp rise in American economic aid, State Department officials said today.   The officials said that Ambassador Samuel W. Lewis, who recently returned to Israel after consultations here, told Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai that although the United States was sympathetic and concerned about Israel's economic problems, the Administration had to see Israel make a coordinated and serious effort to slow the inflation rate, now nearly 400 percent a year, and to lower the trade deficit, which is growing by some $4 billion a year.    Mr. Peres is coming to Washington for talks with President Reagan on Oct. 9. Israeli officials said today that he would be seeking a commitment from the Administration for $750 million to $1 billion in immediate economic grants beyond the $1.2 billion in economic aid and $1.4 billion in military grants already approved by Congressional committees and the Administration for the fiscal year beginning on Oct. 1. A report from Israel in The Wall Street Journal today said that Mr. Peres might ask for as much as $2 billion in additional money, but other Israelis said that seemed much too high.

headline: 9 DIE AS INDONESIAN POLICE BATTLE MOSLEM RIOTERS
abstract: At least 9 people have been killed and 53 wounded here in clashes between soldiers and militant Moslems, officials said today.    A crowd of 1,500 people described by the Government as Moslem extremists rampaged through Jakarta's port area on Wednesday night, burning down three shops and stoning a police station and a Protestant church.   The armed forces commander, Gen. Benny Murdani, said in a statement that soldiers first fired over the rioters' heads but were forced to fire at their feet when the warnings were ignored. The casualties were unavoidable, he added.

headline: An Offer for Levitz Is Made by Alger
abstract: The Levitz Furniture Corporation, already the object of an acquisition offer by the Pritzker family of Chicago, received a competing bid yesterday from Alger Associates Inc. of New York.   Alger is a holding company for Fred Alger & Company, a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, and Fred Alger Management, a registered investment adviser with about $2 billion under management.   Robert M. Elliott, chairman of Levitz, said the Alger offer consists of $20 in cash and $40 face amount of subordinated 15-year debentures for each Levitz share. This offer contemplates participation by present Levitz management in up to 15 percent of the surviving company.

headline: S.A.S. Orders Jets
abstract: Scandinavian Airlines System said it is ordering new jetliners valued at $150 million from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation of St. Louis. Jan Carlzon, S.A.S.'s president and chief executive, said the DC-9-80's would service routes in Europe and within Scandinavia.

headline: Key Bolivian Official Implicated in Plot
abstract: The army high command has dismissed Bolivia's second-ranking defense official and declared him a suspect in an attempted coup against the Government of President Hernan Siles Zuazo, according to an army officer.   The official, Col. Mario Oxa Bustos, was ordered to report for an investigation, the officer said late Monday.   Colonel Oxa is the highest-ranking official implicated in Saturday's attempted coup, which began with the abduction of the President.

headline: AMERITECH: A SURPRISING LEAD
abstract: When seven regional telephone companies were about to be broken away from Ma Bell, many investment handicappers predicted that Ameritech, the Chicago-based regional, would bring up the rear in the race of the new Seven Sisters.    Wall Street's handicappers cited two reasons for their dour predictions about Ameritech: it is situated in one of the nation's slowest-growing regions in terms of population, and its service area includes the Middle West's Rust Belt and its array of declining industries.    But once the regionals went into business last Jan. 1, Ameritech surprised everyone by sprinting out in front of its sister companies. In its first two quarters, Ameritech's return on equity was the highest of the regionals. It was the first regional to market cellular mobile telephones, and, many industry analysts say, it has achieved the lowest cost per telephone line.

headline: Marsh & McLennan Rise
abstract: Marsh & McLennan Companies said yesterday that its second-quarter net income rose 14.2 percent, to $29 milion, or 80 cents a share, from 25.4 million, or 72 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenue for the insurance holding company increased 13 percent, to $268.8 million, from $237.9 million.

headline: Morgan in Teamster Bid Morgan Stanley & Company has formally requested that it be allowed to manage stocks for the $5 billion Central States Pension Fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, while also acting as the fund's adviser. Morgan replaced the Equitable Life Assurance Society as the fund's outside adviser earlier this year.
abstract: In a letter to the Labor Department this week, Morgan Stanley said it now wants to take charge of the fund's stocks from seven outside managers in order to increase efficiency, and lower commissions and management fees by more than $4.3 million a year.   The Labor Department is expected to consider whether Morgan Stanley would have a conflict of interest under this arrangement, because the firm would be deciding how much money should be put into stocks - in effect determining how much it should collect in stock commissions.    In response, Morgan proposed an oversight committee with members from outside the firm to monitor its recommendations and insure that the proper decisions were made.

headline: Gimbels Officer To Retire The Batus Retail Group,
abstract: which owns Gimbels, said yesterday that Stanley Abelson, 61   years old, the chairman and   chief executive officer of Gimbels East, is taking early retirement on Oct. l. Gimbels   East includes the Gimbels   stores in the New York and   Philadelphia areas. M. Ronald Ruskin, president   of Batus, said Mr. Abelson   ''has indicated that he will now   devote his time to civic, educational and charitable activities   in the Greater Philadelphia   area.''

headline: CONFUSION GROWS AS FARES PROLIFERATE
abstract: THE dizzying complexity of the airline industry's rate structure has    fliers feeling confused and frustrated, rarely certain that they have obtained the best available fare.   Trans World Airlines, for instance, offers seven flights a day from New York to Chicago - and 22 different fares. Most of the fares provide the same service, with the spread in price depending instead on other factors: how far in advance the reservation is made, the day of the week of the flight, the length of the passenger's stay or simply the availability of a particular class of cut-rate seats.

headline: CAUTION IS URGED BY BRAZIL BISHOPS
abstract: The hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church in Brazil cautioned church members today against being alarmed by the Vatican's criticism of the theology of liberation.    The Brazilian National Bishops Conference, which, with 358 bishops, is one of the world's largest, issued a statement after the formal publication today of a 36-page Vatican statement that represents the most detailed attack to date on the ''deviation'' of the theology.    The criticism came four days before the start of an official Vatican interrogation of a leading Brazilian theologian who is an exponent of the doctrine.

headline: A.T.& T.-Canada Link
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked permission today to extend its domestic video-conferencing service to Canada. The company, in a filing with the Federal Communications Commission, said it had reached an agreement with Canadian telephone companies that would allow its customers to establish video conferences between 23 American cities and such Canadian cities as Montreal, Toronto, Ottawa, Quebec, Vancouver, Calgary and Edmonton.

headline: U.S. Bond Sale
abstract: A Market Test    After two days of price rises this week, the credit markets face a major hurdle today.

headline: ADVERTISING ; ; The New Yorker Ends French Elle Link
abstract: The New Yorker, which had been selling the advertising for the English-language edition of the French Elle magazine being published here, announced yesterday that it was dropping out of that joint venture and that it expects Hachette, the publisher, to announce a new partner shortly.     ''We couldn't agree on who should be doing what to whom,'' explained Hoyt Spellman, spokesman for The New Yorker.

headline: CODE OF ETHICS
abstract: From its beginnings, the Code of Ethics for Political Campaigns of the American Association of Advertising Agencies has warned advertising agencies against preparing any materials that unfairly or prejudicially exploits the race, creed or national origin of any candidate. Then on the eve of the Democratic Party's nomination of Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Four-A's added ''or gender'' to the prohibitions. And not a minute too soon.

headline: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1984
abstract: The Economy    The nation's major oil companies have agreed to let their franchised gasoline dealers sell other brands, in a proposed settlement of a 13-year-old antitrust case. The result, industry experts say, will be more competition and lower prices. (Page A1.) Service station operators said the settlement could further erode brand loyalty among consumers. (D8.)

headline: Dow Ahead by 0.66 On Lighter Volume
abstract: The stock market, affected by weakness in the credit markets, again turned in a lackluster performance yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.66 point, to 1,232.44. Stocks that advanced barely edged out those that declined, by 770 to 768. Trading slumped to 83.1 million shares, from 116.1 million the day before.

headline: Chevron Planning $2 Billion in Debt
abstract: The Chevron Corporation, formerly the Standard Oil Company of California, announced that it had filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of up to $2 billion of debt securities.    The securities will be issued at various times by Chevron Capital U.S.A., through underwriters to be named later. Proceeds will be used to refinance a portion of the debt incurred with Chevron's acquisition of the Gulf Corporation.

headline: Article 077946 -- No Title
abstract: BellSouth said today that its second-quarter profit was $298 million, or $1.02 a share, on revenues of $2.3 billion. Because of the breakup of the Bell System last Jan. 1, there are no comparable results for a year ago.

headline: First Penn Retiring Warrants
abstract: The First Pennsylvania Corporation said yesterday that it had reacquired virtually all the remaining stock warrants granted to a group of banks in exchange for financing during the company's 1980 financial crisis and that it was seeking those granted to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for its help.    Retiring the warrants would remove the last vestige of the 1980 crisis, which stemmed from a combination of bad loans and heavy investments in Government securities that fell in price when interest rates soared. The resulting liquidity crisis led to a precedent-setting rescue that brought together the resources of banks and the Government. First Pennsylvania Bank, then the nation's 23d-largest commercial bank, received a $500 million, five-year rescue loan, with the F.D.I.C. putting up $325 million and a group of 26 banks lending $175 million and setting up a $1 billion line of credit.

headline: HCW Purchases
abstract: HCW Oil and Gas Inc. said its HCW Oil Income Funds had signed preliminary agreements to buy proven producing oil and natural gas properties for about $47 million.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Credit Card Voiding Curbed WASHINGTON, Aug. 31   (AP) - The American Express   Company cannot cancel customers' credit cards without   notifying them in advance, a   three-judge panel of the United   States Court of Appeals ruled   today. The panel overturned a decision by Federal Judge Harold   H. Greene, who had rejected   the complaint of Oscar Gray, a   lawyer who learned his card   had been canceled when he   tried to pay for a wedding anniversary dinner that he and his   wife had just eaten in a Washington restaurant. Gray later learned that his   account had been canceled because of a dispute over the payment of airplane tickets he purchased with his credit card.

headline: BOND RALLY MAY FACE A HURDLE
abstract: The recent bond market rally, which has cut long-term interest rates by a percentage point since early July, may soon be tested by new data showing that the economy is still growing under a full head of steam.     The outlook for continued low inflation - which attracted investors to bonds and fueled the recent rally - remains in place. Inflation for 1985 is now forecast to be between 3 percent and 6 percent, down from previous estimates of 5 percent to 9 percent.    But with Treasury bond yields down to about 12 1/2 percent, there is concern that investor attention might shift away from the favorable inflation outlook to the strong performance of the economy. Based on past business cycles, the expanding economy is expected to increase credit demands and put upward pressure on interest rates.

headline: New Chief Comments
abstract: The new chairman and chief executive of the Financial Corporation of America declared that a Federal guarantee was not needed to support American Savings and Loan.   ''I don't need or seek a full guarantee of deposits,'' William J. Popejoy said in an interview published today in The Los Angeles Times.

headline: TRADE GAP UPSTAGES EXPORT SURGE
abstract: Buried in last week's announcement of a record trade deficit in July was the news that United States exports were up sharply that month. Administration officials, economists and corporate executives all predicted that the nation's exports would continue to climb in the year ahead, but they said the increase would hardly reduce the trade deficit because import levels are also rising.    The Commerce Department reported that exports rose to $19.4 billion in July, was up $1.8 billion, or 10.3 percent, from the previous month. The July figures, part of an upward trend in exports over all, represented the highest level of exports since September 1981.

headline: Canadian Paper Maker Realigns Management
abstract: British Columbia Forest Products Ltd., a pulp, lumber and plywood company, has named Kenneth P. Benson chairman. He will remain chief executive officer.    Mr. Benson, 57, succeeds Ian A. Barclay, 63, who will become vice chairman. George G. Slater, 59, will succeed Mr. Benson as president and will add the title of chief operating officer.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1984
abstract: The Economy    Morgan Guaranty cut its prime rate to 12 3/4 percent from 13, the first decline in the key lending rate since February 1983. No major bank followed but they are expected to do so soon, based on the assumption that the Fed has eased its monetary policy. (Page 1.)   The Federal Reserve Bank of New York named E. Gerald Corrigan as president, replacing Anthony M. Solomon, who is retiring. Mr. Corrigan, who has been president of the Minneapolis Fed, is considered an expert in regulation of domestic financial markets, but has somewhat less experience in international financial affairs. (39.) Mr. Corrigan is known as both a protege and confidant of the Fed's chairman, Paul A. Volcker. (39.)

headline: Sikh Golden Temple Returned to High Priests
abstract: President Zail Singh returned control of the Golden Temple, the holiest Sikh shrine, to the sect's high priests today after nearly four months of army occupation, the United News of India reported.   The priests, meanwhile, called off plans to mount a major protest march to ''liberate'' the temple, the news agency reported.

headline: DEMOCRATS' FOREIGN POLICIES VEER AWAY FROM PAST LINE
abstract: The foreign policy line that emerged from the Democratic National Convention is less militant and interventionist than the policies of such Democratic Presidents as Harry S. Truman, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, but more assertive than that of George McGovern, the party's 1972 nominee.    In interviews, former officials from Democratic and Republican administrations singled out Walter F. Mondale's ardent advocacy of a negotiated, verifiable freeze on the production, testing and deployment of nuclear arms as the most significant departure from past election-year platforms.   Other specialists cite a plank pushed through by Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and some of Mr. Mondale's comments about Central America as signals of a less assertive American role in the world than in the Truman, Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.    Previous Involvements    Under those Democratic Presidents, the United States took on the defense of Korea, Greece, Turkey and Vietnam, and President Carter declared protection for the Persian Gulf.   The Hart amendment, eventually accepted by the Mondale camp, emphasized the Democratic Party's general reluctance to involve American combat forces in third-world troublespots like the Persian Gulf, except in limited circumstances.

headline: INVENTORIES ROSE 0.8% IN JULY
abstract: Inventories held by United States businesses increased eight-tenths of 1 percent in July, while sales showed their first decline since February, the Commerce Department reported today.   Inventories on shelves and in back lots expanded by $4.4 billion in July, to $551.3 billion, following an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in June.   The July gain marked the 13th consecutive monthly increase in inventories, but analysts said some of the growth was probably involuntary since sales slumped eight-tenths of 1 percent, recording the first decline since a drop of six-tenths of 1 percent in February.

headline: Rise in Cost of Linerboard Spurs Industry Protest
abstract: Makers of cardboard boxes are protesting an increase by paper manufacturers in the price of linerboard, the raw material used to make the boxes.   The increase of $30 a ton, to $350, was effective Aug. 1 and came on top of several other price increases imposed on linerboard. The box manufacturers say the increases are unnecessary and inflationary, but the paper industry says the increases are needed to get the price back to where it was before it plunged in the recent recession.

headline: Korean Opposition Chief Planning to Go Home
abstract: Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean opposition leader, who came to the United States after being released from prison, said today that he had decided to go home in December ''to struggle for the return of democracy.''   Mr. Kim said he had written to President Chun Doo Hwan and to Secretary of State George P. Shultz informing them of his plans.

headline: C.D. YIELDS UP SHARPLY
abstract: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit and money market deposit accounts made their sharpest increases in nearly two months, The Bank Rate Monitor said in its report on the week ended yesterday.    Both items showed their strongest increases since May 16, the week that followed a rise of one-half percentage point in the prime rate, according to the Miami Beach publication.

headline: PERUVIAN DUBIOUS OF HALTING REBELS
abstract: President Fernando Belaunde Terry says he is pessimistic that the Peruvian Army will be able to make much headway in its new drive against leftist guerrillas in the Andean highlands.    Mr. Belaunde Terry, who in 1980 became Peru's first elected civilian leader after 12 years of military rule, put the armed forces in control of the counterinsurgency campaign last month. It is now under way in 13 provinces.   The President said he made the move because violence by the Shining Path, a left-wing guerrilla group, had reached alarming proportions, and that the police were no longer able to cope with it. But he said the decision to bring in the military had not been easy.

headline: Soviet Loan From West
abstract: The Soviet Union today obtained a loan of $166 million from a consortium of nine Western banks, its third loan this year from the West.   Bankers said it was a cash loan to replenish Moscow's hard currency reserves and was not linked to any specific trade deals.

headline: Merrill Lynch Ratings Cut
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company, which recently announced its first loss from operations since it became a public company in 1971, suffered another setback yesterday when the Standard & Poor's Corporation reduced slightly its ratings on Merrill Lynch's long-term bonds.   After the downgrading, Merrill Lynch's long-term debt remains in the high-grade AA category, and its short-term commercial paper still carries the highest A-1x rating.

headline: Reagan Gets Insider Bill
abstract: Congress completed action today on a bill giving the Securities and Exchange Commission authority to collect up to $3 in fines for each $1 of profit gained, or loss avoided, by those caught in insider stock trading.   Final action came as the House accepted Senate amendments to the legislation, and sent the measure to President Reagan.

headline: Warner-Tramiel Talks On Atari Sale Reported
abstract: Warner Communications Inc. is negotiating to sell much of its Atari subsidiary to Jack Tramiel, a computer entrepeneur, according to a newspaper report.   Mr. Tramiel, who built Commodore International Ltd. from a typewriter repair business into a $1 billion home computer company, began talks Friday with the New York-based Warner, The Los Angeles Times said in its Saturday editions.

headline: PERES AND SHAMIR SAY CABINET TALKS HIT SERIOUS SNAGS
abstract: Shimon Peres and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir reported tonight that ''serious obstacles'' were blocking the formation of a bipartisan Israeli government.    The two leaders, representing the nation's major political blocs, were terse and grim-faced as they left a two-hour meeting. The indications that the negotiations were faltering appeared to represent the most serious setback since coalition talks began a month ago.   They parted without setting a new meeting, but said ''further contacts'' would be attempted. Neither Mr. Peres, who heads the Labor Alignment, nor Mr. Shamir, leader of the Likud bloc, would say how or when those contacts would be maintained.

headline: IMPROVEMENT AT NATIONAL, WHEELING AND ARMCO
abstract: Increased demand for steel in the second quarter helped three steel companies report improved results yesterday.     National Intergroup Inc. had a profit, in contrast to a loss a year earlier. The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation had its first profitable quarter since the first three months of 1982. Armco Inc. narrowed its loss.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN RIGHT APPEARS TO GAIN GROUND
abstract: Two by-elections this week involving widely differing white constituencies have stirred speculation here that Prime Minister P. W. Botha's program of limited political change is losing ground to the far right.    The voting took place Wednesday in the Johannesburg suburb of Rosettenville and in the town of Potgietersrus in the north of Transvaal Province.   The elections, for seats in provincial assemblies, represented a rare public test of feeling among the country's 4.5 million whites. The elections came eight months after a referendum Nov. 2 on proposals for a new constitution, and two months before it is scheduled to go into effect. The document offers Indians and people of mixed race places in a three-chamber parliament; it does not offer places to blacks.

headline: News Service Is Started By the Aga Khan
abstract: The Aga Khan, spiritual leader of 20 million Ismailian Moslems in the Middle East, has started a news service to report on events and trends in developing countries for clients in those countries and in the United States, Europe and Japan.   The start of the service, Compass News Features, was announced yesterday in Luxembourg, where it has its headquarters.

headline: STOCKS DECLINE BROADLY IN VERY SLOW TRADING
abstract: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday in the slowest trading in almost a year.     The Dow Jones industrial average, in the loss column throughout the session, ended down 8.61 points, to 1,227.92. In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advancing issues by more than a 9-to-5 ratio.    Volume on the Big Board dropped to 57.7 million shares, from 69.6 million shares on Friday, as institutional participation dried up. Turnover yesterday was the smallest since Aug. 29, 1983, when 53.3 million shares changed hands.

headline: KOREANS DISAGREE ON AID BY NORTH
abstract: Despite long and mostly cordial bargaining, North and South Korean officials failed to agree today on how North Korea could carry out an offer to send relief supplies to recent flood victims in the South.    The two sides, meeting in this truce village inside the Korean demilitarized zone, broke off talks over the issue of whether North Korea would be allowed to carry supplies directly to the South Korean capital of Seoul. There was no firm decision on whether to meet again, and it seemed unlikely - even if another session was scheduled, as North Korea proposed - that either country would compromise enough to allow a historic first exchange of material across their hostile border.    The North Korean Government in Pyongyang had said it was ready to send food and other assistance to victims of severe floods in the South that early this month killed about 190 people, left 200,000 homeless and damaged crops. The North offered medicine, 14,300 tons of rice, 550,000 yards of cloth and 100,000 tons of cement.

headline: 20 Rebels Said to Die in Peru As Troops Step Up Offensive
abstract: At least 20 Maoist guerrillas have been killed in a clash with a combined army and marine force during a stepped-up offensive in a remote area of the Andes, the state-owned television channel said today, quoting a Government source.   The report said two marines were killed Saturday when guerrillas of the Sendero Luminoso movement attacked a patrol near Ayacucho, 360 miles east of Lima.

headline: SWISS VOTERS AGAIN REJECT BAN ON NUCLEAR POWER
abstract: Swiss voters turned down for the second time today proposals that would have eliminated the country's atomic energy power plants by the year 2000.   In a national referendum, a majority of the nation's 23 cantons, or states, rejected proposals to halt construction and replacement of nuclear power plants and find alternative means of generating electricity.   Fifty-five percent of the voters rejected a ban on nuclear power plants to 45 percent in favor, while 54.2 percent rejected a plan calling for energy conservation and alternative fuels, with 45.8 percent in favor. Swiss voters rejected similar proposals in 1979 by a narrower margin of 51.2 percent to 48.8 percent.

headline: Time Inc. Net Climbs by 9.7%
abstract: Time Inc. yesterday reported a 9.7 percent increase in second-quarter net income, helped by a sharp rise in pretax income from its magazines division.

headline: SALVAGE OF SUNKEN NUCLEAR CARGO IS DELAYED
abstract: High winds and a heavy swell today delayed the recovery of highly toxic nuclear cargo from a sunken French freighter.   An official Belgian spokesman said three- to four-foot waves were preventing divers from reaching the lightly radioactive cargo of the 4,210-ton Mont Louis, which sank last Saturday after a collision with a passenger ferry.   A correspondent who flew over the partly submerged French vessel today reported that the only sign of activity was a man on a nearby salvage ship pouring detergent into the sea to disperse oil that leaked from the ship, leaving a thin zigzag trail about half a mile long.

headline: MORGAN GUARANTY TRIMS PRIME RATE
abstract: E. Gerald Corrigan has been named president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Page 39.             The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank, reduced its prime lending rate yesterday to 12 3/4 percent, from 13 percent. It was the first decline in this key lending rate since February 1983, when the rate was reduced to 10 1/2 percent, from 11 percent.

headline: BOND PRICES STAGE LATE RALLY
abstract: Spurred by a pickup in retail demand, bond prices rallied strongly yesterday afternoon. They had fallen as much as three-quarters of a point early in the day after the release of a Government report showing that economic growth in the second quarter was much stronger than initial estimates. Yesterday's trading in the credit markets was light.     The Commerce Department reported that the gross national product rose at a 7.5 percent annual rate in the second quarter, rather than 5.7 percent, as originally estimated. The new figure was higher than most market participants had anticipated. In the last few weeks analysts have been issuing their own projections, with most falling in the range of 6 percent to 7 percent.

headline: Hong Kong Presses U.S. HONG KONG, Friday, Aug. 10 (UPI)
abstract: The Hong Kong Government   delivered a diplomatic note to   the United States consulate today to press the United States   to revise new restrictions on   textile imports that have   stunned apparel manufacturers and could cost American   retailers more than $1 billion.

headline: STEEL QUOTAS WORRY FARMERS
abstract: The huge steel mill has long been a hazy presence on the horizon of Richard Bauer's wheat and soybean farm here, but this summer it looms as a menace.    Mr. Bauer, whose farm lies on the northern edge of this struggling industrial town on the Mississippi near St. Louis where the Farm Belt intersects with the Rust Belt, fears that the steel industry's campaign to limit imports will spark a trade war that will hurt farm exports and send grain prices plummeting.   ''If you give the steel industry the help they want, the whole economy will suffer,'' said the 58-year-old farmer during a break from preparing his new $77,000 combine for the soybean harvest. ''The Europeans will put a tariff on our beans. Then they won't buy as many, and that will lower our price.''

headline: Arco Unit Quits Oilfield
abstract: Atlantic Richfield Indonesia Inc. has relinquished an oilfield in east Kalimantan after deciding that the oil reserve was not big enough, the Government said today.

headline: Market Place; Tootsie Roll's Stock Surge
abstract: A MANHATTAN stockbroker with 20 years of experience was asked last week what he knew about Tootsie Roll Industries. ''Is that a listed company?'' he replied.    Indeed, it is. Not only is it listed on the New York Stock Exchange, but its shares also have been climbing steadily in recent months, while prices of many a big-name corporation were falling.

headline: New Concordat With Vatican Is Approved by Italian Senate
abstract: The Italian Senate today approved a new concordat with the Vatican that will end Roman Catholicism's status as the state religion of Italy and that officially guarantees freedom of religion for non- Catholics.   The new concordat, which will replace one that has been in effect since 1929, will go before the Chamber of Deputies for final approval in September.

headline: OFFICIAL, IN SHIFT, TO PAY U.S. BANKRUPTCY JUDGES
abstract: The Federal judiciary's chief administrative officer today rescinded his July 11 decision not to pay the salaries of bankruptcy judges, yielding to pressure from some Federal judges and from a House committee chairman.   ''In no instance will any bankruptcy judge or employee fail to receive his or her paycheck,'' William E. Foley, director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, said in a memo to judges today.   The considerable disarray into which the bankruptcy court system was thrown by Mr. Foley's July 11 announcement on salaries is likely to be reduced, but not eliminated, by today's action. Because of the confusion, bankruptcy cases are being moved more slowly through the court system in some districts; in some districts, they are not being heard at all.

headline: OPEC Panel Opposes a Rise
abstract: An OPEC committee recommended today that the organization keep its present oil price and production limits. A special session of the full Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is not needed, the panel's chairman said.

headline: FRANCE TO EXTRADITE THREE BASQUES TO SPAIN
abstract: The Government announced today that it would extradite three of seven Basque separatists to Spain.    The three are wanted by Spanish authorities on charges of murdering policemen. Four others, accused of lesser crimes in Spain, were expelled to the West African nation of Togo.

headline: AMIGA'S HIGH-TECH GAMBLE
abstract: In the obscure headquarters here of a two-year-old corporation lies a prototype of a computer that has sparked a pitched battle between the two largest competitors for the home computer market, Commodore and Atari.    The computer and its sophisticated graphics chips, the product of the Amiga Corporation, won attention and praise from analysts and competitors many times Amiga's size when the machine was first shown at a Chicago trade show in June. The Amiga computer has been heralded by some as a serious challenger to the popular Apple Macintosh or the International Business Machines Corporation's PCjr.    In mid-August, Commodore announced that it had bought Amiga. But Atari, now run by Commodore's ex-chief, says the chips are rightfully Atari's as a result of a previous agreement, and has sued Amiga for fraud.

headline: U.S. ARMY OFFICERS HELPED PRIVATE GROUP IN SALVADOR
abstract: A number of United States military officers in El Salvador became actively involved during the last year in helping a group of private Americans donate military equipment to the Salvadoran armed forces, according to Defense Department documents.     The involvement, more extensive than previously reported, included introducing the leader of the private group to the general staff of the Salvadoran Army, encouraging the Americans to send equipment, delivering the materiel to the Salvadoran Army and acting, in general, as a channel between the Americans and the Salvadorans.    According to the documents and Administration officials, much of the liaison work was handled by Maj. Charles A. McAnarey, the chief United States logistics officer in El Salvador.    A spokesman for the United States Embassy in El Salvador, Donald R. Hamilton, while confirming that American military officers had assisted the private group, said today that there ''was nothing inappropriate or unethical about their conduct.''

headline: Article 167356 -- No Title
abstract: (Reuters) - The Higbee Company, primarily an operator of   department stores in northeast   Ohio, said it had entered into a   definitive agreement to be acquired by Industrial Equity   (Pacific) Ltd., a subsidiary of   Brierley Investments Ltd. of   New Zealand, for $50 a share. In over-the-counter trading   today, Higbee jumped $5.50, to  $48.

headline: CONTICOMMODITY BEING SOLD TO REFCO
abstract: The Continental Grain Company, apparently tired of mounting losses from Conticommodity Services Inc., its futures brokerage subsidiary, announced yesterday that the unit would be sold to Refco Inc., another Chicago-based brokerage that specializes in futures.   Fourteen years after starting Conticommodity, Continental said it would get out of the futures brokerage business entirely. Walter Goldschmidt, who founded Conticommodity and recently took its helm again after serving as a senior manager of Continental, said he would move to Refco as a vice chairman.    No price was announced; both the buyer and seller are privately held companies.

headline: TALKS EXPECTED ON COAST THRIFT UNIT
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has the capacity to raise at least $25 billion in the credit markets, more than enough to cover any loans needed by the beleaguered American Savings and Loan Association to meet deposit withdrawals, according to industry sources.   It remains unclear, however, what conditions, if any, the Bank Board might apply before granting additional loans to American Savings and Loan. The directors of the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco are expected to debate that question at a private meeting on Thursday.    The Financial Corporation of America, parent of the thrift unit, announced last Wednesday that it had lost $107.5 million in the second quarter. It also said that American Savings and Loan had borrowed approximately $800 million from the home loan bank, less than the industry average. About $500 million of that amount had been borrowed on Aug. 13.

headline: CASTRO URGES EFFORTS TO ALLAY BITTERNESS IN U.S.-CUBA TIES
abstract: President Fidel Castro said tonight that he would welcome any steps to lessen bitter tensions between the United States and Cuba.    In a speech marking the 31st anniversary of the Cuban revolution, Mr. Castro praised the Rev. Jesse Jackson as a man of peace and, in a conciliatory gesture, said he would seriously consider ''any efforts at decreasing tensions in our area and in the rest of the world, any efforts aimed at decreasing the dangers of the madness of war.'' Mr. Castro's remarks were in sharp contrast to the vitriolic name-calling of his anniversary speech last year. The senior United States diplomat in Cuba walked out of that speech in protest.  Mr. Castro noted tonight that the socialist system in his country and the capitalist system in the United States were ''totally different,'' but he suggested that ''peaceful coexistence'' was possible.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Bank Money Accounts  Money6-monthMarketC.D.'s(%)(%)  Bankers Trust 10.7011.40 Chase Manhattan 10.6311.35 Chemical Bank 10.6311.46 Citibank 10.6311.18 Manufacturers Hanover 10.2411.35 Bowery Savings 11.5512.19 Dime Savings (N.Y.) 10.5011.46 Dollar Dry Dock Savings 10.4111.75 Goldome 9.5912.19 Metropolitan Savings 10.6311.91 City Federal (N.J.) 9.7612.00 First Nat. State (N.J.) 9.7311.00 Midlantic Nat.
