Source: Bank Rate Monitor, Miami Beach, 33140

headline: THATCHER VS. 'RED KEN': WINNER TO TAKE LONDON
abstract: London is about to become a city without a city government.    The abolition of the Greater London Council in favor of the city's 32 boroughs has pitted Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher against Ken Livingstone - ''Red Ken'' to headline writers - the radical Socialist council leader whose efforts to cut fares for public transport and provide grants to groups such as Babies Against the Bomb have already shocked a wide audience.   The Daily Telegraph called him ''the amazing man on the flying trapeze who fell on London.''   For months, Londoners have been barraged with posters and other appeals urging them to ''Save the G.L.C.,'' a campaign that in the end will probably cost the taxpayers some $13 million.   Last week, supported by $104,000 in council money, actors portrayed Mrs. Thatcher as a predatory fairy queen and Mr. Livingstone as a genial but ominous half-mortal, half-fairy in a production of ''The Ratepayers' Iolanthe'' at Queen Elizabeth Hall.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; New Citicorp Head Shifts Key Aides
abstract: In his first major management shuffle since taking over as chairman of Citicorp this month, John S. Reed yesterday began moving his key lieutenants into senior positions in the area of the company headed by Thomas O. Theobald, who was Mr. Reed's chief rival for the No. 1 spot. But Mr. Reed also promoted a number of senior officials who report to Mr. Theobald, signaling that his former rival's staff will still have opportunities within the organization.   Ostensibly, the major managerial change was the naming of James D. Farley, 58 years old, as vice chairman, which makes him a director. But Mr. Farley's actual responsibilities within the bank have been narrowed. Formerly in charge of corporate business in Latin America, Citicorp's single biggest profit center, Mr. Farley will now be responsible for supervising international debt restructurings and for ''special worldwide customer-relations duties.''

headline: BRAZIL'S RULING PARTY SELECTS CIVILIAN AS CANDIDATE
abstract: Brazil's ruling Social Democratic Party today nominated a civilian politician to be the party's candidate for president.   The party's convention voted 493-350 to name Paulo Salim Maluf, a member of the National Congress and a former governor of Sao Paulo state, as its candidate for president over Mario David Andreazza, a retired army colonel and the Interior Minister.   Mr. Maluf, 52 years old, will run against the opposition Democratic Movement Party's candidate, Tancredo Neves, in balloting on Jan. 15 by an electoral college. Mr. Neves is the only candidate seeking his party's nomination, and he is expected to receive it Sunday at the end of a two-day convention.

headline: LETTERS ; Bright Boom
abstract: To the Editor:     Your otherwise comprehensive article (''A Boom That Burns Bright For Now,'' July 1) contributes to the commonly held myth that ''this recovery has been spurred by consumers . . . energized by President Reagan's three-year cut in taxes.'' The Keynesian view of Government deficits and increased consumer spending providing a means of regaining economic growth out of recession would seem to be supported.

headline: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
abstract: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.19     An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds   compiled weekly by The Bond   Buyer.   Aa Utility Bonds*14.13     Salomon Brothers' estimate for   new long-term issues.

headline: Mamiya Receivers
abstract: The Tokyo District Court has appointed two officials as receivers for the Mamiya Camera Company and its three subsidiaries, which plan to reconstruct themselves under court supervision. The four companies applied for receivership last March because of business difficulties resulting from the failure of Mamiya's export agent, J. Osawa & Company. One of the receivers, Akio Yamamoto, said the companies would submit reconstruction plans to the court by July 4, 1985.

headline: SBS Drops a Fee
abstract: Satellite Business Systems, following the lead of GTE-Sprint and the MCI Communications Corporation, said it was dropping the $16 sign-up fee for its Skyline long-distance telephone service. Skyline customers will now face only one requirement in using the service - a $15 minimum use fee per month. SBS, based in McLean, Va., is a partnership of the International Business Machines Corporation, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company and the Communications Satellite Corporation.

headline: THE COST CRACKDOWN AT NEWSWEEK
abstract: A stern restructuring is under way at Newsweek as the magazine searches for leaner operations and higher profits.     After a decade of repeated management changes that left a legacy of a swollen corporate structure and depressed profits, Newsweek has been systematically streamlining itself in recent months under the close scrutiny of the the Washington Post Company, Newsweek's owner.    In late July, tightened cost controls and new operating procedures were installed for the magazine's editorial staff, which had largely escaped the companywide effort at improving profits and efficiency.   Changes in Character Seen    Although Newsweek executives insist that the magazine's quality will not be affected, some staff members say the relatively free-wheeling and independent character of Newsweek Inc. - the corporate body that publishes the magazine - is changing for the worse as it responds to the Post Company's heightened pressure for an improved bottom line.   The goal, both Post and Newsweek officials say, is to maintain the quality of the magazine while increasing a disappointing profit margin of 5.1 percent in 1983 to 12 percent in several years.

headline: Citicorp Paper
abstract: Interest rates were mixed at yesterday's regular weekly auctions of Citicorp commercial paper, the bank holding company announced. For $100 million of 91-day paper the average rate was 11.429 percent, up from 11.378 percent, while $50 million of 182-day paper sold at an average rate of 11.324 percent, down from 11.348 percent.

headline: OIL PRICES UP SHARPLY IN WEEK
abstract: Oil and wholesale gasoline prices have jumped sharply in the past week, reversing a long slide, after industry analysts said the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was apparently producing less oil than thought and after British officials urged oil buyers there to forgo price cuts.     Analysts and industry sources also said American oil companies had cut their crude oil shipments from the Middle East in an effort to tighten supplies and halt the decline in world oil prices.    But the volatility of oil markets was underlined yesterday when prices settled back somewhat, and many industry experts said it is not yet clear whether or how much OPEC has cut its oil production.    'No One Knows for Sure'    ''The problem we all have is that no one knows for sure,'' said Michael D. Smolinski, oil economist at Data Resources Inc.

headline: BURGER SAID TO SUPPORT BAN ON BANKRUPTCY PLAN
abstract: With disarray and confusion mounting in the nation's bankruptcy courts, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger was reported today to have backed up a judicial administrator's refusal to pay the salaries of Federal bankruptcy judges.   The Chief Justice brushed aside a complaint by Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, that the refusal to pay the salaries was ''disobedience'' of the law and would ''create additional turmoil'' in the courts. Mr. Burger expressed his view in a letter to Mr. Rodino late Thursday, the contents of which were summarized by legislative and judicial aides who had read it. The letter, a response to one sent the same day by Mr. Rodino, a New Jersey Democrat, was not made public.   Meanwhile, Federal district courts around the country have differed on whether to refer cases to the roughly 225 bankruptcy judges as directed in a recent act of Congress, the constitutionality of which has been questioned.

headline: GREECE DENIES U.S. CHARGE IT IS LAX IN FIGHTING TERROR
abstract: A senior Greek official denied as ''utterly baseless'' today assertions by United States officials that Greece is lax in combating international terrorism.   Unidentified officials of the Reagan Administration made the assertion in press briefings last week. The Greek official, who himself asked not to be identified, was also reacting to a statement by Assistant Secretary of State Richard R. Burt that the United States found it ''frustrating'' to deal with the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou.   Mr. Burt, speaking before a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee, said Greece was an allied Government that defended the Soviet Union while criticizing the United States.

headline: TRUCK IS GOING BACK TO SOVIET
abstract: The Soviet Union decided today to send home unopened a truck that Switzerland refused to accept as a diplomatic pouch.   The decision defused a dispute brewing since last week when the Swiss asked for details of the truck's contents.

headline: FRANCE'S PREMEIR PLEDGES AUSTERITY
abstract: Prime Minister Laurent Fabius pledged before the National Assembly on Tuesday to maintain the Socialist Government's economic austerity plan, saying France had no other choice than ''modernization or decline.''    Reacting to the statement, the Communist Party, which left the Government last week after Mr. Fabius's appointment, said it could only respond by abstaining from a confidence vote in the Assembly where the Socialists hold an absolute majority.   The vote early today in favor of the confidence motion was 279 to 157, with 46 abstentions.

headline: NEW ZEALAND'S PREMIER WON PERSONAL AND POLITICAL BATTLES
abstract: Prime Minister-designate David Lange is a former criminal lawyer whose road to the top has been swift but rocky.   Mr. Lange (the name is pronounced long-EE), who will become the country's 32d Prime Minister and, at 41 years of age, the youngest to hold the office this century, entered Parliament seven years ago in a socially deprived area in his hometown of Auckland.   Within 30 months he was deputy leader of the Labor Party and in February 1983 he took over the leadership from former Prime Minister Sir Wallace Rowling.

headline: 3 Executive Changes Set by Bristol-Myers
abstract: The Bristol-Myers Company yesterday announced three executive changes, including the appointment of John W. Melton, senior vice president, to be responsible for planning and development, effective Sept. 1.     He will report to Richard L. Gelb, chairman.

headline: Amoco Chemicals
abstract: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said its Amoco Chemicals Corporation unit had agreed in principle to acquire the Gulf Corporation's polypropylene facilities at the Cedar Bayou chemicals complex near Baytown, Tex.

headline: U.S. News Suit
abstract: A Federal judge declined a request by retired employees to block the $176.3 million sale of U.S. News & World Report to Mortimer B. Zuckerman, a Boston real estate developer.

headline: EUROPE CALLED MAIN U.S. ARMS COST
abstract: More than half of each year's United States military budget is spent on the defense of Western Europe, according to confidential assessments of American military spending by the Defense Department and the General Accounting Office.   The two separate reports also show that the United States spends more, in total and per person, to defend Western Europe than nations there spend to defend themselves.   The first assessment, done by the Pentagon, says that 58 percent of the United States military budget for the fiscal year 1985, beginning Oct. 1, has been allocated to the defense of other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.   The second analysis, from the General Accounting Office, an investigative agency of Congress, was based on fiscal year 1982 and says that 56 percent of military outlays were spent on United States forces in Europe or forces in the United States available to reinforce Europe in a conflict.

headline: ; Magazine Survey Finds Profit Percentage Up
abstract: The Magazine Publishers Association has reported that members' average pretax operating profit as a percentage of revenue rose to 10.89 percent in 1983, from 8.76 the previous year.     The survey, conducted for the association by Price Waterhouse, had the cooperation of 154 magazines last year, down from 192 the year before.    The association estimated that after-tax profits, assuming corporate taxes of 46 percent, would be 5.88 percent for 1983.

headline: Slain Priest Back in France
abstract: The body of a French priest, Andre Jarlan, killed during anti-Government protests in Chile last week, was flown home today for burial in his native village of Rignac in southern France. Airport officials said the priest's family had asked that there be no ceremony at Charles de Gaulle Airport.

headline: Gromyko and Shamir Meet at Soviet Mission
abstract: Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, conferred with his Israeli counterpart, Yitzhak Shamir, for an hour and a half last night at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations, according to a spokesman for the Israelis, who said it was the first such meeting in three years.   The spokesman, Judy Dranger, said Mr. Shamir ''raised the problem of Soviet Jewry'' and asked Mr. Gromyko ''to let all those Jews who wish to do so to move to Israel.''

headline: Debt Ratings
abstract: * Burlington Northern Railroad equipment trust certificates have been raised by Standard & Poor's to AAA from AA; its consolidated mortgage bonds and notes to AA from A.     *  Continental Group ratings are being reviewed for a possible downgrading by Moody's Investors Service because of merger offer by Peter Kiewit Sons Inc. and David Murdock.     *  Northern Illinois Gas Co.  first mortgage bonds raised to Aa-1 from Aa-2, and debentures to Aa-2 from Aa-3, by Moody's. Also upgraded was the shelf registration paper of the company, a wholly owned subsidiary of Nicor Inc., to Aa-1 from Aa-2.

headline: Jaguar Set to Go Public
abstract: The Government's sale of Jaguar, the luxury car maker, to the private sector will take place on Aug. 3 and should raise $392 million, according to the prospectus issued today by the bankers handling the deal.   The stock was conservatively priced at $2.18 a share in an effort to make sure that the offer is well received in a period of declining prices on the London Stock Exchange and amid doubts about Jaguar's long-range prospects.   Analysts said that the Government felt it could not afford a repeat of the turmoil surrounding the recent sale of Enterprise Oil P.L.C.. Investors left most of that issue in the hands of the dismayed underwriters.

headline: SPLIT FEARED IN SALVADOR ON CHURCH'S SOCIAL ROLE
abstract: The Vatican's criticism of liberation theology, expressed most recently in a major document made public last Monday in Rome, could have an especially sharp impact in El Salvador, according to Roman Catholic Church officials here.    Some Salvadoran clerics fear that the Vatican's attempt to discourage priests from activist politics will force each side to more sharply define its position, leading to an open breach that has so far been avoided.   ''The right will use this to say we are leftists who have been condemned by the Pope,'' said a cleric here who describes himself as a follower of liberation theology. ''And the leftists will tell the rightists that they don't understand reality. I don't think it will force priests out of the church, but it will polarize us.''

headline: REAGAN AND PAPAL ENVOY TO DISCUSS MOVES AGAINST POLAND
abstract: The White House announced today that the Vatican's Apostolic Delegate to the United States would meet Wednesday with President Reagan at his vacation ranch to discuss the expected easing of American sanctions against Poland.    White House officials said privately that the unusual interruption of the President's vacation had some domestic political overtones of possible value to the President's re-election strategy of appealing to Roman Catholic voters.   But the President's spokesman, Larry Speakes, insisted that the sole reason for the visit was the President's interest in Pope John Paul II's views on how well the Polish Government is fulfilling its promise to ease restrictions on political prisoners. Democratic critics have accused the President of trying to ''pander'' to Roman Catholic voters, a charge denied by the Reagan campaign.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Sallie Mae Is Offering $5 Billion of Zero Bonds
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $5 billion of zero coupon debentures due in 2022 through Goldman, Sachs & Company as sole underwriter. The non-interest-paying securities have the longest maturity, 38 years, of any zero coupon issue, making the issue very attractive to investors wanting a low initial purchase price.    An official at Goldman, Sachs said the issue was offered at various prices but acknowledged that in London there was at least one sale at a price of 2.734, or $27.34 per $1,000 bond, to yield 9.70 percent.

headline: MARINES GONE, MOSCOW IS COURTING LEBANON
abstract: Five months after the withdrawal of the United States Marines from Beirut, the Soviet Union is trying to increase its influence in Lebanon.    The Soviet Union has offered military and economic aid, and Lebanese Cabinet members have visited Moscow.   However, the Government of President Amin Gemayel appears reluctant to accept the Soviet offer of aid, hoping that the United States will still be able to persuade Israel to withdraw from southern Lebanon.   The Soviet position has been strengthened not only by the decline of American influence, but also by the emergence of Syria, a Soviet ally, as the main power in Lebanese politics.

headline: St. Paul Expecting $40 Million Loss
abstract: The St. Paul Companies, a large insurance group, said yesterday that it expected to report an operating loss of about $40 million for the second quarter. The company said fewer than expected tax credits were available to offset underwriting losses.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA LIFTS BAN ON MAVERICK WHITE CLERIC
abstract: The South African authorities today lifted a seven-year-old ban on a white cleric who severed the ties that bound him to his Afrikaner forebears by worshiping with black people and espousing their political cause.    At the same time, the authorities announced that six people detained last month for their opposition to a new Constitution had been released. The relaxations coincided with continuing unrest in Soweto and school boycotts by 93,000 students in other black townships.   The Government's moves, which offered a counterpoint to the crackdown on dissent that the police have been pursuing in recent weeks, seemed designed to offset adverse publicity and to further an oft-used tactic - that of keeping opponents off-balance by embarking on actions their foes would not normally have forecast.

headline: CARNATION: A FAMILY COMPANY'S EVOLUTION
abstract: With its proposed $3 billion offer for the Carnation Company, Nestle S.A. would be acquiring a strong, though largely mature, company.     Best known for its condensed milk from ''contented cows,'' Carnation makes more than 200 products, including Coffee-mate, Instant Breakfast and Contadina tomato products. The company is first in the condensed milk market, first in tomato paste and second - to Ralston Purina - in pet foods.   Five years ago, Nestle took a look at Carnation, its strong balance sheet and well-known brands, and reportedly considered making a bid for the company then. But a deal did not materialize. Carnation, an old-line company run by the Stuart family until late last year, was still wedded to the notion of family management.

headline: JAPANESE WARN OF A BUILDUP BY THE SOVIET MILITARY IN ASIA
abstract: The Government warned today that an ''unrelenting military buildup'' by the Soviet Union had increased the ''latent threat'' both to Japan and to the rest of Asia.    Despite the perceived threat, however, Japanese officials seemed more optimistic than they have been in recent years about the West's commitment to East Asia and its ability to resist aggression.    The Japanese report, an annual evaluation of security problems prepared by the Defense Agency, cited the United States deployment of new bombers and Tomahawk nuclear cruise missiles in the Pacific as signs of an effort to ''strengthen the credibility of deterrence.''

headline: Strike Costs VW Profits
abstract: Volkswagen, West Germany's largest auto maker, lost $180 million in profits because of the seven-week metalworkers' strike for a shorter workweek, Carl Hahn, company chairman, said today.   ''The interim report for the first half-year will show that VW was considerably thrown back by the labor conflict,'' Mr. Hahn told an annual shareholders meeting, leading to speculation that the company will announce a loss for the first half of 1984.

headline: TEXT OF ACCEPTANCE SPEECH GIVEN BY PERES
abstract: Following is the text of an acceptance speech today by Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader and Prime Minister-designate, as translated by The Associated Press from the Hebrew:    Honored Mr. President, gentlemen. I thank the President of the state of Israel for placing on me the function of forming the next government of Israel. I am aware of the gravity of the task and of the expectations of the people. Our people are divided, we are now in a period of dire straits, and I pray that we all, the voters and the elected, will pass it in peace, and that we will grant our people a future of faith.

headline: SANDINISTA PRIESTS TOLD THEY COULD BE DEFROKED
abstract: A senior Nicaraguan bishop warned today that if four priests now serving in the Sandinista Government refused to give up their secular posts soon they would be stripped of their right to function as priests and perhaps excommunicated.     The bishop, Pablo Antonio Vega, said the country's bishops were preparing to write letters to the four next month urging them ''to reflect'' on the wisdom of their remaining in the Government.    He said that ''within 15 days'' after each letter was sent, ''there must be a reply, or there is an ipso facto result, which is the suspension of their priestly functions.''    ''The matter could then reach the point of their being deprived of the right to participate in the rites of the church. We hope it will not get to this point.''

headline: Belgian Aid Bid Barred
abstract: The executive commission of the European Economic Community said it had rejected a Belgian Government plan to give about $30 million in aid to its textile industry in 1984. The commission said Friday that Belgium's first two aid proposals - in 1982 and 1983 - had been so successful that more assistance would serve only ''Belgian national interests'' and could harm fair competition in the trade bloc's textile sector.

headline: PATENTS ; E.P.A. Process Cuts Emissions From Boilers
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency received a patent this week for a process meant to reduce the nitrogen-oxide emissions in the combustion of nitrogen-containing fuels in boilers and gas turbines.     Patent 4,459,126, obtained by Wayne V. Krill and two co-inventors, describes a process of minimizing nitrogen oxide formation by burning a rich mixture of fuel in a catalytic bed. Mr. Krill is program manager in combustion technology for the Acurex Corporation, Mountain View, Calif., which served the E.P.A. as contractor in the case.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ; A South African Judge Bans Weekend Protests
abstract: A South African magistrate placed a ban today on weekend protest meetings in the Johannesburg area. He said such meetings could seriously threaten public order.

headline: G.O.P.'S PLAN FOR THE DEFICITS
abstract: THE 1984 election campaign has polarized the    Republican and Democratic parties on economic policy. The Republicans, in their platform, have declared their opposition to ''any attempts to increase taxes, which would harm the recovery and reverse the trend to restoring control of the economy to individual Americans.''   By inserting the comma between ''taxes'' and ''which,'' a maneuver that could be one of the more subtle and powerful uses to which a comma has ever been put, the platform committee overturned the White House intent to leave room for certain types of tax increases and condemned all of them. In fact, the platform called for still lower taxes.

headline: Reagan Gives Citizen's Medal To U.S. Aide Slain in Namibia
abstract: President Reagan today awarded the Presidential Citizen's Medal posthumously to Dennis W. Keogh, a foreign service officer who was killed in a bomb explosion in Namibia in April.

headline: UNIONS UPHELD AT SPY CENTER IN BRITAIN
abstract: A judge today nullified a ban imposed by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on trade unions at a top-secret intelligence listening post at Cheltenham.    The ruling, which was seen here as a severe blow to Mrs. Thatcher, came as her Government found itself already confronted by a half-dozen major political and economic problems.   Sir Iain Glidewell, a ranking jurist in the High Court, ruled that the prohibition, announced in January, was ''invalid and of no effect.''   He said that governments had the right to limit or forbid union activity at such sensitive installations as the General Communications Headquarters at Cheltenham, but that they could not do so without consulting the unions and staff. Mrs. Thatcher's method, he added, was contrary to ''natural justice.''

headline: TAX PROBLEMS FOR REAL ESTATE SHELTERS
abstract: on some forms of real estate tax shelters, but   for now, the shelters are booming. The reason, real estate experts say, is that even with the new rules, they remain an attractive investment.    ''The only issue is that the ratios will be lower,'' said Douglas W. Banks, a partner with accountants Touche Ross & Company. ''People will be getting 10 to 20 percent less tax write-off.''

headline: NEWSPRINT SALES KEEP MILLS BUSY
abstract: In 1981 MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. added the first new newsprint machine in 10 years at its Powell River plant in British Columbia. Like many of its competitors, this Vancouver- based forestry products company was expanding in response to what had been a severe shortage of newsprint in western North America from mid-1979 to 1981.    Such a move seemed sound at the time, but for MacMillan Bloedel and other expansion-minded producers it turned out to be a costly mistake. Before long the recession stalled consumption while newsprint production capacity soared and operating rates fell. During the industry's 1982-83 slump, newsprint prices plummeted.

headline: MEXICAN PRESIDENT CAUTIONS AGAINST DEFAULT
abstract: President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado today firmly rejected any plan that would result in Mexico's failing to repay its international debts, saying this would cause ''grave damage to the country.''   The statement, delivered in the President's annual report to Congress and the country, was his strongest to date against international talk of joint action by Latin American debtor countries and domestic pressure for Mexico to suspend payment of its foreign debts in order to provide more money for internal needs.   ''An irresponsible attitude in matters of international credit,'' Mr. de la Madrid declared, ''would bring about grave damage to the country by altering our economic relations with foreign countries and would affect for many years the prestige of Mexico. We will not accept adventures of destabilization of the international economy that would damage the weak countries with greater virulence than the rich ones.''

headline: SHAMIR AND PERES PLAN TO MEET TODAY IN ISRAELI ELECTION DEADLOCK
abstract: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and the opposition leader, Shimon Peres, agreed today to consider bringing the ruling Likud bloc and the opposition Labor Party together in a government of national unity.   They said they would meet Wednesday in Jerusalem to discuss the issue.   The accord was announced after the two men had met separately with President Chaim Herzog, who said he had moved to bring the two parties together after messages from citizens convinced him that the nation wanted a national unity government.   Since the elections of July 23, each of the two major parties has been trying to induce smaller groups to form a coalition that would gain a majority in Parliament. There has been concern that such a coalition, depending for survival on small special-interest groups, could not tackle the economic and other problems facing Israel.

headline: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: GLEASON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: NUTRI FOODS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OGLEBAY NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SCHEDULED SKYWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: PIONEER STANDARD ELECTRONCS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: OLD NATIONAL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1984 Companies
abstract: ARA Services got a buyout offer from an investor group headed by senior management for more than $858 million, or $62 a share. The world's largest food service company rejected an offer of $732 million by a former ARA executive in July. (Page D1.)

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; International Chief At Bank of America
abstract: Robert W. Frick has been elected vice chairman of the Bank of America and head of its international operations, the bank announced yesterday.   Mr. Frick, who is 47 years old, assumes responsibility for Bank of America's world banking division, the organization charged with delivering a full range of banking services to corporations, institutions and governments around the world. He succeeds W. H. Bolin, who retired earlier this year.

headline: U.N. Agency Approves Plan to Promote Fishing
abstract: A United Nations agency has approved a plan to pr omote development of the world's fishing resources, which produce nearly one fourth of the animal protein consumed in the world.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Ex-GTE President Named Apollo Chief
abstract: Thomas A. Vanderslice, who abruptly resigned as president and chief operating officer of the GTE Corporation last December, yesterday was named president and chief executive officer of Apollo Computer Inc.    In making the announcement, John W. Poduska Sr., who founded Apollo four years ago, said that Mr. Vanderslice, 52 years old, would succeed Charles P. Spector, 45, as president. Mr. Spector will assume new duties as vice chairman of the board. Mr. Poduska, 46, who had been chief executive officer, will continue in his role as chairman.    Headquartered in Chelmsford, Mass., Apollo makes professional work stations with engineering and scientific applications. The company went public in May of last year.

headline: 5 VENTURES BACKED FOR BELL UNITS
abstract: The Justice Department, completing a court-ordered review, said today that it could support five of eight proposals by Bell regional telephone companies to diversify.   The ventures that were approved include the offering of real estate management services by U S West and Pacific Telesis; the sale or lease of office products, such as computers and word processors made by other companies, proposed by Nynex and Pacific Telesis, and the provision of financing to companies leasing office equipment from Bell Atlantic.   The department also approved the provision of consulting and management services outside the United States to foreign governments or entities by Ameritech and Pacific Telesis, and a bid by U S West to seek a Federal license for a cellular mobile telephone system to serve oil rigs and shipping in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Arvida, Chevron In a Land Deal
abstract: The Arvida Corporation, a unit of Walt Disney Productions, said it had entered into an agreement with the Chevron Corporation for the joint development of Coto de Caza, a 5,000- acre residential and resort community in Orange County, Calif.

headline: Transco Plans Special Payout
abstract: The Transco Energy Company, a Houston-based energy concern, said it would distribute a portion of the partnership units it owns in Transco Exploration Partners Ltd. to shareholders quarterly. The limited partnership has big offshore leases in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: I.B.M. TO PURCHASE COMPANY ON COAST FOR $1.25 BILLION
abstract: In a forceful expansion into telecommunications, the International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it would acquire one of Silicon Valley's leading makers of telephone switching equipment for $1.25 billion in securities.    The acquisition of the Rolm Corporation would be the computer giant's biggest ever and its first in 22 years.   The agreement came less than 24 hours after the two companies surprised the industry by announcing that they were considering a merger. The move places I.B.M. directly in competition with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and major Japanese concerns in the emerging market for a more complex generation of telephone equipment.    Hub of the Automated Office    Rolm specializes in so-called private branch exchange systems, which experts believe will form the hub of the automated office. The nation's largest corporations are already spending $3 billion a year on such networks, which may be best envisioned as computerized, superfast telephone switchboards, carrying not only conversations but also computer data - and eventually pictures and text.

headline: STOCKS OFF AS INDICATORS DROP TO 17-MONTH LOWS
abstract: The major stock market indicators finished at their lowest levels in 17 months yesterday, as prices declined for the fifth consecutive session in slower trading.    The Dow Jones industrial average was down 10.05 points, to 1,086.57, its lowest close since Feb. 22, 1983, when it finished at 1,080.40. Its previous low this year was 1,086.90, on June 15.    Joseph Broder, senior vice president of Stuart, Coleman & Company, said the market may continue to move lower ''unless interest rates decline.''

headline: RIFT WIDENS AMONG BRAZIL'S RULERS
abstract: Brazil's civilian Vice President, Aureliano Chaves, ended his bid last night for the governing party's presidential nomination and moved closer to an open break with the departing military regime.    Another former presidential aspirant, Senator Marcos Maciel, said he and Mr. Chaves would join a dissident Liberal Front within the ruling Democratic Social Party and would no longer participate in meetings of the party's national directorate.   The announcement of the withdrawal from the campaign by Mr. Chaves and Mr. Maciel came after they met in the Vice President's home with leaders of the Liberal Front.

headline: HOLLYWOOD, IN TUMULT, BOOMS
abstract: For all the recent turmoil at the top, some of Hollywood's studios are flourishing at the box office.   The top-grossing studio last year, Paramount - which lost its chairman, Barry Diller, to 20th Century- Fox earlier this month and its president, Michael D. Eisner, to Walt Disney Productions last weekend - is getting a run for its money this year from Warner Bros. And Columbia Pictures Industries, which had slumped last year, is coming up strong, with two of the four most popular pictures.    Between the Memorial Day weekend and Labor Day, three films - Columbia's ''Ghostbusters,'' Paramount's ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom,'' and Warner's ''Gremlins'' - each took in more than $100 million at the box office, the first time that has happened.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM THE SETTLEMENT ANNOUNCED IN I.B.M. DISPUTE
abstract: Following are excerpts from the International Business Machine Corporation's settlement with the European Commission .      The European Position          Official's Statement      A statement by Frans Andriessen, competition commissioner of the Commission:   On behalf of the Commission I have just accepted an undertaking from I.B.M. to change its business practices in the Common Market. As a result, the Commission has agreed to suspend legal proceedings brought against I.B.M. for infringements of E.E.C. competition law.   The Commission has originally objected to four of I.B.M.'s business practices which we believed restricted competition in the most important part of the community market for large computers.

headline: EGYPT SAYS EFFORT TO CLEAR MINES IS EXPECTED TO END THIS MONTH
abstract: Egypt said today that the multinational search for mines that damaged 18 ships this summer in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Suez would end this month. No mines have been found.   ''The naval units searching for mines in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Suez will leave during the second half of September, but probably some French units may remain and continue the search,'' the Defense Minister, Field Marshal Abdel Halim Abu Ghazala, said. ''We have not found any mines.''

headline: CHURCH'S ACTIVIST CLERICS: ROME DRAWS LINE
abstract: The confrontation set for Friday at the Vatican between a powerful cardinal and an influential Brazilian priest signals a hardening of the division within the Roman Catholic Church over the religious-political movement known as liberation theology.    Leonardo Boff, a leading exponent of the controversial interpretation of Christian teachings that has taken strong root in Latin America in the past 15 years, has been summoned to Rome to answer charges that he has committed serious doctrinal errors.    To its advocates, liberation theology, with its emphasis on the church's obligation to combat economic and social oppression, is an urgent response to the sufferings of the Latin American masses. Friar Boff, some of whose works have already been condemned by the Vatican, has written, ''The liberation theologian takes a place on the side of the poor and oppressed.'' He rejects the status quo and calls for structural changes in society.

headline: FIRM CITING C.I.A. LINK IS CHARGED
abstract: The head of a Hawaiian investment firm, who contends that his firm was financed by the Central Intelligence Agency, was accused today by the Securities and Exchange Commission of engaging in a wide-ranging securities fraud.    The S.E.C. charged that Ronald Rewald, and the now defunct firm he founded, Bishop, Baldwin, Rewald, Dillingham & Wong Inc., violated Federal securities laws by making false and misleading statements to investors about Mr. Rewald and how the money was invested.    Mr. Rewald's lawyer, Melvin Belli, could not be reached for comment at his San Francisco office. His press secretary said he was out of town. In the past, Mr. Rewald has defended his actions by saying he was acting for the C.I.A.

headline: New NCR Line
abstract: The NCR Corporation's office systems division announced a new generation of desktop multifunction office work stations. The company said the NCR ''Worksaver 300'' series can be configured into networks that share resources and support various applications while operating on the same database. A typical configuration, priced at $7,795, includes a 12-inch display screen, keyboard, processor module and power supply and has 512,000 bytes of random access memory.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Aug. 13, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Decolonization Committee - 3 P.M.   Committee on Convention Against Mercenaries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: HEAD OF RB INDUSTIRES GOES BACK TO INVESTING
abstract: James A. Nathan has resigned as president and chief executive officer of RB Industries, a retail furniture chain.    Mr. Nathan, 42, said in a telephone interview from his home in Los Angeles that he had resigned to resume his career as a private investor. He will continue to serve on the board of directors.

Source: Bank Rate Monitor, Miami Beach, 33140

headline: DOMINICANS, YIELDING TO I.M.F., PLAN TO RAISE GASOLINE PRICE
abstract: The Government has decided to increase the price of gasoline after months of resisting demands that it do so from the International Monetary Fund, officials here say.   The fund has made price increases a condition of giving the Dominican Republic the second installment of a three-year loan of more than $460 million.   Tens of millions of dollars in aid from the United States Agency for International Development and the World Bank, as well as the renegotiation of the Dominican Republic's $2.4 billion foreign debt, are also contingent upon coming to terms with the fund.   The Dominican officials say that the Government, when it broke off negotiations with the fund over the fuel issue last month, recognized that subsidies that have kept the cost of gasoline artifically low would have to be eliminated if the country is to regain its economic health.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: SATURDAY, JULY 21, 1984   The Economy    Personal income rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in June , twice the May increase, the Commerce Department said. But consumption spending slowed dramatically in June and the nation's savings rate jumped to 6.1 percent from 5.6 percent in May. Economists said the figures confirmed their predictions that the economy has slowed but is still growing at a solid rate. (Page 39.)

headline: AIR CANADA CUTS
abstract: Air Canada announced a fall ''seat sale,'' with cuts off as much as 65 percent from published tourist fares.

headline: Air Florida and Eastern in Deal
abstract: Eastern Airlines will pay Air Florida $7 million for the right to fly its Miami-to-London route and for 16 arrival and departure time slots at airports in New York and Washington, officials of the airlines said. With the money, Air Florida ''will be in a position to start its operations'' again, said John Fasolino, a spokesman for the troubled airline.

headline: Sweden Says Soviet Fighter Intercepted a Passenger Jet
abstract: The Foreign Ministry says that a Soviet warplane intercepted a Swedish passenger jet in this country's airspace and that Sweden has filed a formal protest with the Kremlin.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Almy Stores Inc., a Boston-based department store chain, said its shareholders had approved the company's merger with a subsidiary of Federal Stream Investors Inc., owner of 52 percent of Almy stock.     *  Arrays Inc., a software and book publisher in Los Angeles, said it had decided not to proceed with its plan to buy American Micro Products Inc., a software manufacturer in Richardson, Tex.

headline: HOMES GO UP AND DOWN IN DAILY CAPE TOWN WAR
abstract: Just before dawn today, Susan Jezile, like other squatters outside this city, rose early from her bed and tore down the shelter of black plastic and brushwood that had been her home, exposing her sleeping children to the wintry winds of the Cape of Good Hope.    She did so, she said, because she knew that if she did not dismantle her 10-foot-square igloo of a dwelling, the authorities would demolish it and confiscate the precious materials she needs to rebuild it when they depart. So, she said, she pre-empted them to insure they had nothing to pull down.   A few hours later, officials from the Western Cape Development Board did indeed arrive with crowbars and tear- gas launchers and rubber-bullet guns to demolish some houses at the squatter camp known as Phase Two. Then they left, and Mrs. Jezile rebuilt her home and sheltered her children.

headline: Corporate Bonds
abstract: * Ohio Edison Co.  has offered $150 million of first mortgage bonds, due in 1994, at 15 3/4 percent through Morgan Stanley.     * Texas Utilities Electric Co.  has offered $150 million of first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, due in 2014, through Salomon Brothers.      Common Stock    *   Leiner Nutrinal Products Corp.  has made an initial offering of 1 million shares at $10.25 a share through Kidder, Peabody.

headline: THE LUCK OF AN IRISH VILLAGE: REAGAN STEPPED HERE
abstract: It has been almost eight weeks since President Reagan paid a two-hour visit to this drowsy village in the shadow of the Knockmealdown Mountains, but things have still not returned to normal.    Most people here are fervently hoping that they never do.   The grandstand that stood at Ballyporeen's only crossroad is gone, of course, and so is the big white tent behind the Church of the Assumption, and there are no policemen or hot-dog vans or reporters in town anymore, at least not most of the time. But business is booming, at a time when most of southern Ireland is suffering from a deep recession.

headline: EGYPT'S DWINDLING JEWS CELEBRATE A RARE WEDDING
abstract: Benoit Salem and Fabienne Rousseau exchanged marriage vows recently in what was an especially joyous occasion - the first Jewish wedding in Egypt in 19 years.   It may well be the last.   Egypt's Jewish community, once among the world's largest and wealthiest, has dwindled to 250, most of whom are old.   ''We have one more prospective groom: Benoit's brother, Michael,'' said Morris Guibly, the only Egyptian Jewish doctor left in Egypt. ''Michael is a very eligible bachelor. But finding him a Jewish bride here? Well,'' he sighed, ''we're going to have a problem.''

headline: PERUVIAN BISHOPS CONFER WITH POPE
abstract: A delegation of Peruvian bishops has been meeting with Pope John Paul II and other Vatican officials this week in an effort to resolve differences over the teachings known as the theology of liberation.     The discussions came as the Vatican continued to press its critique of liberation theology and as the Vatican's position became, at least briefly, an issue in Italian politics.   Earlier this month the Italian Communist Party leader, Alessandro Natta, surprised many Italian politicians by strongly criticizing a Vatican statement on liberation theology. Mr. Natta said that the Vatican document took a ''deformed view'' of Marxism. He was immediately denounced by more conservative politicians.

headline: OPEC Trade Deficit
abstract: The overall current account deficit of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries should narrow to about $10 billion in 1984, from $20 billion in 1983, Deutsche Bank said today.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: TECHNICAL FACTORS PREVAIL
abstract: Technical factors rather than economic fundamentals are likely to dominate trading patterns in the credit markets this week, according to analysts, with participants looking for signs of a tightening in monetary policy from the Federal Reserve in advance of the meeting of its Federal Open Market Committee next week on Monday and Tuesday.     ''The market is trying to work its way through what it is confronted with,'' said Philip Braverman, chief economist at Briggs Schaedle & Company, a subsidiary of the Irving Trust Company, ''and that is confusion about what the Fed is up to and what it will be up to. And the last thing the Fed wants to do is to be predictable.''    In the coming week, analysts said, the critical indicator of the Fed's intentions will be movements in the Federal funds rate, the closely watched rate for overnight loans between banks, which has fluctuated wildly in recent weeks, mainly for technical reasons.

headline: Michigan General Talking to Suitor
abstract: A unit of General Felt Industries told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it is involved in negotiations with the Michigan General Corporation aimed at acquiring control of the company. The unit, GFI Nevada Inc., said it already holds 1,648,200 Michigan General common shares, or 14.5 percent of the total outstanding.

headline: VOLUME IS 137.4 MILLION
abstract: A strong buying surge, propelled by indications the economy is slowing, swept into the stock market yesterday and sent prices broadly higher.    Turnover on the Big Board swelled to 137.4 million shares, from 110.6 million shares the day before, as pension managers, insurers and mutual funds poured cash into equities. Yesterday's volume was the largest since Aug. 10, when 171.3 million shares traded.    The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 9.27 points, to 1,237.52, after being ahead 14 points at 2 P.M.  Second Strong Gain    On Thursday, the average soared almost 28 points, its biggest rise in more than a month, fueled mostly by a very strong bond market and by expectations that the Government data released yesterday would support the view that the economy is slackening. An easing economy would tend to depress interest rates.

headline: SALVADORAN TO TAKE CASE ON NICARAGUA TO THE WORLD COURT
abstract: President Jose Napoleon Duarte says he will file a complaint with the International Court of Justice accusing Nicaragua's Government of smuggling weapons to leftist rebels in El Salvador.   ''In some manner, we have to stop this influx of weapons,'' Mr. Duarte said at a news conference on Friday.

headline: Cambodian Border Defenses
abstract: Vietnam has deployed more antiaircraft guns and heat-seeking missiles along the Thai-Cambodian border. The Supreme Commander of the Thai Army, Gen. Arthit Kamlangek, said today that the weapons had been moved near the border opposite Thailand's Surin and Sisaket Provinces.

headline: SOVIET LINKS TALKS ON SPACE WEAPONS TO A BAN ON TESTS
abstract: Text of statement, page 5.         MOSCOW, July 6 - The Soviet Union today reiterated its offer to hold talks with the United States on banning arms in space, but appeared to add a precondition, calling for a mutual moratorium on testing.   A Government spokesman said that such talks, which the Soviet Union has proposed for September, would be ''incompatible'' with the continued testing of space weapons.   The spokesman's comments came at a news conference here after Tass, the official press agency, issued a new statement saying that Moscow's offer for negotiations to ban all types of weapons in space remained open.

headline: WHAT'S NEW AT MCDONALD'S
abstract: For the McDonald's Corporation, it's been quite a summer: Never were the Golden Arches more visible. The far-flung fast-food enterprise starred at the Olympics, joined the Navy, announced a new roadside complex called McStop and dealt with the aftermath of a tragic mass killing that took place at a McDonald's restaurant in San Diego. The incident prompted McDonald's to suspend its advertising for a few days.     McDonald's, which has its headquarters in Oak Brook, Ill., is still the dominant force in fast-food, despite the creative competitiveness of its major rivals, Burger King and Wendy's.

headline: Sikh Sect Begins Repairs On the Golden Temple
abstract: Amid the chanting of prayers, the leader of a Sikh sect and his followers began repairing damage to the Golden Temple in Punjab today. But other Sikh leaders accused them of colluding with the Indian Government and threatened to demolish the restored structures.

headline: S.E.C. Acts On Filings
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it had charged the Bank of America with failure to file timely reports about stock trades it made as trustee for the Carter Hawley Hale store employees' retirement plan.    In a second action, also filed Monday in Federal District Court here, the agency accused the Savings and Profit Sharing Fund of Sears Employees and four individuals of having violated reporting requirements.    The defendants in both cases, without admitting or denying the allegations, consented to a court order that they file on time in the future.

headline: CHINA AND BRITAIN JOINTLY ANNOUNCE HONG KONG ACCORD
abstract: China and Britain announced today that they had concluded a long-awaited draft agreement that would transfer Hong Kong from British to Chinese sovereignty in 1997. The accord may be initialed as early as next week.   The one-sentence announcement, which came after two years of sometimes contentious negotiations, was released first by the British Embassy here and then by the Chinese Foreign Ministry.   ''Draft texts have now been submitted by delegations to Governments on both sides for consideration,'' said the identical announcement read by the British and Chinese spokesmen. Its bland language tacitly confirmed that the negotiations had ended.

headline: GUILTY PLEA IN JOURNAL FRAUD CASE
abstract: Peter N. Brant, a stockbroker charged with profiting from advance knowledge of articles in The Wall Street Journal, pleaded guilty yesterday to three criminal charges of conspiracy and fraud.    Mr. Brant, who is 31 years old and who was the top broker at Kidder, Peabody & Company before resigning in April, also settled civil charges yesterday in the same case.   In an agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Brant said he would return $454,437.19 in profits and stay out of the securities business permanently.    On the one count of conspiracy and two counts of fraud to which he pleaded guilty, Mr. Brant faces a maximum penalty of 15 years in prison and a $30,000 fine.

headline: Two Libyan Students Found Slain in Athens
abstract: Two Libyan students were found shot dead in a downtown apartment today in the third attack in as many weeks on Libyan residents in the Greek capital.   The police declined to speculate whether the two students might have been political foes of Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

headline: Israeli Sees Slow Pullout
abstract: The Israeli Army's chief engineering officer said in an interview on the Israeli radio today that it would take four to six months to dismantle and remove Israel's military equipment in Lebanon after a decision to withdraw has been made.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Cooper Lasersonics Inc. , a Santa Clara, Calif., company that manufactures and markets high-technology devices for medical applications, said it had acquired Plasma Kinetics Inc. of Pleasanton, Calif., a manufacturer of metal vapor lasers. Terms were not disclosed.     *   Crime Control Inc.  of Indianapolis, which is involved in electronic security systems, said its directors had retained Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. to advise them on alternatives to improving the value of its common shares outstanding, including Crime Control's possible sale or merger.

headline: PATENTS ; Voice-Actuated System Controls Machine Tools
abstract: A voice-actuated system for computer control of machine tools has been invented for the Kearney & Trecker Corporation of West Allis, Wis.

headline: MORTGAGE RATES DIPPED IN AUGUST
abstract: Mortgage interest rates, which have been climbing since early this year, slipped slightly in August, the Government said today.   Fixed-rate loans for new homes dropped to an average of 15.01 percent last month, compared with 15.23 percent in early July, according to a survey by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

headline: F.D.I.C. FORMING CONTINENTAL TEAM
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is moving swiftly to line up managers, lawyers and financial advisers to aid it in the possible takeover of the troubled Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company. But the effort is being hampered by rumors and speculation, banking officials said.   Morgan Stanley confirmed today that the F.D.I.C. had retained the firm as its investment bankers, leading some analysts to conclude that other banks may be brought into the rescue plan.   The firm served the F.D.I.C. in a similar role in the rescue of the First Pennsylvania Bank, a project that included the participation of other banks and has become the model for the Continental negotiations. A Morgan spokesman, Peter Roche, said he did not know what services the firm would offer the F.D.I.C.

headline: National Steel
abstract: National Intergroup Inc. said it and Nippon Kokan K.K. had signed a definitive agreement for Kokan's purchase of a 50 percent interest in National Intergroup's National Steel Corporation subsidiary, concluding four months of negotiations. The company said Kokan would pay $273 million in cash and $19 million in notes for its shares of the steel company. It said National Steel would be directed by a six-member group equally split between Intergroup and Kokan.

headline: Statement Asserts Solidarity Loses Support
abstract: A statement signed by a fugitive Solidarity leader, Zbigniew Bujak, today challenged Lech Walesa's assertion that the outlawed union is stronger than ever, saying public support is dwindling. Mr. Walesa called the statement a fabrication.   The remarks by Mr. Bujak, former leader of Solidarity's Warsaw chapter, who has been in hiding since martial law was imposed Dec. 13, 1981, were made in a statement circulated among Western reporters.   The statement by Mr. Bujak, the fugitive most wanted by Poland's Communist Government, complained that ''the activities of the union have ceased to exist in many factories,''

headline: PEOPLE EXPRESS AIRLINES EXPANDS MANAGEMENT
abstract: Harold Pareti was named yesterday as president and chief operating officer of People Express Airlines, the Newark-based discount carrier. Mr. Pareti, 36, replaces Donald C. Burr, 43, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.    Mr. Pareti, who is a native of Carlstadt, N.J., joined the airline in 1980 as a managing officer. He has been responsible for the airline's flight operations and legal affairs.

headline: Club Med Plans First Share Sale
abstract: Club Med Inc., which operates 20 vacation resorts around the world, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 2.58 million primary common shares.

headline: Continental Illinois
abstract: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company said it had agreed to sell a mortgage servicing unit to the First Family Mortgage Corporation of Lisle, Ill.. Neither Continental nor First Family would disclose the price.

headline: SEES HOPE IN REAGAN TALK TODAY
abstract: Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential candidate, met yesterday in New York with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and said later that there was ''an opportunity for significant progress'' when the Soviet official sees President Reagan today in Washington.   When pressed at a news conference to provide the basis for his optimism, Mr. Mondale said it was a conclusion drawn from his session with Mr. Gromyko, which had concentrated on arms control issues.   The former Vice President, speaking at the Plaza Hotel after his meeting at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations, said the discussion had been ''serious and businesslike'' and had covered a wide range of subjects.    Mr. Gromyko, who said earlier in a speech in the United Nations General Assembly that ''concrete deeds and not verbal assurances'' were needed for better relations, repeated during the meeting much of what he had said on arms control, Mr. Mondale said.

headline: Careers ; A Degree, Yes, but Do You Type?
abstract: VICTORIA RUSSO graduated   from Sarah Lawrence College,   prepared a proper resume and went to Manhattan to look for a job. When she got there, employment agencies said she had forgotten something: learning how to type.   Like many other job-hunting college graduates this summer, she has found out that her diploma is not the only thing employers are looking for these days. They want people who can type, who can use word processors and who can write shorthand.

headline: Opposition Parties Unite To Criticize Mrs. Gandhi
abstract: India's opposition political parties opened a national campaign against Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today over the dismissal of the chief minister of the state of Jammu and Kashmir.   At a five-hour meeting, which could have a major effect on general elections due in the next six months, leaders of 19 parties sharply criticized Mrs. Gandhi and her ruling Congress Party.   The Press Trust of India news agency described the meeting as a ''rare show of unity'' among opposition figures.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS KILL 58 IN ATTACKS ON FARM DISTRICTS
abstract: Leftist guerrillas attacked two farming cooperatives and a small village in western El Salvador on Monday, killing 39 civil defense troops and 19 civilians, witnesses said today.    The battles were among the fiercest to occur in this part of the country, which has been relatively tranquil during years of civil war.   Three women and two children were killed in the fighting, which the witnesses, residents of the various areas, said began at about midnight Sunday and lasted until 8 A.M. The rebels, they said, left the area quickly after capturing arms and burning farm vehicles.   Guards Are Untrained    The small settlements were protected by untrained civil defense troops. These guards, who live in the community, are issued an automatic rifle and paid about $1 a day. Reinforcements from the army did not arrive until Monday afternoon, the residents said.

headline: CHINA TELLS OF 'BREAKTHROUGH' ON THE FUTURE OF HONG KONG
abstract: Chinese officials said today that talks with the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, had produced a breakthrough on some problems blocking an agreement on the future of Hong Kong.   Neither side specified what progress had been achieved during the four-day visit of Sir Geoffrey, who left Peking today for Hong Kong after a meeting with Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader. But the Chinese Foreign Minister, Wu Xueqian, said they had discussed some important questions in detail, and he appeared pleased with the results.   ''Yes, you can say it was a breakthrough,'' Mr. Wu said in response to questions from reporters at the airport, before he departed today on an official visit to Latin America.

headline: PATENTS; SEAT USES SPRINGS AS CUSHIONS
abstract: WASHINGTON    A new spring seat meant for offices and airliners was patented this week.

headline: SELLER AIDS IN TRANSFER OF AMERICAN MOTOR INNS
abstract: THE agreement to sell American Motor Inns to Prime Motor Inns does not end the motel career of Joel Krish, American's 60-year-old president. After 27 years in the business, he will stay on to guide the transition. And his brother, Adolph O. Krish, 78, also is remaining chairman of American Motor Inns, based in Roanoke, Va.

headline: Lenders Study Venezuela Plan
abstract: Foreign banks have shown a cautious response to Venezuela's ambitious proposal for rescheduling as much as $22 billion of its debt, sources in the country's 13-bank advisory committee disclosed today.   ''I think it's optimistic,'' one banker said of the plan, which was submitted last week.

headline: Allis-Chalmers Narrows Loss
abstract: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation, citing the impact of cost   containment and margin improvement programs, reported   yesterday that it had narrowed   its loss in the second quarter to  $12.5 million, from $32 million.   Sales slipped 2.8 percent, to  $345.7 million, from $355.5 million.

headline: National Steel Labor Move
abstract: The National Steel Corporation, a subsidiary of National Intergroup, announced yesterday that it is withdrawing from the coalition of major steel companies that bargains with the United Steelworkers of America.    The industrywide group, which also includes the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, is not scheduled to bargain with the steelworkers for more than a year because their current contract expires in August 1986.

headline: People
abstract: *  Eugene O'Sullivan , director of client services of Young & Rubicam New York, was named executive vice president of Y.&R. USA.

headline: St. Regis-Murdoch
abstract: United States District Judge Maurice Paul has continued until July 20 a suit brought by Rupert Murdoch, the publisher, seeking dismissal of a Florida court order that would prevent Mr. Murdoch from buying more stock in the St. Regis Corporation, a paper and wood products company. The Florida Insurance Commission requested the order, contending that Mr. Murdoch's purchase violated the Florida Insurance Code.

headline: Market Place; The Weakness In Oil Services
abstract: ONE of the recurring truths in the energy business is that prices of oil service issues are dependent on the direction - or the perceived direction - of crude oil prices. As a result, current weakness in spot prices for crude and the suspicion, too, that official prices soon might ease have depressed shares of companies that provide an array of services to the petroleum exploration and drilling industry.    Schlumberger Ltd., generally regarded as the jewel of its group, traded yesterday at its lowest price in more than a year. The same was true of the Halliburton Company. Shares of the Hughes Tool Company, which recently reported a second-quarter loss of $135.1 million and later cut its common stock dividend, sold Monday at a six-year low.

headline: Hitachi To Export More Car Phones
abstract: Hitachi Ltd. said that to meet growing demand it would increase its exports of car telephones to the United States to about 60,000 sets in the year ending next March 31, from nearly 20,000 in the last fiscal year. It said it had arranged to supply several American telecommunication companies, including A.T.& T. Technologies Inc., with car telephones for sale in the United States under their own brand names.   Oki Electric Industry Company is the biggest Japanese exporter of car telephone sets, selling about 70,000 a year in the United States.

headline: LETTERS
abstract: To the Editor:      Ann Crittenden is to be complimented for her rather blunt portrayal of the overreaching characteristics of many corporate managers.    Regrettably, although the greed of these managers cannot be condoned, much of the responsibility must fall on the supposedly independent members of the boards of directors. Clearly, the directors have a fiduciary duty not only to the company itself but to its shareholders. When they approve ''golden parachute'' contracts, ''greenmail'' and other similar wastes of corporate assets, the directors ultimately should be held accountable for damages.

headline: Afghan Rebels Say They're Bombing Hotels
abstract: Afghan rebels said today that they had bombed three hotels and a movie theater in Kabul, in addition to the previously reported blast at the Kabul airport, and they warned of more such attacks in the capital.   The guerrilla sources added that the Moslem rebels had turned to urban warfare in their struggle against the Soviet-backed Kabul Government.   They said a bomb blast at Kabul Airport last Friday, which Western diplomats said killed 28 people and wounded 350, and the four other bombings on the same day were part of the new strategy.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; New York State Plans Commercial Paper Sale
abstract: New York State this November expects to begin regular sales of tax-exempt commercial paper, a kind of short-term security that sells with a much lower interest rate than long- term bonds.    ''The commercial paper sales will supplement, but not replace our regular bond sales'' said Marvin G. Nailor, a spokesman for the State Comptroller's office. Rather than paying for capital projects and then selling bonds, the state will raise funds immediately by selling the commercial paper, and have more flexibility in the timing of its bond sales.

headline: American Aide Meets With Gemayel Again
abstract: The Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs held a second round of talks today with President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon, Reagan Administration officials here said.    The officials said Prime Minister Rashid Karami also attended the session with the American, Richard W. Murphy, which took place at the President's summer residence in Bikfeiya, 10 miles northeast of Beirut.

headline: British Hospital Deaths: Spoiled Beef Is Cause
abstract: Contaminated roast beef served in a salad at a psychiatric hospital started a food poisoning outbreak that killed 26 patients, a medical expert said today.   ''There was nothing wrong with the beef itself, but it became contaminated and was the vehicle by which the infection spread,'' said Dr. Geoffrey Ireland, district medical officer of the Wakefield Health Authority.

headline: Sears Signs Deal For Satellite Link
abstract: The American Satellite Company said it had signed a contract with Sears, Roebuck & Company to construct and operate a private communications system for the retailer.

headline: Comserv Plans A Restatement
abstract: The Comserv Corporation said it plans to restate financial statements for 1981 and 1982. Comserv said the restatement results from its discovery of additional contingency commitments and possible contract irregularities.   The company, which provides propriety software products to the manufacturing industry, said its 1982 results were previously restated in September 1983 after it found that certain contingent commitments made in that year were not properly reported within the company.

headline: LTV Layoffs
abstract: The LTV Corporation said it would idle certain semifinishing steel facilities at its Aliquippa, Pa., works, effective Sept. 30, idling 360 workers.

headline: ADVERTISING ; Ogilvy & MatherAnd Grey Show Gains
abstract: Ogilvy & Mather International and Grey Advertising both turned in strong second-quarter financial statements yesterday. Ogilvy's earnings were up 68.4 percent and Grey's 31.2 percent.

headline: FRENCH ARMY'S NEW LOOK DRAWS PRAISE
abstract: A recent reorganization of the French Army has cut its strength by 22,000 soldiers, according to French officials. But Western military analysts say this has been more than counterbalanced by an increase in the quality of the army's units and the introduction of more flexible tactics.  Political and military leaders of the North Atlantic alliance are said to regard the army's reorganization as one of the most significant recent military developments in Western Europe, one that should improve France's effectiveness against any aggression by the Warsaw Pact.    France withdrew from the integrated command of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in 1967. Its armed services, while occasionally taking part in NATO exercises on a limited scale, have developed their own organization, tactics and weapons. French divisions, for example, are about half the size of American and West German divisions.

headline: Argentine Trade Gain
abstract: Argentina had a $2.3 billion trade surplus in the first five months of 1984, up 52.8 percent from $1.5 billion in the 1983 period, the Economy Ministry said today.

headline: Latin Arms Shipments By C.I.A. Are Reported
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency is using small private airlines to fly guns and other military supplies to United States-backed forces in Central America, and false flight plans are sometimes filed to cover up the shipments, CBS News reported Sunday night.   A C.I.A. spokesman, Dale Peterson, said, ''It's not our policy to comment on such allegations.''

headline: Prices Rise in Denmark
abstract: Danish wholesale prices rose four- tenths of 1 percent last month from July and were up 6.6 percent from August 1983, the Government said today.

headline: Chase Dismisses 380 to Cut Costs
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had dismissed 380 employees in its consumer banking division in an effort to cut costs.    ''It was a streamlining move to enhance efficiency and reduce the budget,'' said a Chase spokesman, Fraser Seitel. The layoffs, which followed a performance evaluation of the staff, affected employees in New York, New Jersey and Delaware, and at Chase's consumer lending network in other states.

headline: CREDITORS WON'T EXTEND ARGENTINE LOAN
abstract: Reflecting increasing frustration with Argentina's unwillingness or inability to come to agreement with the International Monetary Fund over terms of an economic adjustment program, the country's 11-bank advisory committee last night informed Argentina that it would not extend a deadline past today on a $125 million loan advanced last month.     The loan, which is guaranteed by Argentine funds held at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was made to help Argentina make interest payments at the end of the second quarter. At the time it was advanced, July 2, the advisory group said that the loan would not be extended past Aug. 15 unless Argentina had signed a letter of intent with the I.M.F.    In its statement, the advisory committee, which is chaired by Citibank, said that it had received a communication from the I.M.F. that ''significant'' agreements have been reached on a number of key policy objectives.    It added, however, that the ''process has not been completed.'' As a result, ''Argentina is proceeding to repay on Aug. 15 the $125 million to the working committee.''

headline: Cost of Climbing Everest Up
abstract: Nepal announced today that fees for Everest expeditions would climb sharply. It will now cost teams $3,000 - roughly 10 cents a foot - to scale the world's highest peak, compared with the old price of $900, officials said.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Amdahl Corp.  of Sunnyvale, Calif., said it had reached a 30-month agreement for Rotelcom Inc., a unit of Rochester Telephone Corp., to market and distribute Amdahl's data communications products.     *  Allegheny International Inc., a manufacturer of small electrical appliances and personal care products based in Pittsburgh, said it had sold its Sunbeam office in Oak Brook, Ill. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: SALVADOR FORMALIZES UNIT ON POLITICAL KILLINGS
abstract: President Jose Napoleon Duarte issued an executive decree today officially creating a new commission to investigate politically motivated killings here.    In a separate move, Mr. Duarte also asked the Salvadoran Army high command to investigate charges by Roman Catholic Church officials that Government troops massacred 68 civilians last month during an operation in Cabanas Province, some 40 miles northeast of the capital of San Salvador, the minister of the presidency, Julio Adolfo Rey Prendes, said.   According to testimony gathered by the Roman Catholic archdiocese legal aid office, army troops killed the civilians in a sweep against guerrillas in the small villages of El Cacao, San Antonio, Llanitos, Tortuga and Azacualpa. The army has officially denied intentionally killing the civilians.

headline: Polish Bishops Seek Action on 1980 Accords
abstract: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops today urged the Communist authorities to follow up the amnesty for political prisoners by carrying out the 1980 agreements that allowed for creation of Solidarity.

headline: Leucadia Raises Its Stake in Avco
abstract: A group led by the Leucadia National Corporation increased its stake in the Avco Corporation to 2,796,400 common shares, or 12.12 percent of the total outstanding, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Chrysler Obtains $1.1 Billion Credit
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that it had completed a $1.1 billion revolving credit agreement with 57 banks from the United States, Canada, Western Europe and Japan. The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company served as agent for the transaction.

headline: RETAIL SALES ROSE 0.8% LAST MONTH
abstract: Retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department reported today.   Economists described the increase as a solid buying performance that would continue to keep the economy expanding at a sustainable level.   The climb in retail sales, to a seasonally adjusted $109 billion, up $875 million from May, was larger than the May rise of five-tenths of 1 percent, but far below the 3.5 percent surge in April, when consumers went on a buying spree in automobile showrooms and department stores.

headline: SHEKEL DEVALUED AS ISRAELIS PLAN TO REDUCE BUDGET
abstract: The newly formed Israeli coalition Government took its first steps toward dealing with the country's severe economic problems today, announcing a 9 percent devaluation of the shekel and a plan to cut this year's $20 billion national budget by $1 billion.     The new Finance Minister, Yitzhak Modai, a member of the Likud bloc, said the austerity program was intended gradually to cut back Israeli living standards to the 1982 level.    Just where the budget cuts will be made has not been decided, Mr. Modai said.    'Reduce Our Expenses'      Prime Minister Shimon Peres, speaking tonight in Jerusalem, said that ''now we feel we have to turn first of all to ourselves, control our standard of living, reduce our expenses and make Israel an independent, self-reliant country from an economic point of view.''

headline: ROBOTS IN THE WORKPLACE: A CALL TO ARMS; MAKING A CASE FOR UNMANNED FACTORIES
abstract: TECHNOLOGICAL advances with industrial robots are making possible drastic changes in manufacturing - changes that will have a greater impact on the economy and society of the United States than any events of the last 40 years.  Because of the development of the microprocessor and research in the field of artificial intelligence, robots are increasingly being used to replace human workers in the production process. The age of the unmanned factory is already at hand.   The United States must take a leadership role in this manufacturing revolution, if it is to retain its position as the world's leading industrial power. It is discouraging, therefore, to see the slow pace at which American industry is adopting the latest gains in automation.

headline: NEWLY BUILT UNITS OUTSELL A MAJESTIC REHABILITATION
abstract: In an 800- acre wooded tract in this Westchester community on the Hudson River, just south of Peekskill, homebuyers have an unusual choice: apartment-like condominiums created out of a former resort hotel or new townhouse condominiums in clusters of two and three units. So far, the townhouses seem to be favored.    The setting is Dickerson Pond, a natural lake that was expanded to its present 50-acre size in the 1920's by a man-made dam. On the northern, more elevated bank of the pond, sits a majestic old hotel called Valeria. Stoned-faced and imposing, with an enclosed inner courtyard and a tower, it was built in the early 1920's by a private foundation as a retreat and convalescent center. The hotel closed in the mid-1970's and was purchased five years ago by a developer, along with the rest of the property. The five buildings of the complex were subsequently gutted and rehabilitated into 47 condominium apartments.

headline: 120 POLES ON TOUR BUSES ASK ASYLUM IN AUSTRIA
abstract: One hundred and twenty Poles aboard four tour buses on their way to Rome have defected here, the police said today.   Authorities here described it as the largest mass defection from Poland since 1982, when about 500 Poles remained in Spain and other countries after the World Cup soccer championships.   The authorities said the buses, carrying 180 Poles of Ukrainian descent, made a detour Thursday to Austria's main refugee camp here, 25 miles south of Vienna.   Viktor Demel, head of the refugee camp's Aliens Police Department, said the remaining 60 Poles went on to Rome in two buses.  ''The other two buses returned home empty,'' he said.

headline: Leftist Exiles Barred From Returning to Chile
