abstract: Six left-wing political exiles, including a former Cabinet minister, returned to Chile on Saturday in defiance of a ban by the military regime, but the police forced them to fly back to Argentina early today.   For 12 hours, until the plane took off again, the police kept the six from getting off the Air France plane that had brought them from Buenos Aires.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Air Express International Corp., Darien, Conn., has elected to its board Alessandro Caffarena, managing director of Fintrasporti in Genoa, Italy; Jack Leong, president of Mutual Distributors Ltd., and Anthony Low-Beer, an associate of M. Kimmelman & Company.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Chibret International, a division of Merck Sharp & Dohme, International, to Rolf Werner Rosenthal for an image campaign.

headline: MOSCOW CRITICIZES REAGAN ON YALTA
abstract: The Soviet Union, reacting to President Reagan's remarks on the division of Europe, today accused him of distorting history and defaming both the Soviet Union and Poland.    Mr. Reagan, speaking Friday at a White House luncheon, said the United States rejected any interpretation of the 1945 Yalta Agreement ''that suggests American consent for the division of Europe into spheres of influence,'' and added that the United States could not passively accept ''the permanent subjugation of the people of Eastern Europe.''   Tass, the official press agency, said Mr. Reagan's remarks, made in the framework of the election campaign, ''challenge the postwar political setup in Europe.''   It said that ''no one, the White House included,'' has the right to call into question the decisions of the Yalta Conference or of the 1975 Helsinki Accords that confirmed the borders of Eastern Europe.

headline: British Prices Rise
abstract: British consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in June from May and were 5.1 percent higher than June 1983 levels, according to the Department of Employment. In a separate report, the Central Statistics Office said industrial production fell 1.3 percent in May from April, and was off five- tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier.

headline: Prime Computers
abstract: Prime Computer Inc. introduced two super-minicomputer systems, which the company said performed 35 percent to 75 percent faster than the systems they replace.

headline: U.S. ASSAILS GREEK CANCELLATION OF EXERCISES
abstract: The United States criticized Greece today for canceling a planned military exercise with United States troops without warning. Such exercises have been regularly held for 20 years.   The incident was the latest in a series between the two North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies that has produced considerable irritation here with the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, even though in recent weeks there had been signs that Mr. Papandreou was trying to ease the tension.

headline: Bonn Sees 2.5% Growth
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that he expects real growth of 2.5 percent this year for the gross national product, despite recent strikes by the West German metalworkers union.

headline: German Price Changes
abstract: West German wholesale prices fell 1.3 percent last month from the July level but were up 1.6 percent from August 1983, the Government said today.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *   Angstrom Technologies Inc.  of Cincinnati told the S.E.C. that it had increased its holdings in Sperti Drug Products Inc. common stock to 347,471 shares, or 35.3 percent.     * Combustion Engineering Inc. , an energy equipment and products concern based in Stamford, Conn., said it had received a $27 million contract from the Tennessee Valley Authority.

headline: VATICAN CENSURES MARXIST ELEMENTS IN NEW THEOLOGY
abstract: The Vatican today made public a major document that was sharply critical of the more radical versions of the doctrine known as the theology of liberation.     The 36-page essay, titled ''Instructions on Certain Aspects of the 'Theology of Liberation,' '' was prepared by the Sacred Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith and ordered published by Pope John Paul II.    The doctrine of liberation theology, which involves the use of Marxist analysis, has been used to justify the activism of Roman Catholic priests and nuns in Latin America over the last 15 years.    Friar to Be Interrogated      The document made public today was presented at a news conference by Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger, the head of the Congregation, who beginning Saturday is to conduct a Vatican interrogation of a Brazilian friar who is a leading exponent of liberation theology,    Cardinal Ratzinger said the document's publication just five days before the questioning of the Brazilian theologian, Friar Leonardo Boff, was coincidental. He said the essay had long been in preparation, although he could not say how long.  In a statement issued by the Brazilian National Bishops Conference, the Brazilian Roman Catholic Church hierarchy cautioned church members against being alarmed by the Vatican's criticism of liberation theology. (Page A11.)

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Aug. 29, 1984 SECURITY COUNCIL   Meets at 3:30 P.M. on complaint by Lebanon.  GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Allegheny Beverage Corp., a soft- drink manufacturer and distributor in Baltimore, said it had acquired the principal assets and operations of the Terminal Vending Co., which distributes food and cigarette products in New Jersey.     *  Ameriwest Financial Corp.  of Albuquerque, N.M., said its board had unanimously rejected an offer from James E. Sowell to acquire the company.     * Bell Canada, the main telephone operating unit for Bell Canada Enterprises Inc., said it had filed for an interim 3.6 percent rate increase to take effect Jan. 1 for certain services.

headline: New Operating Chief At Don Tennant Co.
abstract: Elizabeth D. Harrington has been named president and chief operating officer of the Don Tennant Company, a Chicago advertising agency with annual billings of $35 million. She succeeds Thomas Prchal, who resigned in May.

headline: Convertible Issue For Allied Stores
abstract: The Allied Stores Corporation is offering $125 million of 8 3/4 percent percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2009 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: U.S. Navy Secretary Touring Chinese Bases
abstract: The United States Navy Secretary, John F. Lehman, began a tour of Chinese naval installations today after an ''extremely productive'' series of talks in Peking, the American Embassy said.

headline: Scali, McCabe Resigns 2 Heublein Accounts
abstract: Scali, McCabe, Sloves reports that it has resigned its two Heublein assignments, Harvey's Bristol Cream and Don Q Rum. According to Marvin Sloves, agency chairman: ''We regret having to resign any client, but there are times when it is the best thing for the client and the agency.

headline: NESTLE PLANNING TO PAY $3 BILLION TO ACQUIRE CARNATION COMPANY
abstract: Nestle S.A., the Swiss food conglomerate, will buy the Carnation Company, the Los Angeles-based dairy and foods company, for about $3 billion, the two companies announced yesterday.    Investment bankers described the deal, rumored for two months and completed in intense Labor Day weekend negotiations, as the largest non-oil merger in history. It tops the $2.8 billion combination in May of two other companies involved in food processing, the Beatrice Foods Company and Esmark Inc.   Nestle is Switzerland's largest industrial company, with operations worldwide. It is best known for its dairy, chocolate and baby food products.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Pay'N Save To Study Offer The Pay'N Save Corporation   said it had recieved an offer   from a group of investors to acquire the company for $22 a   share. Based on the company's approximately 15.2 million shares   outstanding, the offer would be   valued at $334.4 million.

headline: Bankruptcy Law Is Signed
abstract: President Reagan signed into law today a major overhaul of the nation's bankruptcy system but complained that it contained unconstitutional restrictions on his power to appoint new bankruptcy judges. One of the key provisions of the measure limits employers' ability to use bankruptcy to nullify union contracts.

headline: New Officer at Sieber
abstract: Robert McCaffrey, 39, executive vice president, creative director with Sudler & Hennessey in New York, is joining the Chicago-based pharmaceutical agency of Sieber & McIntyre, where he will hold the same title.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Electronic Data Net Up 17.5% The Electronic Data Systems   Corporation, citing the benefits   of broad-based growth and   more long-term contracts, reported yesterday that its net income in the second quarter rose 17.5   percent on a 19.6 percent advance in revenues.

headline: Plea for Steel Import Curb
abstract: American steel industry leaders appealed today for Congress to limit steel imports, but an Administration official predicted President Reagan would veto any such legislation.   Industry representatives, during a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing, backed bills before Congress that would limit steel imports to no more than 15 percent of the American market, Such quotas are needed for the United States industry to regain its domestic markets from foreign producers, many of whom are government-subsidized and have been ''dumping'' steel in the United States, according to Robert Peabody, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

headline: NEW OFFER TO ACQUIRE WOODWARD AND LOTHROP
abstract: Monroe G. Milstein, the chairman of the Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse Corporation, said yesterday that he and members of his family had offered to acquire Woodward & Lothrop, the Washington, D.C., department store chain, for $64 a share, or about $237 million.    The Milstein family is making the offer as a group of private investors and the action has no connection with Burlington Coat, a Milstein spokesman said.

headline: ISRAEL'S APOSTLE OF HIGH TECHNOLOGY
abstract: HERZLIYA, Israel    THE names are Middle Eastern.   The geography is, too. But the   story of Avraham Suhami, an Israeli academic turned millionaire businessman, could have been set in Silicon Valley.   Mr. Suhami's company, Elscint, a maker of highly sophisticated medical imaging equipment that takes pictures inside the human body, has had the sort of success normally associated with California's high-technology companies. Started 15 years ago with a $250,000 investment from two friends, Elscint - the name is a contraction of electronic and scientific - has spurted ahead in the past five years. It earned $12.6 million in the fiscal year ended last March, on revenues of $132.1 million. Its payroll totals 3,300. It owns manufacturing plants and research centers in such far-flung cities as Boston, Chicago, Oxford, Paris, Milan, Haifa and Jerusalem.

headline: ONE TIMES SQUARE, ITS FUTURE UNSURE, IS SOLD AGAIN
abstract: While planners and developers debate the future of the odd, 26-story tower at the heart of the $1.6 billion Times Square redevelopment project, the building, from which the New Year's Eve ball has been dropped since 1907, has been sold again.    The new owner of One Times Square is Allan J. Riley, a New York investor. Mr. Riley also owns the land under Washington Mews, a strip of residences in Greenwich Village that is leased on a long-term basis to New York University. In the past he has bought and sold such prominent properties as the office towers at 545 Madison Avenue and at 217 Broadway.    The sale price for One Times Square was $16.5 million, $4 million higher than the previous owner, the TSNY Realty Corporation, had paid for the tower in July 1981. Mr. Riley's partner in the venture is the Three Arrows Company, a New York investment group.

headline: Rumanian Prelate Asks To Remain in Portugal
abstract: Valerian D. Trifa, a Rumanian Orthodox Archbishop who left the United States under a deportation order because of his reported Nazi past, applied today for a Portuguese residence permit, the state radio reported.   Quoting an official at the Interior Ministry's foreign section, the radio said the the Foreign Ministry would be urged to investigate Archbishop Trifa's past as quickly as possible and would have three months to decide whether to allow him to stay.

headline: Mitterrand Responds To Critics on Liberties
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand, seeking to head off opposition charges that his Government has sought to limit personal freedom, announced tonight that he would seek a constitutional amendment permitting national referendums on issues involving ''public liberties.''   The statement by Mr. Mitterrand was apparently in response to accusations that the Socialist Government was abridging basic freedoms through a bill reorganizing the state's relationship to the largely Roman Catholic private school system, and one limiting the number of newspapers owned by an individual or group.   Mr. Mitterrand said he would propose a revision of the Constitution that would allow a President to call a referendum ''on the great questions that concern these precious, inalienable possession that are our public liberties.''

headline: PERU REBELS RAID 2 NEW OFFICES
abstract: Armed commandos of a new guerrilla organization occupied the offices of The Associated Press and United Press International here today, and at gunpoint forced both news agencies to send a revolutionary communique. No one was reported hurt in the incidents.

headline: HOLDING INCREASED IN BAKER, FENTRESS
abstract: The Amalgamated Sugar Company and its chairman, Harold Simmons, told the Securities ans Exchange Commission that they had increased their holdings in Baher, Fentress and Co. to 587,954 common shares or 7.4% of the total outstanding.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
abstract: President Resigns At Scott & Fetzer      Gary A. Childress, who has been president and a director of the Scott & Fetzer Company for less than two years, has abruptly resigned, citing personal reasons.    In a news release issued late yesterday, Scott & Fetzer, which produces dozens of products, including the World Book Encyclopedia, Kirby vacuum cleaners and sump pumps, said that Ralph Schey, the company's 60-year-old chairman and chief executive officer, had been elected to the additional post of president. The company did not elaborate on the reasons for Mr. Childress's resignation.

headline: Botswana's President Is Returned to Power
abstract: President Quett K. Masire's ruling Botswana Democratic Party was returned to power in elections Saturday, but the party dropped at least two seats to the opposition, according to results announced today.   With results of two remote rural constituencies still to come, the ruling party captured 27 of the 34 elected seats for Parliament.

headline: PAKISTANIS REPORT 16 MORE KILLED IN SHELLING
abstract: The Government reported a second straight day of cross-border artillery fire by Afghan troops today, saying that the latest attack had killed 16 people.   The new shelling was said to have taken place Sunday in the same area in which the Government had already reported 33 deaths from Afghan shelling in the last week.

headline: U.N. COUNCIL IS URGED TO GET ISRAEL OUT OF LEBANON
abstract: Lebanon's chief delegate here appealed to the Security Council today to put into effect past resolutions calling on Israel to withdraw from Lebanon and to immediately ''lift its siege'' on southern Lebanon.   The delegate, Rachid Fakhoury, told members of the Council that his country's civilian population was living in ''a continual state of terror'' because of ''the excesses of Israeli occupation.''   It was the fourth time that the Security Council had addressed itself to the problems of the area since Lebanon canceled its peace agreement with Israel last February.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Computer Consoles Inc.  Computer Consoles Inc. said   yesterday that Vaemond H.   Crane, its president, chief operating officer and a director   since February 1983, had resigned all three posts, effective   immediately.  Mr. Crane, who is 45 years   old, will be succeeded by Herman A. Affel Jr., 64, chairman   and chief executive officer of   the Rochester-based company.  No reason was given for Mr.

headline: G.M. Earnings to Be Diluted
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said its earnings would be reduced by about 99 cents a share for five years by its planned purchase of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation.   G.M., in proxy materials dated last Friday, said it would write off about $2.2 billion over the five years, the difference between its purchase price for E.D.S. and the lower book, or accounting, value of the data-processing company's assets.

headline: SIKH HIJACKERS GIVE UP PEACEFULLY IN GULF NATION
abstract: Hijackers who seized an Indian Airlines jetliner and demanded to be flown to the United States freed the remaining 79 passengers and crew of 6 today and surrendered more than 24 hours after commandeering the aircraft.   The hijackers, said by a senior Dubai police official to number seven, are thought to be members of an outlawed Sikh extremist movement called the All-India Sikh Students Federation. A senior diplomat at Dubai airport said they gave themselves up as the passengers streamed away from the plane.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Pennsylvania Offering School Bonds at 10 1/2%
abstract: A $336.8 million financing by the Pennsylvania State Public School Building Authority was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10 1/2 percent for bonds due in 2006, according to underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. For shorter maturities, yields were tentatively set from 7 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 10.40 percent in 1997.

headline: Singapore Aide Is Convicted Of Distributing Official Data
abstract: A top Singapore Foreign Ministry official was convicted today of passing minutes of Washington economic meetings to a local businessman.   Frederick Tan, the ministry's protocol chief, admitted during his trial that he had mailed the official notes on meetings last September between Singapore's Industry and Trade Minister and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and Paul A. Volker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

headline: Italian Deficit Widens
abstract: Italy's current-account deficit widened to $2.44 billion in the first five months of 1984 from $1.22 billion a year earlier, the Bank of Italy said today. The current account measures international dealings - both goods and services.

headline: EX-WALL ST. JOURNAL REPORTER INDICTED IN STOCK FRAUD CASE
abstract: Some lawyers questioned the legal foundation of the indictments. News Analysis, Page D4.               The Federal Government brought criminal charges yesterday against a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal. It accused him and two other men of stealing from The Journal and defrauding its readers by using advance information about articles in the newspaper to profit in stock market trading.   The criminal charges were based in part on the novel legal theory that a newspaper reporter defrauds his readers by failing to report his own financial interests in the subject of his articles. They were believed to be the first criminal charges ever brought against a reporter for his use of information in forthcoming articles.

headline: New Hampshire Ball Bearings
abstract: New Hampshire Ball Bearings Inc. said it had received a $65-a-share offer from the Minebea Company of Japan. Based on New Hampshire Ball Bearings' nearly 1.7 million shares outstanding, the offer would be valued at about $110.5 million.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: 90% of Victor To Datatronic
abstract: Victor Technologies Inc. said it had agreed to sell 90 percent of its common stock to Datatronic A.B., of Sweden, for $28 million. The price is payable in cash and notes guaranteed by letters of credit.

headline: YALTA, AFTER 4 DECADES, IS STILL A DISPUTED TOPIC
abstract: In the four decades since Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin secretly met near the Black Sea resort of Yalta, the meeting and its aftermath have been debated by historians and politicians.    Did the negotiators at Yalta carve out ''spheres of influence'' that in effect ceded control of Poland and the rest of Eastern Europe to the Soviet Union?   Or did the conference, in which Stalin agreed to enter the war against Japan, mark the beginning of the cold war as the Soviet Union betrayed promises of ''free and open elections.''   President Reagan said yesterday that ''we reject the interpretation of the Yalta agreement that suggests American consent for the divison of Europe into spheres of influence.''

headline: SEOUL AWAITS AN APOLOGY BY HIROHITO
abstract: Emperor Hirohito is being called on to express public regret over a part of Japan's militaristic past.    What he will say has become a delicate matter both here and in South Korea, demonstrating how, 39 years after it ended, Japan's long colonial rule in Korea continues to chafe the essentially friendly relations between the two countries.   Twice in the last decade the Emperor has lamented the period five decades ago when Japanese troops occupied much of Asia in his name.   In 1975, on a visit to Washington, he referred to the war between the United States and Japan as ''that most unfortunate war, which I deeply deplore.''

headline: GCA Expansion
abstract: The GCA Corporation said it is considering a ''major expansion'' of its print works complex here. It said the expansion could create several hundred jobs over the next few years and augment its Massachusetts operations, which produce equipment for the semiconductor industry. The final decision depends mainly on the granting of Federal loans to GCA and to the Yankee Tech Corporation, the developers of the complex, GCA said.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Sept. 12, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on International Development Strategy - 3 P.M.   Committee for 40th Anniversary of U.N. - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: White Spending
abstract: White Consolidated Industries said it would spend $60.9 million for new equipment at six plants of its home appliance group as part of a previously anounced companywide $400 million spending program. The plants involved are: the Americold Compressor Company plant in Cullman, Ala.; the Athens Products Company plant in Athens, Tenn.; the Columbus Products Company plant in Columbus, Ohio; the Franklin Manufacturing Company plant in St. Cloud, Minn.; the Webster City Products Company plant in Jefferson, Iowa, and the Webster City Products plant in Webster City, Iowa.

headline: Bank Rates Dip Again
abstract: Average annual yields on money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit continued to drop in the week ended yesterday, accelerating a decline that began the week before, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.   The Monitor's national index for six-month C.D.'s dropped slightly, to 11.15 percent, from 11.16 percent.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: South Africans Meet With Mozambicans    PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 13 (Reuters) - South African leaders held an unexpected meeting with Mozambican Cabinet members today and pledged to crack down on any South African supporters of anti-Government guerrillas in Mozambique.   The two countries signed a nonaggression pact in March, promising they would not allow guerrillas to operate against each other.

headline: A Bid for REDM
abstract: Mark IV Industries Inc. said it had started an offer to acquire all the shares outstanding of REDM Industries Inc. at $18 a share.

headline: OPEC Defers Nigeria's Plea
abstract: Nigeria asked to increase production today as OPEC oil ministers tried to prevent price cuts in a weak market.   The first day of their closed-door talks focused on the oversupply of oil, according to Gabon's oil minister, Etienne Guy Mouvagha Tchioba.

headline: Washington Watch; The Balanced Budget Bill
abstract: WASHINGTON THE balanced budget amendment, a Reagan    Administration proposal bogged down in Congress for the past two years, is showing some surprising signs of life. Although the odds are still against it passing this year, many of its supporters think they have a possibly winning strategy for an issue that is defined in such a way as to admit only one politically acceptable position, as in the case of child-abuse or motherhood.    Amendment supporters seem to have decided, in effect, to try to force Representatives and Senators either to join them or to expose them as being opposed to a balanced budget.

headline: London Subway Crash Kills Driver and Hurts 26
abstract: A crowded subway train ran into the rear of another one today, killing the motorman and injuring 26 passengers, rescue workers said.

headline: Beatrice Issues Bonds, Warrants
abstract: Beatrice Finance, a subsidiary of the Beatrice Companies, issued $200 million of 10-year Eurobonds with warrants to buy common stock through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston. Each $1,000 of the 10 1/2 percent bonds due in 1994 was accompanied by one 10-year warrant to buy 27.3 shares of Beatrice common stock at a price of $36.625. Beatrice stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday at $28.50, up 25 cents a share.   Proceeds of the financing will be used to repay floating-rate debt incurred by the recent acquisition of Esmark Inc.

headline: QADDAFI SAID TO TIGHTEN RULE AS RESISTANCE GROWS
abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who on Sunday marked the 15th anniversary of the military coup that brought him to power, appears to have consolidated his hold over the country in the wake of an attempt to topple him last May, according to Western and Arab residents here.     But they say that thousands of Libyans have been arrested or detained since May and that resistance to Colonel Qaddafi's radical economic and social policies is growing.   ''Colonel Qaddafi is in control, but his basic support is getting narrower,'' one longtime Western resident said. ''He is a leader increasingly at war with his own country.''    According to the Western and Arab residents, the instruments of the deepening political repression are Colonel Qaddafi's ''revolutionary committees,'' about 300 or 400 civilians who act as guardians of the revolution. The members of the committees are broken into smaller groups.

headline: THE COST OF POWER
abstract: To the Editor:     Mark Hertsgaard's tirades against nuclear power in the pages of The New York Times in recent weeks do not seem to agree with history nor with most observers' view of the industry's future.   The marketplace will decide the future of nuclear power, as its inevitable forces have shaped the nuclear industry's past. The units on-line today have saved their customers at least $30 billion, and perhaps as much as $70 billion by replacing more costly coal or astronomically more costly oil. Witness, for example, the current fight in the State of New York over who will get the cheap power from the Fitzpatrick nuclear plant. Clearly, in the past the marketplace has chosen nuclear, and has chosen it correctly.

headline: CLASH OF VIEWS ON LATIN PLIGHT
abstract: RIO DE JANEIRO     THE cyclical expressions of panic and relief   that emanate from the board rooms of major   American and European commercial banks suggest that they still view Latin America's debt crisis in the context of imminent moratoriums or short-term solutions.   There are the quarterly dramas of ''will or won't'' Argentina pay its past-due interest. There is gloom over a Bolivian default and toasts to widening trade surpluses in Brazil and Mexico. There was alarm when the region's debtor governments met in Cartagena, Colombia, last month and optimism when no ''debtors' cartel'' was formed.

headline: Reagan Names Two Senators As Delegates to U.N. Session
abstract: President Reagan announced today that he had named Senators John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, and Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, to be representatives to the United Nations General Assembly session that begins later this month.

headline: Angolans Report 143 Rebels Were Slain One Week in July
abstract: Angolan Government troops killed 143 insurgents in five southern provinces between July 17 and 24, the official press agency said today.   It said the Angolan forces had seized weapons from the guerrilla group, known by the acronym Unita, which has been fighting to overthrow the Government since independence from Portugal in 1975.   Last week the press agency reported that nearly 3,000 guerrillas had been killed in the first half of the year.

headline: Computer Export Curb
abstract: The Western allies and Japan have reached agreement on ground rules restricting the sale to Soviet bloc countries of computers that could be used for military purposes, the State Department said today.   A department deputy spokesman, Alan Romberg, called the agreement ''balanced and reasonable.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: NICARGUA TALKS SAID TO PROGRESS
abstract: Talks between the United States and Nicaragua have progressed better than either side expected, but the prospects for a negotiated solution to the two nations' differences remain remote, Reagan Administration officials said today.    The talks, which began in June when Secretary of State George P. Shultz made an unexpected visit to Managua, have dealt with substantive security issues, including United States demands that Nicaragua end its support of guerrillas in El Salvador, according to the officials.   ''There's been no grandstanding or stalling about procedural issues,'' an official familiar with the discussions said.   ''The talks moved quickly into a serious discussion of the issues that divide us,'' he said. ''The question now is whether either country has the will to reach a settlement. The vehicle for producing one is in place and works well.'' As a result, the officials said, the discourse between Washington and Managua, although still marked by antagonistic exchanges in public, has become considerably less hostile in private.

headline: Fleet Financial
abstract: The Fleet Financial Group yesterday priced $75 million worth of one- year extendable notes carrying a final maturity of July 15, 1991. The notes were priced at par and carry a coupon of 13 percent. Salomon Brothers is acting as the lead underwriter for the issue, which has been rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.& P.

headline: IRANIAN JETS DAMAGE JAPANESE TANKER
abstract: Iranian planes attacked and damaged a Japanese-owned supertanker today in evident retaliation for Iraqi attacks, shipping sources reported.    Diplomats here presumed that the attack on the Liberian-registry Primrose was in reprisal for Iraqi raids against vessels bound to or from Iran and, in particular, a June 24 raid against the Kharg Island oil terminal.    Iranians confirmed today that Kharg Island facilities were damaged in the June 24 raid.   The Primrose was said to have been hit twice but remained sufficiently seaworthy to proceed at full speed toward the Strait of Hormuz.

headline: No Rise Seen In Swedish Tax
abstract: Swedish companies will not face higher taxes in 1985 despite sharply rising profits this year, Finance Minister Kjell-Olof Feldt said today.   But Mr. Feldt said there was a possibility the Government might force companies to put more of their profits into blocked accounts at the central bank to be used for investment.

headline: S.E.C. Move On Bank Plan
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to seek public comment on a proposed new plan that would help commission officials get around foreign bank secrecy laws.   Under the new plan, called ''waiver by conduct,'' Congress would be asked to pass legislation stating that, by the act of trading in United States securities markets, an investor waives the protection of any applicable bank secrecy laws.

headline: INTEREST RATES SEEN STEADYING
abstract: Long-term interest rates, which rose sharply through the first half of the year, are likely to remain at or near their current levels for the next six months or so, analysts now predict.     In fact, some experts are beginning to wonder if the recent rally in bond prices, which began about two weeks ago, represents something more than a mere respite in what is generally seen as a bear market for bonds.    In large part, the change in attitude is due to a shift in market perceptions about inflation, which is now seen as remaining in the 3 percent to 4 percent range for the balance of the year, at least.    ''The odds are only slightly better than 50-50 that those who expect long- term interest rates to rise further are right,'' said Alan Greenspan, president of Townsend-Greenspan & Company, a New York-based economic forecasting concern. ''We are already at the point where the inflation premiums built into the long bond are quite high. The only place that one could argue for a further dip in bond prices is that the economy is still very strong.''

headline: Cattle Total Down 1.3%
abstract: Cattle inventory declined 1.3 percent during the last year, about in line with predictions, the Agriculture Department said today.   The July 1 inventory of all cattle and calves was estimated at 121,950,000 head, compared with 123,540,000 a year earlier.

headline: U.S. Envoy to Nepal Named
abstract: President Reagan has appointed Leon J. Weil, a New York City stockbroker, as Ambassador to Nepal. Mr. Weil has been general partner and senior vice president at Herzfeld & Stern, a Manhattan brokerage concern. Born in New York City, he has been a member of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports since 1981.

headline: Ford Sets 85 Price Rise of 1.3%
abstract: The Ford Motor Company today said that it would increase the retail price of its 1985 model cars by an average of $153, or 1.3 percent, somewhat less than the tentative prices announced earlier.   Ford had told its dealers early this month that prices might increase an average of as much as 1.9 percent, or $225. With the company's approval, Ford dealers have been selling 1985 cars on the basis of the tentative prices, even though the cars were not officially to go on sale until early October.

headline: Sri Lanka Police Ambushed
abstract: Tamil separatist guerrillas today ambushed two police trucks on routine patrol in Jaffna, wounding four policemen and touching off a search operation, Defense Ministry sources said. Two of the wounded policemen were Tamils, the two others Sinhalese. Militant Tamils have been demanding creation of an independent state in northern Sri Lanka.

headline: INDUSTRIAL POLICY REVISITED; AMERICA: STILL A TOUGH COMPETITOR
abstract: -called national industrial policy - government participation in private industrial planning - tell us the American economy is in trouble: We have lost our overall competitiveness in world markets; our economy is de-industrializing, and new job opportunities will become increasingly scarce and concentrated at the low end of the wage scale. If you listen too much to this litany of woes, you might begin to believe it. But if you look at some pertinent numbers, you get a different picture.    Economists at the New York Stock Exchange have just completed a new study, ''U.S. International Competitiveness: Perception and Reality,'' that strongly challenges all three assumptions. While some important United States industries have lost world market share, our overall share of world exports in manufacturing has been much better than most people believe. Among the losers, as we all know, have been autos, steel, textiles and shoes. But computers, office and communications equipment, aerospace, household appliances and others have remained strong.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Solgar Co., Lynbrook, L.I., to Franznick & Cusatis.     * Kirsch Co., Sturgis, Mich., and D'Arcy MacManus Masius/Bloomfield Hills, have terminated their relationship.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Advance Circuits Inc., a printed circuits board company in Minnetonka, Minn., said it had agreed in principle to acquire the multilayer printed circuit manufacturing operations of Multaplex Corp. for about $15 million cash and $3.2 million in securities.     * Consolidated Foods Corp.  of Chicago said it had acquired closely held Porter Foods Inc. of Little Rock, Ark.

headline: British Court Fines Miners
abstract: A judge fined the South Wales branch of Britain's striking coal miners' union $66,000 today, warning that unless the union paid by Wednesday, its entire assets of $4 million would be seized. But strike officials said after the ruling that the branch would carry out national union policy of ''total noncooperation with the courts.''

headline: ECONOMISTS OUTLINE A REMEDY FOR ISRAELI WOES
abstract: The traditional remedy prescribed for countries in desperate economic straits, such as Israel, where the new leadership is trying to devise an economic reform plan, is a painful combination of cutbacks in Government programs, tax increases and slower monetary growth.    Such a combination of austerity measures, often augmented by currency and import controls, has been successfully employed in a number of countries plagued by acute inflation, ballooning budget and trade deficits, and large foreign debts.   The idea is to reverse the country's course of consuming more than it produces. The measures are politically difficult to achieve, given their painful impact on consumers, whose standard of living will decline as they are forced to pay higher taxes, pay higher prices for certain goods and go without some government subsidies and services. But as many Latin American debtor nations have recently found, international lenders typically require an austerity program before extending further aid.

headline: PANAMA SAYS IT WILL RUN MILITARY SCHOOL GIVEN UP BY U.S.
abstract: Panamanian military authorities have announced that an American training school being turned over to Panama will be kept open under Panamanian administration.   Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the chief of the Panamanian defense forces, said Friday that the United States training school for Latin American soldiers would be converted into a scientific military school and its name, the School of the Americas, would be changed.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Bradford National Corp., a wholesaler of computerized financial products, has appointed Michael H. Mindlin to the new position of senior executive vice president in charge of coordinating operations of the subsidiary companies.     *  Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., Los Angeles, an owner and operator of retail department stores, has appointed John M. Gailys executive vice president of finance and operations.

headline: COLONIAL PENN SALE OUTLOOK
abstract: THE Colonial Penn Group writes various types   of insurance. But, as the Philadelphia-based   company discovered earlier this month, there is no insurance coverage for an acquisition deal that falls through.   In June, the St. Regis Corporation, basically a forest products and packaging company, agreed to buy Colonial Penn in a transaction valued at about $35 a share for Colonial Penn's stockholders. Although the acquisition was described by both corporate managements as a move to broaden the insurance operations of St. Regis, there were reports, too, that St. Regis saw this as a way to discourage unwanted takeover bids for itself.

headline: Zale, in Streamlining, Names New Unit's Chief
abstract: In an effort to further streamline its operations, the Zale Corporation announced yesterday that David G. Gan had been named president of a new merchandise services group. The appointment is effective immediately.     The new group will encompass the company's manufacturing and merchandise management systems divisions, as well as its merchandise administration office.

headline: Ryder System
abstract: The Ryder System is offering $100 million of 13 3/8 percent notes due in 1994 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The notes, which are rated A-3 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's, were offered with a yield six-tenths of 1 percent greater than 10-year Treasury notes.

headline: Dissident Is Freed in Poland, Insisting That He Is Innocent
abstract: Henryk Wujec, the last imprisoned leader of the Polish dissident group KOR, was freed under a Government amnesty today but said he had refused to sign a release order to emphasize his assertion that he was not guilty.   The 43-year-old physicist had been in prison since martial law was imposed in December 1981.

headline: French Wheat Crop
abstract: France will have a record wheat crop this year and production of other cereals will be sharply higher than in 1983, producers said today. The cereal growers' federation estimated this year's soft wheat production at 26.8 million tons, up 27 percent from 1983 and well above the previous record of 21.6 million tons set in 1982. Production of hard wheat should rise 24 percent, to 474,000 tons, while barley should jump 61 percent, to 673,000 tons.

headline: LATINS OFFER A SALVADOR MEDIATION PLAN
abstract: The four countries trying to find a peaceful settlement to the conflicts in Central America have offered to help El Salvador's new Government begin negotiations with the country's leftist rebels, according to a Latin American diplomat in the region.   The diplomat said the four countries - Colombia, Mexico, Panama and Venezuela - made the offer to President Jose Napoleon Duarte because ''the bilateral conflict affects the general arrangement'' they are trying to achieve in the region.   Mr. Duarte has said publicly that he is not ready to to negotiate with the leftist guerrillas until he has established ''the conditions first to give a base of security and an atmospere of democracy'' in the country. Other Latin American officials have expressed concern privately that the negotiations may become necessary before those conditions can be achieved.

headline: Aamco Resignation
abstract: Calet, Hirsch & Spector has resigned its assignment from Aamco Transmissions because of ''creative differences.'' In this case, especially, those are the most imporant kind, since the agency has been doing only the creative for the last seven years. Aamco got its media buying and placing elsewhere.

headline: Transamerica Has More Hershey Oil
abstract: The Transamerica Corporation and three subsidiaries told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had increased their holdings in the Hershey Oil Corporation to 1,676,500 shares, or 29.2 percent of the total outstanding.

headline: BRAZILIAN CAMPAIGN OFFERS EVERYTHING BUT VOTERS
abstract: The campaign to pick Brazil's first civilian President in 20 years has begun with all the trappings of democracy except the people's right to vote.    There is a clear choice between the personalities and the platforms of the two contenders. Both are busily seeking the endorsements of prominent citizens and organizations; they compete daily for the public's attention, and public-opinion polls carefully track their popularity ratings.   President Joao Baptista Figueiredo, the fifth army general to rule Brazil since 1964, has also received - and proudly responded to - telegrams from both candidates congratulating him on fulfilling his 1979 promise to return the country to democracy. The end of the military era appears to be in sight.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * People for the American Way, a citizens group, to Plapler & Associates.

headline: Masters Settles Kerr-McGee Suits
abstract: The Masters Energy Corporation said it had settled suits filed against it by the Kerr-McGee Corporation.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: Variable Notes Planned by Mesa
abstract: The Mesa Petroleum Company said yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed offering of $300 million worth of principal amount of subordinated exchangeable variable-rate notes.

headline: EQUIMARK SEES A LOSS IN 2D QUARTER AND YEAR The Equimark Corporation, owner of Equibank of Pittsburgh, will report a substantial second-quarter loss, return to the black in the third quarter but still show a loss for the full year, James D. Lowry, president and chief executive, announced yesterday.
abstract: He said the bank would not pay an $875,000 dividend due Chase Manhattan Bank on $25 million of 14 percent preferred stock it holds. He added, however, that the company might reach agreement with Federal and state regulators by fall on a plan to increase its capital by $100 million from the current $87.5 million.    Bank analysts said the dividend suspension to Chase would not touch off a default. A Chase spokesman said that payments were cumulative and that the bank expected to be paid.

headline: Volvo's Earnings Rise
abstract: Volvo Personvagnar A.B., the passenger car division of A.B. Volvo, said today that its profits in the first six months of 1984 were ahead of the record pace of last year. Roger Holtback, president of the division, said Volvo sold 55,902 cars in the United States - its biggest market - in the period, up 18.8 percent from the 47,054 cars sold a year ago.

headline: U.S.-Latin Debt Talks
abstract: Latin American and United States economic experts tentatively agreed to seek relaxed lending policies by United States-financed development agencies during a two-day international conference on debt and trade that opened today.

headline: Japan Payments Deficit
abstract: Japan's balance of payments recorded a deficit of $2.25 billion in June, compared with a deficit of $1.22 billion in May and a $1.38 billion surplus a year ago, the Finance Ministry said today. The ministry said it was the sixth consecutive month that Japan had shown a deficit in its balance of payments, which measures international transactions in merchandise, services and transfer payments such as investments.

headline: JAPAN SEES NEED TO END NORTH KOREAN 'ISOLATION'
abstract: The Prime Minister of Japan told South Korea's President Friday that efforts must be made to end North Korea's ''isolation'' if there is to be stability on the Korean peninsula.    The Prime Minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, offered no specific proposals in his remarks to President Chun Doo Hwan, and Japanese Government officials emphasized that his comments did not signal a Japanese shift away from basic support for South Korean diplomatic positions.   Japan has some economic ties but no formal relations with the North Korean Government in Pyongyang. Mr. Nakasone reportedly said there was ''no reason why this policy should change unless there is a major change in the international situation.''   Nevertheless, any reference to possible fresh initiatives to North Korea - no matter how thickly veiled - is enough to raise concern among South Korean officials. Mr. Chun, who met with Mr. Nakasone for an hour Friday morning, was said to have called on Japan to act ''prudently and cautiously'' in dealing with Pyongyang.

headline: Stocks Close Mixed; Dow Off 7.95
abstract: Stock prices, buffeted by profit taking among blue-chip stocks, finished broadly mixed yesterday.    The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.95 points, but advances, supported by the strength of secondary issues, outnumbered declines by 855 to 751.   ''After four up days and a rise of about 40 points on the Dow, the market paused and gave back about 8 points,'' said William LeFevre, vice president of investment strategy at Purcell, Graham & Company. ''This is merely institutional profit taking. With last year-end's 1,258.64 within reach, I look for that level to be execeeded very soon, followed by an attempt at a new closing record on the Dow above 1,287.20.''

headline: A.T.& T. NET MARGIN NEARS CAP
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, despite service backlogs and increased competition, has moved closer in recent months to its maximum authorized profit margin for interstate long-distance telephone service.   A company spokesman said last week that A.T.& T.'s rate of return, or profit margin, on long-distance telephone service was 12.36 percent after the first seven months of 1984. The maximum authorized margin is 12.75 percent annually, based on A.T.& T.'s investment in equipment.   Formal reports filed by A.T.& T. with the Federal Communications Commission show the company actually exceeded its authorized margin during the quarter ended June 30, but it fell substantially below the maximum rate during the first quarter.

headline: Fiat Tractor and China
abstract: Fiat Trattori, the tractor manufacturing unit of Italy's largest private industrial group, Fiat S.p.A., said it had signed a letter of intent to renovate two tractor plants in China. Fiat Trattori said Friday that it would renovate plants at Shanghai and at Luoyang under the agreement with China's Ministry of Machine Manufacture. The plants will produce Fiat tractors under license, it said.

headline: STOCK SEIZED BY THE U.S. PAYS OFF, 40 YEARS LATER
abstract: The Government realized a profit today on stock that it seized as enemy assets in World War II and that it had regarded as worthless for more than 30 years.    According to David Epstein, director of the Justice Department's office of foreign litigation, the profit was gained through an unusual chain of events in which the Government first seized the stock, then learned it was worthless, then heard it might have value again, and then sued to press its full claim.    In a settlement of the suit announced today by Attorney General William French Smith, the Government won $850,000 in cash and stock, in addition to $325,000 that the company, the North European Oil Royalty Trust, had paid earlier.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Fenimore Asset Management Inc., a Cobbleskill, N.Y., investment adviser, said it had increased its holdings in Cotton States Life and Health Insurance Co. to 107,850 common shares, or 7.7 percent of the total outstanding.     * First Savings Association of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, said it would sell its Madison branch to First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Madison.     * Ford Glass Ltd.  said its parent, Ford Motor Co., had reached an agreement to acquire Pilkington Brothers P.L.C.'s 49 percent minority interest in Ford Glass. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: INVESTING ; KILLING THE PURVEYORS OF BAD NEWS
abstract: CORPORATIONS are about ready to begin the quarterly ritual of issuing earnings reports. But in the past few weeks, scores of companies have already let Wall Street know that their third-quarter earnings will be below those of last year's. And countless others have said that, while their earnings will be up, they will come nowhere near the levels that optimistic analysts had been predicting.    The market has been unforgiving of these unhappy surprises. In fact, the Street has been picking what Suresh L. Bhirud, portfolio strategist at the First Boston Corporation, calls a daily ''sacrificial lamb.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: *  Allnet Communication Services Inc.  said it had signed a one-year agreement with Southwestern Bell Telephone, a subsidiary of Southwestern Bell Corp., for selective billing services as equal access becomes available. Terms were not disclosed.     *  Cole National Corp., a retailer of prescription eyewear and engraved gifts based in Cleveland, said its acquisition by a new corporation owned by partnerships controlled by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. and certain members of Cole management had been completed.

headline: Swiss Jobless Drop
abstract: Switzerland's unemployment rate dropped to 1.1 percent in June, from 1.2 percent in May, but was still higher than the nine-tenths of 1 percent rate in June 1983, the Federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said today. The number of jobless workers at the end of June was 34,499, compared with 35,565 at the end of May and 26,795 at the end of June 1983.

headline: 4 Indonesians Arrested After Moslem Riot
abstract: The police have arrested four Moslem youths on charges of distributing anti-Government leaflets around the Indonesian capital after a fierce riot last Wednesday, a Government official said today.

headline: Greece Is Canceling Maneuvers With U.S.
abstract: Greece said today it had canceled a series of joint war games with the United States, the latest of which was due to start in 10 days.   Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou made the decision last week on grounds that any threat to Greece came from Turkey, not from its Communist neighbors, Greek officials said.

headline: MEXICAN ARMY ACCUSED ON GUATEMALA EXILES
abstract: A Roman Catholic diocese in southern Mexico says the Mexican Army tortured and killed three Guatemalan refugees last week and has denied food to thousands of refugees along the Mexican-Guatemalan border.   The allegations, contained in the document signed by a representative of the diocese in San Cristobal de las Casas, were strongly denied by a high- ranking official in the Interior Ministry, which is responsible for refugee matters in Mexico.    ''These are just absolutely false statements,'' the official said. ''The transfer of refugees from the jungle camps has been done with all respect for their human rights.''

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: A $50 million issue of Texas general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 7 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 8.5 percent in 1994 and 9.1 percent in 1999 through underwriters led by Citibank. By late afternoon, underwriters estimated about $20 million of the issue was unsold.    The bonds are rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Soviet Copters Reported Deployed in Afghanistan
abstract: Nearly 50 Soviet helicopters have left Kabul, the Afghan capital, for southeastern Afghanistan in a new drive against guerrillas near the Pakistani border, Western diplomats said today.   The diplomats also said Soviet troops had stepped up a campaign of destroying crops now that the harvest season is about to start in Afghanistan. They said that helicopters dropped incendiary bombs on wheat fields south of Kabul and that tanks ran over crops in the Panjshir Valley.

headline: Yields Reduced On M.A.C. Bonds
abstract: Strong investor demand for a new bond issue of the Municipal Assistance Corporation caused underwriters led by Salomon Brothers to reduce yields by a quarter to a tenth of a percentage point for bonds due in 1988 through 1998. The largest part of the financing - $120 million of 9 7/8 percent bonds due in 2008 - was unchanged at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 9.927 percent.

headline: King Radio Suitor
abstract: The King Radio Corporation said it was holding talks on being acquired by a major corporation, which it declined to identify.

headline: PATENTS ;
abstract: Producing Anti-Cancer Chemicals Synthetically    A method of synthetically producing a group of chemicals widely used against human cancers has been patented by T. Ross Kelly, a chemist at Boston College, Chestnut Hill, Mass., and two co-inventors.

headline: Building in Antwerp Bombed; A Link to Basques Suspected
abstract: A bomb damaged the Palace of Justice here today but caused no injuries, the police reported.

headline: Trilogy's Loss Widens
abstract: Trilogy Ltd., a company formed to develop semiconductor, packaging and computer-aided design technologies, yesterday reported a loss of $59.3 million for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $3.2 million in the second quarter of 1983. Trilogy said the latest deficit was after a charge of $43 million, primarily for the writedown of assets related to discontinued development activities and a reserve for future costs of discontinued operations. The company, which is based in Cupertino, Calif., last week abandoned its plans to build a high-speed ''wafer-scale'' computer chip, saying it would instead attempt to design circuit packages made up of conventional semiconductors.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Iran Opposition Group Lists Teheran Killings          PARIS, Sept. 7 - Exile leaders of an Iranian opposition group today made public a list of the names of 10,231 people who it said had been executed by the Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini since June 1981.   The group, the People's Mujahedeen, whose headquarters are in Paris, said the list was an expanded and updated version of one issued a year ago that gave details of 7,746 executions.

headline: U.N. Chief Is in Moscow For Talk on Afghanistan
abstract: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations arrived in Moscow today for talks with Kremlin leaders focusing on Afghanistan.   Mr. Perez de Cuellar was greeted at the airport by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. He is expected to meet Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, during his three-day stay.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Sept. 10, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on Review and Appraisal of Implementation of the International Development Strategy - 3 P.M.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM POPE'S ADDRESS TO EDUCATORS
abstract: Following are excerpts from an address by Pope John Paul II this evening at a meeting with Roman Catholic educators at the Basilica of St. John the Baptist here:      All men and women, and all children, have a right to education. Closely linked to this right to education is the right of parents, of families, to choose according to their own convictions the kind of education and the model of school which they wish for their children (Universal Declaration of Human Rights). Related as well is the no less sacred right of religious freedom.

headline: New Zealand Devaluation
abstract: Prime Minister-elect David Lange devalued the New Zealand dollar today by 20 percent and froze prices for three months in steps aimed at bolstering the nation's sagging economy.   Mr. Lange, whose Labor Party swept to power in Saturday's general election, also removed controls on interest rates, a move expected to bring higher rates and keep money in the country.   At a news conference broadcast to the nation, he said wage restraint would be needed for ''some considerable time.''

headline: September Trial Is Set in Penn Square Case
abstract: A former vice president of the defunct Penn Square Bank pleaded not guilty today to 34 counts of misusing bank funds, actions that reportedly helped lead to the institution's demise two years ago.   A jury trial was scheduled for the week of Sept. 10 for William G. Patterson, 34 years old, who headed the energy division of Penn Square.

headline: 'SUPERCLOCK' IN MARKETS
abstract: THE most strategic spot in any    supermarket is not right at the   checkout, contrary to popular perception. By the time the customer gets there, the buying decisions have already been made.   Instead, the most important location is just before the checkout, in the main aisle that the shopper traverses an estimated seven to eight times in a single shopping trip.

headline: DOW UP 11.48 POINTS IN LATE RALLY
abstract: Stock prices rallied late in the session yesterday, bolstered by a strong rally in the bond market.    The Dow Jones industrial average finished up 11.48 points, at 1,134.05, after being down 5 1/2 points at noon.   Despite the late surge on the Dow, declining issues on The New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advancing ones by 766 to 765 as volume expanded to 74.8 million shares, from 65.9 million shares on Friday.

headline: NICARAGUA VICTIMS MAY BE AMERICANS
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency believes two of the men killed when Nicaragua shot down a rebel helicopter Saturday were American mercenaries, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today.     Mr. Moynihan, a New York Democrat who is vice chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, said the C.I.A. had told him that the two were not directly or indirectly associated with the agency, which has supported the Nicaraguan rebels since 1981. Mr. Moynihan said he had been told that the helicopter was on a reconnaissance mission after a rebel ground attack on a Nicaraguan military outpost.    There have previously been no known American deaths in Nicaragua associated with the three-year-old rebel fight against the Sandinista Government. A primary concern in Congress about American support for the rebels has been the possibility that C.I.A. employees or other Americans would become involved in the fighting.    Some members of Congress have warned that the loss of American lives in the conflict could draw the United States into a more direct and extensive military involvement. The Reagan Administration, partly in response to these concerns, has a standing policy that American Government employees, or anyone working on contract for the Government, shall not take part in any activities inside Nicaragua.

headline: BITTER DISPUTE ON BANKRUPTCY
abstract: THE legal cloud that has hovered over the nation's bankruptcy court system for more than   two years is beginning to look more like a low- hanging, long-lasting fog.   It was in June 1982 that the Supreme Court ruled that the bankruptcy court system set up by a 1978 law was constitutionally flawed, but Congress, the judiciary and the executive branch have still been unable to agree on a substitute that is reasonably secure from constitutional challenge.   Meanwhile, the processing of cases limps along amid confusion about the authority of bankruptcy judges to sign even routine orders. Judges have adopted a wide array of inconsistent legal approaches to accommodate the situation.

headline: RATES RISE IN CREDIT MARKETS
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday, reversing part of the declines that occurred earlier in the week.     Weaker prices for Treasury notes and bonds were not surprising in the wake of the sharp gains that occurred in the past few weeks, many analysts said. They added that prices were also undermined by fears that the Treasury would issue new regulations restricting the sale to foreign investors of zero-coupon securities. If fewer of the secuities can be sold to foreigners, then more of the Treasury's debt must be placed with domestic investors, presumably at higher interest rates than if foreigners were buying as well.

headline: New York Senators Block Banking Bill
abstract: Senate consideration of an Administration- backed bill that would give banks authority to expand into new financial services was frustrated today by the sustained opposition of both New York Senators.    Using the Senate's custom of unlimited debate, Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat, spoke for a total of more than three hours on the Senate floor against a provision in the bill that would authorize states to enter into regional banking pacts.   These regional agreements generally allow interstate mergers and acquisitions between banks in states that are parties to the pact, while excluding others, notably New York and California. For that reason, some big New York banks oppose the bill, and it was their point of view that Senator Moynihan was expressing.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Federal Reserve
abstract: All data in millions of dollars  LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo  Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Sept. 3  216,200 R 215,300 n.a.
