headline: THE FIVE-DAY WEEK: CAN JAPAN LEARN TO LOVE IT?
abstract: A Government advisory council has recommended that hard-laboring Japan move more rapidly toward a nationwide five-day work week - a goal not likely to be achieved easily in a country where six-day weeks were the firm standard until recently.     While it has been the Government's wish for several years that Monday-to- Friday work weeks be adopted, a Labor Ministry study issued last spring showed that only 25 percent of all workers enjoyed a full two days off each week.   Still, the percentage is rising steadily, and most labor experts assume it is only a matter of time before Japan resembles the West more closely in this regard.    But major elements of the advisory group's proposal are likely to arouse controversy and are by no means guaranteed to become official policy. They are expected, nonetheless, to give fresh impetus to a broader national debate, long under way, over whether the Japanese toil too hard or whether their well- known work ethic is eroding.

headline: Mrs. Gandhi Calls For Punjab Unity
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi appealed in the Indian Parliament today for reconciliation between Hindus and Sikhs in Punjab and declared that army troops would not be withdrawn from the area until both groups felt safe from Sikh terrorist threats.   ''The army should come out as soon as possible, but we must also create the conditions that people feel safe - not only the Hindus but also the Sikhs,'' she said.

headline: German Pact On Credit Near
abstract: West Germany has completed   talks with East Germany on a   major new bank credit for East   Berlin and an agreement is   ready to be signed, Peter Boenisch, the chief spokesman for   the Bonn Government, said today.  In an interview on West German television, he said that   Chancellor Helmut Kohl had   not yet agreed to Government   backing for the credit, but the   talks had been concluded.

headline: U.S. SAID TO KNOW LITTLE ABOUT GROUP DESPITE INCREASED INTELLIGENCE EFFORTS
abstract: The United States knows little about the terrorist group that took responsibility today for the car bombing of the United States Embassy in Beirut, according to Reagan Administration officials.    The group, known as Islamic Holy War, warned earlier this month that a ''vital U.S. interest'' in the Middle East would soon be atttacked.    The group took responsibility for three previous terrorist attacks against American installations in the Middle East, including the truck-bombing last October of the United States Marine garrison in Beirut that killed 241 American servicemen.    Administration officials said the Administration does not know who was responsible for the attack today, which killed more than 23 people, including two Americans, and had no specific warning that the embassy would be the target of an attack this morning.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Top Murdock Aide In Biggest Deal Yet
abstract: Raymond F. Henze 3d was prospecting for loan customers for Citicorp when he signed his first deal with David H. Murdock, the Los Angeles financier, in 1975. It was the start of a relationship that has propelled Mr. Henze, now 31 years old, onto center stage in many major corporate dramas.   The biggest such production,according to Mr. Henze, a senior vice president for Mr. Murdock's privately owned investment company, Pacific Holdings Inc., came to a high point last Friday when he and other members of their team learned that their $2.75 billion offer had won the bidding for the Continental Group Inc.

headline: Market Place; Stock Reaction To Bond Trend
abstract: THE stock market finally took its cue late last    week from strength in the fixed-income market, where rates have been declining since shortly after Labor Day. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average climbed nearly 28 points and on Friday it added more than 9 points. It finished the week at 1,237.52, up 30.14 points.    There were new developments, too, to support the thesis of declining interest rates, namely a $2.1 billion drop in the nation's basic money supply and a series of Government reports to indicate a slowing pace in the economy.

headline: LOOKING FOR WEAKEST LINK
abstract: While Colombia's new campaign has proved effective enough for United States officials to discount the need to apply new pressure on the Betancur Government, it has brought a fresh complication to the regional narcotics problem by decentralizing it.   It has therefore revived an age-old debate among drug-enforcement authorities over where the drug chain is most vulnerable.

headline: Penn Square Officer Acquitted on Most Counts
abstract: A United States District Court jury today acquitted a former Penn Square Bank loan officer, William G. Patterson, of 23 charges that he violated Federal bank laws. But the jury was instructed to continue deliberations on two other charges on which it had been unable to agree.   The bank failed on July 5, 1982, primarily because of bad energy loans. The collapse touched off reverberations in banking circles nationwide.

headline: CURRENCY OPTION GETS RESPECT
abstract: Apple Computer Inc., like many other companies with active international operations, faced a problem recently. It agreed to make purchases from Japan, with payment due in yen several months later. The difficulty was that the value of the yen could - and did - swing sharply in those intervening months, altering Apple's dollar costs.     Usually, to hedge such risks, companies agree to buy the yen, marks, pounds or other currency needed several months later at a fixed price in the forward market, paying in dollars. Apple, however, chose a new hedge, the currency option.    Options are the right to buy or sell a set amount of a currency at a specified date. They eliminate the risk of a loss due to exchange movements, but unlike a forward contract, still give the holder a chance to come out ahead if the currency fluctuations are in its favor.

headline: Greek and Turkish Cypriots Accept U.N. Move for Talks
abstract: Greek and Turkish Cypriots both have approved the new United Nations proposals for peace talks the divided Eastern Mediterranean island.   Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader, said the Turkish Cypriots had informed the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, that they were ready to start talks ''at any time, anywhere'' on the basis of ''working points'' that the Secretary General submitted to both sides in August.

headline: POPE, IN MONTREAL, SPEAKS OUT ON THE ROLE OF WOMEN
abstract: Pope John Paul II called on women today to give service that ''transcends the opinions of this world'' and presided over the beatification of a nun who founded a religious order dedicated to service to priests.    Addressing a series of issues that have sharply divided the church in North America, including the role of women, the tasks of priests and the place of sexuality in human life, the Pope declared that Quebec and Canada, and by extension the United States, were living in a ''spiritual desert.''    This evening the Pope received a rousing response of the sort usually reserved for rock stars from a group of 60,000 teen-agers and young adults at a Montreal stadium.     ''In times of darkness do not seek an escape,'' the Pope said. ''Have the courage to resist the dealers in deception who make capital of your hunger for happiness and who make you pay dearly for a moment of 'artificial paradise,' a whiff of smoke, a bout of drinking or drugs. What claims to be a short cut to happiness leads nowhere.''

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Sept. 14, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on International Development Strategy - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Meeting of Parties to the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee for 40th Anniversary of the U.N. - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: FARE WAR SEEN
abstract: Jolted by the prospect of a fare war on the New York-Chicago route and predictions by some brokers of a falloff in performance for the rest of the year, domestic airline stocks sagged across a broad front on Wall Street yesterday. The slump produced a sharp drop of 14.72 points, to 511.38, in the Dow Jones transportation average.     Concern about a fare war stemmed from the plans of People Express, the discount air carrier, to begin daily low-fare service from Newark to Chicago. The company said yesterday that it would hold a news conference in Chicago today to disclose details of the flights.

headline: Libya Issues Complaint About U.S. Planes
abstract: Libya has complained to the United Nations and other international organizations about the presence of American planes over the Gulf of Sidra on Thursday, the official Libyan press agency said today.

headline: BRITISH START WAR GAMES ON CONTINENT
abstract: The operational phase of Britain's largest field-training exercise since 1945 got under way near here today, with nearly 58,000 British soldiers and airmen scheduled to take part.     A total of 131,565 ground and air personnel are involved in the exercise, including the British troops and airmen already in West Germany as well as the American, Dutch and West German forces, which are to play the role of aggressor forces.    The exercise involves transporting 57,700 soldiers and airmen from Britain by air and sea. About 35,000 had arrived by Saturday night, and the remainder streamed through airfields and ports today, with only minor delays, toward the exercise area east of the Rhine River.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
abstract: Treasury Delays Sales To Explain New Notes    Treasury officials said yesterday that the offering of special four-year notes to foreign investors, as well as the regular auction of $5 billion to $6 billion of four-year notes in the domestic market, will be delayed until mid-October, from late this month. The delay is needed, they said, to inform foreign investors and securities dealers about the new securities.

headline: THE DEBATE ABOUT BAILOUTS
abstract: Walter B. WRISTON, who is going off to play tennis for the rest of the month, just before his retirement from the chairmanship of Citicorp, the nation's biggest bank, rejects the charge that he or other bankers took ''unbankerly'' risks because they were convinced that the Government would never let the big banks fail. ''It's a total non sequitur,'' he declared in an interview, ''to say we are reckless because we expect that they will bail us out.''   ''Human motivations,'' he adds, ''are basically to excel and do the best you can - not to do poorly on the hope that someone will rescue you.''   Following the debate over what caused the near- collapse of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, and what should be done to prevent future disasters, attention is focusing on whether bailouts of huge banks are necessary to save the financial system or whether the expectation of such bailouts undermines the system's security by leading to careless lending practices.

headline: AIR AUTHORITIES SAY HIJACKERS CAN EVADE TIGHEST SECURITY
abstract: Airline and airport officials said today that the hijackers who forced an Air France flight to land in Teheran had a variety of ways to bring weapons and explosives aboard the plane.    The officials said the incident, which ended today with the release of all the plane's passengers unharmed despite an explosion in the cockpit, demonstrated the fallibility of even the tightest security measures.   The flight originated in Frankfurt, whose airport is regarded by aviation specialists as having some of the strictest security procedures in the world. Tonight, West German aviation officials said it was still not clear that the men had actually brought their weapons aboard at Frankfurt.

headline: CROWDS IN POLAND ACCALIM ACTIVISTS
abstract: Labor movement activists freed from prison under an amnesty were hailed today by 7,000 people at a special church service here.   The service was marked by applause, tears and prayers. Priests urged an end of censorship and called for restoration of the rights of Solidarity, the labor union banned under martial law in December 1981.

headline: GUATEMALANS IN MEXICO: NOT WHERE THE HEART IS
abstract: Horacio Perez and his family arrived here today to settle reluctantly into their second home in as many years.   The first was in the jungles of the Mexican border state of Chiapas, to which Mr. Perez, his wife and their four children fled in February 1983 from the Guatemalan village of Gracias a Dios - ''Thanks to God'' - after deciding that the safest choice between the Guatemalan Army and the leftist guerrillas was not to choose at all.   The second was to the well-hidden encampment growing slowly outside this tiny community south of Campeche, farther away from his homeland than Mr. Perez ever expected to be. ''It was an order from the Government,'' he said. ''We had to agree.''

headline: U.S. Army Unit in St. Kitts
abstract: -Nevis, Aug. 24 (UPI) - A team of 18 United States Army officers has arrived to conduct a security training program for the St. Kitts Special Services Unit, a Government statement said Thursday. It said the officers arrived Wednesday to take part in a program ''directed toward the peacekeeping role of the police'' in the Caribbean nation, a former British colony.

headline: AFTER THE COUP AT PHIBRO-SALOMON
abstract: DURING the last several Saturday and Sunday mornings while the staff of Montefiore Medical Center has been on strike, the portly, bespectacled figure of John H. Gutfreund has been seen preparing meals and washing dishes at the Bronx hospital. He resolutely refuses to discuss it, saying only, ''You do what you do because you have to.''     Indeed, his compulsion to do what ''you have to'' goes well beyond pitching in during an emergency at the hospital where he serves on the board. Mr. Gutfreund, who has headed Salomon Brothers for the past six years, is a man who likes to be in the thick of things, a ''hands-on'' operator, in business-school parlance. And colleagues and acquaintances on Wall Street said that John Gutfreund again did what he had to do last week when he wrested control of his company from the man who bought it only three years ago.    ''Sometimes, people reach the comfort level when they make enough money, while some have to win the ball game,'' said a former Salomon partner who asked for anonymity. Now, he added, Mr. Gutfreund ''has gotten to be a real hardball player.''

headline: Bid for Reuters Stock Rejected
abstract: The New Zealand Press Association's directors today rejected an offer to buy its shares in Reuters, the British-based news agency.

headline: Treasury Aide Leaving
abstract: John E. Chapoton, Assistant Treasury Secretary for Tax Policy, has resigned effective Aug. 1 to practice law with the Washington firm, Vinson & Elkins. Before his Treasury post, Mr. Chapoton had been a partner in the firm's Houston office. Ronald Pearlman, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy, will succeed Mr. Chapoton on an acting basis.

headline: ATLANTA AWAITS BANK MERGERS
abstract: Despite Atlanta's rapid growth in the last quarter-century, it lacks a locally based bank big enough to rival the leading money-center institutions. While Atlanta is unlikely to challenge New York or San Francisco anytime soon, it is showing new signs of strength.    With this year's passage of legislation permitting bank mergers across state lines in Georgia, Florida, North Carolina and South Carolina, bankers of the Southeast are scrambling to find merger partners. They want to build up their asset, deposit and capital bases as a defense against any hostile takeover attempts by money- center banks.

headline: ISRAEL'S OPTIONS: HARD STRATEGIC DECISIONS FACE NEW CABINET
abstract: The new Government of Israel that emerges from the voting today will take office confronted by a strategic decision in Lebanon of great importance to military security, according to analysts in Israel, the United States and West European countries.  The choice, the analysts say, will be between redeploying Israeli infantry and armored forces farther south - moving from the present line along the Awali River to the Zahrani or Litani rivers - or remaining in place.    The cost of staying put would be more than $1 million a day and a continuation of a casualty rate that, since September, has led to a total of 74 dead and 377 wounded.   The present Israeli line runs eastward along the Awali River, then to the north to cover the heights of Jebel Barukh, southeastward down across the Bekaa and then south, skirting Mount Hermon to the Israeli frontier.

headline: SURGE FOR LUXURY BABY ITEMS
abstract: In a few weeks, Galway Irish Crystal will attempt to cash in on a new baby boom by selling its first infant- related item, a four-ounce, lead crystal baby bottle with a silverplated cap for about $38.50. The Boston-based distributor said there have been more than 5,000 requests for the bottle in the last two weeks.     Lewis of London offers a $1,500 gold-plated crib at its New York store. ''Business is terrific,'' said Mindy Isacoff, the store manager. ''It's baby boom No. 2.''

headline: Earthquake Strikes Armenia
abstract: An earthquake measuring 6 points on the 12-point scale struck Armenia today, but an initial report said there had been no casualties or destruction. The Tass press agency said the tremor was centered nine miles from Yerevan.

headline: TEXTS OF STATEMENTS BY U.S. AND SOVIET ON JEST
abstract: Following are statements involving a quip President Reagan made Saturday during a microphone test for his weekly radio broadcast. The transcript of Mr. Reagan's comment and the text of a statement issued Wednesday in English by the Soviet press agency Tass were supplied by The Associated Press. The text of a statement Wednesday by the State Department was provided by Reuters.  By President Reagan    My fellow Americans. I'm pleased to tell you today that I've signed legislation that will outlaw Russia forever. We begin bombing in five minutes.  By Tass

headline: WORLD ECONOMIC ORDER IS THEME AT THE U.N.
abstract: The Foreign Ministers of France and West Germany voiced concern today about the world economic situation and offered proposals to alleviate it.    A major theme of speakers in the current session of the General Assembly, which opened Monday, has been is the need for changes in the world economic order.    Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France said the world economy had become ''chaotic and unpredictable'' with fluctuations in exchange rates, budgetary disorder, budget deficits and rising interest rates.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Biostim Inc. , a medical engineering concern based in Princeton, N.J., said its Orthopedic Technology Inc. subsidiary had filed for relief under Chapter 7 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.     *  Conwood Corp. , a manufacturer of household insecticides based in Memphis, said it had sold its Hot Shot Insecticide line to Rid-A-Bug Co. for cash, notes and other considerations.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: *   Advanced Telecommunications Corp . said its board had approved a merger with TA Communications Inc., a long-distance telephone service company based in Atlanta.     * Barris Industries, a television program production company based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said it and Jeffrey Silverman had increased their holdings in the common stock of Ply-Gem Industries to 921,856 shares, or 38.4 percent of the total outstanding.     *  Central Illinois Light Co.  of Peoria said it plans to diversify into other businesses and had asked the Illinois Commerce Commission to approve creation of a holding company.

headline: HOME COMPUTERS LAG, TOO
abstract: Shinichiro Takagi dialed a telephone number, put the phone in a coupler and watched as his computer screen sprang to life. ''Welcome to the Personal Computer Telecommunications Network!!!'' it said, followed by a stream of English and Japanese characters.   Such a scene might be common enough in the United States, but it is rare here. Japan's general lack of sophisticated data communications for business extends to the home computer market as well.

headline: Ownership in Australia
abstract: Australia's governing Labor Party today softened its tough line against foreign control of energy projects when it voted to insist on 51 percent Australian ownership only ''where feasible.'' This policy change ends doubts about Japanese participation in a gas project off the northern coast of Australia.

headline: Epstein, Raboy Gets ADR Promotion Effort
abstract: Applied Data Research - or ADR - might be well known in the corporate computer room where its software systems for I.B.M. equipment have been in use for a quarter-century, but the name probably does not ring bells upstairs when spending for the systems is approved. Since $500,000 or so is a typical sum spent on such systems, corporate recognition can pay off.     The Princeton, N. J., company, which transferred its listing to the Big Board from Amex on Friday, is just about doubling its advertising budget, to about $2 million, and will start running ads in consumer business publications in addition to its usual promotions in the computer trade press.

headline: A SALVADOR POLICE CHIEF VOWS AN END TO ABUSES
abstract: The new director of El Salvador's Treasury Police has conceded that some members of the unit were responsible for serious violations of human rights. But he pledged the abuses would not continue under his command.    The director, Col. Rinaldo Golcher, said in an interview this week that a recent decision to disband the treasury police's intelligence squad, known as S-2, had been made because he and President Jose Napoleon Duarte believed the unit had carried out political murders and other human rights abuses.   ''It was a camp inside the camp,'' Colonel Golcher said. ''Even the other soldiers here feared it.''

headline: SHULTZ GIVES VIEW ON GROMYKO TALKS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he and President Reagan plan to deliver ''a very positive message'' to Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko next week on the Administration's desire for ''a more constructive relationship'' with the Soviet Union.   Mr. Gromyko arrived in New York today for the start of the United Nations General Assembly session. Over the next two weeks, he will meet with many world leaders, including Mr. Shultz in New York on Sept. 26, and Mr. Reagan in Washington two days later. In between, he will confer on Sept. 27 in New York with Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential candidate.

headline: GROMYKO RECEIVED BY THE PRESIDENT FOR OVER 3 HOURS
abstract: President Reagan and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko held what was called a ''forceful and direct'' discussion today of the sharp differences between the United States and the Soviet Union.   After the three-and-a-half-hour White House meeting and lunch, it was announced that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Mr. Gromyko would hold further talks Saturday at the State Department. Mr. Shultz and Mr. Gromyko met for three hours in New York on Wednesday.   Mr. Shultz, who spoke to reporters after the White House meeting, said Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gromyko had repeated their known positions at some length and with some force. He did not hold out the likelihood of an early narrowing of the gap between the two nations.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * Hill & Knowlton has acquired Hetu & Lukstat, a Washington, D.C., public relations firm.

headline: Deutsche Bank Names Supervisory Chairman
abstract: Hans L. Merkle, who is to retire this month as chief executive officer of Robert Bosch, the electronic and automotive parts company, has been named supervisory board chairman of the Deutsche Bank, West Germany's largest and most profitable commercial bank.   Mr. Merkle, who is 71 years old, is one of Germany's leading industrialists and succeeds Franz Heinrich Ulrich, who has asked to step down because of ill health. Mr. Ulrich, a former management board chairman of the bank who turns 74 on Friday, will continue to be a member of the board.

headline: Group at Yankee Bids for Company
abstract: Yankee Oil and Gas Inc. said a management group proposed to acquire all its shares outstanding.   The company said shareholders would receive for each share of common stock one share of a new issue of Yankee cumulative senior preferred stock, par value $10 a share, bearing an annual dividend of $1.50 a share.

headline: BRIEFS ; ;  Corporate Notes
abstract: Consolidated Capital Special Trust, a California real estate investment trust, filed an offering of a maximum of 2.5 million shares of beneficial interest through Consolidated Capital Securities Corp., an affiliate of the trust.          Common Stock    *  D'Lites of America Inc. , Atlanta, filed an initial public offering of 1.2 million shares through William Blair & Co.

headline: Salvador Massacre Reported
abstract: El Salvador's army high command has ordered a full investigation into an alleged massacre of 68 peasants last month by a United States- trained army unit, military officials said.   They said the investigation, believed to be the first such military investigation, was ordered yesterday by Defense Minister Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova after he read a report by the Catholic church's human rights monitoring arm, Tutela Legal.   The church group investigated reports of a mass killing in northern Cabanas Province and said troops of the elite United States -trained Atlacatl Battalion shot 68 peasants to death in a ''search and destroy operation'' between July 18 and 22 in three villages some 25 miles north of the capital.

headline: TEXTILE RULES JOLT HONG KONG
abstract: Textile manufacturers and trade officials here are voicing alarm over the decision announced by the Reagan Administration last Friday to tighten textile import regulations.   The tough new rules, made public by the United States Customs Service, would require apparel shippers from Asia, Central America and the Caribbean to certify exactly how their goods were manufactured, the sources of the imported material and their production costs.   After the rules take effect Sept. 7, the United States will accept only products either made completely in the exporting country or products substantially changed there.   The rules could force Hong Kong's garment exporters - who have commonly had much of their clothing assembled in China and other countries where labor costs are lower - to alter a fundamental business practice.

headline: GAINS FOR REBELS SEEN IN CAMBODIA
abstract: An anti-Vietnamese coalition in Cambodia is beginning to cause military problems for Hanoi, Southeast Asian nations were said to have told the United States, Japan and other countries today.   The coalition members led by former Prince Norodom Sihanouk were reported to be ''working very well on the ground'' and coordinating their moves, instead of clashing with each other as in the past.   The report was made at the opening of the annual two-day meeting between the six members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and their Pacific ''dialogue'' partners - the United States, Japan, Australia and New Zealand.

headline: German Auto Output Up
abstract: West German auto makers, idled through much of May and June by strikes at key suppliers, increased production 20.8 percent in July from a year earlier, a trade group said today.   With many workers volunteering to work through their regular July vacations, West German auto makers assembled 255,600 cars in July, up from 211,669 in July 1983, the Auto Producers Federation said.

headline: Long-Distance Dialing
abstract: An article in Business Day on Saturday incorrectly described the extent to which long-distance telephone users can connect with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company if they have selected an alternative carrier under equal access. By dialing a special code, long-distance customers will be able to have their calls bypass their selected carrier and be carried on A.T.& T. By selecting other long-distance company codes, they can similarly bypass their selected carrier and gain access to other companies as well.    You can only choose one primary long-distance company per telephone line. Then you just dial one plus the area code and telephone number to place your long-distance calls. To use another long-distance company, you would have to first dial a special five- digit long-distance access code before the number. Until now, customers wanting to use another carrier had to dial as many as 12 to 14 extra digits.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Chevron Units Draw Kuwaitis A Chevron spokesman said   yesterday that the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation is one of   the companies that has shown   an interest in making a bid for   certain Chevron properties in   the Southeastern United States. The deadline for making a   bid for the properties was yesterday.

headline: AIR FLORIDA RESCUE IS PROPOSED
abstract: Chicago-based Midway Airlines and Air Florida yesterday were given until Sept. 14 to complete a transaction that could rescue the debt-ridden Miami-based carrier.     Under a tentative agreement, announced by both carriers in United States Bankruptcy Court, Air Florida would continue to fly under its own colors with at least four of its leased Boeing 737's and by the end of September would hire 235 of the 1,200 employees who were laid off when it ceased operating and filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act on July 3.    Sidney Weaver, a bankruptcy court judge in Miami, instructed the two carriers to come up with a fully executed document as well as all necessary Government approvals for the deal by mid-September. John K. Olson, an attorney for Air Florida, said many specifics were unresolved, including the value of the transaction.

headline: UGANDA'S LEADER DEFENDS HIS RULE
abstract: President Milton Obote, without referring specifically to allegations that thousands of people have been killed in his country, today defended the policies of his Government and army troops.    ''A lot is being said about Uganda abroad,'' Mr. Obote said in a speech in this town 180 miles west of Kampala, the capital. ''I am not worried at all.'' He added, ''Our policies are correct.''

headline: BETHLEHEM STEEL POSTS A PROFIT
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, yesterday reported net income of $24 million, or 40 cents a share, for the second quarter - its first profit since the fourth quarter of 1981. Bethelehem had a loss of $70.7 million in last year's second quarter.    Donald H. Trautlein, Bethlehem's chairman, attributed the turnaround to cost-cutting and to slightly higher prices and shipments in the latest quarter. Bethlehem's revenues increased to $1.51 billion, up 22.8 percent from $1.23 billion a year before.

headline: German Retail Prices
abstract: West German retail prices fell two-tenths of 1 percent last month from June, but were up 2.1 percent from July 1983, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

headline: Moscow Gets U.S. Proposal
abstract: The United States has submitted to the Soviet Union a proposed agreement on renewing cultural, scientific and educational exchanges, an American Embassy spokesman said Friday. The former agreement expired in 1980.

headline: ECONOMY'S SHIFTING BEHAVIOR
abstract: In some important ways, the American economy is behaving differently from how it used to, elating the White House, disturbing Democrats and dumbfounding analysts who have careers and reputations as the economy's weathermen.  It is growing faster and with less inflation than it has for two decades.  Experts think the colossal Federal budget deficits, of almost $200 billion a year, proved far more stimulative than they expected. With hindsight, some also suspect that the recession was unusually harsh on consumers, producing an orgy of post-recession spending that has continued all through the recovery.    Even those explanations do not go far enough, in some economists' view. They say the economy is undergoing some important shifts. The record number of children born in the years after World War II are buying homes, furniture and appliances, giving the country a far bigger boost than they did as teen-agers buying soda pop and blue jeans.

headline: ATARI'S NEW OWNER ORDERS LAYOFFS
abstract: Jack Tramiel, the new owner of the Atari Corporation, has ordered major layoffs at the computer and video game maker, the company said.    Mr. Tramiel said through a company spokesman, Bruce Entin, that the layoffs were needed to get the company ''leaner and meaner.''    The cuts, which began Thursday and were to end today, came only four days after the entrepreneur bought Atari from Warner Communications Inc. for $240 million in notes.

headline: Digital-A.T.& T.
abstract: The Digital Switch Corporation said its Granger Associates subsidiary had been selected by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to provide its 7400 Transmux model through December 1985. Digital valued the contract at about $33 million.

headline: American Can Lifts Net 32%
abstract: The American Can Company today reported a 32 percent increase in second- quarter earnings. It cited strong growth in its specialty retailing and financial services operations and improved productivity in packaging.

headline: A FLAWED SCIENCE SHOWPLACE
abstract: On the outskirts of town, Sony is erecting what it calls the world's largest television screen. At 82 feet high by 130 feet wide, or almost 2,000 inches diagonally, the Jumbotron is best viewed from two city blocks away.    Nearby is a building, shaped like an oyster with a pearl, in which robots will play with visitors. Yet another building will feature a tomato plant, grown in water instead of soil, with no fewer than 10,000 tomatoes on it.    All this, and much more, will be part of Japan's Expo '85, a science and technology fair that the Japanese hope will establish their nation as a world leader in basic science. Opening in March, Expo '85 will be the coming-out party for Tsukuba Science City, a new town created from forests and farms as an oasis of Japanese science.

headline: Lawhon Furniture
abstract: The John F. Lawhon Furniture Company said it had agreed to acquire all of the stock of 11 Frankart Furniture retail outlets in New York and New Jersey in exchange for one million shares of newly issued Lawhon restricted common stock.

headline: Market Place; Technology Stock Slump
abstract: TECHNOLOGY stocks took a beating yesterday, for two unrelated reasons, and helped to   keep the market on the downside.    First, worry over problems with a disk drive hurt Control Data and Burroughs. Second, the semiconductor issues were battered by a bearish brokerage house report on Motorola.   Burroughs opened down 2 3/8 yesterday morning after an order imbalance. The drop in Burroughs, which closed the day at 53, off 3 5/8, followed Control Data's slide. On Monday, Control Data dropped 2 1/8 points, and it lost an additional 3/8 yesterday, to close at 26 1/8.

headline: Rockwell Profits Up 23.2%
abstract: The Rockwell International Corporation said today that its automotive and electronics businesses were major contributors to a 23.2 percent increase in third-quarter net income, to $132.9 million, or 87 cents a share, from $107.9 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier.   Sales in the latest quarter rose 14.2 percent, to $2.4 billion, from $2.1 billion.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: Sept. 13, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Committee on International Development - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Revco D.S. Denial
abstract: Revco D.S. Inc.'s chairman and chief executive, Sidney Dworkin, said management is not involved in a leveraged buyout plan.

headline: ARCHBISHOP OF MANILA TO VISIT CHINA TO 'PROMOTE HARMONY'
abstract: Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Archbishop of Manila, said in New York last week that he planned to visit China next month to ''promote harmony and understanding.''   Cardinal Sin said the invitation, extended by the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries, could help build bridges between the church and the Communist Government.   ''In our Christian beliefs, we should love Communists though hate Communism,'' he said in an interview at Manhattan College. ''Love is a many splendored thing. Let's see what love can do. We cannot just be promoters of hatred.''

headline: MTV a Sellout
abstract: At $15 a Share The initial public offering of   MTV Networks Inc., which operates two satellite cable networks, was completed yesterday, with the underwriters -   Shearson Lehman/American   Express, Salomon Brothers   and Drexel Burnham Lambert   - reporting that all of the   5,125,000 shares offered were   sold at $15 each. The net proceeds will be used   to finance the acquisition of assets and to pay a note owed to   an affiliate.

headline: Maryland Sets $139 Million Issue
abstract: A $139 million issue of Maryland general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 7 percent in 1987, to 8 1/2 percent in 1994, and 9.10 percent in 1999 through underwriters led by Citibank.    Maryland's bonds, because of high- grade ratings of Aaa by Moody's and AAA by Standard & Poor's, sell with yields lower than most other state issues.

headline: DOG DAYS, WHEN THE AIR DOSEN'T WORK
abstract: SUMMERTIME, and the living is    harried out at Bernie's Auto Air   Conditioning in Woodside, Queens.   The shop begins to build up tension in May and it reaches a crescendo on any muggy Friday. ''The car works O.K., it'll get you there,'' said Craig Spielberg of Bernie's as he surveyed the yawning hoods in his shop. ''But the air doesn't work and they're on the phone and it was like they were putting a pistol to my head if I didn't get their car fixed.''

headline: MANILA TROOPS OPEN BIG DRIVE ON REBELS IN NORTH
abstract: A military official said today that the Philippine Army had begun a major offensive against leftist guerrillas in the mountains of the northern Philippines.   Lieut. Col. Leon Badival, a provincial military commander, said in an interview that the offensive, involving 3,000 troops, was the largest such operation in the region since the rebels first appeared in the area in 1976.   ''We can't hide it,'' Colonel Badival said. ''It's true that military operations are going on right now.''

headline: POLAND'S MIXED EMOTIONS: FUTURE OF U.S. SANCTIONS
abstract: The issue of whether or not the United States should lift the economic sanctions against Poland draws a bewildering variety of responses here, not all of them predictable.   The future of the sanctions, which were applied after the imposition of martial law on Dec. 13, 1981, was unclear today in the wake of Parliament's passage Saturday of an amnesty bill under which almost all political prisoners are to be freed within 30 days.   The Reagan Administration, which had made the freeing of political detainees a major condition for removing the sanctions, welcomed the action and said that President Reagan would probably soon lift some of the measures. But American officials indicated that they were not yet ready to lift the harshest sanctions.

headline: A FEW CLOUDS OVER ROUTE 128
abstract: For nearly 25 years it has been known as ''America's Technology Highway,'' the ''Golden Semicircle'' or simply ''the Road.''     But Route 128, long synonymous with technological innovation and scientific ingenuity, is passing through a jittery middle age.   Although many of the high technology manufacturing companies that nestle along the highway are reveling in a burst of business, lots of them are worried, some of them gravely so, that the political climate in Massachusetts has become at best indifferent and at worst hostile to their needs.   Companies fear steeper taxes and stiffer regulation of their ways of doing business. Many of the established enterprises, though they have no plans to move away, are concentrating their expansion in states with friendlier business climates, such as North Carolina, Texas and New Hampshire. There are worries, too, about the adequacy of the labor pool and the costs of land and labor here.

headline: Panhandle Gas
abstract: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation said its two interstate gas pipeline subsidiaries had made additional progress in negotiating a reduction of their exposure to pay producers for gas not taken that totaled $1.5 billion at the end of 1983. The company's second-quarter report to shareholders said nearly $500 million of gas-purchase obligations had been settled, and a Panhandle spokesman said the new figure represented an increase of $200 million from agreements previously reported.

headline: Federal Reserve
abstract: All data in millions of dollars  LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo  Monetary Aggregates M-1*as of Aug. 20  212,000 211,700 n.a.   Reserve Position, Eight New York Banks Daily averages for two weeks ended Aug. 29 Excess (Deficit) Reserves (Incl. carryover) (8)18 n.a.  Borrowings at Federal Reserve 0 287 n.a.  Net Federal Funds Purchases 9,207 10,870 n.a.  Basic Reserve Surplus (Deficit) (9,215)(11,139)n.a.
