headline: TRW, Milstar
abstract: TRW Inc. said its Electronic Systems Group had received a subcontract to build the Milstar satellite communications payload for the Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, a unit of the Lockheed Corporation. TRW said the contract is valued at more than $1 billion over the next several years if all options are fully exercised. Milstar is the next generation of the Department of Defense's military satellite communications program and will serve the United States' tactical forces with worldwide communications, TRW said.

headline: PETRO-CANADA ISSUE WON'T FADE AWAY
abstract: Many people say that one reason Joe Clark, the leader of the Progressive Conservative Party, lost out in Canada's national elections four years ago was because he advocated selling Petro- Canada, the national oil company, to the private sector.    So it is hardly surprising that in the campaigning for this year's election on Sept. 4, the issue is being approached with caution.    Nonetheless, a growing body of opinion holds that Petro-Canada - now Canada's biggest oil company in assets, with $6.4 billion in United States dollars- may need private money to pay its mounting bills, regardless of whether the Liberal Prime Minister, John Turner, or the Tory challenger, Brian Mulroney, wins the election.   Patricia Carney, the Conservatives' Parliamentary energy critic, recently said the company would get ''no more handouts'' if the Tories take power. Michael Pitfield, now a senator and previously the top aide to former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, has discussed selling shares in Petro-Canada. And Donald Johnston, a surprisingly tough candidate for the Liberal leadership won by Mr. Turner, has advocated selling Petro- Canada's service stations.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: BEIRUT LEADER LAUDS GUERRILLA ATTACKS ON ISRAELIS
abstract: Prime Minister Rashid Karami of Lebanon said today that his coalition Government ''respects'' guerrillas fighting against Israeli occupation troops in southern Lebanon.   ''Their resistance reflects the will of the people,'' he said in an interview here before meeting with President Hafez al-Assad.   Mr. Karami said the Lebanese Government wanted the Israeli troops to leave as quickly as possible.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Corporate Debt   C.I.T Financial Corp . is offering $100 million of 12 1/4 percent notes due in 1994 at a price of 100 through undewriters led by Shearson Lehman/ American Express; the notes, rated Aa-3/AA, may be redeemed by investors after three years and are not callable by the company for seven years. Convertible Bonds    * Equitec Financial Group , a holding company, has offered $20 million of 10 percent convertible subordinated debentures.     * Mattel Inc.  has started an exchange offer for up to $25 million of its outstanding 11 5/8 percent subordinated debentures, due in 2008; the offer involves issuance of 74 common shares for each $1,000 principal amount of debentures.

headline: The U.N. Today July 13, 1984
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: ARGENTINE PROBLEMS STRESSED
abstract: Although bankers and diplomats are optimistic about Argentina's chances of finally signing an agreement with the International Monetary Fund by the end of this month, they remain skeptical about the country's ability to hold to the terms of such an agreement.     Rampant inflation, now running at an annual pace of 648 percent, demanding unions and the lack of a convincing economic plan, they say, weaken the Government's ability to reduce the country's deficit and stabilize the economy.    ''There is a real feeling on everyone's part that this is a make-it-or-break-it time and it seems like things are going well,'' a foreign diplomat said of I.M.F. talks this month.    Showdown Could Be Averted    An accord or substantial progress could avert a showdown on a payment of $750 million due on Saturday and some $900 million due on Sept. 30 and open the way for Argentina to begin talks with its creditors to reschedule payments on $44.4 billion in debt. But a failure to uphold the terms of such an agreement could spell disaster for future rescheduling.

headline: British Dock Strike Talks Make No Progress
abstract: The attempt to mediate the week-old dock strike faltered today and Britain started to run low on imported produce.

headline: ON 'REAL' PEOPLE AND CREDIBILITY
abstract: a year ago, a Nashville socialite, Eugenia Wimberly Fort Hooker, was busy working as a professional interior decorator. This month, Mrs. Hooker, who is known as Tish, appears in advertisements for the Germaine Monteil Cosmetiques Corporation as a ''real'' over-40 woman.    ''We were interested in communicating the fact that it is not just the actresses and the professional models that look great,'' said Sandi Burrows, a vice president at Germaine Monteil. ''So, we set out to find a real over- 40 beauty.''

headline: BELIEVERS FLOCK TO GRAHAM AS THE K.G.B. WATCHES
abstract: Blending gospel citations, personal anecdotes and fiery appeals, the Rev. Billy Graham stood before the icons of the Russian Orthodox Church of the Resurrection today and exhorted the congregation to become followers of Christ.   ''Today the world is in trouble; you hear it on the radio, you see it on television and you read it in the papers,'' Mr. Graham thundered, with an interpreter quickly falling into his cadence, building to the main thrust: ''Jesus Christ said I am the way . . .''   It was a classic Billy Graham sermon, and some in the congregation wept while others listened raptly and mumbled, ''beautiful, magnificent.'' An Orthodox official, Metropolitan Filaret of Minsk, who officiated at the three-hour liturgy, extolled Mr. Graham's words and presented him with an icon of the Holy Trinity.   But among the churchgoers were many well-groomed young men who stood impassively, their attention fixed more on Western reporters and the parishioners themselves than on Mr. Graham. Dozens more K.G.B. agents and policemen patrolled the streets outside, quietly diverting some passers-by from the street leading to the church.

headline: INSTABILITY MARKS FOX'S RECENT PAST
abstract: It is one of the most storied names in American film history, but in recent years the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation has perhaps become better known for the instability in its executive suite than for its cinematic and television successes.     That reputation for instability may change with the announcement yesterday that Barry Diller, the chairman of the Paramount Pictures Corporation and head of the entertainment group at Gulf and Western Industries, would become Fox's chief executive on Oct. 1.    Mr. Diller succeeds Alan J. Hirschfield, whose resignation was announced on Monday after months of speculation that he would be let go by Marvin Davis, the company's owner.   There was little doubt in Hollywood or on Wall Street yesterday that Mr. Hirschfield's three-year reign at Fox had ended involuntarily.

headline: Cargill Inc. Promotes Executive to President
abstract: James R. Spicola has been named president and chief operating officer of Cargill Inc., one of the nation's largest grain trading companies.    Mr. Spicola, 54, has been an executive vice president at the company since 1981. He succeeds M. D. McVay, 65, who is retiring. Mr. McVay has been president and chief operating officer at the giant, privately held international commodity merchandising, handling and processing company since 1977.

headline: City Plans to Sell $850 Million Notes
abstract: New York City said it would sell about $850 million of notes next week through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Investment bankers at Merrill Lynch hope to announce interest rates Monday, they said, but the rates may be adjusted, depending on market conditions.

headline: Shift at Spectra-Physics
abstract: Spectra-Physics Inc. said Samuel D. Colella will resign on Aug. 31 as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Colella's duties will be assumed by Herbert M. Dwight Jr., who continues as chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Colella has served as chief operating officer since 1981. Based in San Jose, Calif., Spectra- Physics makes lasers for scientific, industrial and commercial applications and laser- beam systems for construction alignment, agricultural machine control and contract research.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS BEGIN TO CONSCRIPT CIVILIANS
abstract: A senior Salvadoran guerrilla official said today that leftist rebels had started forcibly recruiting Salvadoran civilians.    The statement, which follows several reports of Salvadoran peasants fleeing forced recruitment by guerrillas, was the first public confirmation by a rebel official that such conscription has taken place.   The official, Ana Guadalupe Martinez, a member of the rebels' political- diplomatic commission and a senior commander of the People's Revolutionary Army, said in an interview with four other members of the commission that civilian conscription had begun ''very recently'' and was not general policy.   She said rebel units had taken young men from some villages in northeastern El Salvador specifically to prevent them from being conscripted by the Salvadoran Army.

headline: TAXES ADD NEW TRAUMA TO DIVORCE
abstract: The new tax law has radically changed the tax    treatment of divorce. In addition to the usual   heartache of a marital breakup, the unwary may now find that the Government will take a much larger share of alimony payments than they originally anticipated, and may even be able to assess tax retroactively, years after a split-up.   The Tax Reform Act of 1984 makes changes in three key areas: alimony, property transfers and dependency exemptions. The law will finally remove a major obstacle to property settlements that often meant husbands were saddled with a large capital gains tax on property that they transferred to their ex-wives as part of the settlement. And it will simplify the wrangling over which parent gets the dependency exemption for any children.

headline: Hershey to Buy Pillsbury Division
abstract: The Hershey Foods Corporation announced that it had reached an agreement with the Pillsbury Company for the purchase of the American Beauty Macaroni Company, a division of Pillsbury.

headline: TWO QUIT AT CHICAGO TRADE UNIT
abstract: The president and executive vice president of the clearing house of the Chicago Board of Trade resigned suddenly Thursday for what were described as ''personal reasons.''   According to a statement released today by the clearing house, which is formally known as the Board of Trade Clearing Corporation, Walter W. Brinkman, president of the Clearing Corporation, and James E. Johnson, executive vice president, submitted their resignations effective Thursday. It was the statement by the Clearing Corporation's board of governors that said they had resigned for ''personal reasons.''

headline: Failed Bank Reopens
abstract: The Bank of Verdigre and Trust Company, the second Nebraska bank to close in two weeks, reopened today as a branch of the National Bank of Neligh. When the Verdigre bank was shut down by the state on Wednesday, it became the second commercial Nebraska bank to close this month and the 58th to fail nationwide this year.

headline: Superior Care
abstract: Superior Care Inc. said its after-tax loss for the fiscal year 1984 was about $3 million, exceeding earlier projections of a $500,000 loss.

headline: President Seeking Rest of Guardian
abstract: The president and chief executive of Guardian Industries said yesterday that he intended to offer $24 a share to acquire the remainder of the company's stock. William Davidson already owns 42.4 percent of the company's approximately 22.1 million shares outstanding.

headline: FINAL RAILS LAID ON KEY LINE TO OPEN UP SIBERIAN RICHES
abstract: After 10 years of work, the last segment of track was laid today on a 2,000-mile Soviet rail project that may ultimately cost an estimated $10 billion and open up vast new Siberian resources.    The railroad, known as the Baikal- Amur Mainline, is intended to help develop copper, asbestos and other mineral deposits as well as commercial timber lands in a 600,000 square-mile region of southeastern Siberia. Many of the resources may be destined for export through Pacific ports.   Dubbed the ''construction project of the century,'' it has been mobilizing workers from all over the Soviet Union as well as army construction troops since work got under way in 1974.

headline: TREASURY TO SELL $8.5 BILLION OF NOTES
abstract: The Treasury returns to the note market this week with an $8.5 billion offering of two-year notes on Wednesday. That will be in addition to the regular weekly bill auctions.    Late Friday, securities dealers offered the new two-year issue with a yield of about 12.38 percent. Before today's sale of new Treasury bills, the outstanding three-month issue was trading with a rate of about 10.32 percent, while the six-month issue was about 10.51 percent.

headline: 9 Hurt by Pamplona Bulls
abstract: Nine men suffered minor injuries today on the third day of the running of the bulls here, the police reported. The bulls' charge from the corrals to the bullfighting ring is part of the festival of San Fermin, which began Saturday.

headline: TREASURY RATES FALL SLIGHTLY
abstract: After fluctuating in a narrow range, interest rates on Treasury securities ended yesterday with small declines for short- and long-term issues.     The enthusiasm that led to higher prices and lower yields last week was not evident in yesterday's quiet trading, market participants said. By late in the day, rates on outstanding Treasury bills were little changed, while note and bond prices were up by about 1/8 point or less. In the long- term bond market, the 12 1/2 percent issue due in 2014 was traded at 102 5/ 32 early in the day but closed at an offered price of 102 22/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 12.16 percent.

headline: Yugoslav Prices Climb
abstract: The rise in Yugoslavia's consumer prices slowed a bit last month. They climbed 3.3 percent from the July figure to a level 59.9 percent above that of August 1983, the Government said today. The rise was less than the 12-month increase of 62.1 percent recorded in July.

headline: Columbia Data
abstract: Columbia Data Products Inc. said it was reducing its work force by about 35 percent in a move that would affect 114 employees at its Maryland manufacturing plant and 189 at its Puerto Rico facility. The company, based in Columbia, Md., makes computers compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's PC.

headline: Iran Exiles Report Execution Of 40, Including Soccer Star
abstract: An exile group opposed to the Iranian Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has asserted that the former captain of the Iranian national soccer team and 40 others opposed to the Government were executed last week at Evin Prison in Teheran.   The Mujahedeen exile group, citing ''reliable reports received from inside Iran,'' said on Saturday that the former soccer captain, Habib Khabiri, 29 years old, was tortured before he was executed last Tuesday.   It was not possible to confirm the group's assertion.

headline: Vietnam Official Wants Talks on Amerasians
abstract: A Vietnamese immigration official has called for direct talks with the United States to speed the resettlement of Amerasians from Vietnam, refugee workers said today.   But United States officials in Bangkok said they saw no need to discuss the issue with Hanoi.

headline: ISRAELI LABOR COULD WIN VOTE BUT FAIL TO FORM A COALITION
abstract: Although all of Israel's major pollsters are now predicting that the Labor Party will win the largest number of seats in the elections Monday, Labor's ability to put together a coalition government remains in doubt.   With five days to go before the 2.65 million Israeli voters cast their ballots for the 11th Parliament, the latest polls show Labor, led by Shimon Peres, with a solid, but in most cases shrinking, lead over Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc.   The most recent Smith poll, published by The Jerusalem Post last Friday, shows Labor winning 39.5 percent of the vote, down from 44 percent a month earlier, and Likud winning 29.5 percent, an increase of 1.5 percent over last month. A poll published by the newspaper Yedioth Ahronot the same day estimated Labor winning 51 seats to Likud's 41 seats, after earlier showing Labor ahead 53 seats to 48.

headline: CANDIDATES VAGUE ON CANADA DEFICIT
abstract: At first glance, the two main candidates for Prime Minister of Canada seem tailor-made for business. Both John Turner, the incumbent and Liberal Party leader, and Brian Mulroney, leader of the opposition Progressive Conservative Party, are former corporate lawyers and argue strongly for free enterprise.    But as the campaign for the Sept. 4 election enters its final two weeks, both candidates have emphasized expansion of social programs, more spending on women's concerns and governmental efforts to cut youth unemployment. They have not put as much emphasis on the concerns of industry. In particular, they have not offered specific suggestions for dealing with Canada's soaring Government deficit.

headline: The Market's Big Climb
abstract: Since Wall Street makes money whether investors are buying or selling, last week's record volume bodes well for brokerage industry profits, which have been battered this year. ''They're coming off a brutal first half and this has brought smiles to a lot of sour faces,'' said Jeffrey M. Schaefer, senior vice president of the Securities Industry Association. ''A lackluster July may turn into a dynamite August.''     It's a rule-of-thumb that the industry breaks even after about 90 million shares, so volumes like Friday's record 238.8 million on the New York Stock Exchange goes directly to the bottom line. Wall Street's dismal 4 percent after-tax return on equity could rise to 10 to 14 percent, if this activity continues another month or two, according to Mr. Schaefer. Perrin Long, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Services, predicts 90- to 100 million-share days through September.  Institutions have so far been the big players, trading massive blocks.  Now all eyes are on the little investor, since the average profit per share is about 40 cents for retail trades compared with about 10 cents a share for institutions. Mr. Long expects that if equity prices continue to rise, small investors should return to the market this week or next.

headline: GERMANS BATTLE WAR GAMES
abstract: At least 96 people were arrested today as hundreds of demonstrators tried to break into munitions depots, damage military equipment and blockade bases to protest NATO military maneuvers, the authorities said.   West German Government and United States military officials denounced what they said were increasingly violent attacks on military personnel and installations during the Autumn Forge exercises, which involve about 250,000 troops from seven countries.

headline: Air Florida Deal Backed
abstract: A Federal bankruptcy judge, despite criticism from numerous airlines and creditors, today approved a $53 million acquisition deal in which grounded Air Florida would begin flying again as part of Midway Airlines.   ''It seems to me there is a sound business necessity for a prompt approval'' of the agreement, said Federal Bankruptcy Judge Sidney Weaver, who has been overseeing Air Florida's financial affairs since July when the Miami-based carrier filed for protection from its creditors.

headline: REGULATION AND GENETIC ENGENEERING; BIOTECH SAFEGUARDS ARE ALREADY IN PLACE
abstract: BIOTECHNOLOGY is a generic term that has come to denote the industry built around some of the new biological fields, such as recombinant DNA, or gene splicing. In fact, the term identifies industry's application of any biological technology, including the fermentation process, which man has been using for the past 6,000 years.    However, while recombinant DNA technology gives promise of many new products and opens up vast new areas of research in the life sciences, a recent lawsuit involving the proposed release into the environment of genetically engineered microorganisms for agricultural use has renewed the debate about the need for increased regulatory control.  No one contests the need to regulate products, to ensure that they are safe and effective. But adequate authority already exists for such regulation, including products of biotechnology. The latest debate is taking an unfortunate turn because it is being used for purposes of intervening in the research and development process, long before a particular product even exists. That should give us all pause.

headline: 2 in Ulster Militia Killed
abstract: Two militia soldiers, one of them a woman, were killed today when their patrol was attacked by landmine and gunfire on the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, the police said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: RALLY CHANGES SOME OPINIONS
abstract: THE explosive rally in stock prices last week    has resulted in a patchwork quilt of opinions   on future equity prospects - with some views changed and others basically left unaltered - among brokerage houses and investment advisers.   Perhaps the most abrupt about-face at a major securities firm was made by Prudential-Bache Securities, which now believes the market will reach new highs in the Dow Jones industrial average by the end of 1984. By contrast, this firm had held to progressively increasing degrees of bearishness, starting in July 1983, on prospects for equities. One reason for its newfound optimism is the assumption that corporate profits, in both 1984 and 1985, will be higher than previously envisaged.

headline: Reliance Agrees To Buy Days Inn
abstract: Reliance Capital Group, a private investment partnership headed by Saul P. Steinberg, the New York City financier, said it had agreed to acquire Days Inn of America Inc. Terms were not disclosed, but last week, Goldman, Sachs & Company, adviser to the sellers, is understood to have told bidders that more than $300 million was wanted.   Days Inn, based in Atlanta, has 322 units with more than 45,000 rooms. Nearly 80 percent of Days Inn is owned by Marian U. Day Smith, widow of Cecil B. Day, founder of the company, who died in 1978.

headline: Magazine for Affluent In New York Suburbs
abstract: City Communications in Atlanta, which believes, and rightly so, that there is lots of dough in the suburbs, has been publishing magazines for the more affluent dwellers on the outskirts of a number of cities. It will take on the New York area in September and November.

headline: 3 ARE CONVICTED IN TOGO OF KILLING AMERICAN Three residents of the West African country of Togo have been found guilty of killing a 23-year-old Peace Corps worker from Oneonta, N.Y. in June, a spokesman for the Togo mission to the United Nations said yesterday.
abstract: Jennifer Lynn Rubin, who had been a Peace Corps volunteer for 12 months in the village of Defale in the northern part of the country, was bludgeoned to death in her home June 11 after she had accused one of the defendants of stealing articles of clothing, according to Peace Corps accounts at the time.   According to Dermene Abdou Traore, the spokesman for the Togo mission, a criminal court in Niamtougou, a town near Defale, sentenced two of the defendants to life in prison during a two-day trial in July. He said a third defendant, who is believed to be still in hiding in a neighboring country, was tried in absentia and sentenced to death by firing squad.   Miss Rubin had been praised by Peace Corps officials for her success in reducing the daily work load for women in the village of Defale. She taught women how to build more efficient wood-burning mud stoves, thereby cutting in half the amount of time the women spent gathering wood, which has become scarce in the northern Togo region.

headline: Futures/Options; Downtrend Aids Many
abstract: The steady erosion of futures prices in recent months has been a welcome bonanza for most investors and managers of commodity funds, for it provided them with what all futures traders pray for - a long and defined trend.   As measured by the Commodity Research Bureau index of futures prices, which uses 1967 as a base of 100, the index peaked this year at 284.2 on May 21, and then steadily sank to a low of 249.4 on July 31. Last Friday, the index closed at 257.5.   For months before futures prices began their decline, most funds and individual investors had seen their capital eroded by brokerage commissions as they tried to get on the right side of markets that were basically trendless.

headline: THE SOCIAL SECURITY SOLUTION; THINGS MAY NOT BE SO BAD AFTER ALL
abstract: TWICE during the last decade the   financial problems of the old-  age, survivors and disability insurance program, which makes up the bulk of the Social Security system, have been hot copy for front- page stories. Questions were raised about the ability of those programs to continue to pay benefits and some analysts predicted the system's imminent bankruptcy.   Now, a little more than a year after Congress passed the 1983 amendments to the Social Security Act, resolving the programs' short-term crisis, Social Security is out of the headlines - and out of the red. In fact, its board of trustees says benefits will be covered for 75 years.

headline: PRINCESS OF WALES GIVES BIRTH TO HER SECOND SON
abstract: The Princess of Wales gave birth today to her second son, who became third in line for the British crown after his father and his 2-year-old brother, Prince William.    The Princess, formerly Lady Diana Spencer, entered St. Mary's Hospital in Paddington, just north of central London, early this morning, dressed in red and smiling broadly.   Her child was born after nine hours of labor, during which the Prince of Wales, the heir to the throne, remained at her side. The baby weighed 6 pounds, 14 ounces, Buckingham Palace announced. There was no word on the choice of a name.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Net at Federal Express Down MEMPHIS, Sept. 21 (AP) -   The Federal Express Corporation said the substantial start-   up costs of its new Zapmail   service caused its profit to decline 71.4 percent in the first   quarter of its current fiscal   year despite a 43 percent increase in revenue. The small-package delivery   company said Thursday that   profit fell to $8 million, or 18   cents a share, in the June-August period from $28 million, or   63 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: FOR JAMAICANS, ONE-PARTY RULE IS A PARTY TOO FEW
abstract: For the first time since Jamaicans were granted universal sufferage by the British 40 years ago, only one political party is sitting in Parliament.   To the surprise of almost everyone, this has not stifled debate, but seems to have fostered freer and livelier exchanges than were customary under the traditional two-party system.   Even so, Jamaicans are not happy with the present situation and say it is only a matter of time before they return to the system they inherited from the British. In fact, most Jamaicans say the one-party Parliament would probably not be working so well were it not for the country's commitment to its traditional form of government.   One thing that is helping to keep the governing party responsive, diplomats and political analysts say, is concern that it not be seen to be abusing power.

headline: Nalco Leader Retires At 61 Because of Illness
abstract: O. T. Collins, who has held every top management post at the Nalco Chemical Company and most recently served as chairman of its executive committee, has taken early retirement for health reasons, the company announced. Mr. Collins, 61, is being treated for ameotrophic lateral sclerosis, commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease.    Mr. Collins was chief executive officer at Nalco, a manufacturer of specialty chemicals for water and process treatment, from 1979 until 1982, and he was chairman of the board from 1982 until last April.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *  American Financial Enterprises Inc., Cincinnati, said it plans to repurchase periodically up to one million of its 13.9 million common shares outstanding on the open market or in private transactions.     *  Beecham Group P.L.C.'s U.S. subsidiary, Beecham Laboratories, said it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to market a new antibiotic called Augmentin that counterattacks a major cause of bacterial resistance to penicillin and cephalosporin drugs.     *  Crown American Corp.  of Johnstown, Pa., said its Hess's Department Store unit had agreed to buy Rices Nachmans Department Store chain from the Phillips-Van Heusen Corp. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: People
abstract: Joseph N. Walsh Jr.  elected vice president, regulatory, planning and marketing for New York Telephone.

headline: 19 ARE WOUNDED IN VENEZUELA AS POLICE FIRE ON STUDENTS
abstract: At least 16 students and 3 national guardsmen were wounded when guardsmen fired at five buses carrying students to a planned protest in Caracas, a Government statement said.

headline: SALVADOR HOSTAGES FREED AS GUNMEN GIVE UP
abstract: Four armed men who said they were leftist rebels surrendered to Salvadoran officials today after bungling a robbery attempt and holding 63 hostages for nearly 23 hours. The hostages were then released unharmed.    The men abandoned their demands for safe passage out of the country after several nations, including Mexico, declined to give them asylum, according to Salvadoran officials.   The men were denied asylum because a guard was killed in the attempted bank robbery and because there were doubts whether the men belonged to any leftist political group, according to Julio Rey Prendes, an aide to President Jose Napoleon Duarte.

headline: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 22, 1984
abstract: Markets    Stock prices surged , pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 22.75 points, to 1,239.73. Strong institutional buying expanded volume to 128.1 million shares, from 75.4 million on Monday. Only 366 stocks lost ground on the Big Board, against 1,274 that gained. Among the stocks that benefited from the rally were blue-chip, transportation and energy issues. (Page D1.)   Short interest rose to a record 212.9 million shares , up 5.6 percent, or 11.3 million shares, in the month ended Aug. 15. The previous record was set on May 15, with 208.1 million shares. (D4.)

headline: IN ENGLAND, KENT MINES FEAR WORST
abstract: For most of Kent County, it is summer as usual. The pace of commuter life has slackened at Kent's western reaches, which border on London. Farmers are tending the orchards and the fields of hops and grains that have earned the county the nickname ''England's Garden.'' Tourists are flocking to Canterbury and the English Channel resorts, and village greens are crowded with cricket players.    In Deal, however, just a few minutes drive up the coast from Dover, and in a handful of nearby communities that dot the gently rolling farmland surrounding Kent's coal mines, the anger and the fear stirred up by Britain's five-month-old coal strike have taken hold. Far from the rest of Britain's coalfields, Kent miners have been among the strike's most stalwart backers. Hundreds have traveled to northern coalfields to take part in mass picketing.   ''If the miners lose this battle, the Kent mines will close,'' said Terry Birkett, strike coordinator in Kent for the National Union of Mineworkers.

headline: Fires Rage in Tanzania
abstract: A fire blackened 40 square miles of pastureland in Ngorongoro Crater, according to reports reaching here, and the ruling Uhuru Party newspaper said another fire on Kilimanjaro, Africa's highest mountain, had been contained after it destroyed large sections of forest. Both sites are tourist attractions and both are in drought- stricken areas.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; New York City Notes Priced to Yield 7.15%
abstract: An $850 million note financing by New York City was tentatively priced yesterday with a yield of 7.15 percent to maturity on June 28, 1985, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Underwriters said that the notes, which have a coupon of 7.6 percent and carry a price of 100.328, were well received.

headline: Delmed Rejects Offer From Grace
abstract: Delmed Inc. said its board had rejected as inadequate a proposal from W.R. Grace & Company to acquire three million Delmed common shares and warrants to buy three million more.

headline: Stock Exchange PicksMcCaffrey & McCall
abstract: McCaffrey & McCall Direct Marketing has been tapped to do the first advertising for the New York Stock Exchange's Options division and New York Futures Exchange.     The New York Stock Exchange, which conducted a competition for the business, uses Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein for its general advertising needs.

headline: SPLIT SAID TO DELAY PLAN TO END BALDWIN CASES
abstract: A split within the securities industry has delayed the settlement of class action suits filed against the country's largest brokerages by holders of Baldwin-United annuities, industry officials said yesterday.    The three officials, all of whom sought anonymity, said Paine Webber Inc. was offering the strongest resistance to the settlement, which involves contributing money to make limited refunds to all annuity holders. Shearson Lehman/American Express Inc. was also balking at the plan, the officials said.    If the two firms do not relent, some Baldwin annuity holders might find themselves receiving a smaller payment than others, depending on where they purchased the policies, the officials said.

headline: C.D. Yields Turn Up
abstract: Reversing three weeks of falling yields, average effective yields for six-month certificates of deposit showed a slight increase nationally, to 11.18 percent, from 11.16 percent, for the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported. Yields for money market funds also increased slightly, to 9.79 percent, from 9.77 percent.

headline: Belgian Princess Wed
abstract: Princess Astrid of Belgium, 21 years old and a niece of King Baudouin, and Archduke Loren of Austria-Este, 28, a grandson of Charles I, the last emperor of Austria, were married today in civil ceremonies in the Gothic chamber of the 18th-century Brussels Town Hall and in religious ceremonies at Notre- Dame des Sablons Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Cuts at Amdahl
abstract: The Amdahl Corporation said it had taken a number of actions to streamline its operations, including reducing its staff by about 4 percent. A spokesman for the Sunnyvale, Calif., computer concern said that the reduction would affect between 250 and 300 employees out of 7,200 worldwide and he noted that the new number would still be larger than the approximately 6,500 employees at the beginning of the year. In explaining the moves, John C. Lewis, Amdahl's president, said, ''We found many areas where consolidation of function, reduction in work scope or a general trimming of expense was appropriate.''

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: UNOCAL STOCK SURGES ON TAKEOVER RUMORS
abstract: Oil fever shook the New York Stock Exchange yesterday for the first time in many weeks as shares in the Unocal Corporation surged $4.62 1/2 on the Big Board by the 4 P.M. close and then advanced a dollar more on the Pacific Stock Exchange to end the day at $36.62 1/2, up $5.62 1/2, on a volume of more than a million shares.     Orders to buy were so heavy that the New York exchange halted all activity in the stock from 1:29 P.M. to 2:44 P.M.    Propelling the sharp rise in Unocal stock were unconfirmed reports that the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) might take over the company, formerly called the Union Oil Company of California. Indiana Standard, with sales of $27.6 billion last year, is the nation's sixth-largest oil company. Unocal, with 1983 sales of $10.1 billion, is 14th-largest.

headline: Adviser Indicted in Seagram Trading
abstract: Giuseppe Tome, an investment adviser based in Geneva, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury in New York and accused of illegally trading in stocks based on inside information obtained from a unit of the Seagram Company.   The indictment, handed up on Tuesday, charges that Mr. Tome, 54 years old, used confidential information about Seagram's acquisition plans to buy stock and options of target companies.

headline: RUSSIAN WHO WON ASYLUM IN BRITAIN IS BACK IN MOSCOW
abstract: A Soviet journalist who spent the past year in Britain turned up here today and said that he was abducted in 1983 by British agents while attending the Venice Film Festival and had been forced to make anti-Soviet statements.    The journalist, Oleg G. Bitov, 52 years old, spoke at a news conference called by the Soviet authorities. He had disappeared in London last month.   (In London, the British Government said Mr. Bitov came to Britain of his own free will last year and it called his statements in Moscow ''absurd and offensive.'')   At the news conference, Mr. Bitov said that he had planned to return to the Soviet Union all along. He said he had waited until he won the confidence of his purported captors and had then simply bought an airline ticket and boarded a plane.

headline: Baker, Fentress
abstract: Baker, Fentress & Company said its board had rejected unanimously an unsolicited $40-a-share offer from the Amalgamated Sugar Company.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: In percent

headline: American Motor Inns American Motor Inns Inc.,
abstract: which is the subject of an offer   by Prime Motors Inc., said it   had agreed in principle to grant   an option to AHC Enterprises   Inc. covering 8.4 million shares   of American Motor's authorized but unissued shares of   common stock at $19.50 a   share. American Motor Inns said,   however, that the option was   dependent on the filing by AHC   of a tender offer for any and all   of the company's common   shares at $21 each no later than   Aug. 29.

headline: TOP EXECUTIVE RETIRING AT AETNA
abstract: In an unexpected move, Filer, chairman and chief executive officer of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the nation's largest stock- owned insurance company, announced that he would be taking early retirement. Replacing him will be James T. Lynn, a director of Aetna and former head of the Federal Office of Management and Budget.   Mr. Filer, who will be 60 years old next week, said in a press release he was stepping down voluntarily.

headline: I.M.F. PANEL AGREES TO REDUCTION IN CREDIT LIMIT OF DEBTOR NATIONS
abstract: Industrial and developing countries have decided on action to curtail international credits available for loans to debt-burdened countries, it was announced here tonight.    The decision, which was made over the protests of many representatives of developing countries, was reached at the end of a day-long meeting of the policy-making Interim Committee of the International Monetary Fund. The 147-nation I.M.F. makes loans to third- world countries that need cash.    The agreement, which reduces access to the I.M.F.'s resources, came about as a result of a compromise chiefly between the United States, which sought deep cuts, and developing countries led by India, which wanted no cut at all.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, has appointed Edward F. Truschke to the post of senior vice president, social policy.     *  Beatrice Companies, Chicago, a marketer of food and consumer products, has named William S. Mowry Jr. executive vice president.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, JULY 4, 1984   Companies    Air Florida filed for bankruptcy protection and grounded all its planes. The Miami-based carrier that first flourished under deregulation fell victim to fare wars and new entrants into its markets. It was the third major airline to file for bankruptcy. Some carriers refused to honor Air Florida's tickets. (Page A1.)   General Motors completed the breakup of its famed Fisher Body division by folding several Fisher plants into the G.M. Guide division. Fisher's dismembering is yet another step in the reorganization of G.M.'s North American operations. (D1.)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Aluminum Company of America, Pittsburgh, named four group vice presidents: Harold S. Evans, international; Clyde R. Gillespie, engineered products; Ronald R. Hoffman, flat rolled products, and Vincent R. Scorsone, primary metals. The company also named Richard L. Fischer, Donald R. Whitlow and James W. Wirth senior vice presidents.

headline: TAX-EXEMPT ISSUES DOMINATE SCHEDULE
abstract: No Treasury note or bond auctions are scheduled this week, although there is a full slate of tax-exempt issues and a potentially large supply of corporate offerings.    The hiatus in Treasury note and bond auctions will last a week and a half, with a two-year note sale expected Aug. 22, followed by a five- year note sale Aug. 29. Before today's regular auction of new Treasury bills, the outstanding three-month issue was bid late Friday at 10.47 percent, while the six-month issue was at 10.60 percent.

headline: TWO GERMANYS SAID TO DISCUSS BROAD ACCORDS
abstract: In a development that appeared to presage a significant improvement in their relations, the two Germanys were reported tonight to be negotiating an ambitious package of agreements.   The accords were said to include a new private bank credit to East Germany and a reduction of the obligatory foreign exchange demanded of West German visitors to the Communist state.   The news of the package, which was reported by West German television and broadly confirmed by diplomats and banking sources, came as a tense situation was defused at the West German diplomatic mission in East Berlin.   All but 6 of 55 East Germans who had taken refuge in the mission were said to have left the building. They were reportedly reassured by commitments that they would eventually be allowed to emigrate to the West.

headline: GANDHI'S OTHERWORLDLY NEMESIS
abstract: When N. T. Rama Rao speaks to a political rally, many people hear the voice of the Hindu god Krishna or Vishnu or Rama. That's because Mr. Rama Rao, who was returned to power Sunday as Chief Minister of a southern Indian state, used to play deities when he was a film star.  Today, a day after forces loyal to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi conceded defeat and reinstated him as Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh, Mr. Rama Rao's former cinematic persona seemed to figure in the accolades. He has emerged as a political hero as well as a figure around whom the usually fragmented national opposition can rally.    Mrs. Gandhi is thought to have repaired her damaged political image by bowing to the will of the majority in Andhra Pradesh. But the praise for Mr. Rama Rao has been something more.

headline: U.S. EXPLICITY PUTS SPACE ARMS IN TALKS PLANS
abstract: The United States today proposed an opening statement for arms talks with the Soviet Union this fall that would explicitly include space weapons on the agenda, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said the previous American proposal for an agenda had not mentioned the issue.   On Friday a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Viktor G. Komplektov, said the previous American reply to a proposal Monday by Moscow for a joint affirmation of readiness to negotiate showed that ''the U.S. does not want talks on such a vital problem as the banning of space weapons.''   One Administration official said the document proposed today represented ''a formulation we think the Soviets will be more comfortable with.''

headline: ECONOMIC GROWTH AT HIGH 7.5% RATE IN SECOND QUARTER
abstract: The nation's economy grew at a surprisingly strong 7.5 percent annual rate in the second quarter, the Commerce Department announced today, and inflation eased when it might have been expected to increase.   Inflation for the entire economy fell to a 3.2 percent annual rate in the second quarter from 4.4 percent in the first quarter, the department reported.   ''I don't know how you can write a script for a better recovery than we're seeing right now,'' said Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, who led the Administration's exultation about the continued good economic news.   Democrats have acknowledged that the economy's strong performance was a big advantage for President Reagan's re-election bid and that his Democratic challenger, Walter F. Mondale, has yet to discover a potent economic theme for the campaign.

headline: ECONOMISTS DISAGREE ON 4TH QUARTER
abstract: The pace of the current economic expansion clearly slowed in the third quarter, but after sifting through the latest data a number of analysts are suggesting that the period of deceleration was short-lived. Rather than continuing to moderate between now and year-end - as projected by many governmental and private economists - the rate of economic growth, some analysts now predict, will increase instead.     In their interpretation, these economists tend to play down recent Government reports as well as activity in the credit markets that suggest softening conditions. Rather, they focus on renewed vigor in consumer spending, on the positive aspects of speedy resolution of labor negotiations with the automobile and coal workers and on a stabilization and possible improvement in the nation's foreign trade deficit.

headline: CASE OF 6 SERBS SIGNALS A CRACKDOWN
abstract: A pending trial of six dissidents is being viewed here as signaling a harder crackdown on domestic political opposition while Yugoslavia tries to maintain a reputation for liberalism abroad.   ''It is not that there were no political trials in Yugoslavia before,'' said Srdja Popovic, a lawyer representing four of the accused.    There are perhaps as many as 500 people in jail for advocating their beliefs. But they are mainly Croats and Albanians who want to separate their ethnic territories from Yugoslavia.   The case against the six is different because they are known through Yugoslav press reports on their dissident activities and because the case is being pursued in Serbia, which has long had a reputation for liberalism.

headline: RENAULT OFFICER NAMED A.M.C. CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: The American Motors Corporation announced today that Jose J. Dedeurwaerder, a former executive of its principal shareholder, Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, had been named chief executive officer, succeeding W. Paul Tippett.   Mr. Tippett will remain as chairman, a position he has held since 1982, and will serve as chairman of the executive committee. His duties, the details of which have not yet been worked out, will include developing long-range strategy and serving as senior adviser on North American operations.

headline: Italy's Retail Prices Up
abstract: Italian consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August from the July level and were up 10.4 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today.

headline: Dailey Office To Marschalk
abstract: umbrella of the Interpublic    Group of Companies, the recently acquired Dailey & Associates of Los Angeles is turning over its San Francisco office to the Marschalk Company. Dailey's Manila office will   be similarly digested.

headline: Norway Trade Surplus
abstract: Norway said today that its balance of payments surplus rose 181.5 percent in the first five months of the year. The Central Bureau of Statistics said the figure for May rose to 12.08 billion kroner, or about $1.459 billion, from 4.29 billion kroner in the period a year earlier.

headline: I.B.M.'S NEW ROLE IN EUROPE
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation has always been considered an outsider in Europe, an American behemoth whose presence has been tolerated only because its products were so sorely needed. But now that it has settled its nettlesome, decade- long antitrust dispute with the Common Market, the company is accelerating a campaign to change that image.    It is striking up alliances with the biggest names in European telecommunications - British Telecom and STET, Italy's Government-controlled telephone company, for example - and it has a foot in the door, if not full acceptance, in Europe's two largest high-technology research programs.   At the same time, the company says it has given more decision-making authority to the nationals who head the major I.B.M. subsidiaries in Britain, France, West Germany and Italy.    ''They will be given goals to reach, but the strategic decisions about how to reach them will be their own,'' a spokesman for I.B.M. Europe said. Major decisions will continue to be reviewed at I.B.M.'s headquarters in Armonk, N.Y., or at its European head office in Paris, however.

headline: Washington Watch; A 'Federation' Of Consultants
abstract: WASHINGTON WITH one convention down, one more to go, and ''For Sale'' signs sprouting around town again, you could swear there's an election on the horizon. No matter who wins in November, Washington's white-collar population will be even more footloose than usual, as political jobs change hands, many at the Pentagon.     The chief scientist there, Richard DeLauer, who is Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering, will be resigning after the election to form what he calls a ''federation'' of private consultants.    He said recently that he has discussed the notion with Louis Meyer, retired vice president for policy planning at the Comsat General Corporation; Eugene Fubini, a longtime Government adviser on military and intelligence technology; Sol Love, former president and chief executive of the LTV Corporation's Vought division, and several acquaintances from the TRW Corporation, where Mr. DeLauer was executive vice president before joining the Reagan Administration.
